webTitle: Lee puts the skids on Pakistan

fields.headline: Lee puts the skids on Pakistan
fields.trailText: A four-wicket haul by the seamer Shane Lee guided Australia to a 15-run win over Pakistan in Melbourne and assured the World Cup champions of a place in the finals of the triangular one-day series.
fields.body:
A four-wicket haul by the seamer Shane Lee guided Australia to a 15-run win over Pakistan in Melbourne and assured the World Cup champions of a place in the finals of the triangular one-day series.

Chasing 261 to win, Pakistan were cruising at 197 for four before a 20-minute rain delay upset their momentum. On the resumption Pakistan's last six wickets fell for 48 runs as the home side powered to their fifth win in a row .

Lee, the former Somerset all-rounder, claimed the crucial breakthrough by bowling Ijaz Ahmed for 85. He then snared the last two wickets of Wasim Akram and Saqlain Mushtaq to finish with four for 37.

Half-centuries by Michael Bevan (83) and Ricky Ponting (53), on the back of three successive ducks, had earlier helped Australia build a solid total. Defeat for Pakistan at least kept alive India's slim hopes of making the best-of-three finals series.

fields.headline: Jim Swanton dies at 92
fields.trailText: E W Swanton, the godfather of cricket journalism, died last Friday in the Chaucer Hospital in Canterbury. He was 92 and as respected for his views towards the end of his life as he had been during seven decades of writing and broadcasting.
fields.body:
E W Swanton, the godfather of cricket journalism, died last Friday in the Chaucer Hospital in Canterbury. He was 92 and as respected for his views towards the end of his life as he had been during seven decades of writing and broadcasting.

Although Ernest was his name, he had always been known as Jim, which lent him a cosy familiarity. Mike Carey, a successor as cricket correspondent at the Daily Telegraph, once observed that Swanton's autobiography should be entitled The Importance of Not Being Ernest.

Pompous was a word that might have been invented for him. When, during the 1976 heatwave, the pub from where his habitual gin and tonic was carried to Broadcasting House ran out of ice, he berated his secretary. "Didn't you tell them who it was for?"

But he could be enthralling, compulsive and generous company for any newcomer to the business, when he was willing to hold forth on anything to do with cricket or "goff" - a game he played enthusiastically at Royal St George's, close to his home in Sandwich, and Sandy Lane, adjacent to his house on Barbados.

Few can claim to have had such a broad experience of the game, beginning with a sight of W G Grace from his pram and ending with last summer's Tests against New Zealand.

His work carried an authority given no other. He frequently watched cricket from committee rooms and presidents' boxes rather than the press box and he had the ear of the game's influential figures, for he counted himself among their number. On at least one overseas tour he was incorporated on to the England (or rather MCC) team's discipline committee.

After working for the Evening Standard in the 20s and 30s, when, to his undisguised regret, he missed the Bodyline tour as a result of a reporting indiscretion, Swanton enjoyed his heyday in the post-war period. He was the Telegraph's correspondent until 1975 and he was in the vanguard of ball-by-ball commentary and television broadcasting.

His summaries of the day's play, delivered on screen and off the cuff in a deep booming advocate's voice, were masterly. If Swanton spoke or wrote, notice was taken. In no other branch of sports journalism can there have been such a singularly powerful figure.

fields.headline: Wilson proposes a loyal toast
fields.trailText: Sheffield Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards has told his chief aggravator, Joe Ashton, that the war of words is over. Yet, given the response of Danny Wilson's side to the brickbats thrown at them, Ashton should perhaps be encouraged to keep the insults flying.
fields.byline: Adam Sills  at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Sheffield Wednesday's chairman Dave Richards has told his chief aggravator, Joe Ashton, that the war of words is over. Yet, given the response of Danny Wilson's side to the brickbats thrown at them, Ashton should perhaps be encouraged to keep the insults flying.

In the past 10 days, while the MP has been busy calling for Richards and Wilson to resign and accusing the club of financial mismanagement, Wednesday have won three times. On Saturday they climbed off the bottom of the Premiership for the first time since August with victory over Tottenham, their first away win of the season.

An Ashton-Richards conspiracy to motivate the team? Not likely but these triumphs in adversity have transformed Wednesday's season and the seven points that now separate them from the safety zone will appear a bridgeable gulf. Wilson, grateful that Richards has kept the faith, is confident his side can escape.

"I've never been in a position where I didn't think we would get out of it," Wilson said. "We can't be complacent and we're certainly not out of the mire yet but results like this help.

"You do consider the sack and the fact is that some people have never been allowed to have a bad run like I've had and have gone long before," he added. "You've got to admire the bravery of the chairman because he's taken a lot of flak and still is unfortunately - undeserved flak in many respects. All we can do is ease the pressure by winning games.

"He's been fantastic for me and I hope that in the future some chairmen see the way he's handled it and do likewise and keep off the trigger finger. He's never panicked but then he can only justify what he does by results."

These amount to four wins and four draws in 22 games, and the pressure on Richards has been strong, but the chairman is determined to stand by his man and draw a line under the recent arguments.

"It's over," he said on Saturday. "We're not going to take it any further. The club needs to get back and win football games. We've always been confident of surviving and we've just had this bit of a hiccup and we've started wrong, but the lads know what we've got to do. This result is a terrific boost for Sheffield Wednesday but in particular for the players and Danny Wilson."

Murky waters could still lie ahead. Next Sunday Ashton and his fellow MP Clive Betts are reportedly meeting Wed-nesday's independent supporters' association, who plan to demonstrate against Rich-ards and the board at forthcoming home games. The away following on Saturday, though, chanted with the joy of finally being rewarded for their travels.

Their patience has been all the more creditable given that the club, whose debts are £12m or £18m depending on whom one believes, cannot afford any new players. "We've come clean with the fans very early and told them there's no money, so they haven't put us under pressure to buy people and they know they have to stick with what we've got," Wilson said. "I believe the lads we've got here are good enough anyway."

It is not a sentiment shared by Tottenham's manager George Graham. While David Ginola hit the bar and the side netting, and narrowly missed with two other efforts, Tottenham lacked sufficient presence up front. Graham admitted that his side had been outplayed in the second half but counted eight attempts on goal for the home side as opposed to just two for the visitors in the first period.

Niclas Alexandersson, supplied by Wim Jonk, took one of these opportunities for Wed-nesday and Gilles de Bilde missed two glorious chances towards the end to make the game safe.

In response the home fans, not for the first time, chided the chairman Sir Alan Sugar to "get his chequebook out" and Graham is desperate to buy a new striker.

"I think I've got money to spend. I hope I've got money to spend," Graham said. "But the next problem is finding players who are available. It's amazing how in demand centre-forwards are at the moment" - not least from the Tottenham faithful.

fields.headline: Wigan held by peers
fields.trailText: There is something appealingly pragmatic about doing things in triplicate. Bristol City have three men in charge after Tony Pulis walked out in a mood of mutual disaffection.
fields.body:
There is something appealingly pragmatic about doing things in triplicate. Bristol City have three men in charge after Tony Pulis walked out in a mood of mutual disaffection.

The arrangement is not new to them. After one previous abrupt managerial departure, the club's dominant chairman Harry Dolman became part of a hastily appointed trio and helped select the team. Not so now with Scott Davidson. He is leaving it to Leroy Rosenior, Tony Fawthrop and David Burnside. There is no immediate rush, it seems, to name a successor to Pulis.

The three sat alongside each other in the dug-out, sharing tactical ideas. Rosenior, at ease in front of the cameras, is the front-man. He would probably like the job permanently, though he is too wise to say so publicly. Bobby Gould, who used to play for the club and still lives nearby, will doubtless be mentioned but his associations with Bristol Rovers will work against him.

Wigan stay on top, but only just. After that long unbeaten run, they have lost impetus. They looked rather ordinary here ; their two best chances, for Alan McLoughlin and Andy Liddell, were needlessly missed. Their leading scorer Stuart Barlow was substituted in the second half. Nothing much wrong with the defence, however, and Roy Carroll is very solid in goal.

For City, the wing-back Mickey Bell made most inroads, down the left. Steve Torpey played like a pre-war centre-forward, big and awkward, winning the ball in the air though failing to get in a shot. Tony Thorpe, the £1m striker virtually written off before surprisingly returning after his loan to Luton, chased hopefully without looking like relaunching a City career.

Fawthrop, City's chief scout, must have been delighted that the teenagers who kept some established players out mostly justified their promotion.

fields.headline: Weah warms to hot spot
fields.trailText: Chelsea were a curious mixture here, not least because they fielded as many as four Englishmen. They opened with some unworldly touches by the silver-booted George Weah and finished with impressive gusto. In between, the multinationals muddled along.
fields.body:
Chelsea were a curious mixture here, not least because they fielded as many as four Englishmen. They opened with some unworldly touches by the silver-booted George Weah and finished with impressive gusto. In between, the multinationals muddled along.

Aston Villa manfully tried to fill in the gaps with a rejuvenated Paul Merson increasingly imposing his creative abilities on the match. It was a measure of Villa's own rehabilitation that he and his colleagues treated this draw almost like a defeat afterwards. They should not be disheartened; more important games lie ahead.

However much Gianluca Vialli and, more improbably, John Gregory press for a European place via a high league placing, it is knockout silverware that is really exercising their minds. Villa and Chelsea have a common enemy - Leicester - and, if this dread- nought can be outmanoeuvred, Wembley beckons.

On this evidence Chelsea will be relying as much on Weah, who is eligible for Sunday's FA Cup tie, as Villa do on Merson for progress. The first full pairing of Liberian and £10m signing could not be deemed a success. Chris Sutton was substituted after 74 minutes but not before Weah, on more than one occasion, pointed to the ground only to see his co-striker respond by lofting the ball vaguely in his direction.

The reborn Merson may now have to become Renaissance Man since Villa's shortage of strikers points to an out-and-out attacking role in the Worthington semi-final first leg against Leicester tomorrow night. Here he produced virtually all Villa's opportunities with crosses and free-kicks, quite apart from his side's most enterprising moment when he chipped Emerson Thome with one foot and then volleyed just over with the other.

Merson, according to Gregory, is now coming off the pitch "with nothing left in the tank" - but for all the right reasons. "He's been totally committed - his fitness level is up - and reminded me that he's first choice. And he's cer tainly commanded a lot of respect in the dressing room for the way he's playing."

One of several curving free-kicks from Merson offered Villa's best opportunity, an unchallenged header squandered by Ugo Ehiogu after 75 minutes. Much earlier Merson induced panic in Chelsea's penalty area that ultimately saw the impressive Jon Harley clear off the line before Benito Carbone shot wildly.

But no one, not even Merson, could match Weah's early silver standard. On one occasion the Liberian appeared to defy geometry in turning past George Boateng; then he demonstrated an extraordinary feat of dexterity to outmanoeuvre the bewildered Ehiogu before grazing a post.

Chelsea threw on Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola but the last word almost lay with Weah. A twisting back-header brought an equally agile tip-over from David James, who then matched the save from his point-blank shot. Weah is not yet match-fit but, ominously, he says: "I'm getting there. I think I'm going to have a very good time in England."

fields.headline: Town rise to pitch battle
fields.trailText: Bolton's Reebok Stadium may have cost £35m but one would never know from the state of the pitch.
fields.body:
Bolton's Reebok Stadium may have cost £35m but one would never know from the state of the pitch.

The Ipswich manager George Burley cited the dreadful surface for his team's failure to impress a crowd of fewer than 12,000 on Saturday.

"It wasn't the type of pitch which allows you to knock the ball around," he said. "It's a lovely new stadium but surely one of the most important things is to have a pitch that you can play football on."

Matt Holland equalised Dean Holdsworth's opener but Bolton's manager Sam Allardyce was more concerned by the silence in the stands. "The lack of atmosphere is becoming a burden," he said. "It can be a demanding place to win football matches when there are so many empty seats."

webTitle: Taylor rages at the Watford gap

fields.headline: Taylor rages at the Watford gap
fields.trailText: The obituaries are being written and the orders placed for next season's copy of the Nationwide League A to Z . Even if Graham Taylor does not like to admit as much, Watford are fast approaching the point of no return.
fields.body:
The obituaries are being written and the orders placed for next season's copy of the Nationwide League A to Z . Even if Graham Taylor does not like to admit as much, Watford are fast approaching the point of no return.

For the first time this season Taylor's side hold the Premiership's wooden spoon with only 14 points from 23 games after coming off distinctly second best in a fixture marked down as a relegation six-pointer as far back as last summer.

They have now shipped 50 goals - an average of over two a match - and only the most improbable feat of escapology will prevent them automatically leaving the Premiership.

"It does not matter whether we are bottom or third from bottom. You know that with our statistics you are going to be in trouble," said Taylor. "I get angry because I find myself saying: 'Are you fellows actually listening to what I am saying? Do you want to do it your way or my way? Because if you want to do it your way, there is only one way we are going.' "

Whether Bradford will be also dragged downstream depends much on their goal count. Or, more appropriately, their lack of goals.

This was only the second time this season they have managed to score three times and their somewhat desperate attempt to entice Stan Collymore out of his cocoon appeared doomed to failure last night after seemingly losing out to Leicester in pursuit of the Artist Formerly Known as Britain's Most Expensive Player.

That Paul Jewell's side requires a new striker is beyond dispute, but there are people better qualified for the job than Mr Angry of the Black Country.

"It's vital we bring in a player or two but at the same time it's important that we don't panic buy," said Jewell. "I've been trying like mad because a fresh face can give the club a lift but I'm never confident because things always happen out of the blue in the transfer market."

The catalyst of victory was Peter Beagrie's 25th-minute penalty after Dean Windass had been grounded in an untidy sandwich between Paul Robinson and Robert Page.

Micah Hyde slid in an equaliser with the game's first incisive attack shortly afterwards but Bradford's response was equally swift as Gareth Whalley advanced and struck a bobbling right-foot shot beyond Alec Chamberlain as Watford's defenders rolled out the red carpet.

The same defensive deficiencies allowed Andrew O'Brien space to head the hosts further ahead from a corner early in the second half and there could have been more goals before Heidar Helguson's 88th- minute volley ensured a degree of anxiety in the closing stages.

In Bradford's position, however, every silver lining has it's cloud. Sure enough, Jewell was left fretting about the fragility of his squad after his goalkeeper Matt Clarke suffered knee ligament damage that will keep him out for two months. Jewell has another keeper, Gary Walsh, injured and may have to make a loan signing.

If so, the new arrival can ex pect a warmer reception than might be reserved for Collymore judging by the splutters of indignation emanating from the players' lounge as news leaked of their club's interest on Saturday evening.

Even in their most troubled times Bradford's players have retained a sense of unity out of keeping with Collymore's previous experiences. As one put it: "That's the last bugger we'd want here".

fields.headline: Robson turning white by mistake
fields.trailText: This is the sort of match that turned Bobby Robson's hair grey. His team missed four great chances before a rare error from his keeper gifted the opposition a goal, the momentum and three points.
fields.body:
This is the sort of match that turned Bobby Robson's hair grey. His team missed four great chances before a rare error from his keeper gifted the opposition a goal, the momentum and three points.

The fact that results elsewhere pulled Newcastle back into relegation's icy grip can only increase the speed with which the United manager's head turns snowy white. But the Toon's travelling army were sanguine enough in defeat. After all, the future is fertile again. Robson has rediscovered life where Ruud Gullit left only shoots of decay.

Where there was hesitation there is now confidence; where there was confusion there is understanding; where there was a run of defeats there are now wins and draws in between.

On Saturday, though, Newcastle fell to "another smash and grab job by Wimbledon," reckoned Robson. "We've made more entries into their box but failed to take our chances."

Robson blamed his team's defeat on poor defending, indirectly at least. For there was more than a hint of envy to be detected in his praise of Wimbledon's rearguard in general and Hermann Hreidarsson's in particular.

In contrast Newcastle's centre-backs Nikos Dabizas and Marcelino were all over the place; the left-back Alessandro Pistone looked frightened to tackle and, after a bright start, the right-back Warren Barton caught the bug and majored in unforced errors.

It was probably uncertainty about how those in front of him were going to react that prompted the goalkeeper Steve Harper to come for Alan Kimble's free-kick just after the break.

It was a bad call. He was always stretching to reach the ball and managed only to push it on to Robbie Earle's knee from where it rebounded in a trickle over the line. "A sad and miserable goal," said Robson.

Wimbledon increased their lead on 68 minutes when Kenny Cunningham crossed from the right and Newcastle's central defenders went awol, Marcus Gayle thumping a free header past Harper.

It could have been so different. Early in the game Wimbledon's Neil Sullivan had denied Kieron Dyer twice, then Nolberto Solano and Gary Speed. Gayle and Carl Leaburn then both missed sitters but Solano somehow managed to slice a close-range shot for a throw-in and Dyer, clean through on goal, shot wide.

"One day you take your chances, the next day you don't," said Robson philosophically. "I don't blame players for missed chances. I only criticise players for not creating them."

Newcastle now lighten their gloom by heading off to La Manga for three days before facing Blackburn in the FA Cup. Wimbledon have two weeks off, one of which will be spent in the Canaries. After two successive defeats, this win will certainly have smoothed their feathers.

fields.headline: Owen's medical mystery deepens
fields.trailText: Even if the afternoon had yielded a game of mesmerising content and unrelenting passion, the talk afterwards would have embraced nothing more exciting than the condition of a young man's hamstrings.
fields.body:
Even if the afternoon had yielded a game of mesmerising content and unrelenting passion, the talk afterwards would have embraced nothing more exciting than the condition of a young man's hamstrings.

Not just any young man, of course. No, most certainly not. The saga of Michael Owen's battered leg muscles is becoming almost Agatha Christie-esque in its complexity - The Strange and Mysterious Case of the Golden Child Gone Lame or, perhaps more fittingly, more pointedly, The Devilish Legacy of the Meddling German Doctor.

Owen's hamstrings have pulled, snapped, strained and bruised with such regularity over the past nine months or so that it is annoyingly easy to treat flippantly a problem which, having already dramatically reduced Liverpool's potency, may yet inflict untold harm on England's summer aspirations.

A game so wretched that it could not muster a single shot on target until its merciful end was in sight had crawled to its 28th minute when Owen delivered an orthodox cross from the right. As the cross went the way of all Saturday's crosses - away from those players in whose direction it had been aimed - Owen remained seated on the Anfield turf.

Briefly, and probably painfully, he stretched his legs out before him before rising to indicate to his manager that, again, his day's work was prematurely at an end.

As he walked slowly and deliberately back towards the halfway line he shouted "hamstring" to the sea of ashen faces in the Liverpool dug-out.

Shortly after the watching England coach, Kevin Keegan, had departed for home, Gérard Houllier was called upon to discuss the fragile nature of Owen's lower limbs.

Now, he may have been tramping around familiar territory but the Frenchman was quite noticeably perturbed, quickly and wisely abandoning his attempt to convince his audience that black was in fact white and that damaged muscle could be described as healthy muscle.

"Obviously, we are a bit worried but I am sure our medical team will sort it out soon," he said with no discernible conviction. "It is not the same muscle as the last time but one in the same group of muscles. It doesn't look too serious."

Houllier's key contribution to the great debate was to come when he was invited to hazard a guess as to when Owen would next be asked to slip into comeback mode.

"We do not have a game next weekend so I hope he'll be back for the game against Leeds United in a fortnight - or maybe for the Arsenal game after that one," he said.

Clearly, all is not well and the possibility of Owen returning to Munich for the laying on of sports injury specialist Hans Muller-Wohlfahrt's healing hands cannot be discounted. Certainly, his chances of playing for his country in next month's friendly against Argentina are slim. Owen had intensive treatment at Liverpool's training ground yesterday and will be looked at again today.

He was actually better off out of this morass of incompetence, for Liverpool could have played for ever and a day and still not found a way through Middlesbrough's smartly drilled defence. As Houllier lamented: "We have had our two main strikers - Robbie Fowler and Michael - for only 60 minutes this season. Does anybody know of someone who can score us a goal?"

Owen's problems apart, only the ever-present possibility of Paul Ince being sent off on his rather unwelcome return to Merseyside kept the punters awake.

Ince's lack of grace after he was thrown out of Liverpool last summer was astonishing - he called for Houllier to be sacked - but he is now a player in sharp decline.

Even so, Ince enjoyed the game's only clear-cut chance. After being released by Juninho, he should have gone on to score but, believing he was offside, he hesitated, allowing Sander Westerveld to save with his feet.

fields.headline: Leicester call for Collymore
fields.trailText: Also: Leicester have offered Stan Collymore the chance to resurrect his Premiership career.
fields.byline: Trevor Haylett  at Filbert Street and  Adrian Murray
fields.body:
Leicester City have reacted in the strongest fashion to their defeat at the hands of West Ham. They have offered Aston Villa's errant striker Stan Collymore the chance to resurrect his Premiership career.

Leicester, who face Villa in a Worthington Cup semi-final tomorrow, are prepared to take over the 29-year-old striker's £20,000-a-week contract with 18 months to run. Collymore is understood to be thinking over the move, which would suit his domestic circumstances since he lives in the centre of Birmingham.

As before though, the transfer fee - or lack of one - could be a sticking point. Though Villa's manager John Gregory would probably pay Leicester to take the player off his hands, Gregory's chairman Doug Ellis is keen to recoup a portion of the £7m they paid Liverpool for Collymore in 1997.

If he does move to Filbert Street, the striker will not be able to ruin Villa's Worthington Cup chances: he played for Fulham in the competition while on loan at Craven Cottage.

West Ham's own lost soul, Paulo Wanchope, may also have glimpsed the road to recovery. Of late the Costa Rican has been exercising the patience of West Ham supporters, one miss in particular from three yards against Aston Villa calling his future at the club into question.

But there is no room for grey in Harry Redknapp's claret-and-blue world. The West Ham manager refused to lose faith and his judgment was underscored with Saturday's two-goal display.

On days like this Redknapp has a striking partnership made in heaven, marrying Wanchope's leggy runs and eye for the main chance with the intricate footwork and unerring control of Paolo di Canio. It was the Italian who supplied the goal of the game, cutting across a line of defenders before firing low into the corner. Without Wanchope's earlier conviction, however, they would not have been in position to seal a first win in 10 matches.

Wanchope's finishing mocked his failure to find the target since November. He scored from his side's first genuine attack, hooking a pass from Frank Lampard beyond Pegguy Arphexad, and while his second had a touch of fortune, as Michael Carrick's drive cannoned off his shins, his work thereafter in squeezing the ball home from a tight angle was worthy of praise.

"He's powerful and strong and a handful for any defence; the only thing that let him down is his finishing," said Redknapp. "People have a right to criticise when they see you miss from three yards, but we have told Paulo that if he keeps working hard his luck will turn."

Last week two Premiership managers decided to test that faith with transfer bids. "I don't want to lose him so the conversation didn't get very far. If I don't fancy a player I will get rid of him after a month but Paulo is young and raw and I believe in him."

It was to Wanchope's and West Ham's benefit that Leicester were a shadow of the team that had put Arsenal out of the FA Cup, which itself was some way short of Martin O'Neil's preferred 11. There are big games around the corner, in the Worthington Cup semi-final against Aston Villa tomorrow and at Chelsea in the FA Cup fifth round on Sunday, and O'Neil took the opportunity to give some of his weary troops a rest. Time to send for reinforcements?

webTitle: Jones rallies to the spirit of Shankly

fields.headline: Jones rallies to the spirit of Shankly
fields.trailText: In the darkest hours of this difficult time Dave Jones remembers the day he was sitting on a bed at Everton's training ground nursing a knee injury. It was a day, more than 20 years ago, when Bill Shankly came to call.
fields.body:
In the darkest hours of this difficult time Dave Jones remembers the day he was sitting on a bed at Everton's training ground nursing a knee injury. It was a day, more than 20 years ago, when Bill Shankly came to call.

Shankly had retired as Liverpool manager but, still living locally, he would occasionally visit his once-great rivals. What he said to Jones left an indelible impression. "That quitters never win and winners never quit," Jones recalled, "and I certainly won't give up."

Less steely characters than the Southampton manager might have done last week. Rumours were rife that this would be his last game; that Lawrie McMenemy was waiting to step in. At a meeting with supporters last Thursday Jones heard that he was out of his depth, had lost the players' respect and ought to resign. "There is a tidal wave of opinion against you," one fan said.

Standing down looked the easy option. On Wednesday Jones will be given a date for his trial on 13 child abuse charges, which he denies. If the date is set for before May 14, it will be interesting to see whether the club continues to stand by him.

After the 5-0 defeat at Newcastle even the chairman Rupert Lowe had rebuked the team's lack of passion. Yet, far from crushing Jones, last week could prove a turning point. Hours before facing the fans, he called a meeting with his players.

"It wasn't heated," said the centre-half Dean Richards. "We had a discussion and a cup of coffee. The experienced players like Mark Hughes said what they thought was going wrong.

"The gaffer took on board what we said but in any case most of us came to the same conclusion - that we were getting too stretched as a team, that teams were playing through us too easily and that we had to get back to a solid base with a solid eight behind the ball." The more familiar feeling here is being stuck solidly behind the eight ball. After two wins from their past 16 matches Richards believes the meeting was not before time. "We've been on a slippery slope and it was good to clear the air," he said. "It was obvious we had problems and hopefully this has sorted them out."

After 45 minutes the signs were not positive; Southampton were booed off. But the team had clearly listened to Jones' message on Thursday: no matter how you are playing, nothing stops you working hard. The reward was to come.

Jones says his clear conscience allows him to stay focused. The talk of his swansong was just talk, he said, "unless the chairman's a very good liar". And no, he had not lost the players' respect: "There have been a lot of Chinese whispers but I never got that feeling."

Richards confirmed as much and spoke of a man who leaves his personal strife at home. "If it wasn't publicised we would not know anything about it because he doesn't bring his problems to work," he said. "I think the boss has blanked that out and got on with his job as best he can. Obviously it's going to put him under a bit of pressure but he's handled it well. The boys have backed him."

The scathing letters in Saturday's pink suggest the fans are less convinced. Lowe, though supportive, has made his feelings clear. "It is fair to say we came down hard on Dave at our board meeting," he said. "We are not trying to build a stadium for Nationwide League football."

This nervy, untidy win hinted that they should survive, though games at Sheffield Wednesday, Bradford and Derby will be decisive. Jo Tessem scored from distance and Matthew Oakley ended a fine run by curling in No2.

"It would have been hard walking down that touchline if we had lost," Jones admitted. "How do I cope? I have to. If you don't you roll down and die." And Shanks would never have stood for that.

fields.headline: John adds to agony
fields.standfirst: Nationwide League
fields.trailText: Given the precarious league positions of both sides this really was a case of five points dropped rather than one picked up on an afternoon that the Forest manager needed like a hole in the head.
fields.byline: Mark Tallentire  at the City Ground
fields.body:
Given the precarious league positions of both sides this really was a case of five points dropped rather than one picked up on an afternoon that the Forest manager needed like a hole in the head.

For David Platt this second managerial post is proving no easier than his first - as "overall supervisor" at Sampdoria, he managed no wins in six games - and while the former England captain's employment prospects do not look in immediate danger, his team are.

To make matters worse Stern John, Forest's only likely source of goals in an uninspiring game, limped off with a ligament injury which will ground him for the foreseeable future. Both of the home side's best chances had fallen to the £1.5m striker but he hit the first against the keeper and then failed to force a save with a header from Matthieu Louis-Jean's cross.

Platt is now expected to step up interest in Grimsby's Jack Lester and must have cast envious eyes over Albion's lively striker Lee Hughes, who had the shot of the match, a volley from four yards, brilliantly saved by Dave Beasant, airborne to his left.

Later, Mickey Evans' header missed a post by inches and the substitute then freed Hughes, who advanced and shot only for Beasant to clear again.

That made it 14 draws in 28 games for Albion. Though the manager was pleased with "a hard day's work" it left his team two points above the relegation places, alongside Forest.

"We've got a new directive from a new chairman and I've given the players a directive, a strong one," said Brian Little, who has written off this season. "Hopefully we will at least be in this division to set up again in the summer and look at a longer-term plan."

Platt, having used 34 players in a variety of positions this term and only once kept an unchanged team, would take that.

webTitle: Hunt hat-trick does not please Curbishley

fields.headline: Hunt hat-trick does not please Curbishley
fields.trailText: For Alan Curbishley's Charlton, the season gets better and better. This was their sixth successive win, a sequence which has carried them four points clear at the top of the First Division and suggests theirs will be a fleeting return to the Nationwide League.
fields.body:
For Alan Curbishley's Charlton, the season gets better and better. This was their sixth successive win, a sequence which has carried them four points clear at the top of the First Division and suggests theirs will be a fleeting return to the Nationwide League.

But that does not tell the true story of Saturday's match. "I was very disappointed," said Curbishley, hardly the words expected of a manager basking in an apparently comfortable away win through Andy Hunt's second hat-trick of the season. "We looked very sluggish."

Fortunately for the visitors their goalkeeper Dean Kiely performed heroics to pave the way for this flattering victory. Four times he kept the home side at bay before the interval, the pick of his saves coming at the feet of Iwan Roberts after a frantic goalmouth scramble.

"It certainly is a funny old game," admitted the Norwich manager Bruce Rioch. "We played really well and yet lost 3-0. But Charlton took their chances and we didn't."

It was perhaps appropriate that the matchwinner once had an unsuccessful trial at Carrow Road. Hunt made City pay by side-footing home Graham Stuart's corner just before the break and added a second when the Norwich goalkeeper Andy Marshall let a weak shot squirm through his grasp.

The Norwich custodian was still licking his wounds when Hunt rose to head in John Robinson's cross five minutes later. "I'm delighted for Andy," added Curbishley. "But I expected more from us today."

"It certainly is a funny old game," admitted the Norwich manager Bruce Rioch. "We played really well and yet lost 3-0. But Charlton took their chances and we didn't." It was perhaps appropriate that the matchwinner once had an unsuccessful trial at Carrow Road. Hunt made City pay by side-footing home Graham Stuart's corner just before the break and added a second when the Norwich goalkeeper Andy Marshall let a weak shot squirm through his grasp. The Norwich custodian was still licking his wounds when Hunt rose to head in John Robinson's cross five minutes later. "I'm delighted for Andy," added Curbishley. "But I expected more from us today."

webTitle: Derby miss the points of daring

fields.headline: Derby miss the points of daring
fields.trailText: Two weeks after the Tranmere farce comes another mess-up involving a fourth official and his electronic numbers. This time the culprit was Andy Hall of Birmingham who, with seconds ticking away, walked purposefully to the touchline and held up a board indicating two minutes of time to be added on.
fields.body:
Two weeks after the Tranmere farce comes another mess-up involving a fourth official and his electronic numbers. This time the culprit was Andy Hall of Birmingham who, with seconds ticking away, walked purposefully to the touchline and held up a board indicating two minutes of time to be added on.

It was nothing short of scandalous. Where Mr Hall found the nerve to inflict another 120 seconds of this rubbish on a crowd already pushed beyond the limits of endurance only he can tell. Had he been doing his job properly he would have abandoned this game long before the concluding whis tle and allowed everyone to go home and watch Final Score in front of the fire.

The abject quality of Saturday's proceedings was entirely down to Derby County. Cautious in the extreme, the Rams mustered few attacks of any merit and laid their gameplan bare by sending only four players up at corners.

"Our priority was not to get beat," said the Derby manager Jim Smith, puffing calmly on a pungent cigar. "It's the first time we've had two home games back to back and not lost, so that was important. We needed not to lose and we didn't, so we're still on course."

But on course for what, exactly? Coventry came with a weakened team and, as their away record read played nine, won nil in the league, it might have been expected that Derby would have plenty of incentive to go for the three points.

Instead the home side managed to carve out only one clear opening, Deon Burton hitting the bar in the 24th minute when he should have scored, and rather than the eventual single point helping to consolidate their crawl away from the relegation zone, as Smith might have expected, Derby simply lost ground to three of the four clubs below them.

The best chance of the game fell in the 73rd minute to the England hopeful Steve Froggatt, who sliced his shot against the post. At which point Mr Hall should have put the match out of its misery.

fields.headline: Brown eclipses old blue moon
fields.trailText: Another self-inflicted wound, but City will recover. Let's face it, after years of practice, they are the experts.
fields.body:
Another self-inflicted wound, but City will recover. Let's face it, after years of practice, they are the experts.

Joe Royle revealed that his players are going away in midweek. "They need some R and R," he said, but did not explain whether that meant rest and recuperation or rant and rave.

The City manager was confident that the blow was not serious but far from happy at the damage done by Michael Brown, who spent six years at Maine Road before being sold to Sheffield United for £400,000 last week.

The 22-year-old midfielder volleyed the winner right in front of City's 6,000 fans. He had handed out match tickets to many of them, so it was a dilemma. Faced by an army of silent, formerly supportive Blue Moonies he did not seem at first to know what to do.

But he knew what he was doing after the game, when he dodged reporters. "He's done his talking on the pitch," came the comical response from some sponsor's lounge.

Even Royle declined to climb the many stairs to talk to the press, but he made his annoyance plain from outside the dressing room. "It doesn't matter who scored the goal," he said. "It's just Sod's Law it was him. What matters is that we were desperately poor. It was easily our worst performance of the season. It happens."

It happened because United worked ferociously, closed City down, defended well in the air and took one of their own chances. They have been transformed - taking 16 points from their past seven games - by the arrival of Neil Warnock, who hurried away on a scouting trip to China, where he is hoping to buy a striker.

United used to sign centre-forwards from places like Driffield and Doncaster but at least their latest arrival is, like Brown, from closer to home.

Alex Notman made his debut on loan from Manchester United, where he is in a lengthy queue of strikers behind Dwight Yorke, Andy Cole, Ole Gunnar Solskjaer and Teddy Sheringham.

The Scot has spent three seasons in the reserves and is desperate just to play in front of a crowd. Bramall Lane provided one - 24,000, their biggest this season - and he was applauded off after 68 minutes.

"I'm just 20 and feel it's time to start getting first-team football," he said. "It is very difficult at Manchester United, seeing internationals sitting on the bench. You hope for a break but you can't wait for ever."

fields.headline: Bassett pulls the Tykes together
fields.trailText: A wit in Barnsley's press room has added the cut-out mug shots of Alan Shearer and David Ginola to a leaflet depicting the world's protected species. In time they may consider adding Dave Bassett's face too.
fields.body:
A wit in Barnsley's press room has added the cut-out mug shots of Alan Shearer and David Ginola to a leaflet depicting the world's protected species. In time they may consider adding Dave Bassett's face too.

For signs are growing that the original chirpy cockney is casting his managerial spell again. Both Forest and Sheffield United have slumped since Bassett was shown the door and this result, Barnsley's sixth win in seven, gives growing credence to the feeling that the man with more promotions than any other is at it again.

On the face of it this was no walk-over. Rovers had been beaten only once in 15 games but the camaraderie instilled by Bassett into every side he has managed shone through from the start. Without fail they all pull together.

Barnsley were helped by dreadful defending. Darren Peacock and Christian Dailly looked like novices rather than the experienced players they are and, before they knew it, it was all over.

Craig Hignett, Neil Shipperley and Darren Barnard all profited. Per Frandsen's free- kick had earlier cancelled out Bruce Dyer's opener but that was as close as Rovers got.

"It's just like watching Brazil," bellowed the home support. "It's just like watching Grange Hill" would have been a suitable reply from the 2,000 travelling fans. As Tony Parkes pointed out, his side did not even win the second half.

"It was a disaster," he said. "For us with aspirations of making the play-offs to lose 5-1 against a side fourth in the table is not good enough."

Bassett was delivering his own post-match deliberations when Parkes said goodbye. "See you in the play-offs, Dave," said the Lancastrians' manager merrily. His opposite number smiled; one suspects he has bigger fish to fry.

webTitle: Agile Gould spares ring-rusty Celtic's blushes

fields.headline: Agile Gould spares ring-rusty Celtic's blushes
fields.trailText: Celtic placed their championship chances in considerable peril at Kilmarnock last night. Missing a clutch of important players, they were frequently outfought and so fell six points behind Rangers, who also have a game in hand.
fields.body:
Celtic placed their championship chances in considerable peril at Kilmarnock last night. Missing a clutch of important players, they were frequently outfought and so fell six points behind Rangers, who also have a game in hand.

It was hardly a happy return from their midwinter break and left John Barnes and the travelling support completely frustrated. The visitors faced an unexpectedly vigorous challenge from Kilmarnock who, according to manager Bobby Williamson, have long been playing better than results would indicate.

Indeed, they might have taken the lead in the 26th minute when Jonathan Gould's instinctive save blocked Gary Holt's header.

Celtic had been unconvincing, but Mark Viduka always carries a threat. Five minutes later he pursued a Regi Blinker pass and carried the ball into the penalty area. His shot eventually found the net with a little help from a deflection off Jim Lauchlan.

But Kilmarnock, undeterred, deservedly equalised five minutes be fore half-time when Mark Reilly's hopeful shot from the edge of the area beat Gould after taking a heavy deflection off Vidar Riseth.

Celtic were seriously embarrassed in the second half. A dreadful mistake by Riseth gave Andy Smith a clear run only for Gould to make a brave block at his feet. The same striker was denied again moments later.

Celtic looked bemused. Tommy Boyd, Stilian Petrov and Jackie McNamara were all booked in one spell so it was clear that they understood their desperate state, and their inability to resolve it. In the end, they counted their blessings and Gould's agility.

webTitle: Big Top is full of holes as circus returns to town

fields.headline: Big Top is full of holes as circus returns to town
fields.standfirst: Rangers smile as they win 5-0 but the joke is wearing thin
fields.trailText: Scotland's football circus is back in town, with Rangers as the ringmaster and Aberdeen in the role of those guys who paint their faces and cavort in silly clothes on Saturday.
fields.body:
Scotland's football circus is back in town, with Rangers as the ringmaster and Aberdeen in the role of those guys who paint their faces and cavort in silly clothes on Saturday.

There was much about Aberdeen's performance at Ibrox that was downright clownish. The saddest face belonged to their manager Ebbe Skovdahl who remains extraordinarily calm and patient as his charges keep falling flat on their faces, without raising the flicker of a smile from their long-suffering supporters.

Overall, Scots could hardly be said to have flocked back to the Premier League for its first games of the millennium.

Rangers did break through the 50,000 barrier but St Johnstone and Dundee United could not even half-fill their grounds and there were 4,000 empty seats at Tynecastle. Many clearly believe that the top 10 is too predictable, the Old Firm astride it and the rest huffing and puffing to gain no greater reward than some comfort in the middle of the table. The Ibrox match was a perfect illustration of the bleakness of it all. The Rangers season ticket holders would pay top money to watch their team score 15 against a scratch side from the Govan pubs and then go home convinced that they were watching potential European Cup winners.

In reality, they are doing nothing of the sort. Rangers' grandiose ambitions are being sabotaged by playing so many games that are no more than gentle sparring sessions against an increasing number of clubs who have given up the ghost against them.

Aberdeen were so poor that any tactic apart from placing every man on the goal-line and telling them to keep their fingers crossed would have failed. They kept Rangers at bay for 35 minutes but the defensive work was so slipshod that they had no chance of holding out over a full match.

Once Rangers had taken the lead via Craig Moore, unmarked for a header, they were always going to win handsomely. If Rod Wallace had shown any form at all the home score might well have ended up in double figures.

With Giovanni van Bronk- horst rising from his sickbed, Billy Dodds and Neil McCann invisible and Jorg Albertz silent, they hardly fired on all cylinders but still managed five goals.

The Rangers manager Dick Advocaat is trying to persuade Marco Negri to return to the fray while Seb Rosenthal flies in from Chile fit and well to seek a new work permit this week. That should all pep up the scoring rate nicely.

Home fans were granted a glimpse of their new £1.2m Turk Tugay Kerimoglu, who came on for 20 minutes. "He will have to play the way we play," the manager said sternly, but the former Galatasaray midfielder's talent is obvious. "It must have something to do with confidence and self-belief," sighed Skovdahl.

There was much about Aberdeen's performance at Ibrox that was downright clownish. The saddest face belonged to their manager Ebbe Skovdahl who remains extraordinarily calm and patient as his charges keep falling flat on their faces, without raising the flicker of a smile from their long-suffering supporters. Overall, Scots could hardly be said to have flocked back to the Premier League for its first games of the millennium. Rangers did break through the 50,000 barrier but St Johnstone and Dundee United could not even half-fill their grounds and there were 4,000 empty seats at Tynecastle. Many clearly believe that the top 10 is too predictable, the Old Firm astride it and the rest huffing and puffing to gain no greater reward than some comfort in the middle of the table. The Ibrox match was a perfect illustration of the bleakness of it all. The Rangers season ticket holders would pay top money to watch their team score 15 against a scratch side from the Govan pubs and then go home convinced that they were watching potential European Cup winners. fields.headline: Third Division round-up
fields.trailText: Leaders Rotherham romp home, Barnet and Swansea keep up the chase and Hull get off to a flying start.
fields.body:
Leo Fortune-West and Paul Warne each scored twice as Rotherham romped to a 5-0 win at home to Exeter to stay top on goal difference.

Exeter were hardly helped when Darren Rowbotham was sent off for violent conduct; Brian Wilsterman was the Millers' other scorer.

Barnet and Swansea stayed hot on their heels, Swansea beating Macclesfield with Walter Boyd's 71st-minute goal while Barnet got the better of Lincoln in an eight-goal feast at Underhill.

Gavin Gordon gave Lincoln the lead but Barnet were 3-1 up by the break thanks to Rob Sawyers, Ken Charlery and an own goal from Paul Smith. Paul Miller pulled one back for Lincoln on the restart but Warren Hackett and John Doolan gave Barnet the points before Tony Battersby's late penalty consolation.

Hartlepool and Northampton kept up with the leaders, Tommy Miller's 53rd-minute goal giving Hartlepool a 1-0 win over Carlisle and Northampton eventually overcoming the bottom club Chester.

Ally Pickering's second-minute goal gave Chester's new manager Ian Atkins hope of an upset against his old club, but Steve Howard equalised in the 31st minute before Ian Sampson and Carlo Corazzin gave Northampton a 3-1 win.

The fastest goal on Saturday was scored by Hull City's Jamaican international Theodore Whitmore after 35 seconds of the 1-1 home draw with Cheltenham.

fields.headline: Second Division round-up
fields.trailText: Rovers thrash blue Oxford, Preston stumble to win and Steve McMahon wins his first game at Blackpool.
fields.body:
Bristol Rovers thrashed Oxford 5-0 to maintain the best away record in the division and go level on points with the leaders Wigan.

It was Rovers' eighth win on the road. Jamie Cureton provided a hat-trick with goals in the 30th, 56th and 80th minutes with Robbie Pethick (74) and Nathan Ellington (75) completing the scoring.

Preston stayed in third place but not without a few alarms against Wycombe who led through Matthew Brady's fifth-minute goal. The North Enders went in 2-1 up at half-time but, after the Wanderers equalised, they needed Jonathan Macken's 18th goal of the season to run out 3-2 winners.

Michael Gilkes scored the only goal of the game to keep Millwall in the promotion hunt and steal a march over rivals Stoke in a 1-0 victory at the New Den.

Darren Ferguson's 74th-minute goal gave Wrexham a 2-1 home win over Cardiff. Karl Connolly had earlier equalised after Joshua Low had given the visitors a 48th-minute lead.

Colchester eased away from the danger zone with a 3-1 win over Bournemouth. A brace of goals from Lomano Lua-Lua in the 63rd and 83rd minutes made the three points safe for Colchester.

Steve McMahon had his first win as Blackpool manager when his visitors beat Gillingham 3-1. Kevin Richardson, Steve Bushell and Robert Matthews gave Blackpool a 3-0 lead but Nicky Southall pulled one back.

fields.headline: First Division round-up
fields.trailText: Wolves run wild, Walsall win away and Fulham continue to stumble.
fields.body:
Wolves were three up inside half an hour against Queen's Park Rangers through Steve Sedgley (22), Michael Branch (23) and Ade Akinbyi (29). As Wolves eased up Rangers came back with late goals from Gavin Peacock and Steve Slade but the Midlanders held on for a 3-2 win.

Walsall pulled off their third away win of the season with a thrilling 3-2 victory at Crewe. Tom Bennett and Michael Ricketts gave the Saddlers a two-goal lead before Steve Macauley pulled one back from the penalty spot. Kevin Harper restored the cushion on the stroke of half-time, although Paul Tait later reduced the arrears.

Fulham's challenge for a play-off place took another body blow when Jack Lester's 56th-minute goal gave Grimsby a 1-0 victory at Craven Cottage, only their second away win.

webTitle: Zidane shines as Juve win again

fields.headline: Zidane shines as Juve win again
fields.trailText: In Italy, Zinedine Zidane scored a superb goal as Juventus won 2-0 at Reggina yesterday to open up a three-point lead at the top of Serie A. The Turin side, unbeaten in their last 14 league matches, lead Lazio, who were held to a 0-0 draw at Cagliari on Saturday.
fields.body:
In Italy, Zinedine Zidane scored a superb goal as Juventus won 2-0 at Reggina yesterday to open up a three-point lead at the top of Serie A. The Turin side, unbeaten in their last 14 league matches, lead Lazio, who were held to a 0-0 draw at Cagliari on Saturday.

The champions Milan came back from 2-0 down at the San Siro to force a 2-2 draw with Lecce, thanks to second-half goals from their captain Paolo Maldini and Oliver Bierhoff.

Roma, 2-1 winners over Piacenza at the Olympic Stadium on Saturday, remain third. Inter recovered from a 1-0 deficit to beat Verona 2-1 with a second-half winner from the substitute Roberto Baggio.

In Spain, Brazil's Rivaldo, who is expected to be named Fifa world player of the year today, scored the only goal against Racing Santander to push Barcelona into second place in the league yesterday.

They are three points behind leaders Deportivo La Coruna who beat Real Betis 2-0 on Saturday. Real Madrid lost further ground as they were held 0-0 at Numancia.

webTitle: In a world of his own

fields.headline: In a world of his own
fields.standfirst: Darryl Fuller is a typical teenage boy living a typical inner-city life. Expelled from school after school, unemployed and ill-educated, his future is at best uncertain. How does he see the world? And how can he get what he wants from life?  Andrew O'Hagan  paints a portrait of the British Male at 16
fields.trailText: Darryl Fuller is a typical teenage boy living a typical inner-city life. Expelled from school after school, unemployed and ill-educated, his future is at best uncertain. How does he see the world? And how can he get what he wants from life?  Andrew O'Hagan  paints a portrait of the British Male at 16
fields.body:
The people on Barking Road are going somewhere. A black woman with a bundle of clothes is padding down to the Laundromat. A guy with drink on his breath is trying to sell a watch. The people in the taxi office are talking into mobile phones. They are making plans for later. The street buses on their way to Stratford and Plaistow come rolling past with people on the top decks deep into novels or the evening paper.

Darryl Fuller is taking up a little corner at Community Links in the old town hall. He sits, smiling, at the end of a group of chairs. This is his classroom. He was born on November 2 1983 in Forest Gate Hospital. When he tries to remember all the houses he has lived in he comes up with a flurry of names: Shaftesbury Road, Upton Park, the Isle of Dogs, Poplar and Beckton, where he lives now with his dad, who is 36, his mother, who is 34, a sister called Sinead, and brothers Daniel and Ricky. They live in a four-bedroom house with a dog called Chloe. He says when he thinks about it he isn't sure if his mum's 34. "I don't like to ask." He doesn't know if the house they live in is rented or bought.

Darryl's first memory is of being five years old. He was walking down the street and he looked over at some girls and then crashed into a lamp post. The first school he went to was St Stephen's, in Green Street. He was excluded after a year. Darryl looks into space when he is trying to remember things. "Some kid wanted to fight me and I just stuck him," he says. Then he went to another school in Shaftesbury Road. He was there three weeks, he says, when an Asian kid pulled a knife on him. The kid with the knife was aged 10. Darryl kicked the knife out of his hand and then punched him out. Around then Darryl's mum had another kid and they all moved to a bigger house on the Isle of Dogs. He talks about gangs bullying his sister and he couldn't stand it so he "flipped".

"What happens when you flip?"

"One minute I was all calm," he says, "and then I turned and I'm out of control. I just don't know what'll happen then. It's always fists - if you can't fight with your fists you can't fight at all. I get mad if someone insults my mum or attacks my sister. I search for people who do that."

Darryl was 10 when they moved to Beckton. He got expelled from North Beckton School and was later allowed back in. Then he went to Brampton Manor and in the first year he was excluded for fighting. They allowed him back in, but he started fighting again and was out by the second year. "By that time," he says, "I was having fights just every other month. At the same time in my life I started bunking. I bunked nearly the whole of my third year and when I was 15 they asked me to leave."

"Did you have friends?"

"Yeah. Virtually the whole school."

"Was there anything you liked about school?"

"Yeah. Football. Pottery. Do you want to see my lessons?"

Darryl's doing a thing just now about the different spellings and meanings of words that sound the same. It's all written down in sheets in his folder.

"When you have toothache you have . . . pain."

"A sheet of glass in a window is a . . . pane."

"White, or having a colourless face . . . pale."

"A bucket . . . pail."

On the arithmetic pages he has shown himself able to add 13 and 34 to make 47. This year he can multiply five by five to make 25. And he can make sense of the proposition that when seven people eat three bars of chocolate each, then altogether they ate 21 bars.

Darryl likes the idea of everything about him being known and written down.

He is the British Male at 16. Or is he just one of them? His star sign is Scorpio. He is right-handed. People he tries to avoid are Liz, Bob, Gary and Danny. He likes to watch Coronation Street, EastEnders, championship wrestling, South Park, a music channel called The Box and tons of movies. He is brilliant at Nintendo. There's a PlayStation game he likes called Knockabout Kings. It's a boxing game. "It's quite hard. I'm the WBA champion undefeated," he says. Not only that, but he's brilliant as well at Tekken - a fighting game.

"I expect you are."

"Yeah. I'm brilliant. I like violent games. I've beat everyone there is down my street."

One time, one of the teachers at one of the schools asked him to come in and play drums at assembly. "It was brilliant," he says. He would love to have a drum kit of his own and he and some of his friends have been trying to fix up a band. His friend Danny's in the band. He doesn't say anything about Danny being one of his people to avoid.

He records cool songs off the radio and off the music show on cable. "Some people say I'm all right on the drums," he says. West Ham United is his football team. A guy called Denver takes him and some of his mates for football practice down at the ground every Wednesday. Three hours every time. "It's brilliant," says Darryl, "I'm a striker. We've had a good start to the season but now we're playing crap."

"You mean West Ham?"

"Yeah."

Darryl says the prime minister is called John Blair, or something. When he thinks of what he'd like to do if he was in charge of the country, he says right away that he'd stop racism. He hates drugs as well, he says. "I have a chance to play for Leyton Orient. I'm trying to calm down and if you do that [drugs], you know what'll happen. It'd be impossible to get rid of drugs but I'd like to. I've got a mate who takes drugs and he just looks so ill."

"Are you really not interested in drugs?"

"No way," he says, "they're for mugs." He smiles.

He paused for ages before saying the third thing he'd do if he ruled the country. "I know," he says, "I would sort charity out. If people need help they should get it - you know - support and that."

Listening to Darryl, you find yourself able both to admire him and to worry. He lives in a precarious personal world. He is only beginning to know what he can trust; he is only beginning to want to be trustworthy. No one would find Darryl an impossible proposition now: he is growing up likeable, with more personality than charm, and more charm than free-floating anger.

He needs only to be talked away from his difficult traits: given lessons, a football coach, a number of small tasks, a weekend job at the Booker cash-and-carry. He needs to be part of something that is slightly bigger than he is himself. At Community Links, on Barking Road, something of the sort has gripped him. The only worry is, can he stick it?

On a typical day, Darryl is woken by his mum at 9am. He gets washed and might eat something, and if his mum's busy he'll iron his own shirt. Then he cycles to Community Links, where he learns the difference between "pain" and "pane", and where there's an environment that allows him to feel he's going somewhere. He also does odd jobs around the building - "helping old people downstairs with their tea and that" - and he sees the time just rolling away with all he's got to do now. "People up here got respect for me," he says. "They leave me to get on with my work. I get on with everybody now."

Darryl says he can't think of anyone to blame about his schooldays. He says if he's honest it was him. "I'm young," he says, "I don't know how my life will go. I just want nothing bad to happen. I just want to be myself." He sometimes gets frustrated because he wants things to go faster. He has learned a lot more than he ever did at school, though. There are only six or seven people in his class at Community Links.

He's been on planes. He went to Lourdes with some folk who couldn't walk. Darryl doesn't go to church but his mum goes. If he had to die for anything, then he thinks it should be his family. His heroes are his mum and his dad and his nan. He'd like to have a silver Porsche Boxster Turbo. He has no fear of cars, even though he was in a crash once, with his dad. Fifteen stitches in his head. It was somebody else's fault: they jumped the lights.

He's not going steady with a girl but he has a few girlfriends he sees all the time. He says that girls admire him for the muscles on his stomach although he doesn't even work out.

Outside the strip-lighted classroom other people are coming into the building for classes and meetings and coffee and tea. You can hear music starting up for a dance class downstairs. All over the place the sense rises up of an effort being made; a sense of things being overcome and time being invested. The sound of laughter travels up the stairs and along the corridor.

For money Darryl relies on his mum. She gives him a few quid here and there. So does his dad. But one of these days he's going to get a part-time job at Booker in Beckton; he would like it if he could have more money for drums or clothes or that Porsche Boxster Turbo.

He is wearing a light green Ben Sherman shirt. He is very pleased with his hooded top from Paul Smith. His trousers cost 60 quid. His favourite shoes are Kickers and the ones he is wearing are brown and comfy. He wears white socks and he thinks that socks are important. His brown hair is cut into a kind of wedge but he says it's not a wedge, it's called curtains.

Darryl sticks his tongue out when he makes a joke. When you ask him what he thinks of the police he begins to look a bit shifty. "They do their job don't they, but I hate the way they pull up my mates just 'cos they've got bald heads." He used to have a bald head himself, but then he got into the pop singer Peter Andre who has hair hanging over his face: curtains.

"I feel quite sorted out in my head," he says. "If I wanted to be a gangster I'd know what to do. But I don't want that. Not now. I don't get off on knowing villains or anything."

He slumps in the chair, smiles in a lop-sided way, and looks around the room where he says good things have happened for him. "I'd like to have a family some day," he says.

Darryl's eyes are hazel. He is five foot five. He is 16 years old and proud of it, thank you. His favourite colour is claret. He walks down the stairs of Community Links smiling at every one and making jokes. The last I see of him, he picks up his bike and wheels it towards the doors. It is dark outside. He smiles a big smile as he hops on his bike and heads into Barking Road. Like the rest of the world out there, he is at his best with somewhere to go.

On the way out I look at a piece of paper. It carries the words of Betty Young, an 86-year-old woman who helped set up Community Links at an East Ham shop in 1978. "The shop was damp and it smelt of coal tar from when the chemist used to be there," she said.

"There was always boys there, at first three and then more, boys who should have been at school. I know some of them were in trouble but they were always good to me. Gradually we got things going. I remember thinking, I've seen a lot of bad things but this is a good."

The 86-year-old's words - on a cold night last October - seemed almost to propel the British Male at 16 on his way up Barking Road.

This article was taken from What if . . ? 15 Visions of Change for Britain's Inner Cities, which is published by Short Books today, priced £5.99. All sale proceeds go to the charity Community Links.

 What If...available exclusively at Waterstones, and selected independent booksellers.

Then he cycles to Community Links, where he learns the difference between "pain" and "pane", and where there's an environment that allows him to feel he's going somewhere. He also does odd jobs around the building - "helping old people downstairs with their tea and that" - and he sees the time just rolling away with all he's got to do now. "People up here got respect for me," he says. "They leave me to get on with my work. I get on with everybody now." Darryl says he can't think of anyone to blame about his schooldays. He says if he's honest it was him. "I'm young," he says, "I don't know how my life will go. I just want nothing bad to happen. I just want to be myself." He sometimes gets frustrated because he wants things to go faster. He has learned a lot more than he ever did at school, though. There are only six or seven people in his class at Community Links. He's been on planes. He went to Lourdes with some folk who couldn't walk. Darryl doesn't go to church but his mum goes. If he had to die for anything, then he thinks it should be his family. His heroes are his mum and his dad and his nan. He'd like to have a silver Porsche Boxster Turbo. He has no fear of cars, even though he was in a crash once, with his dad. Fifteen stitches in his head. It was somebody else's fault: they jumped the lights. He's not going steady with a girl but he has a few girlfriends he sees all the time. He says that girls admire him for the muscles on his stomach although he doesn't even work out. Outside the strip-lighted classroom other people are coming into the building for classes and meetings and coffee and tea. You can hear music starting up for a dance class downstairs. All over the place the sense rises up of an effort being made; a sense of things being overcome and time being invested. The sound of laughter travels up the stairs and along the corridor. For money Darryl relies on his mum. She gives him a few quid here and there. So does his dad. But one of these days he's going to get a part-time job at Booker in Beckton; he would like it if he could have more money for drums or clothes or that Porsche Boxster Turbo. He is wearing a light green Ben Sherman shirt. He is very pleased with his hooded top from Paul Smith. His trousers cost 60 quid. His favourite shoes are Kickers and the ones he is wearing are brown and comfy. He wears white socks and he thinks that socks are important. His brown hair is cut into a kind of wedge but he says it's not a wedge, it's called curtains. Darryl sticks his tongue out when he makes a joke. When you ask him what he thinks of the police he begins to look a bit shifty. "They do their job don't they, but I hate the way they pull up my mates just 'cos they've got bald heads." He used to have a bald head himself, but then he got into the pop singer Peter Andre who has hair hanging over his face: curtains. "I feel quite sorted out in my head," he says. "If I wanted to be a gangster I'd know what to do. But I don't want that. Not now. I don't get off on knowing villains or anything." He slumps in the chair, smiles in a lop-sided way, and looks around the room where he says good things have happened for him. "I'd like to have a family some day," he says. Darryl's eyes are hazel. He is five foot five. He is 16 years old and proud of it, thank you. His favourite colour is claret. He walks down the stairs of Community Links smiling at every one and making jokes. The last I see of him, he picks up his bike and wheels it towards the doors. It is dark outside. He smiles a big smile as he hops on his bike and heads into Barking Road. Like the rest of the world out there, he is at his best with somewhere to go. On the way out I look at a piece of paper. It carries the words of Betty Young, an 86-year-old woman who helped set up Community Links at an East Ham shop in 1978. "The shop was damp and it smelt of coal tar from when the chemist used to be there," she said. "There was always boys there, at first three and then more, boys who should have been at school. I know some of them were in trouble but they were always good to me. Gradually we got things going. I remember thinking, I've seen a lot of bad things but this is a good." The 86-year-old's words - on a cold night last October - seemed almost to propel the British Male at 16 on his way up Barking Road. This article was taken from What if . . ? 15 Visions of Change for Britain's Inner Cities, which is published by Short Books today, priced £5.99. All sale proceeds go to the charity Community Links.  What If...available exclusively at Waterstones, and selected independent booksellers.

fields.headline: Laurel and Hardy comedy classics
fields.trailText: As two movies from one of the greatest Anglo-American partnerships of all time are released in a hitherto unseen format, we pay tribute to the comedy duo
fields.body:
One of the great comedy double-acts, Laurel and Hardy's partnership lasted for 19 years. But were it not for a roast dinner, the duo might never have joined forces.

Born Arthur Stanley Jefferson in Cumbria, England in 1890, Stan Laurel was raised amid the rich tradition of British music hall. He went to America aged 20 to be an understudy to the then unknown Charlie Chaplin, and remained in the country, touring in vaudeville and performing occasionally in silent films. In 1924 he began collaborating with producer Hal Roach - as a scriptwriter and 'ideas man'.

Norvell Oliver Hardy (born in Georgia, USA in 1892) was originally destined for a military career, but, fascinated by silent film, he abandoned his studies and opened a movie theatre instead. He later moved to Hollywood and worked as a jobbing actor with Vitagraph, Pathe and Gaumont. By the mid-1920s, he was working as an all-purpose comic at the Hal Roach studio.

In 1926 Hardy had a part in one of Roach's films, but was prevented temporarily from working after burning his arm (while cooking roast lamb). Laurel was persuaded to take on Hardy's part to complete the filming. So successful was the former scriptwriter's acting turn that he was invited to write a part for himself in 45 Minutes From Hollywood, a short two-reeler. Laurel played a lover, alongside a butler played by Hardy.

Within a year of their first joint appearance, Laurel and Hardy were being hailed as Hollywood's new comedy duo.

Laurel and Hardy's knockabout performance of pratfalls, face-pulling, tie-twiddling and general mayhem in films such as Sons of the Desert exploited the mimic and action potential of silent cinema; but it was the nature of their onscreen relationship - Hardy's childish petulance with the dim-witted Laurel, which generated a ready verbal wit, and enabled the duo to sustain their popularity when the talkies arrived.

The introduction of sound also gave rise to Hardy's famously misquoted catchphrase, "that's another nice mess you've gotten us into" which was in fact only uttered 15 times in their 106 films.

Did you know

 The Battle of the Century required the use of over 3,000 custard pies
 Stan Laurel actually had red hair and blue eyes
 Oliver Hardy was a champion golfer
 Laurel and Hardy filmed much of their material in three languages. The cast all read off prompting cards, with few of them actually understanding what they were saying
 Their song, Trail of the Lonesome Pine, from the film Way Out West, reached no. 2 in the UK charts in 1975

For the first time, classic Laurel and Hardy movies are being released on DVD through Vision Video. Be Big and Laughing Gravy (who's Stan's dog) are available as never before seen in the UK - in their French and Spanish, as well as English versions.

webTitle: Rivaldo eclipses Beckham to win world award

fields.headline: Rivaldo eclipses Beckham to win world award
fields.trailText: Barcelona striker Rivaldo was tonight named FIFA's world player of the year.
fields.body:
Barcelona striker Rivaldo was tonight named FIFA's world player of the year.

The Brazilian star, already named European player of the year, polled 543 points compared to 194 for Manchester United midfielder David Beckham and 79 for Fiorentina's Argentinian striker Gabriel Batistuta.

The shortlisted trio were selected last month by 140 national team coaches from around the world and the final choice was revealed at a gala attended by world soccer legends in Brussels.

Zinedine Zidane, winner in 1998, was fourth in this year's awards.

Rivaldo said: "I'm very proud to have won this award, particularly as I was in competition with two other great players which proves the high standard.

"For me this is confirmation of my European footballer of the year award. It's a reward for all the hard work."
