fields.headline: No: 1562 Whitbread Prize
fields.trailText: Age: 29.
fields.body:
Age: 29.

Appearance: Annual, glitzy, televised.

Purpose: "To celebrate and promote the best of contemporary British writing."

Says who? The Whitbread plc website, who do you think?

What does a beer company have to do with literature? Drinking and thinking are not mutually exclusive - look at Faulkner, Scott Fitzgerald, Dylan Thomas.

How is the winner chosen? It's very simple. The winners of the awards for poetry, biography, novel and first novel are selected by separate panels, each comprising three judges. The winner of each award receives £2,000. A panel of nine judges selects the Whitbread Children's Book of the Year, a separate award worth £10,000. This year, unusually, the winner of the Whitbread Children's Book of the Year will also be eligible for the £21,000 Book of the Year prize, which is chosen from the winners of the individual categories.

That's simple? I was being ironic.

Who's in the running - Ted Hughes, I suppose? No, having won it for the past 17 years, this year his posthumous offering, a translation of Alcestis, was knocked out at shortlist stage. That leaves David Cairns's Berlioz (biography), Tim Lott's White City Blue (first novel), Rose Tremain's Music and Silence (novel), and Seamus Heaney's translation of Beowulf (poetry).

And the children's award? Not announced until tomorrow, but J K Rowling's mega-selling Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban is hot favourite.

Who does the final judging? A hand-picked jury of obscure littérateurs and celebrities.

Such as? Jerry Hall, Ann Widdecombe, Imogen Stubbs, Sandi Toksvig.

Which category do they fall into? It would be ungallant of me to say.

Do say: "I'm only here for the Beowulf."

Don't say: "I'm only here for the three-course meal and unlimited booze."

fields.headline: No headline
fields.trailText: Watch television, listen to the radio or even flick through this newspaper and you will see and hear commercials and advertisements that entertain, that are visually stimulating, that are traditionally creative in some way. But the internet? Now that's a different story.
fields.body:
Watch television, listen to the radio or even flick through this newspaper and you will see and hear commercials and advertisements that entertain, that are visually stimulating, that are traditionally creative in some way. But the internet? Now that's a different story.

The average advert on the net consists of a series of glaring, over-busy images, a flashing logo and - nine times out of 10 - a "click here" or "press me" button. That's because research carried out a year ago found that advertisers increased the chances of users accessing their sites by 50% if they specifically instructed them to.

And this, it would appear, is as sophisticated as most net advertising is at the moment. When it comes to the world wide web, you can forget about anything fancy: the new media equivalent of the Guinness "surfer" is hardly going to present itself at regular intervals.

The reasons for this are plentiful and - happily - largely surmountable, suggesting that this ghastly stuff is not going to be with us for ever. "It is in its formative stages," says Chris Ketley, managing director of Zenith Interactive Solutions. "It has only just begun. We are learning all the time about how to influence online customers, and ads are becoming more refined."

Indeed, so new is it that traditional agency creatives are still not really getting involved. It is more often than not left to the technical IT person at a web development company to devise the adverts rather than a properly trained traditional agency creative, hence the, erm, lack of creativity.

Frank Harrison, director of strategic resources at Zenith Media, says: "Net advertising is like radio was 20 years ago. The sort of people who used to be given radio adverts to do were the most junior or the least talented. It's just not sexy, and creatively is still very limited. So people who are IT knowledgeable are the ones producing the ads."

Advertising on the web so far has also just been about getting hits rather than looking pretty - but this is something that is likely to change as the medium matures. Last week, Revolution magazine reported on Sony's first ever web campaign for the launch of its digital camera, Mavica. "Rather than follow the herd with a selection of static banners [the panels across the top of websites] it entered the arena by specially tailoring video banners for the internet," the magazine said.

The adverts show people actually using the Mavica over the line - "save your memories to floppy disc and upload them to the world". The adverts appeared on sites for FHM and Maxim as dotmusic.com and Trinity Mirror's ic24 portal. Actually demonstrating the product? For the web, that's innovative.

Simon King, business development manager of Pixel Park, a full-service new media agency specialis ing in online marketing, explains why this is still the exception rather than the norm: "Net advertising does not have much thought about it, but it is about direct marketing and interaction. It's not about looking at an advert and thinking, 'That's really brilliant.' It's about eliciting a reaction, not looking nice."

The opportunities to advertise on the web consist, mostly, of banners. Aside from these there are buttons, or smaller boxes, usually at the bottom right, that are rather more subtle sponsorship arrangements with the site owner. There are also "landing pages" or "microsites", very small sites dedicated to specific subjects, and even something called virtual marketing, which involves highly targeted emails that exploit people's contacts or distribution lists by a type of electronic chain letter.

Given this complexity, it is perhaps not surprising that campaigns are also currently media-led, not creative-led, driven more by media buyers within agencies and web design companies, rather than creative teams, because they understand all the different opportunities.

Rob Watts, media manager at Pixel Park, says: "Unlike the traditional offline advertising route, where the creative arm of the agency will produce a full campaign to a client's brief and the media arm adapts to place it, here a campaign is media-led. I come up with a strategy then go to the creative team who will do the design."

The creatives will be told, for instance, that they have to devise buttons or banners of a certain dimension and they will simply be asked to come up with the strapline, the corporate colours and the tone of voice. But creatives need not be too nervous. Some basic rules of advertising apply as much to the net as to traditional offline media. As with press adverts, there are three ways to grab the consumer's attention: first with the headline, second via a picture or graphic, and third by means of a familiar logo that the consumer knows and trusts. Once they are dragged in, they can then be targeted with longer copy and a fuller advertising message.

Wisdom is also building regarding advertising creativity on the web. Doubleclick, a company that delivers banner ads to a network of internet sites, has even erected a list of creative dos and don'ts on its website. These involve top tips such as what colours to use (blue, green and yellow work best, apparently); how animation can increase response rates by 25%; how the "click here" button should be located on the right hand side rather than the left; and how using questions in the copy rather than state ments can increase the click-through rate by up to 16%.

The ultimate block to creativity to date, however, has been the technology itself. Restrictions in bandwidth, for instance, have meant that media-rich sites, or sites that contain lots of complicated graphics and visuals - ie, stuff that excites the average agency creative - still take time to download. Given that most users find this frustrating, advertisers are stubbornly sticking to the simple "click me" approach. Harrison says: "An increase in bandwidth will mean video capability, for example. The medium is in rapid transition and what works today won't necessarily work tomorrow. The timescale is extremely compressed. The whole infrastructure and hardware and software are changing all the time."

Despite all this, some advertisers are achieving a degree of inventiveness in their net adverts. Comet recently mounted a campaign that consisted of more than 40 banners, instead of the usual four or five, each of which was specifically tailored to the separate host sites.

IBM, too, last year ran one of the most successful banner campaigns so far, targeted at students who were leaving university. The company bought up a database enabling it to talk to users about the specific university they had been to: such highly personalised messages meant that 50% of those who saw the site clicked on it.

Some banners are also dropping the click-through mechanism altogether and incorporating more information in themselves, so the user does not have to leave the host site and go meandering off into cyberspace. Interflora's banners, meanwhile, include a device for ordering and addressing flowers without users having to visit their site at all.

Whether creativity improves or not, advertising on the internet is obviously here to stay. Recent studies have suggested that consumers are becoming increasingly punch-drunk by offline advertising and so compa nies are turning more to the web as a medium. Amazon.com also found at the end of last year that people admit they are highly influenced by online ads - more so, even, than traditional advertising.

In the light of this almost guaranteed, even limitless, expansion of the net as a medium, it would be good to think the advertising will get a little prettier. It can't get much worse.

fields.headline: How clever is this?
fields.standfirst: Barnardo's shocking new campaign is not the first to court controversy - but it might be the last. As doubts grow about the effectiveness of such tactics,  is the advertising industry is turning shy?
fields.trailText: The first blink-and-you-won't-miss-it shock advert of the year caught the public's attention as soon as it was launched on Friday. Initially intended to run in the Saturday and Sunday supplements of most broadsheet newspapers, it caused such a fuss within three hours of its appearance that the charity who commissioned it - Barnardo's - began trying to persuade politicians such as Mo Mowlam to offer verbal support.
fields.body:
The first blink-and-you-won't-miss-it shock advert of the year caught the public's attention as soon as it was launched on Friday. Initially intended to run in the Saturday and Sunday supplements of most broadsheet newspapers, it caused such a fuss within three hours of its appearance that the charity who commissioned it - Barnardo's - began trying to persuade politicians such as Mo Mowlam to offer verbal support.

It's an advert based on the sort of solid truth that flashes through your mind every time you hand over 50p to a beggar - that everyone is born an innocent baby, and what is it that goes so wrong as to put that little ball of trust and love out on the Strand at midnight?

Indeed, you've probably seen earlier adverts in the campaign already. One shows a three-year-old child about to jump off a multi-storey car park. Another shows a small boy slumped on the street under a dingy bridge. Yet another features a little girl in a sleeping bag in a rain-soaked high street. All carry wording similar to that in the latest ad: "Battered as a child, it was always possible that John would turn to drugs. With Barnardo's help, child abuse need not lead to an empty future. Although we no longer run orphanages, we continue to help thousands of children and their families."

Of course, the baby wasn't hurt in making of the advert. His face was a composite of him sitting in a studio and his mouth wrestling with a huge bar of chocolate. The child's image was superimposed on the grimy surroundings. It was all very clever. Should we be at all bothered? It is surely a laudable aim for a worthwhile charity to use state-of-the-art advertising practice at one of Britain's leading agencies - Levi's agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty - to raise funds to help children.

It's not as if Barnardo's is the first charity to be attacked for its advertising. In November 1998 the RSPCA launched a hard-hitting anti-fox hunting campaign showing a fox having its bowels ripped out by a pack of dogs under the line: "Whatever else you think about foxes, you have to admire their guts."

Other RSPCA campaigns have featured a harrowing photograph of a dog with its jaw hanging loose, its mouth half open in a grimace of pain and its left eye hanging out of its socket; a dead horse hanging from a meathook; and a pile of dead dogs.

In October 1995, environmental pressure groups and charities, including Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth and the International Fund for Animal Welfare, were criticised by the Advertising Standards Authority for making overzealous and exaggerated claims. In September 1998, the Commission for Racial Equality ran three overtly racist ads, building up to the catchline: "What was worse? This ad, or your failure to complain?" The organisation suffered weeks of flak from politicians and newspapers alike.

The problem Barnardo's faces is that the advertising industry is becoming increasingly divided over the use of such powerful images. Last week David Abbott, the founder of the UK's largest advertising agency, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, attacked the Advertiser of the Year award to French Connection UK for its fcuk campaign.

"Fcuking great idea to put fcuking four-letter words on fcuking big posters where every fcuking eight-year-old can see them," he wrote, in a letter to Campaign, the magazine that sponsors the awards. "What a fcuking cool way to get up the noses of those fcuking parent and teacher tossers who are trying to bring their kids up as fcuking goody-goodies. That's the way to sell a youth brand, though haven't I seen it fcuking before on the lav walls?"

Abbott has become something of a champion of gentler publicity and has spoken out against shock advertising on a number of occasions. Gradually, elements of the industry are coming round to his point of view, many of them because they fear a Labour government could bring in legal rules to an industry that is currently self-regulated.

It is in this climate that the Committee for Advertising Practice - which writes the rules that the Advertising Standards Authority enforces - moved extremely fast on Friday morning by ruling that the Barnardo's advert was likely to cause offence. The CAP issued an ad alert, advising the media not to carry it.

As the campaign was booked into many Saturday and Sunday supplements, most of the magazines had gone to press before the warning was issued. The agency had booked the advert into the Guardian, the Observer, the Independent, the Independent on Sunday and the Daily Telegraph. The Mail had previously refused the advert but agreed to carry an earlier version.

Barnardo's fought the ruling, arguing that the CAP was wrong to invoke two clauses on offence and sensitivity. It said that other CAP clauses suggested that, since the charity's motives were pure, the environment for the advert was mature and the advert was unlikely to encourage three-month-old babies to use heroin, the ban was unnecessary.

"This execution has been carefully planned and considered," says Andrew Nebel, Barnardo's director of marketing and communications. "We have invested over a year in this campaign, during which time it was researched, and at no time did our findings give us cause for concern that our audience found it unduly shocking or distressing."

Nonetheless, one of the reasons Barnardo's has turned to this form of advertising is that it needs to draw itself to our attention. After all, in charity terms it's in something of a brand graveyard. Apart from the old donors who have been donating to Barnardo's on the understanding that it runs those children's homes where everyone gets long country rambles and healthy breakfasts, few members of the British public seem to think the charity has any function now that Queen Victoria is dead.

"We're a well-known charity," explains Nebel. "We've been around for 130 years, but if you ask people what we do they still think we run orphanages, something we've been disengaging from since the 60s. We now work in the community to help children stay with their family and friends and hopefully help them meet the threats which could end up putting them on the streets or turning them to drugs when they are older. Whenever you see a homeless person and sniff that it's all their own fault, it's worth remembering that it was probably something in their childhood that pushed them into it."

But is an image of a baby with a syringe really appropriate for a high-profile rebranding strategy? Isn't there a danger that cash-laden punters will be so turned off by the horror of the message that they will turn from the charity in disgust, withholding any potential payment?

"If you accepted that argument you would only cater to the lowest common sensitivity," says John O'Keeffe, creative director at Bartle Bogle Hegarty. "I don't think anyone would be served by advertising that only exists within parameters set down by Mary Whitehouse. When I used to work on the NSPCC account, I'd actually see the police surgeons' log books and, let me assure you, the truth is so much worse than anything you or I could imagine. We do shield people from the worst of it, but I don't think the population should be shielded from everything bad that happens in the world."

But what about the oldest problem in advertising? That people will remember the shocking image of baby and needle but forget who used it and what they used it for? After all, monster.co.uk is using images of children to flog job adverts on the internet. Won't the messenger be drowned by the message?

"Our work is a medium-term job," O'Keeffe says. "It takes time but when people hear 'Vorsprung durch Technik' they don't think of Ford. And this sort of advertising works. Again when I worked on the NSPCC, we ran what were considered shocking ads, but we managed to raise a lot of money through those ads which the NSPCC put to very good use. I think the results will bear this campaign out."

Finally, of course, there are those that think this sort of charity activity has gone way too far and yearn for a quieter and more respectful age. What, for example, would Dr Barnardo think? Well, considering that the combative Dr Barnardo set up one of the UK's first photographic studios in order to develop his pictures of starving, homeless children - which he shoved in middle-class faces as part of his shock-tactic fund raising - one imagines the good doctor would approve wholeheartedly.
fields.bodyText: The first blink-and-you-won't-miss-it shock advert of the year caught the public's attention as soon as it was launched on Friday. Initially intended to run in the Saturday and Sunday supplements of most broadsheet newspapers, it caused such a fuss within three hours of its appearance that the charity who commissioned it - Barnardo's - began trying to persuade politicians such as Mo Mowlam to offer verbal support. It's an advert based on the sort of solid truth that flashes through your mind every time you hand over 50p to a beggar - that everyone is born an innocent baby, and what is it that goes so wrong as to put that little ball of trust and love out on the Strand at midnight? Indeed, you've probably seen earlier adverts in the campaign already. One shows a three-year-old child about to jump off a multi-storey car park. Another shows a small boy slumped on the street under a dingy bridge. Yet another features a little girl in a sleeping bag in a rain-soaked high street. All carry wording similar to that in the latest ad: "Battered as a child, it was always possible that John would turn to drugs. With Barnardo's help, child abuse need not lead to an empty future. Although we no longer run orphanages, we continue to help thousands of children and their families." Of course, the baby wasn't hurt in making of the advert. His face was a composite of him sitting in a studio and his mouth wrestling with a huge bar of chocolate. The child's image was superimposed on the grimy surroundings. It was all very clever. Should we be at all bothered? It is surely a laudable aim for a worthwhile charity to use state-of-the-art advertising practice at one of Britain's leading agencies - Levi's agency Bartle Bogle Hegarty - to raise funds to help children. It's not as if Barnardo's is the first charity to be attacked for its advertising. In November 1998 the RSPCA launched a hard-hitting anti-fox hunting campaign showing a fox having its bowels ripped out by a pack of dogs under the line: "Whatever else you think about foxes, you have to admire their guts." Other RSPCA campaigns have featured a harrowing photograph of a dog with its jaw hanging loose, its mouth half open in a grimace of pain and its left eye hanging out of its socket; a dead horse hanging from a meathook; and a pile of dead dogs. In October 1995, environmental pressure groups and charities, including Greenpeace, Friends of the Earth and the International Fund for Animal Welfare, were criticised by the Advertising Standards Authority for making overzealous and exaggerated claims. In September 1998, the Commission for Racial Equality ran three overtly racist ads, building up to the catchline: "What was worse? This ad, or your failure to complain?" The organisation suffered weeks of flak from politicians and newspapers alike. The problem Barnardo's faces is that the advertising industry is becoming increasingly divided over the use of such powerful images. Last week David Abbott, the founder of the UK's largest advertising agency, Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO, attacked the Advertiser of the Year award to French Connection UK for its fcuk campaign. "Fcuking great idea to put fcuking four-letter words on fcuking big posters where every fcuking eight-year-old can see them," he wrote, in a letter to Campaign, the magazine that sponsors the awards. "What a fcuking cool way to get up the noses of those fcuking parent and teacher tossers who are trying to bring their kids up as fcuking goody-goodies. That's the way to sell a youth brand, though haven't I seen it fcuking before on the lav walls?" Abbott has become something of a champion of gentler publicity and has spoken out against shock advertising on a number of occasions. Gradually, elements of the industry are coming round to his point of view, many of them because they fear a Labour government could bring in legal rules to an industry that is currently self-regulated. It is in this climate that the Committee for Advertising Practice - which writes the rules that the Advertising Standards Authority enforces - moved extremely fast on Friday morning by ruling that the Barnardo's advert was likely to cause offence. The CAP issued an ad alert, advising the media not to carry it. As the campaign was booked into many Saturday and Sunday supplements, most of the magazines had gone to press before the warning was issued. The agency had booked the advert into the Guardian, the Observer, the Independent, the Independent on Sunday and the Daily Telegraph. The Mail had previously refused the advert but agreed to carry an earlier version. Barnardo's fought the ruling, arguing that the CAP was wrong to invoke two clauses on offence and sensitivity. It said that other CAP clauses suggested that, since the charity's motives were pure, the environment for the advert was mature and the advert was unlikely to encourage three-month-old babies to use heroin, the ban was unnecessary. "This execution has been carefully planned and considered," says Andrew Nebel, Barnardo's director of marketing and communications. "We have invested over a year in this campaign, during which time it was researched, and at no time did our findings give us cause for concern that our audience found it unduly shocking or distressing." Nonetheless, one of the reasons Barnardo's has turned to this form of advertising is that it needs to draw itself to our attention. After all, in charity terms it's in something of a brand graveyard. Apart from the old donors who have been donating to Barnardo's on the understanding that it runs those children's homes where everyone gets long country rambles and healthy breakfasts, few members of the British public seem to think the charity has any function now that Queen Victoria is dead. "We're a well-known charity," explains Nebel. "We've been around for 130 years, but if you ask people what we do they still think we run orphanages, something we've been disengaging from since the 60s. We now work in the community to help children stay with their family and friends and hopefully help them meet the threats which could end up putting them on the streets or turning them to drugs when they are older. But is an image of a baby with a syringe really appropriate for a high-profile rebranding strategy? fields.headline: National inquirer
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report

As Newsnight celebrates 20 years of news analysis, Jeremy Paxman, its most feared front man, talks about John Birt, BBC managers and the art of spin (oh yes, and that Mandelson revelation)
fields.trailText: Some weeks ago Jeremy Paxman received a letter. "Dear Mr Paxman," the letter started, politely. "I am writing an article which I hope to have published in Arses and their Reasons. I was wondering if you could help me out by replying to the following questions." It continued: "1) Why are you such an arse? 2) Have you always been an arse? 3) What would you say the qualities are of being an arse? 4) Do you look up to any famous arses for inspiration?"
fields.body:
Some weeks ago Jeremy Paxman received a letter. "Dear Mr Paxman," the letter started, politely. "I am writing an article which I hope to have published in Arses and their Reasons. I was wondering if you could help me out by replying to the following questions." It continued: "1) Why are you such an arse? 2) Have you always been an arse? 3) What would you say the qualities are of being an arse? 4) Do you look up to any famous arses for inspiration?"

Paxman will reveal the letter to the world next week, at the beginning of the BBC's celebration of the most important news programme on television. Newsnight is 20 years old and Paxman is fronting the programme dedicated to its impact. He reads the letter, laughs and puts it to one side. A lot of people hate Jeremy Paxman. A lot of them write to him to tell him so. You've got to laugh, haven't you?

Paxman sits in his small, airless office to the side of the main Newsnight newsroom. Today he is pre-occupied with the changes to the RUC being announced by Peter Mandelson. He watches the monitor transmitting prime minister's questions, grumping and raising his eyebrows as one political platitude is followed by another. "That's crap," he says at one point and it's not clear whether he's talking about the PM or some other issue burning a hole in his intellect. Either way, Tony Blair is probably well aware that Paxman thinks a lot of things are crap.

Newsnight has been called many things. An important part of the democratic process (Will Hutton); a traitor in our midst (the Sun); dangerous (Margaret Thatcher); increasingly irrelevant (Alastair Campbell). Newsnight made Paxman a household name, from attacks for "sneering interviews" (Sir John Birt) to that Michael Howard encounter.

From its start in 1980, Newsnight also made itself a household name - from the Falklands to Arthur Scargill tripping up Peter Snow, from Vincent Hanna at the Darlington by-election to the sandpit of the Gulf war, from the meltdown of the Tories to New Labour's control machine.

Cajoling, intimidating, aggressive, revealing, persistent. Paxman, Kirsty Wark and Jeremy Vine - the unholy triumvirate, the interviewers from hell. Howard says it sacrifices light for a lot of heat; Sin Kevill, the present editor, admits it was once all too "macho and Oxbridge". But it's still there, a needle in the thigh of the establishment.

Unsurprisingly, there are two establishment figures who won't be featuring in the anniversary programme. Outgoing BBC director general John Birt was asked to appear, took an age to reply, couldn't work out a time and "sort of drifted out of the mix", according to one source. Birt is known not to like Newsnight's interrogatory style, preferring the "let people explain" culture of interviews. The fact that he isn't in the programme, and the new director general, Greg Dyke, is, says volumes for the relationship between Birt and the BBC's top news programme.

"Will I be glad to see the back of John Birt?" Paxman says. "That is rather a 'When did you stop beating your wife?' type of question. I've met the guy a few times; I don't think he's my greatest fan." And Paxman isn't Birt's either because Paxman isn't a man who likes structures and Birtist strategy meetings and focus group management.

"I firmly believe this organisation only has any raison d' etre if it lives on ideas," Paxman says. "It doesn't live on structures, or editorial chains of command. It lives on ideas, and clever, talented people who ought to be given their head. Frankly, I can't see any other justification for the licence fee apart from creating an environment where people can create."

The other notable absence from the programme is the clip that put Newsnight into the headlines for weeks in October 1998. Times columnist Matthew Parris was being interviewed by Paxman about the resignation of Ron Davies, the former Welsh secretary, who indulged in a "moment of madness" on Clapham Common. Parris suddenly said that there were members of the cabinet who were gay and, when asked by Paxman, yes, one of them was Peter Mandelson.

Paxman quickly and inelegantly changed the subject, probably sensing that this was going to cause an almighty stink. And it did. All sorts of allegations flew around: that Paxman and Parris had cooked up the wheeze to "out" Mandelson; that Paxman's note of apology to Mandelson was rebuffed; that the BBC handled it as well as an elephant playing baseball.

The BBC high command sent out a memo following the incident warning editors and presenters not to mention it. This caused another row. "I thought the BBC dealt with it ludicrously," Paxman says. "It revealed the flat-footed and heavy-handed way that bureaucracies have, it made the whole issue that much bigger than it actually would have been."

Many criticised Paxman for writing to Mandelson - something which seemed to smack of special treatment for the former secretary of state for trade and industry. "I don't socialise with politicians but Mandelson is one of the few people that I do bump into socially because we have mutual friends. I did feel that it was unfortunate. What the letter said was that I took the view that people's private lives are their own affair unless they make it a public issue and I hope that he accepted that." And Mandelson's reportedly prickly response? "You would have to ask him about that."

The fact that the clip has been omitted has led some to the obvious conclusion: censorship. "I can't see any reason why it shouldn't [be in the programme]," Paxman says. "I don't think it was our greatest hour and it was rather a mistake. I think there is a good argument for putting it in. But in the 20 years there are loads of things that are much more dramatic. Actually-" He pauses, a long Paxman pause that leaves you wondering if he's forgotten you're there. "I don't think it should be in. By comparison with things like the spat over the Falklands or the Gulf or the Michael Howard interview, those things strike me as things that Newsnight did as opposed to that particular moment."

Senior staff on Newsnight considered the Mandelson clip but knew it would entail a huge fight with the dead hand of BBC bureaucracy. "It just wasn't something it was worth fighting for," said a source. "There was so much other ground to cover."

Alastair Campbell once said that Newsnight was becoming increasingly irrelevant because of its "dwindling" audience. "That's balls," is Paxman's succinct reply. Indeed. Newsnight has had a good year. Viewing figures are up 8% to 1.1m as the public searches out more serious analysis in a world of increasing consumer news.

Kevill, who oversaw the programme's relaunch last January, says it now has a broader, more accessible agenda - from the documentary-style films from a Salford housing estate to arts and culture - but not at the expense of depth. "I'm quite traditional," she says. "I prefer three items in the programme rather than four. It gives more time." The scrapping of News at Ten has also been a factor.

One part of the "accessibility" package was the surprising announcement that Nicky Campbell, former host of Wheel of Fortune and Radio 5 presenter, was to join the team. Was Paxman surprised when he heard the announcement last August? "No." Why not? "Because someone had phoned me to tell me about it." He pauses. He knows he's not answering the question. Was he surprised? "Mind your own business." There is another long pause. "I think he is very good on radio."

There is the rub. Many Newsnight staff were unhappy at what they saw as the overpromotion of Campbell's role when it was revealed in Media Guardian last year. Campbell's press people insisted it was a presenting role; BBC sources said it would be a few outside broadcasts. Whatever the agreement, it looks like it's coming to an end. Campbell is deemed not to have fitted in with the tough, journalist-led ethic of the programme. Senior staff say he'll probably do a couple more packages before saying farewell.

Paxman has the weary air of a man who works long and hard in an organisation famed for its inability to use one manager where eight could do the job less effectively. The rest of the Newsnight team suffer the same. Last week the BBC announced it was ridding itself of the nine "super-editors" it had put in place less than two years earlier to "increase communication" between television and radio news - another step along the dreaded route of bi-media. Paxman hated the idea of "super-editors" then, and sees the U-turn as embarrassing but necessary.

"Another inspired decision. This whole thing has been built, this great news centre palace." He waves his hands towards the new news and current affairs floor outside his office. "The World Tonight [Radio 4] sits over there, we sit over here and there is not a great deal of cross- fertilisation. The super-editors thing was a stupid idea which has been recognised as a stupid idea. It is unfortunate that it took two years for that to happen.

"I still believe that this is a fantastic organisation if you treat it like a publisher. But if you decide to spend your time concerned with the politics of it, that is a recipe for self-destruction."

But not concerning yourself with the politics of the BBC is like a golfer not concerning herself with that big bunker just before the 18th green. It's just there, always getting in the way. Take the Scottish and Welsh opt-outs from the main Newsnight programme at 11pm.

"It's a problem," Paxman, who once called it a "damn fool idea", admits. "Instead of dealing with a 45-minute canvas what you have is a 30-minute programme plus a 10- or 15-minute appendix. It is not the case that this merely affects viewers in Scotland, who are deprived of the last 15 minutes of the programme. It affects the whole make-up of the programme.

"The thing was cooked up as a bureaucratic way of buying off the demand for a Scottish six o'clock news, and the sooner it's dead and buried, the better."

Does Paxman ever think that he should change his style to something more amenable to the caring, sharing new millennium? Of course he doesn't. "Any self-respecting journalist must be concerned to define for themselves what the important issue is and then to pursue it and not blindly to follow some line laid down by the vested interest in question," he says. "I wouldn't want to work for a programme that didn't have that policy."

The programme's role as the nagger of the nation's conscience is becoming all the more important as viewers and listeners are increasingly overwhelmed by rolling news which, of necessity, lacks the one thing Newsnight has - context. "There is a lack of analysis and generally finding out if people are telling the truth," Paxman says. "Things rush on [to television] at a fantastic speed, get recycled, pushed out and not thought about again. The fight is about controlling what goes through that sausage machine, which is what the spin doctors are about."

There have been discussions about a regular, highbrow interview programme on BBC2 for Paxman in the style of his head-to-head with Bill Gates. Broadcast magazine reported last week that he has drawn up a wish list of people he would like to interview - Hillary Clinton, Rupert Murdoch, Steven Spielberg. But that doesn't mean he's retiring.

"Assuredly someone will come along at some stage and say, 'Let's get rid of this bloke,'" he says. "'Let's get someone who's younger, older, different sex, different race.' I don't suppose that one will go on for ever.

"I love it. Even on days when it is very thin, when you are trying to make bricks without straw, it is tremendous fun. The thought that you're being paid to do what's not really a proper job is fantastic. I've no plans to shuffle off this mortal coil yet." Happy birthday, Newsnight.

History in the making

Falklands war (1982)

Peter Snow caused a storm of protest for prefacing his report with the statement that it was the British government's version rather than simply the truth.

 "There are traitors in our midst. What is it but treason to talk on TV, as Peter Snow talks, questioning whether the government's version of the sea battles was to be believed?" - The Sun

 "We were all surprised that . . . laying out the facts for people to make up their own minds, should be misconstrued as something that was essentially traitorous." - Tony Hall, BBC News chief executive and ex-Newsnight producer

Darlington by-election (1983)

Vincent Hanna launched the political sketch on TV by tailing SDP candidate Tony Cook. Labour won by a landslide, much of it put down to Hanna's merciless treatment of Cook.

 "I was always aware of Vincent hovering. He was either participating by trying to get an interview or he was just around. And I felt at one stage that he was actually trying to intimidate me." -Tony Cook

Arthur Scargill interview (1984)

Arthur Scargill asks Peter Snow if he has read the full text of a speech he made in Moscow. Snow says yes, but under questioning later in the interview admits he hasn't.

 "It was a major personal disaster. It was disgraceful. I didn't do my homework." - Peter Snow

Michael Howard interview (1997)

Jeremy Paxman asks Michael Howard the same question 14 times over the Derek Lewis prison affair. Paxman says he persevered because his producer said the next tape wasn't ready.

MH: I was entitled to express my views. I was entitled to be consulted.

JP: Did you threaten to overrule him?

MH: I was not entitled to instruct Derek Lewis and I did not instruct him. And the truth of it is . . . JP: Did you threaten to overrule him?

MH: And the truth of the matter is Mr Marriott was not suspended. I did not . . .

JP: Did you threaten to overrule him?

MH: I did not overrule Derek Lewis.

JP: Did you threaten to overrule him?

MH: I took advice on what I could and could not do . . .

JP: Did you threaten to overrule him, Mr Howard?

MH: . . . and I acted scrupulously in accordance with that.

 "I realised it hadn't been the best interview I'd ever given, but it's not entirely uncommon for a politician not to answer a question directly. It's pretty uncommon for them to be asked the same question." - Michael Howard
Carolyne Ellis

Newsnight at 20 is on BBC2 at 5.50pm on Saturday January 29

"I wouldn't want to work for a programme that didn't have that policy." The programme's role as the nagger of the nation's conscience is becoming all the more important as viewers and listeners are increasingly overwhelmed by rolling news which, of necessity, lacks the one thing Newsnight has - context. "There is a lack of analysis and generally finding out if people are telling the truth," Paxman says. "Things rush on [to television] at a fantastic speed, get recycled, pushed out and not thought about again. The fight is about controlling what goes through that sausage machine, which is what the spin doctors are about." "Assuredly someone will come along at some stage and say, 'Let's get rid of this bloke,'" he says. "'Let's get someone who's younger, older, different sex, different race.' fields.headline: Under the influence
fields.standfirst: The White House has been paying TV networks to insert anti-drug messages into their shows. A worthy crusade or a blatant attempt at censorship?
fields.trailText: The soldiers in the war on drugs are never at rest. So it was surprising, but not shocking, when it recently came to light that White House anti-drug officials had quietly opened a new media front in their efforts to steer the nation's youth away from temptation.
fields.body:
The soldiers in the war on drugs are never at rest. So it was surprising, but not shocking, when it recently came to light that White House anti-drug officials had quietly opened a new media front in their efforts to steer the nation's youth away from temptation.

In exchange for a reduction in the number of public service announcements they must broadcast by law, the US TV networks allowed the White House Office of National Drug Control Policy (ONDCP) to review the scripts and watch advance screenings of shows such as ER and Beverly Hills 90210. The drugs body then suggested ways that characters or plots could be changed, inserting or reinforcing an anti-drug message.

Under the scheme, which has been running with little public comment since 1997, Barry McCaffrey, President Clinton's drug tsar, allotted advertising points for TV shows that conveyed the desired message - a scene in which a teenage actress rejects a joint, for example, or depicting groups of stoned teenagers as losers. These points, or credits, can be cashed in, allowing the networks to sell advertising time at commercial rates that it would otherwise be obliged to fill with the descendants of Nancy Reagan's "Just Say No" media blitz.

News of the scheme, which was revealed by the online magazine Salon.com two weeks ago, created a predictable uproar. Media watchdogs called the deal a form of censorship, and warned that in creating financial incentives for the networks to air covert anti-drug messages the government was setting a bad precedent.

"In allowing government to shape or even be consulted on content in return for financial rewards, the networks are crossing a dangerous line they should not cross," boomed a New York Times editorial. "On the far side of that line lies the possibility of censorship and state-sponsored propaganda."

Others say the deal amounted to a contravention of the first amendment, guaranteeing the right to freedom of speech. "The broadcasters scream about the first amendment until McCaffrey opens his chequebook," says Andrew Jay Schwartzman, president of public interest law firm Media Access Project.

The former chief counsel of the Federal Communications Commission, Robert Corn-Revere, called the campaign "pretty insidious. Government surreptitiously planting anti-drug messages using the power of the purse raises red flags. Why is there no disclosure to the American public?"

The outcry moved President Clinton to defend the arrangement. "I don't think there was any attempt to try to undermine the content or the independence or the integrity of the networks and the programming," he told reporters. "If the networks were willing to put a good anti-drug message in heavily watched programmes, particularly by the most vulnerable young people, that would be a good thing."

The networks, while supporting the war on drugs, denied that they had ever changed a programme at the behest of the White House. Instead, they confirmed that they consulted government officials on how to portray the issue of drugs abuse and supplied scripts and tapes of programmes so the officials could determine if the shows counted toward a credit. "At no time has the independence or creative integrity of our programming been compromised," said a CBS spokesman, echoing similar statements from ABC, NBC, Fox and Warner Bros.

The White House said that not only had the arrangement been made public, it had in fact only benefited the networks to the tune of £16m over 18 months.

"It's been open, public, and a wonderful thing because we're very proud that last year juvenile drug use declined by 13%. What we are doing is working," said a spokesman for the the agency.

Whatever the resistance to the principle of government having any hand in modelling the content of the media, an anti-drug message is not one that can be said to be very controversial. The networks are hardly purveyors of youth-corrupting messages anyway - unless you count the transmission of mind-numbing mediocrity - in part to sustain advertising from big companies that would shy away from any kind of controversial message.

And the networks like to be seen as socially conscientious. "We enjoy doing something that is pro-socially responsible, especially since we reach a younger audience," says Jamie Kellner, chief executive of Warner Bros. "I think people should applaud the government for being clever."

A recently released report on 168 prime-time television episodes broadcast over three months in 1998 showed that illegal drugs were seen being taken in only 3 % of the episodes viewed, while tobacco was used in 19% and alcohol in 71%.

The report, on the influence of television on teen substance abuse, found that only three major characters were seen using illicit drugs. A male adult and a male teenager smoked marijuana, while a female teen was seen taking a drink laced with the date rape drug. "These findings make it clear that the broadcast television industry is sending our kids the right messages about drug abuse," concluded McCaffrey.

The idea of exchanging content for advertising credits evolved from a congressional mandate that for every dollar of anti-drug advertising purchased by the government from a network, the network was required to donate another dollar's worth of advertising time.

Initially, the networks welcomed the billion dollar advertising deal but soon cooled to the idea of selling time at half-price as the boom in dot.com advertising kicked in. The White House then came up with the idea of releasing networks from their obligations in exchange for positive anti-drug messages within their shows.

The calculations worked according to a set numerical formula under which the drug-policy office assigned financial value to each show's anti-drug message. If the office decided that a half-hour pushed an endorsed anti-drug theme sufficiently , it got valued at three units, with each unit equalling the cost of one 30-second ad on that show.

For instance, a two-episode Beverly Hills 90210 story involving a character's downward spiral into addiction exempted Fox from broadcasting anti-drug commercials during ad time worth around £300,000. Several episodes of ER with anti-drug subplots redeemed £900,000 in ad time for NBC to be able to sell elsewhere. ABC recouped approximately £300,000 with episodes of Home Improvement.

But in the wake of continuing controversy, ABC announced it would stop trying to collect government credits for inserting anti-drug messages. And in an effort to "eliminate any misunderstandings and prevent any inference of federal intrusion in the creative process" the drug policy office said it will no longer review programme episodes for credits until after they have been broadcast.

webTitle: Prescott plans to abolish council housing

fields.headline: Prescott plans to abolish council housing
fields.standfirst:
With a £22bn repairs backlog, and thousands of abandoned properties, local authorities are unable to provide low-cost housing, ministers say

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Radical plans for town halls to hive-off all council housing within 10 years to non-profit making companies are being drawn up by officials in John Prescott's department of the environment, transport and the regions.
fields.body:
Radical plans for town halls to hive-off all council housing within 10 years to non-profit making companies are being drawn up by officials in John Prescott's department of the environment, transport and the regions.

Faced with a repairs backlog of about £22bn, and thousands of abandoned homes on difficult-to-let estates, councils are increasingly incapable of providing low-cost social housing, ministers believe. They are preparing to launch what insiders call a "big bang" under which authorities will be persuaded - and eventually forced - to offload the remaining 3.2m council homes by 2010.

Internal policy papers in the department, which monitors and funds local government, show that hiving-off council housing - what critics have labelled back-door privatisation - has gained a new urgency with the treasury and Downing Street anxious to find new ways of providing affordable homes. Ministers are concerned that poorly maintained and derelict housing is further tarnishing Labour's already battered image in big cities and the party's heartlands - where the Liberal Democrats are now seriously challenging Labour.

Much of the impetus for the drive will come from a new inspection regime in the environment department, in which under-performing councils with poor housing management will be told to put services out to competition.

They will be threatened with spending cuts if they refuse.

So far only 110, mainly smaller, authorities have transferred 360,000 houses all told to non-profit making companies and housing associations, which are funded by the government's housing corporation.

But 23 councils have said they plan to transfer a total of 270,000 homes.

Significantly, this includes Birmingham, England's largest council landlord, with 90,000 houses and flats. The council has a multi-billion pound repairs backlog. Under current progress, however, it will take almost 20 years to transfer all housing stock to new companies and housing associations.

One adviser said: "Ministers feel this is far too long a time-frame and that much more pressure is needed to force the pace.

"Councils increasingly will be charged with setting housing standards in their areas, but not owning and controlling houses."

With the condition of council housing worsening by the day, authorities are unable to provide sufficient funds for modernisation. Under treasury rules, they are prevented from using assets, or future income from rents, as security to borrow on the open market. Housing associations, or new social companies, face no such restrictions.

Problems have intensified since the 1980s when 1.6m homes, mainly better properties, were sold to tenants under the Conservative government's right-to-buy policy - raising £7bn in the biggest privatisation of all. This has left councils with old, and poorly maintained homes on "sink" estates, which are proving increasingly difficult to let. While some might have to be abandoned, ministers believe that redevelopment - tied to a new image for council housing - could turn others round.

That task will now fall on new companies and housing associations. The magazine Inside Housing says transferring ownership will "kill a number of birds with one stone".

"The government will not have to worry about the £22bn albatross for putting housing right currently hanging around the taxpayer's neck."

The only problem is that, under present guidelines, tenants have to approve hiving-off their homes in special transfer ballots, usually organised by the Electoral Reform Society.

About one in 10 transfers is currently rejected.

In Cambridge last year, for instance, 67% of the city's council tenants rejected the transfer option on a 72% turnout.

fields.headline: Private defective
fields.standfirst: Novelist Jonathan Lethem is riding high in the US - thanks to a sleuth whose Tourette's syndrome turns hard-boiled narrative into gobbledegook.  Brian Logan reports
fields.trailText: Novelist Jonathan Lethem is riding high in the US - thanks to a sleuth whose Tourette's syndrome turns hard-boiled narrative into gobbledegook. Brian Logan reports
fields.body:
Motherless Brooklyn is a detective novel with a difference. Sleuthing in a mysterious Zen temple, private eye Lionel Essrog shatters the meditative calm by yelling, "Ziggedy zendoodah!" Coolly terminating a cliff-top stand-off with his dead boss's duplicitous widow, Lionel throws his gun out to sea - then slings her gun, his pager, a cellphone and his right shoe after it. As one American reviewer remarked, "rituals like this tend to ruffle a detective's Bogart impression".

Lionel, you see, has Tourette's syndrome. It compels him to tap people's shoulders, to number his actions, to mimic others' movements - and it enslaves him to obsessive wordplay (his name becomes Unreliable Chessgrub, or Ironic Pissclam) and volcanic eruptions of speech. "I'm an airbag in a dashboard," he says, "packed up layer upon layer in readiness to explode, expand all over you, fill up every available space."

Author Jonathan Lethem - a former painter, student contemporary of Bret Easton Ellis, and writer of four acclaimed novels in the past five years - has created, from what sounds like a ludicrous gimmick, one of fiction's most memorable narrators. Through Lionel - nickname Freakshow - he explores the relationship between what makes us tic and what makes us tick. "I came across Tourette's the way anyone might," says the 35-year-old Lethem, "by reading about it in Oliver Sacks. The germ of inspiration, that really freeing sense that this was an image of human life that I could inhabit, turn inside out and make my own, was right there in Sacks's essay."

Lethem's interest in the condition was based not only on a psychological fascination - "it hovered in my mind as a metaphor for that aspect of human existence that is helpless, compulsive, twitchy" - but on a keen sense of its literary potential. "I've always had an element of Joycean wordplay in my books, some characters who were in charge of the babbling or frothing at the mouth. I began to wonder what I was getting at, and what I was avoiding by keeping that on such a tight rein. Tourette's gave me the opportunity to put the wordplay and the free association front and centre."

The results are playfully poetic. It's as if Benjy from Faulkner's The Sound and the Fury had escaped on to the pages of Raymond Chandler. "So you'd describe yourself as a friend of the deceased?" a cop asks our hero. "Trend the decreased!" Lionel replies. "Mend the retreats!" Unfazed, the cop insists on an alibi. "Alibi hullabaloo gullible bellyflop smellafish," Lionel responds, at which point, were I the questioner, I'd call it a day.

In Lethem's native US, Motherless Brooklyn has been a startling success. Alone among writers, Lethem appeared on Newsweek's list of "100 Americans for the next century", which he dryly comments was "flattering to the point of ludicrous". The novel is being developed for Hollywood by Fight Club star Edward Norton. Hunky screen star plays neurological disorder? Expect Oscars.

It's no surprise that Tinseltown beckons. Lethem's reputation in the US is as a writer who combines and reanimates genres. Having spent his formative years at work in a second-hand bookshop, he is fiction's answer to Quentin Tarantino. He may insist that his genre-mashing is an increasingly incidental by-product of the "omnivorous cross-genre enthusiasm in my reading", but Motherless Brooklyn slots neatly into an oeuvre that already includes Girl in Landscape (western meets dystopia) and Gun, With Occasional Music (detective fiction meets sci-fi).

Lethem found it natural to place his obsessively twitchy protagonist within a crime-novel plot. "The manic pace of the detective investigation was what I needed to set off that digressive inertia of the Tourettic consciousness," he says. The effect is gleefully absurd, even if the formulaic gumshoe plot pales next to the twinkle-toed narrative footwork.

"On one level," Lethem says, "the book hinges on the joke of replacing the hard-boiled narrator - who's supposed to be this Bogart figure impressing everyone with his Machiavellian control of circumstances and conversation - with this absolutely soft-boiled chaos of language." The out-of-control Essrog takes to an extreme what Lethem describes as "the undermining of the traditional American male figure" in 50s film noir. "It's almost a given that my heroes will be incompetent."

At points, Lethem's conception of Lionel's syndrome is brilliantly vivid. "Tourette's," Lionel declares, "is just one big lifetime of tag, really. The world (or my brain - same thing) appoints me it , again and again. So I tag back. Can it do otherwise?" Elsewhere, the condition lends itself a little too easily to Lethem's genre gameplay and literary pyrotechnics, and you start to wonder how realistic this is.

Lethem concedes that "Lionel's vast proliferation of utterances and the number of different kinds of Tourettic symptoms he displays all at once are probably pretty unlikely. But there's nothing impossible about him; he's just a hypertrophied, literarily decorated version." The most remarkable feature of his spin on the condition is how Lionel's ultimate tic is to "relate everything to my Tourette's". The recreation of the world in Tourettic terms is a considerable imaginative feat, which Lethem admits is "my own invention. I have a weakness for meta-fiction, for sentences that think about themselves and characters on whom it dawns that they might be characters. Once I'd given Lionel such an animated, literary voice, it was natural for me to have him think about that voice." Among his thoughts are that the two figures in popular culture who most satisfy his Tourettic impulses are Daffy Duck and the Artist Formerly Known as Prince.

Lethem's hyperreal sufferer has met with nothing but approval from the many real-life Tourettics who've contacted the writer. "Lionel's constant struggle to negotiate his tics, that internal battle to censor them and mete them out only when he's absolutely forced to, struck them as so accurate that they were surprised I didn't have Tourette's myself."

Perhaps sufferers were flattered, too, by Lionel's metaphoric stature. In Motherless Brooklyn, Tourette's is a microcosm of the human condition. Lionel describes it as something outside himself, like an invisible friend. It reminds us of the duality of human consciousness, how we all make war with our own gibbering interior monologues, because the brain has a mind, if you will, of its own. "I've come to see Tourette's as something that exists on a continuum," says Lethem. "I think there is an element in almost anyone. If the book succeeds, it should give you pause, it should make you diagnose yourself, at least briefly, as having some Tourettic tendencies."

The syndrome also reflects "the writer's condition: the need to constantly rearrange and order language, to string it together and to compulsively metaphorise experience. The act of revision is a kind of grooming, counting, ordering impulse. Now I see a lot of my writing habits as an extremely well-managed and productive version of Tourette's."

The detective work done, Lionel Essrog himself is unmasked and there, blinking in the incriminating glare, is Jonathan Lethem. Or Jollify Lefthand. Or Leviathan Heathcliff.

 Motherless Brooklyn is published by Faber & Faber, price £9.99

"Alibi hullabaloo gullible bellyflop smellafish," Lionel responds, at which point, were I the questioner, I'd call it a day. In Lethem's native US, Motherless Brooklyn has been a startling success. Alone among writers, Lethem appeared on Newsweek's list of "100 Americans for the next century", which he dryly comments was "flattering to the point of ludicrous". The novel is being developed for Hollywood by Fight Club star Edward Norton. Hunky screen star plays neurological disorder? Expect Oscars. It's no surprise that Tinseltown beckons. Lethem's reputation in the US is as a writer who combines and reanimates genres. Having spent his formative years at work in a second-hand bookshop, he is fiction's answer to Quentin Tarantino. He may insist that his genre-mashing is an increasingly incidental by-product of the "omnivorous cross-genre enthusiasm in my reading", but Motherless Brooklyn slots neatly into an oeuvre that already includes Girl in Landscape (western meets dystopia) and Gun, With Occasional Music (detective fiction meets sci-fi). Lethem found it natural to place his obsessively twitchy protagonist within a crime-novel plot. "The manic pace of the detective investigation was what I needed to set off that digressive inertia of the Tourettic consciousness," he says. The effect is gleefully absurd, even if the formulaic gumshoe plot pales next to the twinkle-toed narrative footwork. "On one level," Lethem says, "the book hinges on the joke of replacing the hard-boiled narrator - who's supposed to be this Bogart figure impressing everyone with his Machiavellian control of circumstances and conversation - with this absolutely soft-boiled chaos of language." The out-of-control Essrog takes to an extreme what Lethem describes as "the undermining of the traditional American male figure" in 50s film noir. "It's almost a given that my heroes will be incompetent." At points, Lethem's conception of Lionel's syndrome is brilliantly vivid. "Tourette's," Lionel declares, "is just one big lifetime of tag, really. The world (or my brain - same thing) appoints me it , again and again. So I tag back. Can it do otherwise?" Elsewhere, the condition lends itself a little too easily to Lethem's genre gameplay and literary pyrotechnics, and you start to wonder how realistic this is. Lethem concedes that "Lionel's vast proliferation of utterances and the number of different kinds of Tourettic symptoms he displays all at once are probably pretty unlikely. But there's nothing impossible about him; he's just a hypertrophied, literarily decorated version." The most remarkable feature of his spin on the condition is how Lionel's ultimate tic is to "relate everything to my Tourette's". The recreation of the world in Tourettic terms is a considerable imaginative feat, which Lethem admits is "my own invention. I have a weakness for meta-fiction, for sentences that think about themselves and characters on whom it dawns that they might be characters. Once I'd given Lionel such an animated, literary voice, it was natural for me to have him think about that voice." Among his thoughts are that the two figures in popular culture who most satisfy his Tourettic impulses are Daffy Duck and the Artist Formerly Known as Prince. Lethem's hyperreal sufferer has met with nothing but approval from the many real-life Tourettics who've contacted the writer. "Lionel's constant struggle to negotiate his tics, that internal battle to censor them and mete them out only when he's absolutely forced to, struck them as so accurate that they were surprised I didn't have Tourette's myself." Perhaps sufferers were flattered, too, by Lionel's metaphoric stature. In Motherless Brooklyn, Tourette's is a microcosm of the human condition. Lionel describes it as something outside himself, like an invisible friend. It reminds us of the duality of human consciousness, how we all make war with our own gibbering interior monologues, because the brain has a mind, if you will, of its own. "I've come to see Tourette's as something that exists on a continuum," says Lethem. "I think there is an element in almost anyone. If the book succeeds, it should give you pause, it should make you diagnose yourself, at least briefly, as having some Tourettic tendencies." The syndrome also reflects "the writer's condition: the need to constantly rearrange and order language, to string it together and to compulsively metaphorise experience. The act of revision is a kind of grooming, counting, ordering impulse. Now I see a lot of my writing habits as an extremely well-managed and productive version of Tourette's." The detective work done, Lionel Essrog himself is unmasked and there, blinking in the incriminating glare, is Jonathan Lethem. Or Jollify Lefthand. Or Leviathan Heathcliff.  Motherless Brooklyn is published by Faber & Faber, price £9.99

fields.headline: The gender benders
fields.standfirst: Last week, the poet Hugo Williams won an award for a collection that included a description of a female orgasm.  Lucretia Stewart asks if a man can really write how a woman feels and vice versa
fields.trailText: Last week, the poet Hugo Williams won an award for a collection that included a description of a female orgasm. Lucretia Stewart asks if a man can really write how a woman feels and vice versa
fields.body:
Why can't a woman be more like a man?" was, if my memory serves me well, Professor Higgins' bewildered complaint in My Fair Lady, as Eliza Doolittle led him a merry dance. How times have changed. Now men want to be more like women, sometimes even to be women. Failing that, the question today seems to be: "Can a man think, feel and therefore write like (or possibly as) a woman?"

Last week, the poet Hugo Williams won the 1999 T.S. Eliot Award for his new collection, Billy's Rain. The book contains a poem called Rhetorical Questions in which the narrator, the "I" who dominates most of the poems, asks his lover (rhetorically) how she thinks he feels when she sets off "alone/down the hall of collapsing columns", a metaphor for orgasm. One (male) critic said Williams had written "as fine a description of female orgasm as a man can". Which begs the question: can a man really know how a woman feels and vice versa? And is it possible for a male writer to understand, really understand, what it's like to be a woman and vice versa?

The subject of last week's In Our Times, the Radio 4 discussion programme presented by Melvyn Bragg, was masculinity in literature. In it, Martin Amis and Cora Kaplan, an American feminist critic who is also Professor of English at Southampton University, discussed the way men had been portrayed in fiction in the 20th century and how that portrayal had changed as a result of feminism.

Amis' novel Night Train, published in 1997, was written in the voice of an American policewoman, Detective Mike Hoolihan. Note the masculinity of the name and note also the opening sentence of the book: "I am a police." It continues: "That may sound like an unusual statement - or an unusual construction. But it's a parlance we have. Among ourselves, we would never say I am a policeman or I am a policewoman or I am a police officer. We would just say I am a police." This, in turn, leads one to wonder to what degree political correctness has influenced matters - and to what extent Amis, who claimed a new, softer attitude towards women, was sending up political correctness.

Often the reason writers want to experiment with not just another voice (from another social or economic group or nationality, as Kazuo Ishiguro did in The Remains Of The Day) but with another gender is to see whether they can bring it off. It is also to see whether it liberates them, frees them up to express feelings, thoughts and opinions that might sit oddly in their "normal" voice.

Sometimes writers like to tease the reader by refusing to reveal the sex of the narrator, as in Rose Tremain's The Towers Of Trebizond, Virginia Woolf's Orlando or Jeanette Winterson's Written On The Body. Winterson said of the mystery she had created: "It is not important, it doesn't matter to me which it is - my own feeling is that it is both throughout the book and that it changes, that it is sometimes female, sometimes male, and that is perfectly all right."

If the narrator is not apparently driven by issues of masculinity or femininity (ie sex), is he, she or it not free to concentrate on higher things? This is all very well in theory. In practice, when you have a gender-free narrator, the reader keeps looking for clues and that can be distracting.

I am not suggesting that such political correctness should prevail in creative writing where only gay men are permitted to write gay novels, only lesbians lesbian novels, etc. This limits the imagination. If this perspective ruled, there would have been no science fiction, no crime stories, no Book of Revelations. If writers had been permitted to write just from their own experience, the canon of literature would consist only of a kind of dreary social realism.

There is a difference, however, between, say, Tolstoy creating a wonderful fictional female character like Anna Karenina and a male writer trying to write as a woman. Like the outcome of a sex-change operation, it is rarely totally convincing.

When the French sado-masochistic novel The Story Of O was first published, it was attributed to Pauline Réage. For a long time, however, it was believed to have been written by a man (because, I imagine, it was thought to have been too sexy for a woman). Years after its publication, and after her death, it was revealed to have been the work of Dominique Aury. She had written the book in an attempt (successful, it turned out) to re-kindle the interest of her lover, Jean Paulhan.

Victorian pornographic novels were often written as if by a young girl, presumably in order to reassure the (male) reader that the girls were ready and willing. The girls always gave their repeated spankings and gamuchings (a Victorian term for cunnilingus) a terrific write-up.

A good writer almost always has the potential to be interesting, whatever voice he or she chooses to adopt. (Incidentally, Martin Amis described a discussion with Will Self on the use of pronouns: instead of always using the pronoun "he", Amis said he opted for "they"; Self said he made a point of often using "she", a gesture of what he described as "war reparations". Adam Phillips apparently does the same.) Some experiences are universal: death, loss, exile, bereavement, fatigue, itching, hunger, headaches. Headaches may (famously) have feminine causes, but a headache does not differentiate between men and women.

The reader should not be fooled, however, into believing that a man can know what the pain of childbirth (or indeed menstrual cramps) feels like just because he has read or heard or thought about it. By the same token, a man can't know, or describe, what a female orgasm feels like. Nor can a woman know what a male orgasm feels like, or how mind-numbingly boring it is to shave every day. Orgasms are a bit like that remark about the piece of string (as in "how long is"). Each is different.

Tiresias, a Theban seer who lived for seven generations, had the unusual experience of living first as a man, then as a woman, then again as a man. When Zeus and Hera were arguing about whether a man or a woman enjoyed sex more, Tiresias was called in to arbitrate. His opinion, having seen it from both sides, was that sex was nine times as pleasurable for a woman.

Now, his would have been a view worth having.

 Lucretia Stewart's novel Making Love: A Romance is published by Chatto & Windus.

fields.headline: Key's five-year plan
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we ask a county cricketer what he's been up to in the close season. This week we talk to Kent opener Robert Key
fields.trailText: Robert Key, 20, is an opening batsman for Kent. He made his county debut in 1998, and went on the England A tour of 1998-99 to Zimbabwe and South Africa. Last season he scored 836 first-class runs at 26.96.
fields.body:
Robert Key, 20, is an opening batsman for Kent. He made his county debut in 1998, and went on the England A tour of 1998-99 to Zimbabwe and South Africa. Last season he scored 836 first-class runs at 26.96.

"I've been doing some coaching, three nights a week with kids, and now we're back in pre-season. We came back just before Christmas. Until then I was doing one-on-one sessions with Brian Luckhurst [the Kent and England opener of the 1970s]. I also play hockey for Beckenham: the standard is fairly good, and it helps keep me fit. It's good to live so far away from Canterbury - I can get away from it all. Other than that I've not been doing a lot: playing a bit of snooker, and dossing really, living like a student.

I was disappointed not to go on the A tour, but to be honest not that surprised. I didn't do myself any favours by not having a great A tour last time, or put enough pressure on the selectors last summer. I never really felt out of nick - I certainly got enough starts - but I kept getting dismissed in the 30s, which is a bit lazy really.

In five years' time, I want to be established as an England opener, and that all starts this summer. I know that if I get off to a good start, get a few centuries early on, there might be a vacancy there, especially if someone like Ian Botham gets on the selection committee: he's said he'd give youngsters a chance. It's nice to see a few A-team players being fast-tracked - it seemed to take longer a few years ago for people like Deano [Dean Headley]. Especially people like Swanny [Graeme Swann] and Michael Vaughan who were on an A tour with me only a year ago. Michael [Vaughan] was an excellent captain, a really calm, collected sort of bloke, who was really up front with you if he had anything to say.

I'm looking forward to playing with Rahul Dravid. I haven't seen much of him, but his average suggests he's a top player. I've played with some good overseas players now: Hoops [Carl Hooper] especially was great fun to play with: if you were at the wicket when he came in he'd take the pressure off, simply because bowlers were so scared that he'd take them apart.

Having a rest this year should be good for me: for the last three winters I've been touring, and you don't get much of a break - especially last year, when I was back in pre-season as soon as I finished the A tour, which might have had something to do with all the wasted starts. After six months off this winter, I'm really looking forward to getting back now."

Rob Key was talking to Rob Smyth.
