fields.headline: Back to the kitchen sink
fields.standfirst:
Martin Wainwright on the latest survey showing that one third of mothers are forced out of full-time jobs through the inflexibility of working practices
Plus: Pets to declare
fields.trailText: Once again, a piece of detailed research undermines a vague general impression: a sample of working mothers will reveal tonight that a third are dropping full-time jobs or quitting altogether rather than face the strain of balancing home, office and guilt about latchkey children waiting for a decently cooked tea.
fields.body:
Once again, a piece of detailed research undermines a vague general impression: a sample of working mothers will reveal tonight that a third are dropping full-time jobs or quitting altogether rather than face the strain of balancing home, office and guilt about latchkey children waiting for a decently cooked tea.

Amid the confident faces of successful balancers - not just Cherie Blair, but the women who increasingly appear in City page columns about the latest headhunting moves - the figures are unsettling. They point in the opposite direction from the government's declared intention of encouraging young mothers back to work, to use all that energy and enterprise which in past years has spiralled down the kitchen sink.

The worn-out respondents in the BBC's Panorama investigation also echo other recent, chilly revelations of the real world encountered by far too many women: the Pythonesque insistence of golfers in Stoke and schools in Gateshead that executives and pupils who aren't chaps should wear skirts. The world of peculiar ritual, justified only because things have always been done in a certain way, is not confined to Gormenghast on Monday night TV.

Unease at the strength of such crusty, spirit-crushing attitudes is fanned by the Panorama research, which shows again and again that the quitting young mothers are not actually taking on too much. This is the nostrum often peddled by kindly relatives, concerned for their grandchildren or nieces as a whacked working woman comes home late again, and dishes up Burger King instead of something home-made.

The report, aptly titled Back to the Kitchen Sink, does indeed report respectable evidence from Prof Heather Joshi's marathon study at the Institute of Education that children of working mothers can suffer academically. But the answer is not to opt for the "Don't overdo it, dear" approach which simply curbs the bubbling potential of every human life. Take a day at the office (fire station, lorry cab or whatever) and a day looking after two toddlers and say honestly which leaves you feeling more like the proverbial limp rag.

The different nostrum "Get a busy person to do the job" is the point: varied and fulfilling work taps a man or woman's boundless potential, and for that we need an encouraging culture at work as well as at home. Not sarcasm about skirts or asides that "Your child seems to get sick more often than other people's" (a comment which recurs depressingly in the BBC research). But the sort of world created by Joseph Rowntree in his Tanner's Moat cocoa works at York in ... goodness ... 1891.

Appointing his first woman overseer, Rowntree set in train changes to a male-dominated culture which were to make his firm a byword for enlightened practices - at no cost to financial success. Indeed he was taking up the even earlier recommendation of the factory inspectorate in 1864 that "the employment of a mature married woman as 'onlooker' wherever large numbers of women are employed" would be "greatly to the advantage of the owner of such a business".

The argument is not that women are better, kinder or gentler than men. Just that lopsided cultures leave the minority at a bullied disadvantage. And then of course there's the question of why the kitchen sink should be unoccupied when mum gets home. You don't have to be female to understand a Jay-cloth.

Related story and link
One third of mothers forced out of full-time working
Work Unlimited

Pets to declare

The growing likelihood of pet passports, as the European Union becomes ever more cosy, threatens more expense and paperwork for our groaning government machine. The canny investor will be looking up data on photobooth companies, as demand prepares to soar to cope with every Rover and tabby which will have to be snapped.

But wait; isn't there a stimulating challenge here for customs officers, as the ferries and Le Tunnel disgorge arrivals with their budgies and hamsters? The point about owning a pet is how quickly you and your creature come to look - and behave - like one another.

It isn't a precise physical resemblance, except in certain cases involving horses and bloodhounds. It's the mannerism copying between animal and owner which is so phenomenally quick. A name tag and a glimpse through a Heathrow two-way mirror should sort out, as it were, the legal sheep from the smuggling goats. This is one bit of bureaucracy we can happily do without.

RSPCA
HM Customs and Excise

fields.headline: 3D map to launch virtual astronauts
fields.standfirst: Space exploration: special report
fields.trailText: Scientists in Australia are close to an astronomical breakthrough that will help solve some of the riddles of the universe and allow virtual deep-space travel from a computer screen.
fields.body:
Scientists in Australia are close to an astronomical breakthrough that will help solve some of the riddles of the universe and allow virtual deep-space travel from a computer screen.

Astronomers at the Anglo-Australian observatory on Siding Spring mountain, 250 miles north of Sydney, have spent 18 months developing a unique three-dimensional map of the universe.

Using photographs of the night sky and a device called a two-degree field spectrograph, which measures the distance of objects from earth, they have logged the positions of 100,000 galaxies, peering almost to the furthest reaches of space.

By the time the map is finished next year, 250,000 galaxies will be charted on this vast census of the universe - 10 times more than have been studied before.

The map will enable astronomers to examine galaxies and quasars beyond our solar system - some of them 11bn light years distant - and assist research into the expansion of the universe. The map will not cover the entire universe, because the telescope can see less than one-tenth of the night sky from its position in the southern hemisphere.

Despite that, Siding Spring, in a remote region of bush land in northern New South Wales, was chosen to be the observatory for the 3D map programme, partly because it lies under some of the darkest skies in the world.

Although the atmosphere above this part of Australia does not provide particularly sharp images, the location is ideal for wide, sweeping surveys of the cosmos.

The director of the Anglo-Australian observatory, Brian Boyle, said the map would be a powerful tool in efforts to understand space.

"We think the cosmos was formed between 12bn and 15bn years ago - the 'big bang'. This map logs stars 11bn light years away and so is looking back over 90% of the history of the cosmos. That is approaching the farthest reaches of space," said Professor Boyle.

"Because our telescope can look at such a large segment of sky at one time we can build up a 3D image of the universe very quickly."

Prof Boyle added that although 3D maps of the Milky Way galaxy already exist, this map is much larger and the first to chart such a great number of galaxies.

"We'll know a lot more about our place in the vast universe, how galaxies are formed and perhaps even our universe's ultimate fate," he said.

The map will eventually be released on a CD-rom which will be aimed at schools, colleges and armchair space-travellers. Viewers will be able to jet between spiral and elliptical galaxies at the speed of light, learn about the history of the cosmos and gain an idea of its vast size.

fields.headline: Belgian challenge to Pinochet ruling
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The long-running saga of former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet took a new twist last night when sources close to the Belgian foreign ministry indicated it would launch a legal challenge if Jack Straw, the home secretary, halts extradition proceedings against the general.
fields.body:
The long-running saga of former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet took a new twist last night when sources close to the Belgian foreign ministry indicated it would launch a legal challenge if Jack Straw, the home secretary, halts extradition proceedings against the general.

A spokesman for the Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, said its government would be seeking a new medical investigation of the general's health on "an objective and independently verifiable basis".

"We are trying to defend our interests in the best way possible. We've asked British lawyers to do all they can and tomorrow it's ready to go to the high court if necessary," the source told Reuters.

Belgium is one of four countries that issued warrants against the general. The others are Spain, France and Switzerland.

The representation from the Belgian government follows Jack Straw's announcement two weeks ago that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against Gen Pinochet on humanitarian grounds following a medical examination earlier this month.

The home office last night confirmed that it had received an approach via the Belgian government's solicitors and that it was being considered. A spokeswoman added that a final decision on whether to allow Gen Pinochet to leave Britain would not be made before Thursday.

Mr Straw gave interested parties a week to make representations, and last week requested clarification of some of these from Amnesty International, the Spanish government and Gen Pinochet's lawyers. The deadline for those to be received is 5pm this afternoon.

Sources close to the general have ruled out the possibility that he would undergo further medical tests at the behest of any of the countries seeking his extradition.

"The general does not accept the jurisdiction of Spain or any other country in this matter," the source said.

Amnesty International and the representations of other human rights groups to the home secretary centred on the inadequacy of the tests.

The groups claimed that the fact the general was not examined by an old-age psychiatrist specialising in the diagnosis of dementia invalidated the findings of the medical team. They also claimed it was impossible for them to make adequate submissions to the home secretary without seeing the medical evidence.

However according to the home office Mr Straw cannot release medical records without Gen Pinochet's consent. The general has already indicated he will not grant it.

Any legal challenge to Mr Straw's final decision seems unlikely to succeed as the home secretary has wide powers of discretion to release a fugitive on humanitarian grounds.

A Chilean airforce jet ready to fly Pinochet to Santiago will remain in Bermuda until a decision is reached.

webTitle: Flying the battle flags of the South

fields.headline: Flying the battle flags of the South
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report

Bush and McCain have lost their principles before the primaries
fields.trailText: Bush and McCain have lost their principles before the primaries
fields.body:
Put out more flags. That has been the perennial refrain of campaign managers, though the stars and stripes came late to American politics. It was not until 1889 that it was even flown over the White House, at the behest of the last civil war general to become president, one Benjamin Harrison. It only slowly caught on as a badge of true "Americanism".

In the competition for excess, it is also necessary for a candidate's handlers to denude every dime store within a hundred miles of its stock of red, white and blue balloons. Thus accoutred, it is all right to parade naked of ideas or principle.

But the politics of the flag are trickier this year and, for a change, revealing. The question is, which flag? Down in South Carolina, where they started the civil war by firing on the federal Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor in April 1861, one of the big flags fluttering above the statehouse dome in the warm breezes of Columbia is 13 stars on a blue cross.

It is the battle flag of the army of the Confederacy. Did someone forget to take it down when they lost? No, this piece of history goes back only to the 1960s. They put up the Confederate flag then with the official explanation that they were marking the centennial of the civil war.

There is certainly a legitimate pride in the heroism of the boys in grey, but in the 1960s it just happens that South Carolina was in the forefront of the battle to preserve the ugliest aspect of Dixie: its maintenance of slavery by "Jim Crow" laws of segregation. By lynching and dispossession, blacks were denied the vote, decent schooling and healthcare, and altogether went in fear of their lives. What South Carolina ran up the flagpole in the early 1960s was the jolly roger of apartheid. It remains the only state not to recognize Martin Luther King's birthday as a state holiday.

Controversy about the flag rumbled for years. No other southern state flew the Confederate colours over its capitol. This year the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People has forced the issue on to the presidential election agenda by calling for an economic boycott of South Carolina. It is a shrewd weapon against a state that earns more than $6bn from tourism, including an estimated $300m from black visitors. More importantly, it has brought the Republican "Southern" strategy into the open to the dismay of the frontrunners George W Bush and John McCain.

The strategy was concocted, of course, by George Wallace, the racist governor of Alabama, who recognized in 1964 and 1968 that Republicans could break the Democratic hold on the solid South by appealing to the anti-black sentiments of white working and middle-class men and women. Wallace's attacks on Washington's "pointy-headed bureaucrats" were easily read as rejections of the civil rights laws.

Bush has been campaigning as an inclusive candidate; he is at pains to speak Spanish to the Latinos. McCain has been making much of his virtue as a straight-shooter who does not waffle like other politicians. But both men, faced with the Confederate flag, have laid down their principles with alacrity. Bush says simply that people should "butt out" of an issue which only concerns South Carolinians. It is what they said in Charleston in 1861.

McCain's first impulse was to condemn the flag as "a symbol of racism and slavery", then he thought the better of his candour. He made a written statement. The text announced there were two sides to the question. "Some" saw the flag as a symbol of slavery, others as a symbol of heritage. "Personally," he concluded, "I see the battle flag as a symbol of heritage." What matters, of course, is not the perception of the ambitious senator from Arizona but that of the 30% of the state's population who have a humiliating daily reminder of slavery and segregation. Fifty thousand of them vented their feelings in a protest march.

It is a pathetic display from two pretenders to leadership. There is, however, someone with more candour: the flag-raiser-in-chief, Arthur Ravenel, who put the matter bluntly. A state senator and former Republican candidate for governor, Mr Ravenel opined at a pro-flag rally that the NAACP was the National Association for Retarded People. Later, he said it was a slip of the tongue, then apologised - not to the NAACP but to retarded people. Pressed to disassociate himself, Bush has called the comments "unfortunate" but refused to say whether he thought Ravenel should apologise.

South Carolina's February 19 primary is critical, coming after Iowa's caucuses and New Hampshire's primary and before the March 7 cluster of caucuses and primaries which include New York and California. South Carolina is a key one for McCain who hopes to derail Bush's triumphal progression by winning support from the state's 400,000 veterans.

But what is there to choose between two white flags?

webTitle: Cruise and Jolie win Golden Globes

fields.headline: Cruise and Jolie win Golden Globes
fields.trailText: Tom Cruise of "Magnolia" and Angelina Jolie of "Girl, Interrupted" won motion picture supporting actor honors at Sunday's Golden Globe awards.
fields.body:
Tom Cruise of "Magnolia" and Angelina Jolie of "Girl, Interrupted" won motion picture supporting actor honors at Sunday's Golden Globe awards.

And a poignant moment came when Michael J. Fox was named best actor for the TV comedy "Spin City", which he announced he is leaving because of his fight against Parkinson's disease.

"Wow. God, I didn't expect this," Cruise said, then thanked wife Nicole Kidman, who couldn't attend because of work. "Her generosity, her support, her sacrifices, her talent - she inspires me."

Cruise plays a TV guru who pitches a "seduce-and-destroy" program to men in the ensemble drama "Magnolia."

"It's great to see the view from up here," said Jolie, who plays a manic sociopath in "Girl, Interrupted." "The experience of it just being with people and being together and exposing ourselves to each other."

Sarah Jessica Parker of "Sex and the City" won best actress in a TV musical or comedy series.

American Beauty" was the leading movie contender going into Sunday night's 57th Golden Globes, which often forecast what will come at the Oscars. The dark American suburban fable gained six Golden Globe nominations, including best dramatic picture, dramatic actress for Annette Bening, and dramatic actor for Kevin Spacey.

"The Talented Mr. Ripley," a tale of social envy that turns to murder, was close behind with five bids, as was "The Insider," based on the story of tobacco-industry whistle-blower Jeffrey Wigand.

The leading television nominees were the mob drama "The Sopranos" and the risque comedy "Sex and the City," with five bids each.

The awards are selected by reporters from the Hollywood Foreign Press Association. Other top nominees included the films "The End of the Affair" and "Being John Malkovich," which held four nominations each. Films with three bids included "The Hurricane" and "Notting Hill."

"Boys Don't Cry," "The Straight Story," "Man on the Moon," "Analyze This," "Toy Story 2," "An Ideal Husband," "Sweet and Lowdown," "The Cider House Rules," "Magnolia," "Anna and the King" and "The Sixth Sense" had two bids each.

Barbra Streisand, winner of more Golden Globe trophies than any other entertainer, including best actress for "Funny Girl" and "A Star is Born," was to receive the Cecil B. DeMille Award for "outstanding contribution to the entertainment field."

Some movies that received awards buzz were largely ignored. They included "The Green Mile" starring Tom Hanks, "Anna and the King" with Jodie Foster, and "Angela's Ashes" starring Emily Watson. Stanley Kubrick's final film, "Eyes Wide Shut," received just one nomination, for best score.

Golden Globe shows have come to be known for bordering on the giddy. In recent years, Jack Nicholson delivered a salty acceptance speech, Ving Rhames bestowed his statue on Jack Lemmon and Christine Lahti took the stage with toilet paper on her shoe, a reference to the year she was in the ladies' room when her trophy was announced.

The awards have gained in prestige, overlapping to an extent with the Academy Award bids to be announced next month.

But they once were viewed with suspicion because of allegations of corrupt voting and questionable professionalism.

The low point came in 1981, when Pia Zadora was given a statue for the bomb "Butterfly" and networks refused to show the program.

After an effort to regain respectability, the ceremony was welcomed back by television in 1996. This year, association members quickly returned pricey watches sent to them by the company that released the Sharon Stone comedy "The Muse."

"We are not stupid," said association president Helmut Voss. The awards bring the group $2 million in income and members wouldn't endanger that by casting doubt on their integrity, he said.

fields.headline: American Beauty sweeps Golden Globes
fields.standfirst: Today, three awards for Sam Mendes's debut feature, plus recognition for Toy Story 2, Phil Collins and Tom Cruise | Full-length Blackadder movie | Ministers prepare to woo Spielberg | in brief | and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Today, three awards for Sam Mendes's debut feature, plus recognition for Toy Story 2, Phil Collins and Tom Cruise | Full-length Blackadder movie | Ministers prepare to woo Spielberg | in brief | and the latest casting news
fields.body:
American Beauty (pictured) has swept the board at this year's Golden Globe awards.

The film, a dark comedy about mid-life crisis and teenage angst in America's suburbia, directed by Britain's Sam Mendes, won awards for Best Drama, Director and Screenplay.

The Golden Globes, staged by the 82 members of the Hollywood Foreign Press Association, is regarded as a good indication of who will win Oscars in March.

It was also a good night for Britain's other hopefuls. Janet McTeer won Best Actress in a Musical or Comedy for her performance as the hippy southern mother in Tumbleweeds, while Phil Collins won the Best Original Song for You'll be in My Heart (from Tarzan).

The Golden Globe awards ceremony, which has been increasing in popularity and credibility over the last few years, was estimated to have been watched by 300m people worldwide. The full results are as follows:

Best Picture, Drama: American Beauty.

Best Actress, Drama: Hilary Swank in Boys Don't Cry.

Best Actor, Drama: Denzel Washington in The Hurricane.

Best Picture, Musical or Comedy: Toy Story 2.

Best Actress, Musical or Comedy: Janet McTeer in Tumbleweeds.
Best Actor, Musical or Comedy: Jim Carrey in Man on the Moon.

Best Foreign Language Picture: All About My Mother.

Best Supporting Actress, Drama, Musical or Comedy: Angelina Jolie in Girl, Interrupted.

Best Supporting Actor, Drama, Musical or Comedy: Tom Cruise in Magnolia.
Best Director: Sam Mendes for American Beauty.
Best Screenplay: Alan Ball for American Beauty.
Best Original Score: Ennio Morricone for The Legend of 1900.

Best Original Song: You'll be in My Heart from Tarzan by Phil Collins.

Full-length Blackadder movie to be made

Rowan Atkinson is to make a film version of Blackadder, with our hero playing a pop manager who misses out on signing the Beatles.

There have been rumours of a feature-length version of the popular BBC series for a number of years now, intensified recently by the reunion of the characters in Back and Forth, the short film currently showing at the millennium dome in the Skyscape cinema. But the stumbling block for Atkinson and co-writers Ben Elton and Richard Curtis has been the period in which to set the film.

However, according to cast member Stephen Fry, the team have finally decided on the 60s. "We have had great fun thinking what the next one ought to be. We've decided it should be set in the 60s, where Rowan would be a manager of a band that was on the night after the Beatles played at the Cavern Club - so he just misses [them]... and he's enraged with bitterness," he said.

Atkinson will play the Svengali Brian Epstein-esque manager Edmund Blackadder, and as usual will be joined by Tony Robinson, this time as the band's bald drummer, Rick. The remainder of the band will be played by Hugh Laurie, Tim McInnerney and Rik Mayall. Together they spend the 60s trying and failing to make it big by emulating the Beatles.

It is not yet known when the film will go into production.

Ministers prepare to woo Spielberg

The government hopes to persuade Steven Spielberg to make Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone in the UK, and are preparing a charm offensive to woo the director over here.

Ministers will highlight the success of Aardman Animations, the company that make Wallace and Gromit, which signed a £150m deal with Spielberg's DreamWorks studio last year to produce five films.

One option for the dome at the end of the year is to turn it into a studio: a plan backed by Ministers. They believe that the move would plug one of the main weaknesses of the British film industry - lack of studio space.

Government support for the project will be a boost to the consortium headed by the Madame Tussaud's group, which is behind the plan to turn the dome into a state-of-the-art film and TV studio.

In brief

As well as cleaning up at the Golden Globes, American Beauty also did pretty well at the Las Vegas Film Critics Society Awards. It won Best Film, while Kevin Spacey walked away with the Best Actor award. Other winners include Haley Joel Osment for The Sixth Sense, and director Spike Jonze for Being John Malkovich. The awards themselves will be presented in late February.

Casting couch

 Nicole Kidman is to star in Ang Lee's next film, a world war two drama set in Berlin. Kidman will play Marie Vassiltchikov, a Russian princess who worked for the Nazis in the German foreign office.

 Catherine Zeta-Jones is in talks to star in Steven Soderbergh's forthcoming film, Traffic. Based on the British TV mini-series Traffik, Soderbergh's film will take a look at the business and politics of drug trafficking.

Best Original Score: Ennio Morricone for The Legend of 1900. Best Original Song: You'll be in My Heart from Tarzan by Phil Collins. Full-length Blackadder movie to be made Rowan Atkinson is to make a film version of Blackadder, with our hero playing a pop manager who misses out on signing the Beatles. There have been rumours of a feature-length version of the popular BBC series for a number of years now, intensified recently by the reunion of the characters in Back and Forth, the short film currently showing at the millennium dome in the Skyscape cinema. But the stumbling block for Atkinson and co-writers Ben Elton and Richard Curtis has been the period in which to set the film. However, according to cast member Stephen Fry, the team have finally decided on the 60s. "We have had great fun thinking what the next one ought to be. We've decided it should be set in the 60s, where Rowan would be a manager of a band that was on the night after the Beatles played at the Cavern Club - so he just misses [them]... and he's enraged with bitterness," he said. Atkinson will play the Svengali Brian Epstein-esque manager Edmund Blackadder, and as usual will be joined by Tony Robinson, this time as the band's bald drummer, Rick. The remainder of the band will be played by Hugh Laurie, Tim McInnerney and Rik Mayall. Together they spend the 60s trying and failing to make it big by emulating the Beatles. It is not yet known when the film will go into production. Ministers prepare to woo Spielberg The government hopes to persuade Steven Spielberg to make Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone in the UK, and are preparing a charm offensive to woo the director over here. Ministers will highlight the success of Aardman Animations, the company that make Wallace and Gromit, which signed a £150m deal with Spielberg's DreamWorks studio last year to produce five films. One option for the dome at the end of the year is to turn it into a studio: a plan backed by Ministers. They believe that the move would plug one of the main weaknesses of the British film industry - lack of studio space. Government support for the project will be a boost to the consortium headed by the Madame Tussaud's group, which is behind the plan to turn the dome into a state-of-the-art film and TV studio. In brief As well as cleaning up at the Golden Globes, American Beauty also did pretty well at the Las Vegas Film Critics Society Awards. It won Best Film, while Kevin Spacey walked away with the Best Actor award. Other winners include Haley Joel Osment for The Sixth Sense, and director Spike Jonze for Being John Malkovich. The awards themselves will be presented in late February. Casting couch  Nicole Kidman is to star in Ang Lee's next film, a world war two drama set in Berlin. Kidman will play Marie Vassiltchikov, a Russian princess who worked for the Nazis in the German foreign office.  Catherine Zeta-Jones is in talks to star in Steven Soderbergh's forthcoming film, Traffic. Based on the British TV mini-series Traffik, Soderbergh's film will take a look at the business and politics of drug trafficking.

webTitle: Pope pleads on US death penalty

fields.headline: Pope pleads on US death penalty
fields.standfirst:
The US elections: special report
George W Bush official site
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II has pitched his moral force into today's Iowa primary by begging George W Bush, the Republican frontrunner, to commute a death sentence scheduled for tomorrow.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II has pitched his moral force into today's Iowa primary by begging George W Bush, the Republican frontrunner, to commute a death sentence scheduled for tomorrow.

The Pope has stepped up pressure on Mr Bush, as governor of Texas, to spare the life of Glen McGinnis, who was 17 when he shot dead an attendant in a dry cleaner's in a bungled burglary in 1991.

In a letter to Mr Bush, the Pope wrote: "Every human life is sacred and I pray that McGinnis is saved."

There was no immediate response at the weekend, and the execution by lethal injection is expected to go ahead at Huntsville prison.

However, the intervention threatens to ignite capital punishment as a campaign issue and lay down a marker that the pontiff will try to mobilise US Catholics during the election.

During a visit to Missouri last year he successfully pressured Mel Carnahan, the governor, into sparing Darrell Mease days before he was due to be executed for several murders in 1988.

Human rights activists hope that such papal appeals become a thorn in the flesh for Mr Bush and his pro-execution rivals. The Vatican has made opposition to capital punishment a key theme of this year's holy year, or jubilee.

Mr Bush, who is expected to win in Iowa, has approved 116 executions, more than any other US governor in modern times. He also opposed a bill banning executions of the mentally handicapped or ill.

The Democratic candidates Al Gore and Bill Bradley have also publicly supported execution.

fields.headline: The best punk scene
fields.standfirst: Summer of Sam
fields.trailText: New York, 1977. Having agreed to attend their musically minded friend Richie's live debut, Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Dionna (Mira Sorvino) pull up outside the venue, punk hotspot CBGB's. Dressed in full disco regalia, they stare in horror at the hordes beside them.
fields.body:
New York, 1977. Having agreed to attend their musically minded friend Richie's live debut, Vinny (John Leguizamo) and Dionna (Mira Sorvino) pull up outside the venue, punk hotspot CBGB's. Dressed in full disco regalia, they stare in horror at the hordes beside them.

"Is this it?" a slack-jawed Dionna inquires. "Is this where we're going?"

"Well, the sign says CBGB's, right?" Vinny replies. "And this is the corner of Bleeker and The Bowery."

"This is The Bowery? This is where my father told me all the bums went."

Repulsed, Dionna gazes at the crowd.

"Who are these people? What is this?"

"Richie made us come over here, what the hell's the matter with him? I wouldn't even park my car here. What the fuck is this?"

A pair of heavily pierced girls catch Dionna's eye.

"Oh my God, look at those girls looking at me like that - like I'm the freak."

"Don't pay any attention to them."

Dionna turns to Vinny.

"I don't like this place. I think maybe we should go."

"Where d'you wanna go?"

"Anywhere. I don't care."

She hesitates.

"54."

"Studio 54? That's where you wanna go? Well, it's your night..."

Casting a nervous glance behind them, they drive away.

See also: The Great Rock'n' Roll Swindle, After Hours, Out Of The Blue, Repo Man

Don't see also: Star Trek IV: The Voyage Home

Pointless trivia: Mira Sorvino graduated from Harvard University with a BA in Asian Studies, and speaks fluent Mandarin.

fields.headline: Man Utd 1 - 1 Arsenal
fields.trailText: Man Utd: Bosnich, G. Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs, Cole, Yorke. Subs: Van Der Gouw, P. Neville, Berg, Solskjaer, Sheringham.
fields.body:
Man Utd: Bosnich, G. Neville, Stam, Silvestre, Irwin, Beckham, Keane, Butt, Giggs, Cole, Yorke. Subs: Van Der Gouw, P. Neville, Berg, Solskjaer, Sheringham.

Arsenal: Seaman, Dixon, Keown, Grimandi, Silvinho, Parlour, Vieira, Petit, Hughes, Ljungberg, Henry. Subs: Winterburn, Wreh, Manninger, Malz, Luzhny.

Referee: P Durkin (Dorset)

Arsenal are up against it for this crunch match at Old Trafford, which is tonight entertaining the largest Premiership crowd ever - 58,293. Arsène Wenger is without Tony Adams, Marc Overmars and Dennis Bergkamp who are injured, while Davor Suker is suspended and Nwankwo Kanu is on international duty with Nigeria in the African Nations Cup. If Wenger believes his team are stronger with "their backs against the wall" then tonight would be the night to prove it.

1 Arsenal kick off, after a delay caused by Mark Bosnich wearing the same colour shirt as the Arsenal team. They immediately play it back to David Seaman for the first clearance of the game.
2 Arsenal put some early pressure on the United goal but the ball is cleared for Nicky Butt to race onto the clearance. Seaman beats him to it.
4 Patrick Viera passes to Ray Parlour who attempts to forge a break down the right, but the ball goes for an Arsenal throw. Thierry Henry unable to find space on the edge of the United area.
7 Both teams still looking to find their rhythm but Arsenal come close when Fredrik Ljungberg dispossess Gary Neville and crosses to Henry in the six-yard box. The Frenchman gets his header in and forces Bosnich to make a great save.
9 Arsenal getting the better of the early play as Jaap Stam gives the ball away and allows the Gunners to attempt another break.
10 Lee Dixon feeds Parlour on the right but his attempt to get behind the defence is too heavy-handed.
11 GOAL: Manchester United 0 - 1 Arsenal Arsenal take their chance when Stam is again caught in possession by Ljungberg on the edge of the penalty area. Ljungberg looks up and shoots through the legs of the advancing Bosnich into the bottom far corner for his fifth goal of the season.
15 Arsenal win a corner. Emmanuel Petit takes it and the ball is immediately played back out. Back in again to Henry on the edge of the area but his first touch lets him down and United clear.
17 Bosnich appears unable to get any length to his goal-kicks and Arsenal are immediately able to pick up where they left off.
19 A long ball finds Ryan Giggs out the left; he cuts inside and fires towards David Beckham who is advancing towards the six-yard box. Seaman gathers.
20 Beckham, in space on the right, finds Dwight Yorke on the edge of the penalty area; he swivels and cuts the ball square to Andy Cole, who plays it back for Roy Keane to fire in a shot from 25 yards - Seaman saves at the second attempt.
21 Ljungberg comes close again when he turns Mickael Silvestre inside the United penalty area. His shot goes just wide of the right-hand upright.
22 United beginning to wake up as they realise their holiday is well and truly over. Ryan Giggs, 20 yards out, gets his head to a long ball but he puts it wide of Seaman's goal.
24 Substitution: Nigel Winterburn on for Silvinho.
26 Arsenal almost get a second when Ljungberg finds space in the middle of the park and runs up with Henry in support; he loses possession and the ball comes to Henry who cuts in to shoot from the left corner of the area, but Stam deflects what looks to have a goal-bound effort.
27 United's best chance so far when Cole races into the left of the Arsenal area and finds Yorke six yards out. Yorke skies his chance under pressure, while United appeal for a penalty after Giggs appeared to have been held back.
32 Keane side-foots a shot from just outside the penalty area; goes nowhere but comes out to Beckham on the right. He plays it back in but the ball is lost in the goalmouth crowd and goes out for a corner. Beckham takes and plays it deep onto the head of Yorke just inside the area - a great effort down that fails to find the foot of the turning Cole and the ball is kept out by Gilles Grimandi with more than a hint of handball.
38 A golden chance for Arsenal after some poor defensive work by United. Henry gets the better of Silvestre and charges up with only Bosnich to beat - somehow he doesn't.
41 Booking: Grimandi for obstruction on Yorke.
42 United win a corner; Beckham takes but the ball is put behind by Grimandi. Beckham takes again but an Arsenal head again gets there first and the ball is cleared.
44 United win a free kick 35 yards out. Beckham has a crack but fails to find the target.
45 Top chance for United after Beckham plays a long ball to Cole 30 yards out. Cole immediately finds Nicky Butt who runs at and through the defence and toe-pokes a shot for Seaman to make a superb diving save. The ball comes out to Giggs who rifles a shot into the side netting. Half-time.

46 The second half starts with a good deal more urgency than the first as United search for an equaliser.
47 Arsenal win a corner on the right. Petit takes and Bosnich apparently gets a hand to it; the ball lofts up and comes down for Denis Irwin who falls on top of Henry before recovering to make a goal-line clearance. Arsenal claim that the ball was over the line while United claim that it was Henry who handled to make the clearance.
51 End-to-end long balls as both teams search for an opening.
52 Nigel Winterburn intercepts Beckham on the break and the ball eventually finds Parlour out on the right. He cuts inside but is challenged on the edge of the United area.
54 Petit wins the ball inside the United half and slides a pass behind Stam to Henry who is mustered well by Silvestre.
57 Arsenal win a corner on the right. Petit takes but it is too deep and misses everyone.
59 Giggs races away down the left, crosses from the corner flag but Seaman rises to make the catch.
60 Beckham tries something similar down the right; he crosses from a deeper position but his effort is wasted when no United players get themselves into position in front off goal. Beckham has a good shout at everyone.
63 Beckham and Stephen Hughes appear to be enjoying an on-off barney as Beckham races half way up the pitch to make a crunching tackle on Hughes.
65 Arsenal's defence look up to the task of keeping United at bay - every time United get the ball the Arsenal back four drop back to smother any chance for Cole and Yorke to take advantage.
66 Substitution: Teddy Sheringham on for Cole. Keane lucky to avoid a booking after he barges Ljungberg off the ball and then chests referee Paul Durkin as he whistles for the foul.
68 United step up the pressure as first Keown blocks a shot from Butt and then Grimandi gets in the way of a vicious strike from Keane.
69 Keane again at the centre of things as he finds Sheringham on the edge of the area; Sheringham works a one-two with Yorke but he plays the return too long and Seaman gathers.
70 Substitution: Stefan Malz on for Hughes.
71 Ljungberg comes close to getting a second. He picks up the ball on the left of the six-yard box but his shot is deflected over the bar under pressure from Silvestre.
72 Man Utd appear to have been galvanised by the arrival of Sheringham while Arsenal are visibly tiring.
73 GOAL: Manchester United 1 - 1 Arsenal Keane finds Giggs wide on the left; he puts in a fine cross that Seaman gets a hand to, but Beckham knocks the ball back to Sheringham in space on the edge of the six-yard box to side-foot the equaliser into an unguarded net.
76 A Keown error just inside the Arsenal half almost allows Butt to run clear but the defender recovers to make a vital interception while still on the ground.
81 United win a corner on the left, Arsenal clear but give the ball away to Irwin as United push up in search of a winner.
83 The game has died down as Arsenal try to stifle United's frenzied attacks by pushing up themselves.
86 Arsenal's second wind continues as Ljungberg plays a one-two with Henry before the Frenchman slides the ball out Parlour on the right. Keane gets back to make a great covering tackle.
88 Substitution: P Neville on for Irwin. A drop-ball is awarded; it falls in United's favour and the move results in a corner for United. Beckham takes and plays it back to P Neville who loops the ball to Stam on the edge of six-yard box; his header goes over.
90 Four minutes of stoppage time. United again step up a gear as Arsenal give the ball away with disturbing frequency. They will surely thank their defence if they secure a draw tonight. Scrappy stuff as Arsenal win the ball back. Henry wins a corner, Grimandi heads the ball across the face of goal. United clear. Full-time. It's a draw, and it's a fair result.

Sheringham the saviour
Perfect pitch helps champions hold ground

fields.headline: Time Warner/EMI merger: details announced
fields.trailText: EMI chairman Eric Nicoli today said he was optimistic that EMI's merger with Time Warner's music division will be cleared by the competition authorities.
fields.body:
EMI chairman Eric Nicoli today said he was optimistic that EMI's merger with Time Warner's music division will be cleared by the competition authorities.

"On the regulatory approval front, we are at the very start of the process," he said. "But we think we have a compelling case and we are optimistic."

Between them, the pair will have a global market share of 20%, even higher in certain regions. However, Mr Nicoli, who will be co-chairman of the new Warner-EMI Music, believes there is little to fear from industry watchdogs such as the US federal trade commission and the European commission.

The companies said they complement each other geographically, with Warner Music Group's strength in the US and EMI's strong market positions across Europe and other countries. The enlarged group would be a leading source of music for both traditional sales in shops and, more importantly, over the internet; Time Warner's merger with America Online would give EMI an unprecedented opportunity to sell via the internet.

"It enhances our ability to realise the opportunities present by the internet and other new media, and it will allow us to deliver all of our main strategic objectives in a dramatically shorter timeframe," Mr Nicoli said.

The alliance between EMI and Warner Music will assemble a huge talent pool, including the Rolling Stones and Madonna. The new company will have combined sales of more than £5bn and rank second only behind Seagram's Universal music group. Time Warner and EMI would each control half of the new company, to be called Warner EMI Music. It would have combined revenues of £4.9bn and a pretax profit of £650 million.

Warner EMI Music will be headquartered in New York, with international headquarters in London. Mr Nicoli and Time Warner president Richard Parsons are to be co-chairmen of the merged company.

The new firm would represent some 2,500 musicians. EMI brings to the deal the Virgin, Priority and Capitol record labels - including names like the Spice Girls, Van Morrison and Frank Sinatra. Time Warner contributes its Atlantic, Elektra and Warner Brothers labels that include Cher, Eric Clapton, Phil Collins, Madonna, Metallica and REM.

The merger marks the end of Britain's last great music company. EMI led the pack in the swinging sixties when the Beatles were the most famous group on the planet and Abbey Road the most instantly recognisable recording studio.

"It's a shame to see the last major British music company effectively fall into overseas hands," said Alison Wenham, chief executive of the Association of Independent Music.

Lorna Tilbian, analyst at the brokerage house WestLB Panmure, agreed: "EMI is one of the few UK companies with a double digit market share in every global market. It has a back catalogue that has taken over a century to put together and to drift into American hands in the digital age when you want to be world leaders as well is a bit of a shame," she said.

Meanwhile, German media giant Bertelsmann, long rumoured as a suitor for EMI, denied reports that it was preparing a bid of its own for the British company to break up the deal.

webTitle: Death exposes risks of gene therapy

fields.headline: Death exposes risks of gene therapy
fields.standfirst: Inquiry uncovers safety breaches and deception in case of teenager who died at esteemed centre
fields.trailText: When Jesse Gelsinger, an 18-year-old volunteer from Arizona, died during trials of an experimental gene-based medical treatment last September, his father called him a hero and praised the scientists treating him.
fields.body:
When Jesse Gelsinger, an 18-year-old volunteer from Arizona, died during trials of an experimental gene-based medical treatment last September, his father called him a hero and praised the scientists treating him.

But at the weekend, after US investigators probing an astonishing catalogue of safety violations and deception shut down all experiments at the once-esteemed Pennsylvania Institute for Gene Therapy, a shattered Paul Gelsinger was seeing his son in a new light: that of victim.

"Everybody was wrong," he said in a US interview. "Even me."

The Arizona teenager is the first person to die as a direct result of gene therapy, the medical revolution-in-waiting which promises to cure scores of incurable diseases but has yet to cure one.

In the wake of his death increasingly troubling accounts began to emerge of the institute's cavalier practices. But the radical move on Friday by the US food and drug administration to suspend indefinitely all seven gene therapy studies at the institute, one of the world's biggest, still shocked the international genetic research community.

In Britain, Norman Nevin, chairman of the government's gene therapy advisory committee (GTAC), said that there were no plans to re-examine the 40-odd gene therapy trials under way here in the light of the FDA's move.

About 350 patients are involved in the trials.

The GTAC, which licenses all gene therapy experiments in the UK, had already reviewed its programme after Gelsinger's death, Professor Nevin said. None of the British trials was directly comparable to what was going on in Pennsylvania.

Risk

"I'm very happy that no patient in the UK is at risk as a result of what happened to Jesse," said Prof Nevin.

Jesse Gelsinger suffered from an inherited liver complaint called ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency (OTC). The institute was testing a method of helping sufferers by using a modified cold virus to carry the gene which produced the deficient enzyme into their liver.

After he was injected with the virus, Gelsinger's immune system launched a massive counter-attack to reject it which destroyed his liver and spleen and badly damaged other organs, killing him four days later.

The institute is accused of giving Gelsinger too high a dose of the virus, ignoring clinical signs that Gelsinger was not fit to take part in the test and concealing from the authorities that previous volunteers had shown toxic reactions to the virus.

Investigators could find no evidence that all the 18 patients recruited for the trial had been fully informed of the risks beforehand. Consent forms were doctored without the authorities' permission to omit the fact that monkeys who took part in a similar trial had died.

Instead of screening the 18 for eligibility before they were recruited, the institute printed up eligibility forms only after Gelsinger died, leaving them unsigned and undated.

The institute, which has an annual budget of $25m, is headed by the distinguished James Wilson, past president of the American Society for Gene Therapy.

Dr Wilson has yet to respond publicly to the FDA's latest move. As founder of the biotech firm Genovo, he stood to benefit financially from a successful outcome of the trial which led to Gelsinger's death.

Genetic researchers and biotech lobbyists were trying to distance themselves at the weekend from what happened at Pennsylvania, arguing that it was down to bad administrative practice rather than bad science and that a crackdown by the regulators would ultimately be good for the field's image.

"I think the public will have more confidence if they know the FDA will enforce the rules," said Michael Werner of BIO, the Biotechnology Industry Organisation. The crisis at Pennsylvania comes as biotech shares are surging on world stock markets.

Wake-up call

"This is really a wake-up call, where perhaps we get a little comfortable with things as they're going on and then get a little cavalier," said Estuardo Aguilar-Cordova, a gene therapy adviser to the US national institutes of health.

The first gene therapy trials were in 1990. Hundreds are now under way around the world, none yet offering a definitive cure but all sustained by the enthusiasm of drugs companies, the desperate eagerness of sufferers from inherited illnesses and the conviction of scientists that breakthroughs are near.

Gene therapy covers a multitude of treatments, all involving somehow getting artificially manipulated genes into the human body to alter the way it works.

This can mean changing the genes of a virus to kill cancer cells, using a gene to trigger an otherwise inert drug, or - the greatest challenge - replacing genes which do not work properly.

It was this last method that the Pennsylvania team was trying to use. But their technique - injecting a cold virus modified to carry "good" genes directly into the bloodstream of a sufferer - was known to carry a risk of triggering an immune system reaction.

Prof Nevin said that 11 gene therapy studies were under way in Britain using the cold virus, or adenovirus, but none involved injecting into the blood.

Sufferers from inherited diseases fear that kneejerk public hostility to genetic medicine could rob them of a cure.

Bill Gleeson, spokesman for Britain's 200,000 sufferers of retinitis pigmentosa, a genetic defect which causes blindness, said: "There's a difference between clamping down on someone who might be a bit of a rogue and stopping research altogether. Early surgery costs lives. Early anaesthesia costs lives. You wouldn't want to turn the clock back on anaesthesia, would you?"

webTitle: EMI and Time Warner form giant music group

fields.headline: EMI and Time Warner form giant music group
fields.standfirst:
£12bn merger putting some of the world's biggest music artists on the same label is a testament to the growing power of the internet
Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
fields.trailText: A dream line-up of the some of the world's biggest music acts, including Madonna, the Spice Girls, Robbie Williams and Janet Jackson, was assembled yesterday through the £12bn merger of Britain's EMI and the record labels of US group Time Warner.
fields.body:
A dream line-up of the some of the world's biggest music acts, including Madonna, the Spice Girls, Robbie Williams and Janet Jackson, was assembled yesterday through the £12bn merger of Britain's EMI and the record labels of US group Time Warner.

The deal to create Warner EMI will be formally announced this morning and will catapult the combined group to the top of the music business charts alongside Sony, Germany's Bertelsmann and Universal PolyGram. Warner EMI will have sales of more than £5bn a year and account for almost one in every four CDs sold worldwide.

The merger has been driven chiefly by the increasingly global nature of the £23bn music market, which is seeing the same acts charting in cities from Bangkok to Berlin.

It is also a tacit acknowledgment of the profound impact that the internet will have on music distribution and is part of the continued convergence of old and new media.

The deal will mean that America Online, which acquired Time Warner earlier this month, will end up as the one of the largest record companies in the world - a testament to the growing power of the internet over the music industry.

EMI recently predicted that 10% of its sales would be generated via the internet within five years and had already begun making investments in a series of web-based music firms. Industry experts believe it is only a matter of time before most music is sold over the internet, by downloading directly onto recording devices.

Directors of EMI and Time Warner were locked in the offices of City investment bank Warburg Dillon Read yesterday negotiating the final details of the transaction and issued only a brief statement saying that the merger would "represent an opportunity to establish the world's premier music group".

EMI, which began life as the Gramophone Company in 1897, was the last sizeable British music group.

"It's a shame to see the last major British music company effectively fall into overseas hands," said Alison Wenham, chief executive of the Association of Independent Music.

The merger unites labels including WEA, Elektra, Atlantic, Virgin, Capitol, Chrysalis, and Blue Note.

EMI made £75m profits in the first half of its financial year on sales of just over £1bn, with its most notable success coming in Japan where the company sold 9m units of schoolgirl Utada Hikaru's R'n'B debut album First Love. Warner's sales are focused in the US, where it had 23 of the top 100 albums during 1998.

Music sales worldwide have been sluggish recently. The industry has suffered in comparison with the sustained period over which buyers replaced their vinyl collections for CDs.

Consequently the industry has witnessed a succession of large-scale mergers including Canadian group Seagram, which owns the Universal business, acquiring PolyGram. The Warner EMI tie-up is likely to face intense scrutiny from competition authorities.

There was some speculation last night that Bertelsmann, which had been named as a potential bidder for EMI in recent weeks, may attempt to spoil the party with Time Warner or else try a merger with another of its rivals.

Although EMI and Time Warner will have equal stakes in the new company the US giant will be firmly in the driving seat. The new business will have headquarters in New York, and Roger Ames, head of Warner Music Group, will be installed as chief executive. Costs of up to £300m are likely to be stripped out through combination of the two groups' promotion, marketing and distribution networks, which could spell job losses in Britain.

The British music industry contributes £3.2bn to the economy and employs 130,000 people, with British artists accounting for 10-15% of worldwide sales.

EMI has been the subject of almost constant takeover speculation for the past two years. It saw off a hostile approach from Seagram and has also been linked with Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation and Walt Disney.

EMI will retain its quote on the London stock market but will effectively become a holding company for its share in the joint venture.

webTitle: Desktop icons No 3: The mouse mat

fields.headline: Desktop icons No 3: The mouse mat
fields.trailText: The beauty of the mouse mat, for those who search for beauty in such things, is its simplicity. A little piece of textile-backed foam, the mouse mat has one simple function - to provide a bit of rough. Its textured surface is designed to create enough friction for the trackball on a mouse to operate smoothly, and that's it. Nothing that the desk surface itself couldn't do. Or indeed a bit of sandpaper, if you are particularly horny-handed.
fields.body:
The beauty of the mouse mat, for those who search for beauty in such things, is its simplicity. A little piece of textile-backed foam, the mouse mat has one simple function - to provide a bit of rough. Its textured surface is designed to create enough friction for the trackball on a mouse to operate smoothly, and that's it. Nothing that the desk surface itself couldn't do. Or indeed a bit of sandpaper, if you are particularly horny-handed.

The first computer mouse, invented by Douglas Engelbert in the early 60s, had vertical and horizontal wheels that required only a smooth surface to operate effectively. The innovation of the trackball made navigation easier, but also provided the little vermin with the perfect dust trap. Enter the mouse mat, a spongy, non-slip surface where they could run around all day without getting clogged up and refusing to behave.

Of course, it didn't take long for the further possibilities of a desktop mat - conveniently TV-shaped - to be spotted. "Mouse mats give you rent-free desk space," says a spokesman for the UK's leading manufacturer, Listawood, which estimates that 90% of the 10m made in Britain every year are promotional freebies. In fact the mouse mat, like the mug and the ballpoint pen, is one of those items which no one ever buys but everyone owns. They just seem to appear overnight - clear signs, perhaps, of an infestation.

Inevitably, the mouse mat has its admirers; there is even a museum dedicated to its endless variety of form, located (of course) on the internet. Visitors to the First Virtual Mousepad Museum can learn about the first patented mat, and view a collection of 400 from 90 countries - votes are invited for the favourite design. Topping the poll is a mat featuring a woman being frightened by a mouse (geddit?). Hilarious. In close pursuit, however, is "the most important German highways on a mousepad". One for aficionados only, perhaps.

webTitle: Sir Anthony's Oscar saved from flames

fields.headline: Sir Anthony's Oscar saved from flames
fields.trailText: The coveted mementoes of Oscar-winning actor Sir Anthony Hopkins were today saved from destruction by firefighters tackling a blaze at his luxury London home.
fields.body:
The coveted mementoes of Oscar-winning actor Sir Anthony Hopkins were today saved from destruction by firefighters tackling a blaze at his luxury London home.

The fire broke out on the second floor of the Kensington property this afternoon, spilling out of windows and sending smoke billowing into the street, London Fire Brigade confirmed.

Awards and other souvenirs charting Sir Anthony's screen and stage successes were scattered through the four-storey house, including the Oscar for his performance in the hit film Silence of the Lambs.

It is understood his estranged wife Jenni still lives in the house despite Sir Anthony's move to Los Angeles in 1998.

The actor, who also starred in films such as The Remains of the Day and the Mask of Zorro, bought the house with his wife in the mid-1990s.

A Fire Brigade spokesman said they had managed to contain the fierce fire on the second floor after a 45-minute battle to save the rest of the house.

Assistant Division Officer Max Dissanayake said the crews had brought the fire under control just in time as it was threatening to destroy the entire building and its contents.

He said: "They arrived very quickly which was lucky because the fire had reached a stage whereby it had engulfed the room of origin and broken the windows.

"From that point, because of the direct flow of air, there is only a matter of minutes in which to save the property."

Between 15-20 firefighters attended the blaze after a neighbour raised the alarm at about 1pm. Mr Dissanayake said some of the men had forced down the door and had gone in with breathing equipment to make sure there was no one trapped inside.

The second floor bedroom in which the blaze broke out was badly damaged by fire but the rest of the house was intact despite a small amount of smoke damage, he added.

Mr Dissanayake said: "According to the crews there were a lot of photos, awards and statuettes around the house, including the Oscar." And he confirmed the valuables had been removed to a safe place while investigations and a clean-up operation were under way.

He added: "We commend the crews who acted extremely well in the circumstances. It was only a matter of minutes before the whole house went up in flames."

webTitle: Pathé to offer huge newsreel archive free on internet

fields.headline: Pathé to offer huge newsreel archive free on internet
fields.trailText: From the Wright brothers' flying experiments to Mussolini's march on Rome, Pathé News documented many of the defining moments of the 20th century, yet barely a quarter of its footage made it to the screens.
fields.body:
From the Wright brothers' flying experiments to Mussolini's march on Rome, Pathé News documented many of the defining moments of the 20th century, yet barely a quarter of its footage made it to the screens.

Now the newsreel company's 3,000-hour archive is being rescued from the obscurity of its Pinewood vaults to be put on the internet, in an ambitious project to make these images of history freely available.

In Pathé's 74-year film-making history, 50 million feet of 35mm film was canned and meticulously catalogued. Since the final newsreel was shown in 1970, some of the footage has been reshown in television documentaries, commemorative videos, and movies, but thousands more hours of rushes and out-takes have lain relatively untouched in the company's archive.

Rarely seen images include Queen Victoria at a garden party, the suffragette Emily Davison being fatally injured when she threw herself under the King's horse at the 1913 Derby, and Winston Churchill cracking jokes on the Empire State Building in the 1930s.

Julian Aston, the managing director, said: "Some of this stuff has never been opened since the day the editor put it in the can."

The company was founded in Paris in 1896 by the visionary Charles Pathé and his brothers, who quickly realised the potential of 35mm film as a newsgathering medium. A London office was opened in 1900. From 1910 until 1970, when Pathé gave up the fight against the might of television news, it produced twice-weekly bulletins which were shown in cinemas around the country and abroad.

At the height of their popularity, particularly in the inter-war period, these newsreels drew huge crowds. They were the public's only visual source of information on world events.

When the last one flickered from the cinema screens, British Pathé, by now separate from its parent organisation in France, moved into the lucrative business of selling licences to film-makers and broadcasters.

Until the advent of the internet, however, it could not meet the demand from hundreds of people who make contact every year, keen to track down long-lost relatives or simply to obtain footage of their favourite film star. This new medium, Pathé believes, will allow it to satisfy this growing appetite, and it hopes the net archive will become a valuable resource for schools and colleges.

The project will take two years, but some of the images will go online in the next few months. The first will be the archive of Eve's Film Review, a women's magazine feature produced from 1920 to 1931, which Mr Aston described as a complete social history of women at the time.

"We are taking every can of film in a methodical way, cleaning it and transferring on to a digital format, cataloguing it in great detail," he said. "It's all fascinating stuff."

Anyone with access to the internet will be able to call up British Pathé's website, search the catalogue and view their chosen material without charge.

Initially it will not be in a form which can be downloaded, because of the difficulty of licensing the material, but copies of the selected footage can be ordered. A basic catalogue and a selection of images is already online at www.britishpathe.com

Fifty million feet of film

 Founded in Paris in 1896, London office set up in 1970

 100 crews in 100 countries produced 50m feet of 35mm film from 1896 to 1970

 Pathé was forced to buy in footage of the explosion in 1937 of the Hindenberg airship: its cameraman was reloading at the exact moment the ship went up in flames

 British Pathé library is the world's oldest newsreel archive

 A licence to reproduce archive shots in a feature film costs £120 per second used

 British Pathé plc, which controls the archive, is not to be confused with the now-separate Pathé film distribution and production house

webTitle: Hague delivers knockout blow - on the judo mat

fields.headline: Hague delivers knockout blow - on the judo mat
fields.trailText: Fresh from one of his more successful weeks in the knockabout world of parliamentary politics, it was revealed last night that Conservative leader William Hague has landed a real knockout blow on his close aide Sebastian Coe.
fields.body:
Fresh from one of his more successful weeks in the knockabout world of parliamentary politics, it was revealed last night that Conservative leader William Hague has landed a real knockout blow on his close aide Sebastian Coe.

Mr Hague left Mr Coe, a former gold medal winning Olympic athlete, unconscious during one of the pair's thrice weekly judo bouts. It is understood the Tory backbencher passed out while being held in a neckhold by his party boss.

A worried Mr Hague revived his sparring partner with several slaps to the face, and he was uninjured.

Mr Hague, who is a green belt, has been taking part in regular judo bouts for more than two years.

 Neil Kinnock, the European commission vice-president, last week fought off a would-be mugger who tried to snatch his wife's handbag in Soho, central London, his spokesman Steve Morris said yesterday. The former Labour leader tackled the attacker, then chased him down the road.

webTitle: Spain turns out in force to condemn ETA bombing

fields.headline: Spain turns out in force to condemn ETA bombing
fields.standfirst: Bombs in Madrid: special report
fields.trailText: Up to a million Spaniards packed the streets of central Madrid yesterday to demonstrate their revulsion at the return to bombing by the Basque separatist organisation ETA.
fields.body:
Up to a million Spaniards packed the streets of central Madrid yesterday to demonstrate their revulsion at the return to bombing by the Basque separatist organisation ETA.

The march was the largest anti-ETA demonstration in Madrid since the protest that followed the kidnap and murder of the young Basque councillor Miguel Angel Blanco in July 1997.

The Spanish prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, walked at the head of the vast crowd, accompanied by three former prime ministers - Felipe Gonzalez, Leopoldo Calvo Sotelo and Adolfo Suarez - as well as ministers and union leaders.

Spain's young, old and families with children marched peacefully on a bitterly cold but sunny morning behind a banner reading "For peace, for liberty and no to terrorism!"

Hopes for a peaceful solution to the Basque question, which has cost almost 800 lives in 30 years, have been dashed after an 18-month reprieve from terrorist killing before last Friday's bomb blast. For the first time since 1997, many demonstrators had painted their hands white to represent innocence untainted with blood.

Many of those who marched were critical of the demonstrations taking place in the north calling for Basque prisoners to be moved to jails near their homes. "The families of those prisoners can at least visit them in jail, but the families of their victims can only visit their graves in the cemetery," said one middle-aged woman.

Several banners yesterday were critical of the president of the supposedly moderate Basque Nationalist party (PNV), Xabier Arzallus, whose ambivalent attitude towards ETA has infuriated many Spaniards. "Arzallus, we didn't see you at the funeral!" read one banner.

Although the PNV condemned the death of Lieutenant-Colonel Pedro Antonio Blanco in last Friday's blast, it announced it was "suspending" - but not severing - its links with ETA's political front, Euskal Herritarrok.

Police have issued electronically created pictures of the two men who they believe detonated more than 20kg (44lb) of explosives in the stolen car that killed Col Blanco. One bears a close resemblance to Josu Ordonez, whose photograph - along with those of four other ETA suspects - was distributed last month after ETA announced it was calling off its ceasefire.

Shortly before yesterday's demonstration there were two firebomb attacks in the Basque country. One was against a civil guard barracks in San Sebastian, which damaged several parked cars. The other - believed to have been targeted at a resident Socialist politician - destroyed a building in the town of Guetxo.

Despite the renewed outbreak of terrorist violence, most people continue to believe that the only solution to the Basque question will be through negotiation.

A poll published yesterday in the Spanish newspaper Diario 16 indicated that only 29% believed the government should refuse to negotiate.

fields.headline: Mitterrand 'gave £10m to Kohl'
fields.standfirst:
German scandal deepens with report that late French president sanctioned payment 'for good of Europe'
German corruption scandal: special report
fields.trailText: The Germany slush fund scandal deepened dramatically yesterday amid reports that the late French president, François Mitterrand, personally sanctioned a covert £10m payment to former chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats to help them win the 1994 general election.
fields.byline: Tony Paterson  in Berlin and Paul Webster  in Paris
fields.body:
The Germany slush fund scandal deepened dramatically yesterday amid reports that the late French president, François Mitterrand, personally sanctioned a covert £10m payment to former chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democrats to help them win the 1994 general election.

The cash was said to be part of a £28m payment made in 1992 by the French oil consortium Elf Aquitaine to the Kohl government for the giant east German Leuna refinery and a chain of petrol stations in the region in the same year.

The allegations, the most serious yet in the Kohl scandal, were made by Germany's ARD television and the French France Deux channel after a joint investigation into the roles played by Mitterrand and Elf Aquitaine in the affair.

German and French television quoted what they said was a high-ranking informant from Mr Mitterrand's immediate circle who denied that the £10m payment to Mr Kohl's CDU was illicit.

"It was not a bribe: the money was for an election campaign. The payment was in the interests of the state - for Europe," the informant was quoted as saying.

The cash handover was said to have been overseen by German intelligence officers and to have taken place at the Richmond hotel in Geneva. From there it was secretly transferred to banks in Switzerland and Liechtenstein, the TV channels said.

In France justice officials said that a French businessman, Pierre Guélfi, who handled the transfer of some £10m to Germany in 1993, would be questioned about whether Mr Mitterrand ordered the payment to the CDU.

They said Mr Guélfi was already under investigation about the transaction, which he has said was a "commission" paid in the Leuna deal.

Although from different ends of the political spectrum, Mr Kohl and Mr Mitterrand enjoyed a long-standing and close personal friendship.

Both leaders viewed the Franco-German axis as a cornerstone of European integration and as a foundation for the successful reunification of Germany. They frequently stood together against Margaret Thatcher and John Major, underlining their personal friendship by holding hands during a commemoration of the first world war battle of Verdun, where France and German lost nearly 1m men.

They both also publicly supported Elf Aquitaine's involvement in Leuna and saw it as a transaction which set the seal on their much-vaunted Franco-German alliance. The deal is also said to have persuaded Mr Mitterrand to become more than merely lukewarm in his support for German unification.

Mr Kohl has refuted the allegations of an illegal Mitterrand connection. Through a spokesman he described them as "the continuation of a smear campaign against me". But Volker Neumann, the Social Democrat MP chairman of a parliamentary committee which is investigating the scandal, said that the reports pointed to "barely conceivable" goings on at inter-government level during the former chancellor's tenure.

He said the allegations would prompt his committee to start an intensive search for German chancellery files relating to the Leuna deal. The chancellery disclosed last month that although it had a list of the documents, most of the actual files on Leuna had mysteriously gone missing. So far no one in the former Kohl government has provided any evidence as to the whereabouts of the papers.

In France there was no immediate high-level denial of the allegations. Observers said it would be difficult to convince public opinion that Mitterrand, who died in 1996, did not do everything possible to help Mr Kohl win the 1994 German general election.

Leuna has been the subject of investigations by judges in France and Switzerland since the mid 1990s.

If substantiated, the new allegations would answer many of the questions surrounding the Kohl scandal. Most significantly, they would destroy his repeated claims that neither he nor his government was "bribeable" on major political and economic policy decisions.

Mr Kohl has admitted accepting DM2m in undeclared campaign donations, but has refused to name the donors who paid into the secret party accounts he set up during his 25 years as Christian Democrat party chairman. He has insisted that to name them publicly would be a breach of confidence. Christian Democratic Union officials said last night that an internal party audit by accountants Ernst & Young had been unable to explain the origin of the DM2m received between 1993 and 1998.

Mr Kohl has refused to name the donors who paid into the secret party accounts the former chancellor set up during his 25 years as Christian Democrat party chairman. He has insisted that to publicly name them would be a breach of confidence.

In a further development, German parliamentary investigators confirmed yesterday that they wanted to question a British aircraft industry executive, Stuart Iddes, who is alleged to have been offered at least £1.75m in backhanders by a German arms dealer at the centre of the affair, Karlheinz Schreiber.

Mr Iddes was said to have been offered the payment during his time as vice-president of Europe's Airbus consortium which he left in 1994. Mr Iddes, who now lives in Mexico was quoted at the weekend as saying: "I have never done anything I should not have done."
