fields.headline: The fine art of navel-gazing
fields.trailText: MediaGossip, Media-central, Mediainfo, Hot Copy. If you're thinking of starting a website devoted to the media, you may be too late. Some of the best names have already been taken.
fields.body:
MediaGossip, Media-central, Mediainfo, Hot Copy. If you're thinking of starting a website devoted to the media, you may be too late. Some of the best names have already been taken.

It was absolutely natural, of course. News services of all kinds have mushroomed in the past few years as writers discovered an unlimited new space for their deliberations online. There are now more ways to find out about stock markets, UFO sightings and rainfall levels in Abergavenny than ever before. The fact that sites linked to the media are now one of the biggest growth areas in America should come as no surprise.

MediaGossip.com provides links to 16 websites devoted to general media news and 10 more to "indie" sites. Its list, which includes Brill's Content and Smug.com, tries to avoid any sites that demand registration or payment from users. This proviso excludes the increasing number of reports by organisations such as the Wall Street Journal as well as trade magazines such as Billboard.

Jim Romenesko, a former coroners' court reporter, launched MediaGossip.com last May after he realised how many fellow journalists were visiting a site that offered a selection of oddball stories from US papers. The daily compilation of media stories now attracts more than 30,000 visits a week. Romenesko recently left a job with Pioneer Press in Minnesota to work full time on the website under the auspices of the Poynter Institute of media studies.

The proliferation of media-related sites over the past year has done little to deter newcomers to the market. Kurt Andersen, the commentator, novelist and former editor-in-chief of New York Magazine, is to launch a web-based news and information service about the industry at the end of March.

Andersen expects to raise between $10m and $15m this week after talking to potential investors about his new venture, Powerful Media. It has already attracted $5m from James Cramer, founder of TheStreet.com, and other investors. It has also appointed 60 members of staff, half of whom are journalists.

Andersen, the author of a novel about the internet age, admits to finding it difficult to describe the new company. But he does know that "this entity, service, publication, whatever you're going to call it" will cover the gamut of media interests from traditional print to entertainment to publishing.

Powerful Media has targeted an estimated core audience of 1.3m in the US alone. This is the number of professionals involved in the relevant industries who might be willing to pay for its mix of news, analysis and specialised services. Such people include "everyone from Barry Diller to journalists to record company workers," says Andersen. The company hopes that the broader audience who might click on to the site for its free news and information services will be "10 times" that number.

The desire to cover the many sides of the media industry comes at the right time. If nothing else, the AOL/Time Warner merger suggests the internet story is increasingly about entertainment and information rather than pure technology.

Andersen, a consummate media insider, is hardly a baseball cap-wearing net-nerd. Yet he waxes lyrical about the idea of customising news and information for individual users and providing a sort of one-stop shop for media recruitment. "I am actually excited by the possibilities that all of these internet technologies theoretically permit," he says, in a surprised tone.

There is little doubt that the growth of online media sites reflects the narcissism of the hack-proclaimed information age. Journalists are usually more interested in themselves and what their colleagues are doing than anything else.

But the conversion of Andersen and others in the US points to interesting trends in all industries, not just the media. The internet allows users to access specialised information from anywhere in the world, which it can then customise for them. Why then should they have to wade through an acreage of print to find what they're interested in?

In spite of the fact that media-obsessed websites are growing faster than you can say mega-merger in the US, they are still rare in Europe. Andersen says Powerful Media has "vaulting ambitions" to go global and will employ two stringers in London for its launch.

Domain names are important to catch the attention of a global audience, a fact that has helped prompt bidding wars for some URLs. In an email exchange, Andersen was cagey about the name of his website, indicating that the company was still in discussions with the owner of it.

The bottom line is that the name frenzy is unlikely to deter website wannabes. After all, who had heard of Matt Drudge before he broke that story about the President and an intern?

Jane Martinson is the Guardian's Wall Street correspondent. You can email her on janemartinson@compuserve.com

In an email exchange, Andersen was cagey about the name of his website, indicating that the company was still in discussions with the owner of it. The bottom line is that the name frenzy is unlikely to deter website wannabes. After all, who had heard of Matt Drudge before he broke that story about the President and an intern? fields.headline: Cash? No thankyou
fields.standfirst: It is being called 'a second revolution' and the strategy is already taking hold in the US. Channel 5 is pioneering plans to give internet start-ups the airtime they crave - in return for potentially lucrative shares
fields.trailText: Watch television, listen to the radio or even flick through this newspaper and you will see and hear commercials and advertisements that entertain, that are visually stimulating, that are traditionally creative in some way. But the internet? Now that's a different story.
fields.body:
Watch television, listen to the radio or even flick through this newspaper and you will see and hear commercials and advertisements that entertain, that are visually stimulating, that are traditionally creative in some way. But the internet? Now that's a different story.

The average advert on the net consists of a series of glaring, over-busy images, a flashing logo and - nine times out of 10 - a "click here" or "press me" button. That's because research carried out a year ago found that advertisers increased the chances of users accessing their sites by 50% if they specifically instructed them to.

And this, it would appear, is as sophisticated as most net advertising is at the moment. When it comes to the world wide web, you can forget about anything fancy: the new media equivalent of the Guinness "surfer" is hardly going to present itself at regular intervals.

The reasons for this are plentiful and - happily - largely surmountable, suggesting that this ghastly stuff is not going to be with us for ever. "It is in its formative stages," says Chris Ketley, managing director of Zenith Interactive Solutions. "It has only just begun. We are learning all the time about how to influence online customers, and ads are becoming more refined."

Indeed, so new is it that traditional agency creatives are still not really getting involved. It is more often than not left to the technical IT person at a web development company to devise the adverts rather than a properly trained traditional agency creative, hence the, erm, lack of creativity.

Frank Harrison, director of strategic resources at Zenith Media, says: "Net advertising is like radio was 20 years ago. The sort of people who used to be given radio adverts to do were the most junior or the least talented. It's just not sexy, and creatively is still very limited. So people who are IT knowledgeable are the ones producing the ads."

Advertising on the web so far has also just been about getting hits rather than looking pretty - but this is something that is likely to change as the medium matures. Last week, Revolution magazine reported on Sony's first ever web campaign for the launch of its digital camera, Mavica. "Rather than follow the herd with a selection of static banners [the panels across the top of websites] it entered the arena by specially tailoring video banners for the internet," the magazine said.

The adverts show people actually using the Mavica over the line - "save your memories to floppy disc and upload them to the world". The adverts appeared on sites for FHM and Maxim as dotmusic.com and Trinity Mirror's ic24 portal. Actually demonstrating the product? For the web, that's innovative.

Simon King, business development manager of Pixel Park, a full-service new media agency specialis ing in online marketing, explains why this is still the exception rather than the norm: "Net advertising does not have much thought about it, but it is about direct marketing and interaction. It's not about looking at an advert and thinking, 'That's really brilliant.' It's about eliciting a reaction, not looking nice."

The opportunities to advertise on the web consist, mostly, of banners. Aside from these there are buttons, or smaller boxes, usually at the bottom right, that are rather more subtle sponsorship arrangements with the site owner. There are also "landing pages" or "microsites", very small sites dedicated to specific subjects, and even something called virtual marketing, which involves highly targeted emails that exploit people's contacts or distribution lists by a type of electronic chain letter.

Given this complexity, it is perhaps not surprising that campaigns are also currently media-led, not creative-led, driven more by media buyers within agencies and web design companies, rather than creative teams, because they understand all the different opportunities.

Rob Watts, media manager at Pixel Park, says: "Unlike the traditional offline advertising route, where the creative arm of the agency will produce a full campaign to a client's brief and the media arm adapts to place it, here a campaign is media-led. I come up with a strategy then go to the creative team who will do the design."

The creatives will be told, for instance, that they have to devise buttons or banners of a certain dimension and they will simply be asked to come up with the strapline, the corporate colours and the tone of voice. But creatives need not be too nervous. Some basic rules of advertising apply as much to the net as to traditional offline media. As with press adverts, there are three ways to grab the consumer's attention: first with the headline, second via a picture or graphic, and third by means of a familiar logo that the consumer knows and trusts. Once they are dragged in, they can then be targeted with longer copy and a fuller advertising message.

Wisdom is also building regarding advertising creativity on the web. Doubleclick, a company that delivers banner ads to a network of internet sites, has even erected a list of creative dos and don'ts on its website. These involve top tips such as what colours to use (blue, green and yellow work best, apparently); how animation can increase response rates by 25%; how the "click here" button should be located on the right hand side rather than the left; and how using questions in the copy rather than state ments can increase the click-through rate by up to 16%. The ultimate block to creativity to date, however, has been the technology itself. Restrictions in bandwidth, for instance, have meant that media-rich sites, or sites that contain lots of complicated graphics and visuals - ie, stuff that excites the average agency creative - still take time to download. Given that most users find this frustrating, advertisers are stubbornly sticking to the simple "click me" approach. Harrison says: "An increase in bandwidth will mean video capability, for example. The medium is in rapid transition and what works today won't necessarily work tomorrow. The timescale is extremely compressed. The whole infrastructure and hardware and software are changing all the time."

Despite all this, some advertisers are achieving a degree of inventiveness in their net adverts. Comet recently mounted a campaign that consisted of more than 40 banners, instead of the usual four or five, each of which was specifically tailored to the separate host sites.

IBM, too, last year ran one of the most successful banner campaigns so far, targeted at students who were leaving university. The company bought up a database enabling it to talk to users about the specific university they had been to: such highly personalised messages meant that 50% of those who saw the site clicked on it.

Some banners are also dropping the click-through mechanism altogether and incorporating more information in themselves, so the user does not have to leave the host site and go meandering off into cyberspace. Interflora's banners, meanwhile, include a device for ordering and addressing flowers without users having to visit their site at all.

Whether creativity improves or not, advertising on the internet is obviously here to stay. Recent studies have suggested that consumers are becoming increasingly punch-drunk by offline advertising and so compa nies are turning more to the web as a medium. Amazon.com also found at the end of last year that people admit they are highly influenced by online ads - more so, even, than traditional advertising.

In the light of this almost guaranteed, even limitless, expansion of the net as a medium, it would be good to think the advertising will get a little prettier. It can't get much worse.

webTitle: Flu and gales drive castaways back to comfort

fields.headline: Flu and gales drive castaways back to comfort
fields.standfirst: Flu epidemic: special report
fields.trailText: The BBC yesterday admitted that a third of the participants in the Castaway 2000 series, who were supposed to be living rough on a remote Scottish island, had been staying in holiday cottages on the island of Harris.
fields.body:
The BBC yesterday admitted that a third of the participants in the Castaway 2000 series, who were supposed to be living rough on a remote Scottish island, had been staying in holiday cottages on the island of Harris.

Illness and bad weather meant that 12 of the volunteers had been taken by helicopter from Taransay to Tarbert on neighbouring Harris, said the programme's makers.

The £2.4m Castaway 2000, the preliminary episodes of which have been a welcome ratings hit for BBC1, was supposed to document 36 people living together away from modern civilisation for a year on an inhospitable island.

The first fortnight of what the BBC billed as a "unique social experiment" was dogged by problems as the castaways struggled to settle on the unforgiving island.

Some volunteers were taken off earlier this month with flu; the others left after gale force winds ripped roofs from their huts.

The series was intended to be about how the 28 adults and eight children organised themselves as a community and dealt with problems, said its executive producer, Jeremy Mills.

The "teething problems" had not undermined the project because it was unfair to expect the modern day castaways to live in unfinished accommodation. "It was just temporary until the builders finished. We had 20 people, including children, sleeping in one room, and many of them had flu. We couldn't risk it."

Some of the 12 were still in the holiday flats, he said, but he promised that once the series got started properly nothing other than a medical emergency would allow the volunteers to leave Taransay.

All the early misfortunes are being covered in the programme, which will continue on BBC1 on Tuesday and Wednesday.

"Two-thirds of the people are still there and have always been there. This is not a physical survival series; it is a sur vival series of the emotional and psychological aspects of leaving the world you know behind.

"The viewers have not been conned. The intention was to see if you could create a society for disparate people from different backgrounds.

"The very fact that things have been forced upon them by bad weather and illness is something we thought would always happen."

A BBC spokeswoman said that "in those circumstances it would have been irresponsible to keep people on the island".

webTitle: NHS labs used clerks to test patients' samples

fields.headline: NHS labs used clerks to test patients' samples
fields.trailText: Most NHS hospital laboratories are using unqualified staff to test patients' samples because of severe understaffing, an official survey has found.
fields.body:
Most NHS hospital laboratories are using unqualified staff to test patients' samples because of severe understaffing, an official survey has found.

A survey by the Institute of Biomedical Science found that 88% of NHS laboratories are understaffed and that 58% of them have to use "inappropriate or unqualified staff instead of biomedical scientists".

One in 10 laboratories has to call on clerical staff to help carry out important testing to cope with the work load.

Biomedical scientists deal with 100m pathology tests each year, playing a crucial role in the treatment of disease. They carry out all blood and cell tests, including smears, Aids and blood tests, and give a diagnosis which determines treatment.

A IBS spokesman said yesterday: "These are the people that make the diagnosis. It is frightening to think [the tests] are being carried out by administration staff."

Alan Potter, IBS chief executive, said: "The findings are worrying and highlight the fact that the NHS recruitment crisis is critical. Our laboratories are severely understaffed. Many are at breaking point and forced to use untrained and unqualified staff to cover the workload."

The institute blames "unacceptably low salaries" for the lack of qualified staff.

Mr Potter said: "It is astonishing that after a minimum of five years training and secur ing an honours degree, a biomedical scientist can expect to earn less than £9,500, a figure low enough to qualify for housing benefit and family credit, and equivalent to a supermarket shelf stacker's pay.

"It is inevitable that with employees who are severely overworked, low paid and working under intense pressure, mistakes will be made. The situation is critical and will not im prove unless these valuable individuals, and their contribution to the nation's healthcare, is recognised."

The figures included in the report are based on 1,163 questionnaires sent to hospitals.

A department of health spokeswoman said: "To become a cytologist, part of the training involves the examination of tests and slides. However, this must be under the supervision of a fully-qualified biomedical scientist. It would be negligent for any hospital not to ensure this supervision.

"However, we acknowledge that there are staff shortages within the NHS which we are determined to tackle. That is why we have offered medical laboratory scientific officers a pay increase of up to 26% for the lowest paid.

"Further, we have established a national advisory group for scientists and technicians to look at ways of improving the situation. Their main objective is to create an employment environment that will improve recruitment and retention."

Fooling the body: how trials are proceeding in UK Brain cancer

Royal Marsden hospital, Institute for Cancer Research

The idea: fool cancer cells into triggering their own destruction. Genes wrapped in a virus are injected directly into a brain tumour.

The genes switch on production of an enzyme in the tumour cells which, in turn, makes an otherwise inert chemotherapy drug start working, killing the cells.

Cystic fibrosis

MRC human genetics unit, Edinburgh, Royal Brompton Hospital, Oxbridge-Leeds- Manchester group

With 6,000 sufferers in the UK, cystic fibrosis is the most common life-shortening single gene disorder. The method under test involves spraying synthetic fat droplets carrying the 'working' CF gene into the lungs of sufferers. Initial trials with a nasal spray showed good results, but only for a very short time.

Head, neck and ovarian cancer Beatson Institute, Glasgow, and other centres

Uses the modified cold virus employed by the Pennsylvania researchers, but in a completely different way. Instead of being a courier to deliver 'good' genes into an ill human, here the virus's own genes are modified so that, introduced into the human body, it becomes a cancer killer.

Guy's hospital, London

In 1997 permission was given to begin testing gene therapy to counter the most common cancer for women over 35 in the UK.

Two human genes which play a key part in breast cancer are packaged in a virus called vaccinia and injected into the body. One gene 'unmasks' breast tumour cells while the other 'recruits' specialist cells able to destroy them.

Gastrointestinal cancer

Royal Marsden hospital

This family of cancers, including stomach cancer, causes about 44,000 UK deaths a year. A minority of sufferers develop malignant ascites, a life-threatening build-up of fluid in the abdominal cavity.

The trial aims to use the same cold virus used in Pennsylvania to introduce a human tumour suppression gene into the affected area.

fields.headline: Sun abandons Tyson fight sponsorship
fields.trailText: The Sun newspaper has abandoned plans to sponsor Mike Tyson's heavyweight fight with Julius Francis. Its involvement was displayed at a press conference announcing the fight last month, but last week the paper withdrew from the deal, believed to be worth about £100,000, shortly before an agreement was due to be signed.
fields.body:
The Sun newspaper has abandoned plans to sponsor Mike Tyson's heavyweight fight with Julius Francis. Its involvement was displayed at a press conference announcing the fight last month, but last week the paper withdrew from the deal, believed to be worth about £100,000, shortly before an agreement was due to be signed.

The fight will be broadcast on a pay-per-view basis on Sky television which, like the Sun, is owned by Rupert Murdoch's News International.

The group confirmed that the Sun would not be sponsoring the bout, but refused to comment on the reasons.

A spokesman for the fight promoter, Frank Warren, said: "We had been negotiating with the Sun over the last fortnight and they were the favourites to sponsor the fight, but they never put pen to paper on a deal."

Several companies have since been in competition to win the rights to be the main sponsor of the fight, which is expected to break previous UK records for a pay-per-view audience. The winning bidder, believed to be a holiday company, will be announced today.

The Mirror newspaper meanwhile has struck a deal with Tyson's opponent. It has bought the space on the soles of Francis's boots, banking on them being exposed to TV cameras.

Yesterday Warren attacked the publicity surrounding Tyson, describing the media attention as a freak show. "The people of Brixton showed their true feelings. People of all ages and races, and a lot of women, turned out and loved him," he told a press conference at the Grovesnor House Hotel on Park Lane, London. Tyson is staying there until Wednesday when he will move to Manchester to prepare for the fight on Saturday night.

fields.headline: Row over hunting inquiry 'bias'
fields.standfirst: The hunting debate: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw has reopened the bitter dispute over Labour's manifesto pledge to ban fox hunting by appointing potential sympathisers of blood sports to the independent inquiry into the rural pursuit.
fields.body:
Jack Straw has reopened the bitter dispute over Labour's manifesto pledge to ban fox hunting by appointing potential sympathisers of blood sports to the independent inquiry into the rural pursuit.

MPs still smarting over the home secretary's mishandling of the plan to curb jury trials, his about-face on Augusto Pinochet and his poor showing on freedom of information, last night accused him of "total stupidity" in appointing people with strong connections to the hunting world to such a delicate investigation.

Confidential information obtained by the Guardian shows that all four inquiry members, chosen in consultation with the chairman, Lord Burns, a former treasury permanent secretary, are linked to institutions that publicly support hunting or have supported the practice, while five other people - put forward by anti-hunting bodies - were ruled out by Mr Straw.

The inquiry, which is due to report in late spring, is to examine the impact on the rural economy of a ban on hunting and how a ban might be implemented. The government is awaiting its conclusions before deciding whether to proceed with legislation.

The most controversial appointment is that of Lord Soulsby of Swaffham, a vet specialising in parasites in pets, who became involved in a hunting controversy by demolishing the scientific findings on deer hunting made by Patrick Bateson, provost of King's College, Cambridge. Lord Soulsby's report, commissioned by the British Field Sports Society, was used to discredit the National Trust's move to ban deer hunting. This led to a row between him and five other academics.

Two of the other three chosen for the inquiry have strong connections with the Royal Agriculture College in Cirencester, Gloucestershire, which has its own beagle hunt - which would be banned under the legislation. One is Michael Winter, the college's former director of rural studies and author of a report about deer hunting on Exmoor being a rural institution. The other is Victoria Edwards, on the advisory college board and a Forestry Commission member.

The remaining appointment is Sir John Marsh, former director of the centre for agricultural strategy at Reading university - which is a member of the standing conference on country sports, a think-tank that meets twice a year and, according to its own literature, has as its sole objective the task of "maintaining countryside sports as an integral part of the national way of life".

According to a home office memo, the five people rejected by Mr Straw are AJF Webster, a vet at a research institute, working in the division of animal husbandry at Bristol; Piran White, a lecturer in environmental studies at York university; Donald Broom, a professor in animal welfare at St Catharine's College, Cambridge; Stephen Harris, a professor of environmental science based at Bristol university; and Baroness Young, chairwoman of English Nature.

Last night officials at the hunting inquiry strongly defended all the appointments. An official who did not wish to be named told the Guardian that he accepted the facts that had been presented to him. But he added: "Their personal views are irrelevant. They will decide on the merits of the case put forward by pro- and anti-hunting groups after hearing all the evidence."

Ian Gibson, the Labour MP for Norwich North, who has tabled five questions concerning the inquiry appointments, said yesterday: "This is total stupidity. You would have thought that the home office would have had the sense to protect its own integrity and credibility and would have at least appointed a balanced team or neutral people to look at this. What they have done appears to put on the inquiry people from institutions who support hunting. What with the home secretary already failing to follow through other matters - if he is not careful this will finish him."

Mike Foster, the Labour MP for Worcester who is promoting a bill against fox hunting, said: "I have already expressed disquiet to ministers about the appointment of Lord Soulsby. I shall now be demanding to know who made all of the appointments."

Mike Baker, UK director of the International Fund for Animal Welfare, said: "We have very real concerns over the make-up of the inquiry team. This has become a matter of trust between the government and the public, and we do not expect that trust to be betrayed."

John Cooper, chairman of the League Against Cruel Sports, said: "Our supporters, including many backbench MPs, will see this as an attempt to stitch up the animal welfare movement. The vast majority of Britons want to see a hunt ban. Mr Straw should treat them with more respect. He should reiterate his commitment to give an anti-hunt bill government time."

The home office initially said Lord Burns made the appointments, but after a denial by Lord Burns's office, a statement said the home secretary made the appointments in consultation with Lord Burns.

fields.headline: Russians find general's body
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Kremlin said yesterday that rescue teams had found the body of a senior Russian general who disappeared in fighting in Grozny last week.
fields.byline: Olga Petrova  in Sleptsovsk, Ingushetia, Russia
fields.body:
The Kremlin said yesterday that rescue teams had found the body of a senior Russian general who disappeared in fighting in Grozny last week.

Last week Russia admitted that one of its top military commanders, Major-General Mikhail Malofeyev, was missing after leading an attack on the rebels in the no man's zone in the Chechen capital.

The rebels had claimed that Malofeyev had been captured and interrogated outside Grozny, and said they had video footage to prove it.

But news agencies yesterday quoted a spokesman for the acting president and prime minister, Vladimir Putin, as saying the general's body had been found by rescue teams.

The wife of the Chechen president, Aslan Maskhadov, had earlier contradicted Russian reports that he had been wounded. Kusama Maskhadov said that she had spoken to him by phone and he was "alive and well".

Despite severe winter weather, Russian forces continued to hammer Chechen rebel positions in mountain gorges and in the shattered capital but reported little headway in their gruelling week-long drive to storm the city.

On Saturday pro-Moscow Chechen militiamen raised a Russian flag over a residential district on the edge of Grozny. But the city centre remains in guerrilla hands.

The city's maze-like streets and Soviet-era nuclear bunkers make it a haven for urban guerrillas working in small groups of snipers, machinegunners and mortar grenadiers. Between 10,000 and 40,000 civilians remain, trapped in cellars.

Malik Saidullayev, a pro-Moscow Chechen businessman, had been due to fly to Chechnya from Moscow last night to meet the leaders of armed groups and try to bring them onto Russia's side. But he postponed his visit till later this week.

Rebels have dismissed his initiative. Far from adopting a conciliatory tone, they opened an embassy in Afghanistan yesterday. A green, white and black flag with six stars and a wolf was raised over a building in Kabul's city centre.

The Taliban, ruling a country where thousands of Russian soldiers were killed by Islamist guerrillas during the Soviet army's 1979-89 intervention, is the first movement to have recognised a Chechen separatist government.

The Taliban's deputy foreign minister, Abdul Rehman, praised Chechen separatists for putting up what he called stiff resistance to a vast Russian force which has been trying to crush their resistance in Grozny.

He urged other Muslim states to rally behind the Chechen people. Reuters

fields.headline: Slugging it out over Tyson
fields.trailText: Speaking as a 34-year-old black woman, I am saddened to learn just how low the self-esteem of black youth in Brixton has become, as evidenced by their idolising of a rapist and wife-beater (To Brixton, to meet the brothers, January 22). That several women joined in the chorus of approval not a thousand yards from where Marcia Lawes was raped and murdered by a black man in 1995 is deeply shocking. A great tradition of Brixton walkabouts (Mandela, Ali etc.) has been tarnished by this opportunist thug, and Brixton youth shouldn't allow itself to be so easily suckered by a shrewd marketing ploy.
fields.body:
Speaking as a 34-year-old black woman, I am saddened to learn just how low the self-esteem of black youth in Brixton has become, as evidenced by their idolising of a rapist and wife-beater (To Brixton, to meet the brothers, January 22). That several women joined in the chorus of approval not a thousand yards from where Marcia Lawes was raped and murdered by a black man in 1995 is deeply shocking. A great tradition of Brixton walkabouts (Mandela, Ali etc.) has been tarnished by this opportunist thug, and Brixton youth shouldn't allow itself to be so easily suckered by a shrewd marketing ploy.

Brenda Ramsey
London

 I usually enjoy living in Brixton but Friday afternoon was definitely an exception. A black woman got raped and yet somehow I'm some sort of racist for taking her side.

There are many struggles against racism in desperate need of support that is not forthcoming. A friend of mine's husband has recently arrived from Africa but the government seems less keen to find "compassionate grounds" for him to stay with his wife than they were to allow Tyson to stay so that he could have a fight.

The asylum and immigration laws in this country are racist. People who are fighting this sort of injustice are real heroes. Mike Tyson is nothing of the sort.

Name and address withheld

 I was outraged when Jack Straw decided to let Mike Tyson into the country and my worst fears were confirmed when I read of Tyson's visit to Brixton and the welcome he received there. To see him described as a "hero" and a "positive model for black kids" by local people was alarming. I have retained my Labour membership through difficult times aplenty but this, for me, is the final Straw.

Nicky Conlan
Brighton nicky.conlan@free4all.co.uk

 It might have been worse. If Mike Tyson had murdered as well as raped his victim, perhaps the whole of south London would have been brought to a standstill by well-wishers.

Dr Martin Farr
Wareside, Herts mfarr@hiscomputer.org.uk

 You stated that demonstrators at the Grosvenor Park Hotel on Thursday had placards reading "Tyson, go home" (Why Tyson brings out the worst in us, January 21). The Socialist Workers Party would never demonstrate for anyone to be sent "home". We are opposed to all immigration laws, as they are inherently racist.

Thursday's demonstration was designed to highlight the hypocrisy of Jack Straw and New Labour; immigration laws do not recognise having been raped as grounds for gaining asylum, yet these laws are disregarded to allow a rapist to enter the country.

Helen Rogers
London swss@swp.org.uk

 Defenders of Mike Tyson discount the jury's verdict on him because the jury was white. Isn't judging people solely on the colour of their skin usually called racism?

Mark Pack
London markpack@cix.co.uk

 The point is not, as Ian Williams rightly says (Letters, January 22), the colour of a jury, but neither is it Tyson's guilt or otherwise. The victim was a fan who had gone willingly to his hotel room and whose evidence was unsupported. A British court would have rejected such a conviction on appeal as unsafe. The point is whether he was found guilty beyond all reasonable doubt. He was not. Of course, there are many other valid reasons for exclusion, but not the rape case.

John R Batts
Banbury, Oxon

fields.headline: Table fables
fields.trailText: I read with delight Charles Burgess's article on Subbuteo in the 1970s (In memoriam: big-bottomed Bobby on green baize, January 22). As a fellow manager round that dining room table in Carlisle I have to correct a few inaccuracies, however. It is common knowledge that the best team of the 1970s was my immortal Newcastle United quadruple-winning team under the great Bobby Moncur.
fields.body:
I read with delight Charles Burgess's article on Subbuteo in the 1970s (In memoriam: big-bottomed Bobby on green baize, January 22). As a fellow manager round that dining room table in Carlisle I have to correct a few inaccuracies, however. It is common knowledge that the best team of the 1970s was my immortal Newcastle United quadruple-winning team under the great Bobby Moncur.

Obviously it would been silly to have a club side in the World Cup but we would certainly have won it if we had been invited to enter.

Charles's memory of the tactics employed is also a little faulty. It was common practice to slyly withdraw your opponent's men from the pitch until he noticed. What would Peter Reid make of that one?

Alastair Fraser
West Mickley, Northd

fields.headline: Offending Sky's the limit
fields.trailText: You argue that BBC News 24 should be funded out of the television licence (Leader, January 21). This is akin to arguing that public money should be used to produce a broadsheet in competition with the Guardian that is then given away free to your readers.
fields.body:
You argue that BBC News 24 should be funded out of the television licence (Leader, January 21). This is akin to arguing that public money should be used to produce a broadsheet in competition with the Guardian that is then given away free to your readers.

It would be a clear case of using licence fee payers' money to distort the market. And it is exactly what happens now when the BBC uses the licence fee to fund News 24 and then gives it away to cable operators. Such tactics have deprived hundreds of thousands of homes of receiving Sky News as cable companies have substituted a channel that charges openly for one with a hidden tax. Now the BBC plans to introduce additional digital channels - including children's, sports and educational services - areas in which companies are now, or will be, operating such channels without a penny of taxpayer subsidy.

The BBC is free to operate News 24 as a commercial venture, just like Sky News or the planned ITN news channel. BBC World, News 24's international sister channel, already operates in this way.

All we have ever sought is a level playing field. BSkyB has never advocated the abolition of News 24, and it is offensive to suggest that it would trade its opposition to the digital licence fee for such an outcome.

Nick Pollard
Head of Sky News

 Sky Sport dispensed with the services of Geoffrey Boycott after allegations of him beating up his ex-girlfriend. Yet they've no qualms about screening the Tyson fight, and throwing money at a convicted rapist.

David Cowan
London

webTitle: Some helpful hints on Tony's troubles

fields.headline: Some helpful hints on Tony's troubles
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is a man who seems obsessed with his place in history and clearly desires to be seen as a great reforming prime minister. He should understand that if he accepts even the least reactionary of the Wakeham proposals, he will be remembered as the prime minister who didn't have the guts for change.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is a man who seems obsessed with his place in history and clearly desires to be seen as a great reforming prime minister. He should understand that if he accepts even the least reactionary of the Wakeham proposals, he will be remembered as the prime minister who didn't have the guts for change.

When it comes to Lords reform, electoral reform, freedom of information, the autonomy of the Welsh assembly and the Scottish parliament and the freedom of his own party members to choose who they wish as candidate for London mayor, Blair increasingly appears as a slightly less effective version of Margaret Thatcher. The hard evidence is that he is part of - or at least an apologist for - the very forces of conservatism that he declares himself opposed to.

The secret to being remembered as a radical reforming prime minister, Mr Blair, is to introduce some radical reforms. Go on, I dare you.

Tim Farron
Milnthorpe, Cumbria, t.farron@lancaster.ac.uk

 Tony Blair's ambiguous promises on health spending are ludicrous. There's nothing magic about a European average which will rise as Britain's spending increases. It's a meaningless moving target.

We should set service targets, not spending targets; say how many intensive care beds and how many staff the NHS should have; work out the pay, training and investment budgets required. Then set the tax rates to raise the money.

Ed Wilson
Stockport, ed@wilson-net.freeserve.co.uk

 You criticise Tony Blair for describing any opponent as "a force of conservatism" (Leader, January 22), yet you continue to use the spin-doctors' term "modernisation" as a synonym for whatever he chooses to do (Blair turns on his critics, January 22, and passim).

Brian Fewster
Leicester, bfewster@gn.apc.org

 Blair turns on critics, screams your headline. However, I searched the article in vain for details of how he turns them on.

Alan Wesson
Exeter

fields.headline: Repealing Scots
fields.standfirst:
Devolution in Scotland: special report

Scenes from a clerical and bigoted past
fields.trailText: Under the terms of the devolution settlement for Scotland, the 1988 local government act - which applied north and south - is being dismembered sep- arately. As far as the Westminster parliament and the laws of England and Wales go, the repeal of Section 28 (which inserted into 1986 legislation a clause forbidding local authorities to "promote" homosexuality for example in schools) has not been a source of great commotion. Repeal caused a frisson or two among the Tories and may have secured the defection of Sean Woodward MP, but otherwise this redemption of an old promise by Labour has frightened only the obvious old nags.
fields.body:
Under the terms of the devolution settlement for Scotland, the 1988 local government act - which applied north and south - is being dismembered sep- arately. As far as the Westminster parliament and the laws of England and Wales go, the repeal of Section 28 (which inserted into 1986 legislation a clause forbidding local authorities to "promote" homosexuality for example in schools) has not been a source of great commotion. Repeal caused a frisson or two among the Tories and may have secured the defection of Sean Woodward MP, but otherwise this redemption of an old promise by Labour has frightened only the obvious old nags.

In Scotland, however, repeal has become a national cause. Consultation on the relevant Scottish clauses (due to be introduced next month in a public standards and ethics bill and almost certain to be carried) has turned into an exercise in self-scrutiny and the fraught politics of 21st-century identity; with the Cubie proposals on student finance, it is the first real test of the new executive's relationship with Scottish sentiment. Repeal has become the focus of intense campaigning and raised spectres from a clerical and bigoted past some Scots would rather forget. Modern Scotland, it seems, cannot entirely escape its shadows.

Controversy has swirled, not for the first time, around Cardinal Thomas Winning's soutane. Here is a priest who, as with his views on abortion, seems unable to resist the temptation of making his own moral absolutism (shared by his fellow Catholics?) the touchstone of public policy in a plural society. He has been joined by dark presbyterians in conjuring allegations about the predilections of gay people that are not just deeply offensive to gay public servants but to all those employed in child protection and education services.

And yet the energy of this debate is a testimony to devolution. It is not inconsistent to relish the cut and thrust as a reflection of diversity within the UK and insist on killing off a useless and discriminatory law. Scottish progressives and the Scottish gay community have been challenged. It is for them to respond to the cardinal and the "pro-family" campaigners and to make the case for diversity in the face of that strain of ambiguity about gay rights shown in recent Scottish polls. On this, Donald Dewar and Scottish executive colleagues have yet to offer an inspiring lead.

fields.headline: Links in the food chain
fields.trailText: While I sympathise with Nick Child (Letters, January 22) that his battery-powered bicycle did not win a Millennium Award, what has our humble 96% fat-free carrot cake done to deserve such criticism?
fields.body:
While I sympathise with Nick Child (Letters, January 22) that his battery-powered bicycle did not win a Millennium Award, what has our humble 96% fat-free carrot cake done to deserve such criticism?

We were subjected to vigorous examination by the Design Council to ensure that we met the criteria - innovation: we were the first to produce a cake with such a low fat level; creativity: a small manufacturer had responded to the government's exhortation to contribute to the nation's healthier diet; design: the product was perceived by the consumer to be as good as, if not better than, the full fat version.

We are proud of our Millennium Award. I recommend our product to Mr Child - it will be better for him than the full fat chocolate cake he suggested.

Tom Lambie
Managing director, California Cake & Cookie Ltd Glasgow

 Nick Child would have been even less impressed if he had seen Jane Grigson's recipe from her book English Food, published in 1974. The ingredients do not include fat although the egg yolks and the almonds must contain some. Perhaps Nick should develop a low-fat bicycle.

Ken Grayling
Tharston, Norfolk, Kenarf@aol.com

 If Peter Davis, the new saviour of Sainsbury's (Company vitae, Jobs and Money, January 22) wants to redress the company's plummeting market value, he could start by sacking the team of people he employs solely to kick tins of Economy Peeled Tomatoes out of shape. These are the only tins so treated throughout the store, with the result that those of us who buy them are made even more aware of our low position in the food chain.

Reg Walker
Norwich, RegWalker@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Spare parts for ethics
fields.trailText: Your coverage of sale of spare parts for Hawk jet fighters to Zimbabwe (Labour in retreat over ethical foreign policy, January 21) has so far failed to explain the full context of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) which is principally about the attempts of Rwanda and Uganda to prevent attacks by rebels across their borders. The response of DRC President Laurent Kabila has been to train thousands of interahamwe and ex-FAR soldiers (participators in the Rwandan genocide and keen to "finish the job") and promise to "go all the way to Kigali [the Rwandan capital]" supported, among others, by Zimbabwe, whose jets have bombed Goma on the DRC/Rwanda border.
fields.body:
Your coverage of sale of spare parts for Hawk jet fighters to Zimbabwe (Labour in retreat over ethical foreign policy, January 21) has so far failed to explain the full context of the war in the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC) which is principally about the attempts of Rwanda and Uganda to prevent attacks by rebels across their borders. The response of DRC President Laurent Kabila has been to train thousands of interahamwe and ex-FAR soldiers (participators in the Rwandan genocide and keen to "finish the job") and promise to "go all the way to Kigali [the Rwandan capital]" supported, among others, by Zimbabwe, whose jets have bombed Goma on the DRC/Rwanda border.

Has the prime minister really thought this through? On the one hand, his minister for international development has led the way in providing aid for the rebuilding of Rwanda, a very poor country. On the other hand, to supply spare parts for Zimbabwe's Hawks is to support the very forces of darkness that seek to destroy it and any chance of stability in the Great Lakes region.

Alex Morton
London

 After last year's tirades against "subversive British agents" and the "gangster gays" of Blair's cabinet, President Mugabe has this month ranted about Zimbabweans "not wanting your decadent [British] culture imported to us". Presumably bits of Hawk jets are excluded.

But more worrying is the British government's continuing support for the Mugabe regime. This mirrors the Thatcher government's hand in the Matebeland massacres of the 80s. The notorious "North Korean-trained" Fifth Brigade were in fact trained by the British army from 1981, and right through the time they maimed or killed over 20,000 Ndebele people.

This figure, given by Mugabe last year at the time of Nkomo's death, may be an under-estimate and, as you pointed out last week, over 30,000 may have been executed - nearly 10 times as many as in Pinochet's Chile. Let's send the right signals this time - we owe it to the Zimbabwean people.

Name and address withheld

 If our government has contracted to finance the sale of spare parts for Hawk fighter jets and if the government of Zimbabwe has not fulfilled its obligation to pay its installments on time in the past then it is the Zimbabweans who are in breach of contract and we would be right to cancel further supplies and revoke the contract. It is very simple and straightforward if we seriously want to stop peddling arms.

J Prajapati
London

fields.headline: The killing pound
fields.standfirst: The treasury must at least state its policy
fields.trailText: The government must come clean about its attitude to sterling. The pound is at its highest level for 14 years and could rise even more according to many city analysts. Sterling is now over 30% above the level the IMF regards as its equilibrium rate and industry is bleeding. This is an unmitigated joy for people holidaying abroad or buying property or overseas assets. It is also helping to keep inflation down in Britain by making imports cheaper. Tony Blair, an instinctive believer in a "strong" currency, probably sees it as international endorsement of Labour's achievements - severing the party's historic link with devaluation.
fields.body:
The government must come clean about its attitude to sterling. The pound is at its highest level for 14 years and could rise even more according to many city analysts. Sterling is now over 30% above the level the IMF regards as its equilibrium rate and industry is bleeding. This is an unmitigated joy for people holidaying abroad or buying property or overseas assets. It is also helping to keep inflation down in Britain by making imports cheaper. Tony Blair, an instinctive believer in a "strong" currency, probably sees it as international endorsement of Labour's achievements - severing the party's historic link with devaluation.

The assumption that the overvalued pound will either go away or that it doesn't matter was put into perspective yesterday by Wim Duisenberg, president of the European Central Bank. He told the Observer that if Britain wanted to join the single currency it would have to observe the rules - sterling would have to remain "stable" in the two years preceding entry. The meaning is clear: if sterling remains close to its present level it won't get a pre-entry devaluation. We would be locked into an overvalued currency forever. This makes it urgent that the government states what its long term policy towards sterling is. The Bank of England washes its hands by stating that it is merely carrying out treasury instructions to keep inflation in check using interest rates as the instrument.

That is why it is raising them again - making the pound even more attractive to foreigners, out of fear that inflation might take off in 18 months time despite scant evidence that this will happen. Meanwhile manufacturers are bleating about the danger to competitiveness that the ludicrously overvalued pound has brought to no avail. The government claims the recent revival of exports proves that the strong pound can't be doing much harm. But these orders were taken ages ago at low or zero profit margins in the hope that the pound would come down, and exports always rise at any given value of the pound when world trade revives. Sure, manufacturing is less than 20% of the economy but it still generates most of the UK's exports. Most of the new dot.com companies are just a fancy way of selling goods that have to be manufactured. In the absence of treasury leadership, industry is forced to presume it will have to live with an overvalued pound. The only way to do that is to close UK factories and buy abroad. That is why companies like Marks & Spencer and BMW (formerly Rover), which used to buy over 90% of their goods in the UK, are being forced to source abroad.

It is possible to run an economy on the premise that Britain will merely be an assembly line for imported components (as long as multinational companies don't move the assembly lines abroad as well). This is not something we - or France, or Germany, or Japan or the US - would recommend. We think it would lead to the wanton destruction of highly viable industries which can't compete with a 20-30% price handicap on their goods. But it would at least be a definite policy and its effects could be judged. But it would be absolutely disastrous if the government marched sterling up to the top of the hill and - after the factories have closed down - marched it down again. It is much easier to close a factory than to open a new one years later when sterling has fallen to a more realistic level and the markets have been captured by overseas corporations. It is for this reason the government should tell the British people whether they want a permanently "strong" currency or not. And if not, what are they going to do about it?

webTitle: Cherie goes back to the future

fields.headline: Cherie goes back to the future
fields.trailText: It was, of its kind, an impressive film, with Keanu Reeves giving one of his better performances. I'm not, myself, a great admirer of movies set in the future, but the special effects were above average and the science-fiction story more intelligent than usual.
fields.body:
It was, of its kind, an impressive film, with Keanu Reeves giving one of his better performances. I'm not, myself, a great admirer of movies set in the future, but the special effects were above average and the science-fiction story more intelligent than usual.

But I still can't work out why Cherie Booth QC and her colleagues should have named their new barristers' chambers after the film. Matrix Chambers will no doubt have chairs similar to the ones you had to sit on to be whisked into the cinematic Matrix; but surely the barristers will not need to be fitted with electrodes in order to be transported into court? Perhaps the link is symbolic. In the movie, the normal world was awful and derelict; only the Matrix was wonderful.

But I approve of the trend of calling the new breed of dynamic, thrusting chambers after films, and I eagerly await Lethal Weapon 3 and The Terminator; or, more honestly, For a Few Dollars More, or Greed. (One barrister grumpily suggested to me that the Booth Bunch should have called themselves Mammon Chambers).

Or have I got it wrong? Perhaps the reference is to the Matrix Churchill (Arms to Iraq) affair, in which case the new trend is towards naming chambers after scandals during Tory rule. Cash for Questions Chambers, anyone?

It's only fair to say what matrix really means. The OED says it's a place or medium in which something is bred, produced or developed; a place or point of origin and growth - like the jam-jar in which I once grew an avocado. Jam-jar Chambers hasn't quite got the same ring.

So the Wakeham Commission has chickened out of proposing that the law lords should no longer be part of the legislature. One of the reasons given is really curious: that, by being part of the law-making chamber, senior judges could be made aware of the social developments and political balances that underlay most legislation.

The assumptions that, by the time they become the most senior judges in the land, they still need to be taught about relevant social developments in our country and, even more absurdly, that a good place to learn about such matters is the House of Lords are both patronising and unreal. There's also a strange proposal that, in order to prevent Lord Hoffmann-type embarrassments, law lords in future should set out in writing, and publish, a statement of the principles that will govern their taking part in debates in the House, and their sitting on cases which might raise issues on which they've spoken in those debates.

I get the feeling that the Royal Commission didn't have the time or inclination to really think about the law lords issue. It won't go away and I'm sure it's only a matter of time - five years at most - before the constitutional anomaly is removed and our top judges become part of a proper Supreme Court removed from any law-making process.

fields.headline: Case of the week
fields.trailText: On a June afternoon in 1998, Andrew Buckland joined the customer service desk queue at Barclays Bank in Stockport. When his turn came, he handed the clerk an envelope on which he'd written: "This is a robbery, give us the money, I have a gun." It was signed with his real name. In case there was any doubt, the envelope, which had come from the local council, had Buckland's name and address typed on the front. There was no sign of the gun and the clerk asked him to take a seat while he dealt with the inquiry.
fields.body:
On a June afternoon in 1998, Andrew Buckland joined the customer service desk queue at Barclays Bank in Stockport. When his turn came, he handed the clerk an envelope on which he'd written: "This is a robbery, give us the money, I have a gun." It was signed with his real name. In case there was any doubt, the envelope, which had come from the local council, had Buckland's name and address typed on the front. There was no sign of the gun and the clerk asked him to take a seat while he dealt with the inquiry.

While Buckland waited patiently for his money, the clerk had activated an alarm alerting the police. When they arrived, they walked right past the would-be robber, who made no attempt to leave even though he was sitting by the door. The clerk pointed him out and he was arrested without a struggle.

A blue plastic imitation handgun, price £1.50, was found in his tracksuit pocket.

He was convicted of attempted robbery. Unfortunately, a few years earlier he had been involved in another incident with the police. On Christmas night in 1992 he had been drinking and taking a cocktail of soft drugs. He'd picked up a cap-firing pistol at a friend's house and later, when stopped by police for drunken behaviour, he'd run off, turning and firing the pistol once. He was convicted on that occasion of an offence under the Firearms Act and given a four-year sentence.

Remember "two strikes and you're out"? The controversial law, enacted in 1997, required the courts to impose an automatic life sentence on anyone convicted of a second violent offence, including robbery, unless there were exceptional circumstances. So Buckland was sentenced to life for what the Court of Appeal described as "an almost farcical caricature of a professional bank hold-up".

Now the Lord Chief Justice and two other judges have ruled that the circumstances of the robbery were indeed exceptional. Lord Bingham pointed out: "It is certainly very unusual for a bank robbery to be carried out with the incompetence and lack of aggression shown by the appellant. No physical injury was, or could ever have been, caused. The appellant never produced his blue plastic firearm. Any distress to the bank staff must have been far from extreme." The court reduced the sentence to four and a half years.

fields.headline: Home and (cast)away
fields.standfirst:
The future of the BBC: special report

We should be glad they are proving soft
fields.trailText: The southern softies cast adrift by the BBC (along with camera crew, sound engineers, director, mobile phones and a construction team to put a roof on for them) did not even last a fortnight. Despite all that intensive selection and training shown in the first programmes of Castaway last week, the Outer Hebrides proved too much. It was unfair, said the producer, that 20 people should sleep in one room; some had flu; the builders had not yet put in all mod cons. So he decided to call in Harris Air and helicopter some of them off Taransay to the urban delights of Tarbett. They have spent the best part of their sojourn in the wilds in holiday flats, down the road from pub and fish and chip shop.
fields.body:
The southern softies cast adrift by the BBC (along with camera crew, sound engineers, director, mobile phones and a construction team to put a roof on for them) did not even last a fortnight. Despite all that intensive selection and training shown in the first programmes of Castaway last week, the Outer Hebrides proved too much. It was unfair, said the producer, that 20 people should sleep in one room; some had flu; the builders had not yet put in all mod cons. So he decided to call in Harris Air and helicopter some of them off Taransay to the urban delights of Tarbett. They have spent the best part of their sojourn in the wilds in holiday flats, down the road from pub and fish and chip shop.

The predictable response is to sneer. Just to see the would-be castaways confronting such elementary tasks of rural economy as wringing a hen's neck, milking a cow and shovelling the shit, predicted how they would shape up once they had left the cosseted confines of training camp for the real thing: wind speeds off the Beaufort scale, raging seas, illness, misery and all. Robinson Crusoe did not get to scamper back to civilisation and its creature comforts until he had learned self-reliance.

And yet, isn't there something worth celebrating in how unlike that proto- imperialist adventurer these BBC castaways are turning out to be? Their only empire is the sheep and the black deer - no natives to be exterminated or enslaved. (Gaelic speakers have been kept well out of shot.) These post-modern castaways inherit an empty space. Gulliver, Crusoe, even the Swiss Family Robinson were discovering themselves; but castaways in an imperial age necessarily gained knowledge from other, different people. The age of empire is over; now it is the inner territory which fascinates. What the producers of this show want is confrontation with inner selves leading to an exhibition of group dynamics - a soap opera in the Hebridean wind and rain.

fields.headline: A race to rights
fields.standfirst: Since 1993, more than 20 claims of racial discrimination have been brought against the Crown Prosecution Service - by its own staff.  Clare Dyer reports
fields.trailText: The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is meant to be a beacon for fair play and impartiality in the justice system. Its code requires it to be even-handed in taking prosecution decisions, not prosecuting a black suspect when it wouldn't take action against a white, or laying a heavier charge against a black suspect.
fields.body:
The Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) is meant to be a beacon for fair play and impartiality in the justice system. Its code requires it to be even-handed in taking prosecution decisions, not prosecuting a black suspect when it wouldn't take action against a white, or laying a heavier charge against a black suspect.

But lawyers in the service say there is no such guarantee of fair treatment for them. The CPS stands accused of institutional racism by ethnic minority prosecutors who claim an impenetrable glass ceiling blocks their climb to the top jobs.

No fewer than 22 claims of race discrimination have been brought since 1993, putting the CPS in a league with the London Borough of Hackney, notorious for its steady stream of racism allegations by staff. It's fair to say that of the 22 against the CPS, five were withdrawn, one struck out and another not upheld by the tribunal. Four more are awaiting judgment, but six have been settled and when crown prosecutor Neeta Amin won her case last October, it was the third discrimination finding against the CPS in less than 12 months.

Two tribunal cases are going on at the moment. Next month, a tribunal will start hearing the latest claim to be brought by Maria Bamieh, a crown prosecutor who has already won two discrimination cases and rejected a settlement offer of £110,000 which would have required her to leave her job. In the latest case, she alleges she was unfairly rejected for promotion as one of the 42 chief crown prosecutors who head up the service's regional offices.

The Commission for Racial Equality (CRE) gave the CPS notice that it would launch a formal inquiry this month unless the director of public prosecutions, David Calvert-Smith, and CPS chief executive Mark Addison showed sufficient determination to put things right. After accusations of foot-dragging, the CRE has now agreed to allow the service three months more to demonstrate its commitment to change. This week an independent investigator, Sylvia Denman, commissioned and paid for by the CPS, will start trying to pinpoint how its procedures and practices have failed black and Asian lawyers. The CRE, which has only suspended its threat of a formal inquiry, has demanded a preliminary report from her by the end of April.

The CPS has a good record for employing a diverse workforce - in London 30 per cent of lawyers come from ethnic minorities - but the top ranks are largely white and male. A painstaking selection process for the 42 new chief crown prosecutors appointed last year laid much emphasis on equal opportunities, and included the black chairman of the Bar's race relations committee, Lincoln Crawford, on the interview panel. Yet all 42 who won through were white and only eight were women, though one black woman, Melanie Werrett, was chosen as one of three assistant chief crown prosecutors in London, the next level down.

Few ethnic minority lawyers applied: few had progressed far enough in their careers to be in the running for the top jobs, it seems. Like Hackney - also the subject, in 1997, of an independent investigation - the CPS seems to have been satisfied that it was doing its bit for equality in recruitment, but failed to follow through with equal opportunities for promotion and career development.

Mark Addison admits: "Overall our representation isn't bad, in terms of the national benchmark, but it's very, very skewed. The further up the structure you go, the fewer ethnic minority staff we have. So if you look at the most senior managers, in particular at the chief crown prosecutors and the directors, it looks thin."

He adds: "If you asked a lot of our ethnic minority staff in the areas and in HQ whether they feel that they're fairly treated and whether they have confidence in the procedures that we have for looking at things like recruitment, appraisal and promotion, and for selection for special types of opportunities which might come up, I think we would find that they don't have confidence that those procedures are fair by any means. So we have a problem in terms of the way the staff think about the way we as a management treat them."

The problem is one Addison and Calvert-Smith, who took over what was widely seen as a "poisoned chalice" in 1998, inherited from the previous administration. Apart from dissatisfaction with promotion prospects for ethnic minority lawyers, staff generally were beleaguered, swamped by a tide of bureaucracy and paperwork, and morale had plummeted.

The new administration says it is determined to solve the race problem. Addison says the CRE thinks that "although our hearts are in the right place, we haven't actually put enough oomph into tackling these issues and giving a big enough lead from the top that we mean business and we want to speed up the process of reform."

Sir Herman Ouseley, chairman of the CRE, confirms: "We reached the point in December where we were very frustrated by the lack of progress and the way we were being fobbed off. But by the early part of January we felt the CPS were demonstrating sufficient urgency and commitment to tackle the problems about which we were concerned."

Barbados-born Denman, who qualified as a barrister, worked as an academic lawyer and now chairs Camden and Islington health authority, is a former member of the Race Relations Board (the CRE's predecessor). She faces a daunting task in producing an initial report in three months. "In three months I can no more than get a sense of what the size of the problem is, before I can go forward to analyse properly and prescribe what the organisation should be doing."

The job is a delicate one too: when independent investigators come into an organisation buffeted by tribunal claims, there is often a climate of fear in which staff are reluctant to be seen coming forward. Management at the CPS's Ludgate Hill headquarters were uncertain last week that they could find Denman a room there: she might have to be billeted at a satellite office at Victoria, they warned. But Denman made it clear she was determined to set herself up at Ludgate Hill, where most of the senior staff work and the bulk of the papers she will need to study are held. She plans to operate an open door policy, ready to see anyone who chooses to turn up, and will probably move later to another location more acceptable to staff who are reluctant to come to HQ. "I don't want people who might feel vulnerable to think that they're being spied on."

The first phase will be to get a feel of the organisation and find out what happened in the tribunal cases. She will go on to make findings about where the problems lie, draw up an action plan to implement change, and then she hopes to oversee the monitoring of the changes and suggest any necessary adjustments.

Peter Herbert, chairman of the Society of Black Lawyers, says ethnic minority staff still feel "passed over, left out and marginalised". He adds: "It's an odd situation when the Met and most of the police are further forward than the CPS in terms of equality. Our view is they have to take a pounding before there's an improvement."

webTitle: EU withdraws its invitation to Gadafy

fields.headline: EU withdraws its invitation to Gadafy
fields.standfirst: The European Commission: special report
fields.trailText: The European Union ended an embarrassing row over foreign policy yesterday by effectively dropping an invitation to the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, to visit Brussels.
fields.body:
The European Union ended an embarrassing row over foreign policy yesterday by effectively dropping an invitation to the Libyan leader, Colonel Muammar Gadafy, to visit Brussels.

Romano Prodi, the European commission president, issued the invitation just before Christmas, but decided after talks on Friday that Col Gadafy was not yet ready to meet EU terms.

Mr Prodi's invitation had raised hackles because he failed to consult member states, the EU's foreign policy supremo, Javier Solana, or Chris Patten, the commissioner in charge of external relations.

A statement from Brussels said Libya had not accepted EU conditions for the visit: unequivocal commitments to human rights, democracy, free trade and support for the Middle East peace process.

Diplomats said Libya had continued to demand that Israel and the Palestinian Authority be excluded from the 27-strong Barcelona grouping of the EU and Mediterranean littoral states.

The EU decision is a blow to Col Gadafy's attempts to end his pariah status after finally handing over the Lockerbie bombing suspects and securing an end to UN sanctions.

The commission said talks between Mr Prodi and Col Gadafy on Friday had "made clear that the conditions are not there for a prompt and constructive visit".

Mr Prodi insisted he had the right to issue the invitation, but EU sources said the former Italian prime minister had not accepted that he no longer has the autonomy of a head of government.

The episode caused embarrassment amid EU attempts to increase its clout in the Middle East, with high-profile diplomacy and signals that it will bankroll a final peace settlement between Israel and the Palestinians.

Yasser Arafat, the Palestinian leader, meets EU foreign ministers in Brussels today as Mr Solana reports on his visit to the region. Last week the former Spanish foreign minister went to Egypt, Syria and Israel, where he told leaders the EU was concerned about delays in peacemaking.

Diplomats said Mr Arafat would be asked to strengthen transparency and the rule of law in the spending of the Palestinian Authority. "Arafat has already responded positively," said one official. "But the message will be repeated. It is important to maintain the willingness of the donors to provide further assistance."

The EU gave more than 600m euros (£367m) to help reconstruct the Palestinian infrastructure in 1994-98, making it the most generous international donor.

webTitle: Enter Saddam to rescue Italian children's theatre

fields.headline: Enter Saddam to rescue Italian children's theatre
fields.standfirst:
HM Customs and Excise
Iraq: special report
fields.trailText: Across swathes of the Middle East, Saddam Hussein is a monster who gasses, bombs and torches villages. But for one Sicilian village, he will today become the saviour of its children's theatre.
fields.body:
Across swathes of the Middle East, Saddam Hussein is a monster who gasses, bombs and torches villages. But for one Sicilian village, he will today become the saviour of its children's theatre.

The parents of Santa Maria di Licodia could not afford the cement and marble so they dipped into the world of geopolitics and got a gift. With one or two strings attached.

In a lemon grove, Kais Al Yacoubi, Iraq's ambassador to Italy, will this morning lay the foundation stone for an open-air amphitheatre. In three months it will be ready and pupils from the neighbouring Don Bosco school will perform their first play for an audience of 500 parents and teachers.

Engraved in tiny letters on the bottom step will be a dedication to the Iraqi president.

That is one string. The other is to change the curriculum so that, in addition to imperial Rome, the children will learn of another ancient civilisation, the Sumerians, who carved a mighty empire in Mesopotamia, not a million miles from modern day Iraq.

Locals talk dreamily of their lemon grove becoming the pariah state's gate to Europe, nine years after Iraq invaded Kuwait and incurred a crippling UN embargo.

Spurning the butcher of Kurds made little sense to the village of 7,000 people languishing on the tip of an island which is undergoing its own economic crisis. The fractious council, split between the Communist Refoundation party and the far-right National Alliance, united instantly when opportunity knocked.

No criticism has come from the Italian government. As Italy is the first European Union member to open up to pariah states such as North Korea, Algeria and Libya, no one expects it.

The amphitheatre initiative came three months ago from Salvatore Nicotrae, a former Nato pilot who sells oil from Iraq so that it can buy medical supplies. The Iraqis were supportive and the result is what is believed to be the west's first Theatre of Saddam.
