webTitle: Bit of breast, love, or meat and two veg?

fields.headline: Bit of breast, love, or meat and two veg?
fields.standfirst: Luisa Dillner on why women at the British Library have refused to swallow the naked sculpture in the staff canteen
fields.trailText: A naked sculpture of Buddha's mother, it was announced on Friday, is to be removed from the British Library canteen so that women staff can eat without "feeling sick". The combination of her large breasts and mysterious look of ecstasy, not to mention the elephant hovering above her, proved too much for the female staff at the Library who signed a petition requesting her removal.
fields.body:
A naked sculpture of Buddha's mother, it was announced on Friday, is to be removed from the British Library canteen so that women staff can eat without "feeling sick". The combination of her large breasts and mysterious look of ecstasy, not to mention the elephant hovering above her, proved too much for the female staff at the Library who signed a petition requesting her removal.

Woman as curves in all the right places is a theme that runs through society, from FHM to saucy seaside picture postcards. But this was Buddha's mum, for goodness' sake. Buddha himself isn't usually portrayed as such a sexy guy - in my sculpture from Thailand, he has a definite pot belly. Did that come from his dad?

Art has traditionally enjoyed a sort of diplomatic immunity: you can't take action against it because of what it is - subjective, creative, attention-seeking. But isn't it suspicious that women so often seem to have breasts like cantaloupe melons, waists that go in and hips like those of pubescent boys?

Perhaps we shouldn't be surprised that the British Library staff reacted to the sculpture as they did. It's as if there is only one way of looking at a woman these days: with a sexual gaze. We have become so saturated with sexual imagery - and, as a gender, so used to viewing ourselves and other women as objects - that we have lost the visual vocabulary to see ourselves in other ways. Yet that gaze is at odds with what we know to be the truth about our own bodies. Everywhere you look as a woman, you are reminded of the gap between your body and what is desirable. And with each year you grow older, each baby you have, that gap becomes the size of a small canyon. So no wonder the women of the British Library thought enough already and picked an easy target. Why should they be reminded, as they tuck into their fish and chips, that women are meant to be sex objects?

With apologies to Buddha, some of this is undoubtedly Darwinian. We are programmed to procreate, which for men means picking women whose bodies scream fertility. They look for large breasts, childbearing hips and a youthful appearance. The media aren't going to promote images of older women whose bodies show the effects of gravity because, frankly, they aren't the stuff of men's fantasies. In their personal relationships, they may love very ordinary (normal) women but they won't pay to look at them.

It is largely due to breasts, for which there is no male equivalent. If men's penises were exposed to the same scrutiny as women's breasts, women would be a lot happier. It's unfair that breasts are such an everyday, leered-over commodity while men's sexual bits are rarely portrayed.

Breasts, like most of the rest of the body, are meant to be functional as well as sexy. This is a burden, especially since once you use them, they are never quite the same again. Breastfeeding, being asexual for most men, remains something many would prefer not see. In the US, the government has been forced to legislate to give women the right to do so. So forgive us if we get a little antsy about the double standard.

Meanwhile, in Hollywood, we are meant to believe that age withers the sexual appeal of only women actors. Last week Sharon Stone, whose knickerless pose in Basic Instinct established her as that year's sex object, complained that she now isn't offered the film roles she wants because, at 40, she is too old. But watching Michael Douglas pawing Gwyneth Paltrow in A Perfect Murder left me chilly. Only men would believe that young actresses find geriatric actors sexually irresistible. Old men touching young flesh is not a fantasy of mine.

If most images of women are sexual these days, then perhaps we will get to a point at which they become so commonplace as to be boring. Magazines for men such as FHM will presumably have to go a little off the wall to attract attention. One magazine recently focused heavily on that sexiest of areas, pubic hair. Esquire are planning to go even further: they say they are taking scantily-clad women off the cover. One of the editor's friends was apparently too embarrassed to take the magazine out at home in front of his family. But that's not the only reason. According to their press officer: "These images are also insulting to men."

fields.headline: Dirty protesters
fields.trailText: Here we are at the beginning of MM and our house looks like a slum tenement. One day there comes a point at which its charmingly eccentric disorder turns to hideous chaos, probably seething with germs. For me that day has come. I suddenly see the truth. The house is ruining our lives. My mother cannot entertain her friends. She is deeply ashamed of her environment and moulders alone in her room, a social outcast. Daughter has become an obsessive tidier upstairs, so that when guests arrive she can blindfold them, lead them through the grime and gloom, over the moth-eaten carpets and into her own oasis of cleanliness and chic.
fields.body:
Here we are at the beginning of MM and our house looks like a slum tenement. One day there comes a point at which its charmingly eccentric disorder turns to hideous chaos, probably seething with germs. For me that day has come. I suddenly see the truth. The house is ruining our lives. My mother cannot entertain her friends. She is deeply ashamed of her environment and moulders alone in her room, a social outcast. Daughter has become an obsessive tidier upstairs, so that when guests arrive she can blindfold them, lead them through the grime and gloom, over the moth-eaten carpets and into her own oasis of cleanliness and chic.

Perhaps Gardener is the catalyst. Now that he has moved in, another mountain of possessions has had to be accommodated, including his twig and stone collections. The words "throw away" are anathema to him. Meanwhile, down in the kitchen, the oven has died, the cupboard doors dangle and fall, the clutter spreads and residents grow crabbier. There is only one thing for it. The whole house must be redecorated, starting with the kitchen.

It is heavenly to make a decision. For an hour or so, one feels brave and determined. The brain is cleared and whitewashed. But then come the nightmares. Who will empty the kitchen while it is transformed and where will the mountain of crockery/food/cutlery/dog's bed go? How will we eat/cook/live/not go raving mad? I wake up in a panic and rush out to buy a cooker. This is our priority. Once we have a cooker, the new life will have begun.

But cookers have changed. Dual fuel is in vogue. This means gas hob and minuscule electric oven barely large enough to roast half a quail. You must lie on the floor to inspect your oven and grill. At last we find a gas cooker with double oven. Perfect. Just what we want.

It is not in stock. Neither is my second choice. They may be available in six weeks. I stamp out of John Lewis in a temper and have a scream on the pavement. I have no cooker and a parking ticket.

No roast dinners for weeks and I have automatically bought a chicken. I run round to Rosemary's house and put it in her oven. However will I manage if she moves? Will the new start ever begin?

I run round to Rosemary's house and put it in her oven. However will I manage if she moves? Will the new start ever begin?

fields.headline: Skies safer despite more crashes
fields.trailText: The number of airline accidents in the 1990s was 28% higher than the 1980s, figures released yesterday showed.
fields.body:
The number of airline accidents in the 1990s was 28% higher than the 1980s, figures released yesterday showed.

The number of people dying in crashes also rose, from 10,600 to 11,950, according to statistics from Flight International magazine. But in the past decade, the number of passengers increased by 32%, the number of flights rose by 30% and the average distance flown per journey was up 12.5%.

"This means that the average risk to passengers fell," said David Learmount, the magazine's safety editor. But some international airlines "maintain a dogged resistance to safety improvement".

The figures showed that there were 370 accidents in the 1980s and 480 in the 1990s.

In 1999, the number of fatal accidents was 48, the same as in the previous year. The number of deaths, though, dipped from 1,244 to 730.

"Crucial safety programmes are now coming to fruition," Mr Learmount said. "If the industry delivers to its potential, the next 10 years promise much safer flights for the world's air travellers."

fields.headline: Republicans battle for 'pro-life' vote
fields.standfirst:
Contest for Iowa swings right as abortion and capital punishment come to fore

The US elections: special report
George W Bush official site
fields.trailText: Party activists in Iowa will cast the first votes of the 2000 US presidential race tonight amid clear signs that the volatile battle for the Republican nomination is being pulled to the right over the contentious issue of abortion.
fields.body:
Party activists in Iowa will cast the first votes of the 2000 US presidential race tonight amid clear signs that the volatile battle for the Republican nomination is being pulled to the right over the contentious issue of abortion.

Fears of a stronger-than-expected showing in tonight's Iowa caucuses by the staunch anti-abortion Republican candidates Steve Forbes, Gary Bauer and Alan Keyes forced the party frontrunner, George W Bush, to bolster his own anti-abortion stance at the weekend.

But the renewed battle for conservative support for abortion could ultimately harm Mr Bush's chances in the fight with the pro-choice Democrats later this year.

Mr Bush had been under mounting pressure from conservative Republicans to stiffen his stance on abortion as voting day neared in Iowa. This weekend he stated that the US supreme court had exceeded its constitutional authority by proclaiming a right to abortion in the 1973 Roe v Wade case, the anniversary of which yesterday was marked by anti-abortion protests in many US cities.

By saying he believed that state legislatures should have the right to determine their own abortion laws, Mr Bush was hoping to solidify his support in Iowa, where a poll this week by the Des Moines Register showed that 40% of the state's Republican voters considered themselves born-again Christians.

By emphasising the states' rights issue, Mr Bush was also looking ahead to the first post-New Hampshire primary in South Carolina, where the same issue is at boiling point over the display of the pro-slavery southern Confederacy flag.

The millionaire publisher Mr Forbes has spent more than $3m this year in Iowa in an effort to establish himself as the leading conservative alternative to Mr Bush. He describes Mr Bush as a "Johnny-come-lately to the pro-life cause" and has recently lambasted him in campaign advertisements as "a pro-life pacifist".

Unlike Mr Bush, Mr Forbes pledges to have an anti-abortion vice-presidential running mate, and to make overturning Roe v Wade a litmus test for any appointments to the supreme court that he might make as president.

Mr Bauer and Mr Keyes in turn regard Mr Forbes as less than a whole-hearted believer in the anti-abortion cause, and they are both fighting hard to capture the conservative vote in a state with powerful religious networks.

Mr Bauer mounted the most dramatic anti-abortion campaign event of a highly charged weekend by visiting the grave of a foetus in a Des Moines cemetery to commemorate the Roe v Wade decision.

"We have taken a whole class of Americans - our unborn children - and said to them they have no rights," Mr Bauer said after laying two roses on the grave. "We treat our own flesh and blood like styro-foam cups. If we can't get this issue right, we're not going to get any of them right."

No one, including his opponents, expects Mr Bush to do anything except win tonight's Republican caucuses in the predominantly conservative plains state. But in a contest where the media's portrayal of the candidates' showings is at least as important as the actual result, the Bush campaign is now trying to dampen earlier expectations of a record win.

Mr Bush's conservative opponents have gambled most of their time and money on a strong showing in tonight's Iowa contest, hoping for a boost which will carry through to the February 1 primary in New Hampshire.

The most recent Iowa polls have suggested Mr Forbes, in particular, is building a late surge of support, which threatens to keep Mr Bush's vote tonight under 50%. Any lesser showing would risk being seen as a defeat in the all-important expectations game.

The danger from Mr Bush's perspective is that he could become the victim of a pincer movement by his opponents, with the conservatives wounding him in Iowa, and Senator John McCain, who is not competing in Iowa, then defeating him from the left in New Hampshire. Current polls put Mr McCain six points ahead of Mr Bush in the New Hampshire contest.

The wider problem for the Republican favourite is that too many concessions to the right in the race for the party nomination may come back to plague him in the presidential contest itself. A new Gallup poll shows that abortion ranks 19th out of 25 issues in importance to US voters and is seen as "extremely important" by only one in five Americans.

How the caucus works

The caucus is a form of decision making that was once commonplace in US politics but which has now been largely replaced by the system of primaries, such as that which begins in New Hampshire next week.

In contrast to the primaries - in which registered supporters vote in secret in polling booths - the caucuses are the domain of party activists and well-organised (for which, read well-financed) candidates.

In Iowa tonight each of the 2,100 state precincts (roughly equivalent to a British electoral ward) will hold party meetings.

Recent experience suggests that approximately 10% of Iowa's 1.8m, overwhelmingly white, registered voters will answer the call and brave the winter weather to turn out tonight.

Since there is a contest in both the Democratic and Republican parties this year, candidate turnout is likely to be split fairly evenly between the two parallel state elections.

Voting at the caucus meetings is normally effected by a show of hands, which are then totalled up state-wide.

On the Republican side, the result is a straight count of heads for each candidate.

The Democrats, by contrast, require each caucus to divide up the votes among candidates with at least 15% support at each meeting.

webTitle: Sinn Fein angered by claim its MPs may be kept from Commons

fields.headline: Sinn Fein angered by claim its MPs may be kept from Commons
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein reacted angrily last night after Ulster Unionists claimed that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, would refuse their two MPs access to the Commons - which was promised last month - until the IRA began to decommission its weapons.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein reacted angrily last night after Ulster Unionists claimed that Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland Secretary, would refuse their two MPs access to the Commons - which was promised last month - until the IRA began to decommission its weapons.

Downing Street and the Northern Ireland Office played down the claims, which came from Ken Maginnis, the Ulster Unionists' security spokesman. They insisted that there had been no change of policy, but that fell short of a denial.

They emphasised Mr Mandelson remained committed in principle to allowing Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness the use of Commons facilities, but, significantly, they said consultation with MPs was still under way. No decision had yet been made to bring the required motion before Parliament.

Mitchel McLaughlin, Sinn Fein chairman, said any policy switch would be a breach of the recent agreement with the government. That would send a "very negative signal".

But Mr Maginnis was confident that there had been a shift. "They will now not bring a motion before the house until there is a start to IRA decommissioning."

Nerves of politicians on all sides were becoming increasingly stretched yesterday with General John de Chastelain, chairman of the international commission on decommissioning, set to complete his latest report before the end of the month. It is expected that he will be unable to announce a start to IRA decommissioning, and that will plunge the peace process back into crisis.

David Trimble, the Ulster Unionist leader, has promised his party that he will quit as first minister, so collapsing the fledgling power-sharing executive, when his ruling council reconvenes on February 12 if there have been no moves on IRA arms. His three Ulster Unionist ministers would also resign.

He would prefer Mr Mandelson to suspend the executive, because that would allow it to resume its operations more easily if a second review of the Good Friday agreement was successful. If Mr Trimble quits, it is difficult to see how he would be re-elected under the complex cross-community voting arrangements because of the strength of his opponents within unionism.

Mr Mandelson is thought to be ready to take the initiative, but the question will be when. General de Chastelain will attempt to paint as positive a picture as possible, and he may also impose a deadline for the start of decommissioning. Mr Mandelson would be reluctant to take any action until that date is passed.

Mr Trimble was sounding an upbeat note. "What I want to say to people in Northern Ireland and elsewhere is that, even if we do have a problem and a crisis, I think actually it will be a temporary one and we will be able to work our way through it in a satisfactory way."

But Mr McLaughlin sounded the harshest republican note in recent months. He blamed Mr Trimble for creating a new crisis by imposing a deadline outside the agreement.

"I think that decommissioning has been achieved in republican terms, in that the IRA are not using their weapons. That's decommissioning for Sinn Fein."

In the first public comments by a leading republican on the suggestion that the IRA might accept sealing its arms dumps, Mr McLaughlin said: "The idea that governments would accept, and that their legal systems could accommodate, the idea of guns being sealed somewhere with everybody's knowledge and nobody will go near them - that's outlandish."

Sir Ronnie Flanagan, RUC chief constable, said yesterday that he had no intelligence reports that armed groups were preparing to decommission. They retained their capability to return to violence, although he doubted whether there would ever again be a sustained campaign.

Gerry Adams, Sinn Fein president, fuelled unionist fears with an endorsement of the current IRA membership. He told a mass rally in west Belfast to commemorate Tom Williams, hanged for the murder of an RUC constable: "We are Irish republicans. We will always be Irish republicans. We are unrepentant about the right of the people of this island to freedom."

His comments came four days after Mr Mandelson provoked unionist ire with his announcement of sweeping reforms to the RUC. He argued yesterday that the grief of the families of IRA men killed in the troubles was as intense at that of RUC widows.

More than 20,000 people attended the commemoration for Williams, whose body was re-interred in a family grave at Milltown Cemetery last week. It was the largest turnout in west Belfast since the funeral of the IRA hunger striker, Bobby Sands, in May 1981.

Williams was executed in September, 1942. Five others, including Joe Cahill, who addressed the rally, had their death sentences commuted.

webTitle: Care worker's release on rape charge prompts CPS to seek review of law

fields.headline: Care worker's release on rape charge prompts CPS to seek review of law
fields.trailText: A care worker charged with raping a woman with a mental age of two years and eight months has walked free without standing trial, angering   professionals working with people with severe learning disabilities who fear the law leaves such people with too little protection.
fields.body:
A care worker charged with raping a woman with a mental age of two years and eight months has walked free without standing trial, angering professionals working with people with severe learning disabilities who fear the law leaves such people with too little protection.

The crown prosecution service may ask the attorney general, Lord Williams of Mostyn, to refer the case to the appeal court for a ruling on the law, though that would not affect the outcome of the case.

David Jenkins, a former support worker at a project providing supported housing for about 100 adults with learning disabilities in Ealing, west London, admitted a sexual relationship with the woman after she was found to be pregnant and DNA testing was carried out.

The CPS decided to charge Jenkins, aged 61, with rape, rather than the possible alternative charge of "sexual intercourse with a woman who is defective" under the 1956 sexual offences act, which carries a maximum sentence of two years.

When the case opened two weeks ago at the Old Bailey, Glynis Murphy, professor of clinical psychology of learning disability at the University of Kent, gave evidence during legal argument in the jury's absence that in order to consent to sex a woman must be able to understand "what is proposed and its implications and must be able to exercise choice". She was citing Law Society and BMA guidelines on capacity to consent to sexual relationships.

But after reviewing the law and cases on rape, judge Simon Coltart decided that the guidelines were wrong. Following the sexual offences act 1956, he said, the issue was whether the woman consented to sex, and "consent" had to be given its ordinary English meaning.

With the crux of Prof Murphy's evidence excluded from the jury, the prosecution had no choice but to offer no evidence on the rape charge and applied to have the charge of sex with a defective - where consent is irrelevant - added to the indictment. But the judge refused after the defence argued that it had prepared to defend a rape charge, and that Jenkins should not have what was effectively another prosecution for the same offence.

Mencap, the Royal Society for Mentally Handicapped Children & Adults, is furious at the outcome of the case. Sarah Talbot-Williams, head of communications, said: "It is a fundamental miscarriage of justice against a woman who has suffered long term abuse and emotional torment. As a care assistant, the accused was in a position of trust and now, without a conviction, he is free to work with very vulnerable people. People with learning disabilities are at risk and often seen to be an easy target by abusers. The legal system is there to protect them, not side with their abusers."

Prof Murphy said: "It is well known that people with learning disabilities are extremely vulnerable to abuse and there has been widespread concern recently that they have not been receiving proper access to justice."

Nigel Turner, chief executive of the Ealing Consortium, a voluntary organisation which runs the home where Jenkins was employed, said: "There is a very strong feeling here that it had been quite proper for the CPS to bring a charge of rape and a great deal of dismay that the case did fall apart. If someone can't take the oath and can't be a credible witness, you'd like to think the court would protect them more strongly. In this case the opposite has happened."

fields.headline: Loyalist factions at war
fields.standfirst:
The shooting of a Portadown man has unleashed a wave of hatred
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Fear and loathing are as much the natural constituents of air in Portadown as are oxygen and nitrogen. Sectarian conflict always chokes the atmosphere, but the most potent poison in the Co. Armagh town now is war within loyalism.
fields.body:
Fear and loathing are as much the natural constituents of air in Portadown as are oxygen and nitrogen. Sectarian conflict always chokes the atmosphere, but the most potent poison in the Co. Armagh town now is war within loyalism.

It exploded into the headlines a fortnight ago when Richard Jameson, 46, was shot dead in his jeep as he arrived home from his roofing business. Security sources quickly identified him as mid-Ulster leader of the mainstream Ulster Volunteer Force. The hardline Loyalist Volunteer Force, formed after a split in the UVF in 1996, is suspected of the murder, and fears of imminent retaliation are leaving pubs deserted.

Mr Jameson's family deny he was a UVF member, and say he was executed because of his opposition to LVF drugs activities. He was involved in a mass brawl with LVF men last month as they marked the second anniversary of the shooting of their founder, Billy Wright.

Most people in Portadown believe they know the two men who killed Mr Jameson. The UVF has issued a death list of five leading LVF figures. But Mr Jameson's family insists there must be no more killing.

His brother, Bobby 48, is instead leading an unprecedented campaign with his three other brothers. They toured loyalist housing estates in a blue pick-up van at the weekend, armed with nothing more lethal than ladders, rollers and tins of paint. They attacked with relish each LVF mural, obliterating the message with lashings of grey emulsion.

They had done the same the previous weekend, and returned on Tuesday after LVF supporters had sought to restore their murals. They also pasted up posters, attacking the LVF as drugs dealers.

But fresh graffiti underlined LVF defiance. One mural hinted at a renewed alliance with the Ulster Freedom Fighters.

One man on the UVF death list said: "Things are very tense just now. There's a lot of anger being shown regarding the denials of the Jameson family. Reality can't be bent because of grief."

Bobby Jameson, vice-chairman of Portadown football club, said: "We want the silent majority to stand up to these thugs. There is a hardcore of about 15 who can only operate through intimidation. They are the drugs volunteer force. They have nothing to do with loyalism, and are besmirching its name."

The simmering hatred was underlined last week when Richard Jameson's 10-year-old daughter, Kirsty, opened a card sent to his widow, Moira. It said simply: "Professional job well done."

Two men have been charged with subsequent possession of the murder weapon.

webTitle: Kerb-crawler school runs short of clients

fields.headline: Kerb-crawler school runs short of clients
fields.trailText: Britain's only re-education programme for kerb-crawlers is to close after a police decision to save money.
fields.body:
Britain's only re-education programme for kerb-crawlers is to close after a police decision to save money.

Offenders attend the school in Leeds as an alternative to being named and shamed in court, provided police agree to refer them. Clients are given anonymity, but no second chance if they re-offend.

The classes cost an attender £110. They have been praised by evaluators at Leeds Metropolitan university, and only one of 80 "students" in the year-long trial has re-offended.

But the "John School", pioneered in the United States and named after the slang for a kerb-crawler, has not had referred to it anywhere near the 25 clients a month needed to be self-financing - obliging West Yorkshire police authority to finance the shortfall.

"The police say they have to save money, but they could do that by referring us more of the men they send to court," said Julie Bindel, deputy director of the programme at the university's research centre for violence, abuse and gender.

"We have had fantastic support from one station - Chapeltown in Leeds - but very little interest from others. It's ridiculous when you think of prostitution's links with drugs, theft, violence and other crime."

Calls to save the school will be pressed next month during a visit by Charles Clarke, the home office minister.

webTitle: Ski worker cut free after lift accident

fields.headline: Ski worker cut free after lift accident
fields.trailText: A ski lift attendant was recovering in hospital last night after becoming trapped in the tow mechanism of a ski-lift.
fields.body:
A ski lift attendant was recovering in hospital last night after becoming trapped in the tow mechanism of a ski-lift.

The 26-year-old man, who has not been named, was trapped for more than three hours at White Corries ski centre in Glencoe.

He was cut free after a surgeon and anaesthetist were flown to the site by Sea King Rescue helicopter, which was on exercise in the West Highlands.

He was taken by helicopter to Belford hospital in Fort William before being transferred to 600-bed Raigmore hospital in Inverness.

The decision to airlift the medical team 3,000 feet to the upper slopes of the winter sports centre was taken by staff at the Rescue Co-ordination Centre at RAF Kinloss after they learned of the seriousness of the situation.

"The man concerned became trapped at the top of the chairlift in a piece of machinery known as a 'bull wheel'," a spokesman said.

A spokeswoman at the resort headquarters at the Glencoe Ski Centre said last night that staff were stunned at the accident, which happened on the highest tow in good weather conditions.

She said the centre operated strict safety procedures and an investigation would be launched into the cause of accident.

She added: "It was a lovely, beautiful day, sunny with a very light wind. We just can't believe it. It's terrible."

The spokeswoman said that the centre stayed open throughout the incident but would be closed today.

She said that she could not comment on how the man became trapped in the mechanism but described the bull wheel as a giant wheel that the tow bars go round as they reach the top of the run.

fields.headline: Renewed call for all-women shortlists
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Labour women are pressing for a return to all-women shortlists or other positive discrimination after recognising that the next parliament will see fewer rather than more Labour female MPs.
fields.body:
Labour women are pressing for a return to all-women shortlists or other positive discrimination after recognising that the next parliament will see fewer rather than more Labour female MPs.

The party general secretary, Margaret McDonagh, is among those making the case for change as the party embarks on candidate selections for the next election.

MPs and the Fawcett Society, a women's lobby, warn that, particularly in Scotland and Wales, where MPs have moved to the devolved parliament or assembly, few vacancies in what are safe Labour seats are expected to go to women.

So far four of Labour's 101 female MPs intend to step down at the election, and more are in vulnerable marginal seats.

Women MPs are calling on the government to legislate to allow parties to present all-women shortlists for Westminster selections.

Labour used such lists prior to 1997 until forced to stop when successfully challenged at a tribunal.

Labour's first 1,000 days will today be marked with a robust defence of its women MPs.

A Fabian pamphlet, written by Fiona Mactaggart, MP for Slough, fiercely rejects the "Blair Babes" media tag. Analysing weekly prime minister's questions, she concludes "these women are not more sycophantic than men", and finds that in parliament women are "not silent" but ask as many questions as their male counterparts.

In answer to alleged failures of nerve, such as the 1997 benefit cut for lone parents, she argues "women are less tempted than men to have a public profile offered by the opportunity to rebel without actually changing the policy, and are more likely to persist with the long, slow campaign".

This month Deborah Mattinson, of Opinion Leader Research, whose research work contributed to Labour's appeal to "Worcester woman" in 1997, reported that female floating voters were significantly less likely to be "satisfied" than men when asked how the government was doing.

According to research for the Fawcett Society, women voters are keen to see more female MPs, but they suspect that the effort made by Labour to redress the balance prior to 1997 was a one-off, a "plot" aimed at winning their votes.

Harriet Harman, the former social security secretary and minister for women, last week warned her party to seek out women's votes if it wanted to retain its majority.

Women MPs calling for positive action, whether all-women shortlists or "twinning" of constituencies so as to ensure half of them choose women candidates, acknowledge that they are too late to alter the gender outcome of the next election.

One party source said: "We'll see how we go this time.

"But, if we do have some attrition in the numbers, that will help make the case for the future.

"The problem is that, though most minds have changed at the top, it's still difficult to persuade the local parties."

fields.headline: Kinnock beats off mugger
fields.trailText: Neil Kinnock, the EU Commission vice-president, fought off a would-be mugger who tried to snatch his wife's handbag in central London, his spokesman Steve Morris said yesterday.
fields.body:
Neil Kinnock, the EU Commission vice-president, fought off a would-be mugger who tried to snatch his wife's handbag in central London, his spokesman Steve Morris said yesterday.

The former Labour leader tackled the attacker, then chased him down the road, Mr Morris said.

The incident happened in Soho on January 15 after Mr Kinnock and his wife Glenys had been to see Alan Bennett's the Lady in the Van at the Queen's Theatre.

The incident was not reported to police, said Scotland Yard.

Neither Mr Kinnock nor his wife were injured in the attack.

The incident happened in Soho on January 15 after Mr Kinnock and his wife Glenys had been to see Alan Bennett's the Lady in the Van at the Queen's Theatre. fields.headline: William 'offered Edinburgh place'
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Prince William's inclination to shun the ivy towers of Oxford and Cambridge appears to have been rewarded with the offer of a place at Edinburgh university.
fields.body:
Prince William's inclination to shun the ivy towers of Oxford and Cambridge appears to have been rewarded with the offer of a place at Edinburgh university.

Provided he achieves three Bs at A-level, he could begin his chosen history of art degree course at the university next year, after taking a year out.

It was reported yesterday that the prince had placed Edinburgh first on his Ucas application form, ahead of Oxford and Cambridge, and had received a conditional offer of a place. Yesterday, Buckingham Palace said: "We have not made any announcement. We are not confirming or denying anything."

Revealingly, the spokeswoman added: "When Prince William is ready to make it public, he will do so."

If he gets the grades, he is promised a stimulating period of study.

"The history of art is an intellectual and aesthetic storehouse of fundamental and often controversial issues of almost unlimited scope," says the university's handbook.

The prince, 17, sits A-levels in English, geography and art history this year. It was widely reported that he was looking at alternatives to the traditional Oxbridge route.

When reports emerged last year that he was considering Edinburgh, the society magazine Tatler sang the city's praises: Oxford had waned, while Edinburgh was no longer the dour Athens of the north but "Ibiza, Prague and Dublin rolled into one".

Edinburgh university already has a royal connection: the Duke of Edinburgh is its chancellor. It has also become a favoured destination for aristocrats. Current students include Edward Sackville, son of Earl De La Warr; Lord Frederick Hervey; and the Marquess of Bristol.

The university refused to be drawn on the reports about the prince. A spokeswoman said: "All applications are confidential. There is absolutely no way I can say anything about any application, regardless of who it is from."

fields.headline: Gay law repeal worries Carey
fields.standfirst:
Archbiship wants 'safeguards' as cardinal denies Nazi comparison
Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The Archbishop of Canterbury last night intervened in the debate on the repeal of Section 28, raising the prospect of a new outcry over the legislation, which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools and local authorities.
fields.body:
The Archbishop of Canterbury last night intervened in the debate on the repeal of Section 28, raising the prospect of a new outcry over the legislation, which bans the promotion of homosexuality in schools and local authorities.

George Carey said that he could not see homosexual relationships as an acceptable alternative to marriage, and called for safeguards to be put in place for schools and pupils.

His comments came as the leader of Scotland's Roman Catholics, Cardinal Thomas Winning, denied that he had compared the homosexual lobby with the Nazi forces during the war; and as a Catholic priest went public about a secret support network for homosexual priests in Scotland.

Repeal of Section 28 is a Labour manifesto commitment from the 1997 election.

For England and Wales, the repeal had been progressing through the Westminster parliament almost unnoticed.

But for Scotland, the Edinburgh parliament is holding a public consultation, which has caused great controversy.

Dr Carey, speaking in London to church leaders of various denominations, said that the issue was a matter of concern to him.

"I condemn totally prejudice against anyone on the basis of sexual orientation," he said. "But I also resist placing homosexual relationships on an equal footing with marriage as the proper context for sexual intimacy.

"With or without Section 28, we need to be sure that there are adequate safeguards in place for schools and pupils. I know that the education secretary, David Blunkett, is aware of such concerns, and has been considering them carefully."

Tim Hopkins, of the Equality Network in Edinburgh, said that Dr Carey was entitled to his view, but he hoped that his intervention would not lead to the same kind of bitter debate that had gripped Scotland: "It would be unfortunate if there was a similar huge explosion about this in England."

Cardinal Winning yesterday expressed regret if any offence had been taken at his remarks, but denied that he had drawn an analogy between gay activists and Nazi forces.

In a speech in Malta at the weekend, the cardinal was reported to have said: "All over Europe an active and militant homosexual lobby is pushing for greater power and the threat to the Christian family is very real.

"I would ask you to cast your minds back to the dark days of the second world war... in place of the bombs of 50 years ago you find yourselves bombarded with images, values and ideas which are utterly alien."

Yesterday he said his words had been misrepresented: "The section of my speech dealing with homosexuality made no reference whatsoever to the war.

"The word 'Nazi' does not appear at any point in my address, and I believe it would be inappropriate, offensive and fatuous to compare the current debate to what happened in Germany in the war years."

George Galloway, Labour MP for Glasgow Kelvin, said the cardinal's words were "so loaded and so pernicious" as to further poison the debate, after the cardinal had used the word "perverted" in a previous comment.

"Cardinal Winning is not fit for the great office that he holds," said Mr Galloway. "I think that his contribution to the debate has perhaps been the worst contribution of all."

It was also reported yesterday that a network of gay priests has been set up in Scotland in the light of the cardinal's attacks.

Father Gordon Brown, of the parish of St Margaret's in South Queensferry, near Edinburgh, said many gay churchmen saw the controversy over Section 28 as the final straw.

"There are a number of gay priests like me throughout Scotland, and the feeling is that enough is enough. The word 'perverted' is deeply offensive and it seems in the eyes of my church it's all right to be and not to do."

Polls continue to show confusion about the Section 28 debate. Surveys in Scottish Sunday newspapers found that 60% wanted the clause retained, but 9% tolerated homosexuality and 62% of Catholics disagreed with the cardinal's comments.

webTitle: South Africans flown in to ease social work crisis

fields.headline: South Africans flown in to ease social work crisis
fields.standfirst: South Africans to plug gaps amid social worker crisis
fields.trailText: Social workers from South Africa will this week start work in Essex in a dramatic reflection of an acute staffing crisis threatening services across Britain for at-risk children and vulnerable adults.
fields.body:
Social workers from South Africa will this week start work in Essex in a dramatic reflection of an acute staffing crisis threatening services across Britain for at-risk children and vulnerable adults.

Essex county council plans to bring in up to 16 South African social workers over the next few weeks, with more to follow later. Mike Leadbetter, the authority's social services director, said: "You could call it desperation or good planning, or both."

While a career move from Cape Town to Canvey island may seem unusual, social work leaders say they will be forced increasingly to recruit overseas - unless the government acts to promote the profession at home.

Vacancy rates are soaring in most areas and running above 10% in London and the south-east. Many employers admit to poaching staff from neighbouring authorities, fully expecting to have others poached back.

Numbers coming forward for training have plummeted to less than half the usual intake, according to one clearing house.

It has become unexceptional for hospitals to recruit nurses overseas, and foreign social workers, like teachers, have often come to Britain on working holidays. But Essex is seeking as many South Africans as it can get its hands on.

Mr Leadbetter said: "It's not just social workers we have a problem with: it's care assistants, home carers and even some finance and personnel professionals. I have advertised three times for a personnel manager. We have now had to second somebody in from somewhere else."

Part of the problem is the poor image of social care, which lacks the public sympathy accorded to nursing, and which is regularly blamed for failing to protect children, or to care for mentally ill people in the community.

Jo Williams, president of the Association of Directors of Social Services, said last night: "We have been pressing government for some time to promote social care as a rewarding career for young people."

David Smith, of the recruitment agency ASA, which represents Essex in South Africa, said British social workers were quitting "in their droves".

Persuading staff to move from north to south was meanwhile becoming impossible because of the widening gap in housing costs. "The re sult is that virtually every London authority will now have overseas staff working for them," Mr Smith said.

The South African social workers coming to Essex on two-year working visas have had four years of training - twice the British standard.

Mr Smith, a former social work team manager, said they would quickly pick up the differences in the job and its legal framework. "The basic principles of social work are universal and South Africans, in particular, seem able to adapt quite well."

Mr Leadbetter said that Essex had previously taken on a number of Canadian social workers who had been "superb", but who had not stayed very long. "I think they found it a significant drop in living standards. They came to places like Southend, Thurrock and Basildon and found it a bit of a culture shock. We're going to be a bit more mindful of that this time."

Social work recruitment figures released three months ago show vacancies for qualified staff - who earn between £17,000 and £23,000 a year - running at 7.1% in England and Wales, but at 10% in the Essex area, 10.4% in greater London and 11.2% in the south and south-east.

The social work admissions service, which co-ordinates applications for more than 4,500 training places, says that numbers fell by 45% between 1995 and 1998, from 11,526 to 6,521. Early results for last year show a further 25% drop.

Ms Williams said: "It would be very nice, on the back of recent statements made about nurses and teachers, if the government would do something for the social work profession."

webTitle: Labour pension fund to sell shares in vivisection firm

fields.headline: Labour pension fund to sell shares in vivisection firm
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Trustees of the Labour Party's staff pension fund are set to sell the fund's shares in a vivisection laboratory amid fears of protests from pensioners.
fields.body:
Trustees of the Labour Party's staff pension fund are set to sell the fund's shares in a vivisection laboratory amid fears of protests from pensioners.

It emerged yesterday that the fund has 75,000 shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences (HLS), Europe's largest research laboratory and a frequent target for animal rights protests after it was condemned by the home office in 1997 for cruelty to dogs.

A Labour party spokeswoman admitted the fund had investments in the firm, but said the trustees were already involved in drawing up new "socially responsible" investment guidelines.

However, in carrying out a review they are doing no more than obeying new government rules requiring trustees of all pension funds to examine the option of restricting investments to socially responsible companies.

Privately Labour sources acknowledged that the revelations were already provoking a reaction from retired staff. "Labour party pensioners won't like it," said one official. The source added: "The pension fund is likely to be withdrawn from Huntingdon."

The research centre, in Cambridgeshire, conducts experiments on live rats, mice, cats, dogs and baboons for companies testing products such as detergents and soaps, agrochemicals and industrial pesticides.

A home office investigation into HLS in April 1997 found unsatisfactory conditions at the Cambridgeshire research centre and its licence was revoked for six months.

News of the investments brought fierce protests from animal rights campaigners. The International Fund for Animal Welfare, which made a £1m donation to Labour before the 1997 general election, said it was unlikely to make future contributions unless the shares are sold.

An IFAW spokesperson said: "We will be writing to the prime minister to ensure that this situation is changed as quickly as possible. It is appalling."

TV writer and campaigner Carla Lane told the Sunday Telegraph: "A lot of animal people will withdraw their support from Labour over this. They should. Labour doesn't deserve our votes."

fields.headline: Looking for evidence
fields.standfirst:
New Labour in power: special report

New Labour is trumpeting its use of research, but how much does this empirical approach really influence government policy ?
fields.trailText: Seven days after panic-button Sunday it seems a good time to ask whether this is, as advertised, an evidence-led government, making its decisions on the back of fact and causality rather than prejudice and seat-of-the-pants political instinct.
fields.body:
Seven days after panic-button Sunday it seems a good time to ask whether this is, as advertised, an evidence-led government, making its decisions on the back of fact and causality rather than prejudice and seat-of-the-pants political instinct.

The answer, of course, is that politics rules OK, however many rationalist strategy reports the cabinet office produces urging more use of data and research. Ten days ago its Performance and Innovation Unit produced two mighty tomes with forewords by Blair himself advocating more planning, more analysis, more evidence ... less politics. Then Tony Blair went on television to make that extraordinary commitment to increased health spending. It was the response of a vote-gatherer to public mood and media, not that of a dispassionate analyst. The evidence on health was presented to Alan Milburn at an Institute of Public Policy Research seminar just before Christmas and has since been ignored. UK health outcomes "compare favourably" with other countries which spend much more; money does not buy health defined in terms of life expectancy, likelihood of dying from various diseases, days off sick and so on. The evidence does not say increase outlays to 8% of GDP; politics does.

Evidence is usually taken to mean research or special study that allows you to say if a, then b follows, or at least finds some correlation between a and b. There are some shining examples of policy with that kind of intellectual integrity. The £500m Sure Start programme for under-fives which got going a year ago is anchored on studies showing how intervening in the lives of very young children (Head Start) improves their life chances.

Several years' worth of research on rough sleepers informs what homelessness tsarina Louise Casey has been saying. Ladling out soup is a lot less effective than getting them into jobs and housing. But was this empirical research only taken up because it went with the grain of New Labour's belief in work rather than welfare?

The government has put money into evidence- gathering. This year the Economic and Social Research Council is getting 3% more in real terms than last; there will be another 2.5% in 2000-01. Not all is for policy-relevant work - indeed the ESRC's newly appointed chief executive Professor Gordon Marshall says grants will be given on the basis of scientific rigour not New Labour's agenda. But the ESRC does have a new "evidence-based" initiative, asking how the vast amount of social knowledge produced by think-tanks and research institutions gets presented to the wider world.

Whitehall research is on a roll. The home office research division has got a significant spending boost. The department for education and employment is spending £7.4m on research this year, against £5.3m last. (It is insisting on practical research to tell it how education improves employability.) Among other big spenders, the department for environment, transport and the regions has an extensive programme, including revising its needs index, which is the basis for allocating capital and housing subsidies to councils. The chart shows, however, that social researchers (sociologists and similar) are still thin on the ground inside government. And the PIU is bemoaning Whitehall's lack of "analytic capability".

Suma Chakrabarti, the former head of the PIU (he has just moved to head the cabinet office economic secretariat) and Moira Wallace at the Social Exclusion Unit have brought useful knowledge from outside into their policy reviews. The Joseph Rowntree Foundation, a major sponsor of research for policy, has found the government interested even in such controversial work as its evaluation of how well New Labour is doing in cutting poverty.

There is a buzz around about "what works" - basing policies on demonstrable evidence of effectiveness. Illustrative of the new approach is Communities that Care, a charity supported by JRF, which has published a manual for deprived neighbourhoods, listing ways of improving educational attainment, lessening crime and better quality of estate life.

An influence here is the Cochrane Centre at York University which collates evidence on which medical treatments work. The new National Institute for Clinical Excellence will do more of this. Among departments the DfEE has pledged to make more and better use of the huge amount of information that government collects. But the PIU report, Adding it Up, notes ways in which cost- saving (such as a new computer system for legal aid) has reduced the reliability of some official figures.

More evidence does not mean policies are any better informed. Last month's civil service reform package was oddly innocent of the results of the big ESRC programme on the civil service - which started and finished before ministers turned their attention to reform.

There are umpteen examples of New Labour policies not led by evidence. Performance-related pay for schoolteachers is one. It rests on a model of behaviour for which there is no reliable empirical evidence. Yet next week David Blunkett is making a big speech extolling the way his policies at least are being informed by evidence - and there is £12.5m for better collaboration between teachers in schools and university researchers aiming to bring knowledge to bear on improving performance. Even if, one wonders, it undermines the crash-bang approach to education reform taken by the chief inspector of schools, Chris Woodhead?

fields.headline: Mother claims £120,000 over split condom
fields.trailText: A mother who claims she became pregnant because her boyfriend used a faulty condom will break new legal ground today when she takes her £120,000 compensation claim against the manufacturers to the high court.
fields.body:
A mother who claims she became pregnant because her boyfriend used a faulty condom will break new legal ground today when she takes her £120,000 compensation claim against the manufacturers to the high court.

Marion Richardson, 36, is claiming damages from LRC Products (formerly the London Rubber Company) for loss of earnings, the discomfort, pain and inconvenience of the pregnancy and birth, and the cost of bringing up her daughter Kara, who will be four next month. She and her boyfriend, Anthony Pugh, kept the sheath as possible future evidence after it broke unexpectedly while they were having sex in May 1995. It was later scientifically tested.

The case is thought to be the first claim for the cost of bringing up a child born as a result of a defective contraceptive.

Ms Richardson, who is on legal aid, is suing the condom's manufacturers under the consumer protection act 1987 for supplying a defective product. The little-used act introduced "strict liability" for faulty products, making it unnecessary to prove that the manufacturers were negligent. However, there has not yet been a case where a court has ruled in a claimant's favour against a manufacturer.

The case is also the first of its kind to come to court since the House of Lords ruled last November that mothers who conceive as a result of a doctor's negligence - usually through a botched sterilisation or a failure to warn that a small number of vasectomies are not permanent - may no longer claim the cost of bringing up a healthy child.

That ruling reversed a line of court judgments stretching back more than 10 years which led to six-figure settlements in scores of cases, including the cost of school fees for parents who were having their other children privately educated.

Ms Richardson's lawyers are pinning their hopes on an indication by the law lords that the position might be different where claims were not based on negligence.

Her solicitor, Carole Watts of the Norfolk law firm Cunningham John, said: "In a clinical negligence case the courts decide that it is not possible to sue for the birth of a healthy child.

"But although Ms Richardson's daughter is perfectly healthy, this case is brought under product liability legislation and so the decision of the court may be different."

The law lords ruled that mothers could still claim for the discomfort and expenses of the birth.

But in the case of a Scottish couple who had a fifth child after the husband's vasectomy, they disallowed the bulk of the claim covering the cost of the child's upbringing.

In papers filed with the high court, Ms Richardson says she already had two children, Nicolle, nine, and Courtney, six, and did not want any more.

The writ says the pregnancy led to the breakdown of the couple's relationship and the shelving of a business project they planned together.

Kara's birth by caesarean caused her "considerable pain", Ms Richardson adds, and she was forced to buy a larger car to accommodate an extra child.

To succeed, Ms Richardson, of Carlton Colville, near Lowestoft, Suffolk, will have to satisfy the court not only that the condom was defective but that the pregnancy happened on the occasion it burst.

The company may also decide to argue that she should have prevented the birth by taking the morning-after pill once she realised the condom had split.

LRC Products states in literature supplied with condoms that they "offer protection against unwanted pregnancy" if used correctly.

But the leaflet states: "No method of contraception can provide 100% protection against pregnancy or sexually transmitted diseases.

"Be careful. Condoms are very strong, but can be torn by sharp fingernails, rings or rough skin."

webTitle: Gulf war veterans link illness to chemical

fields.headline: Gulf war veterans link illness to chemical
fields.trailText: Veterans seeking to convince the ministry of defence that they are suffering from Gulf war syndrome have produced new evidence that suggests the illness was caused by an injection with the illegal substance squalene.
fields.body:
Veterans seeking to convince the ministry of defence that they are suffering from Gulf war syndrome have produced new evidence that suggests the illness was caused by an injection with the illegal substance squalene.

In medical tests only those who have subsequently developed the so-called syndrome show antibodies to this substance. The tests, carried out by the department of microbiology and immunology at Tulane medical school, New Orleans, in the United States, show that the illness suffered by thousands of servicemen and women after the 1991 conflict could have been caused by the injection. The new evidence was disclosed by the National Gulf Veterans and Families Association.

The group's vice-chairman, Angus Parker, said: "At last we have medical evidence that proves beyond all doubt that veterans are ill and that that illness is in some way linked to what they were injected with back then."

He added: "This is an unforgivable crime committed against the loyal soldiers of this country. The ministry of defence must be held accountable for this crime, which I believe breaks national and international law."

Squalene, which is derived from shark livers, has been identified in the past by sufferers as the cause of the mysterious ailment.

Gulf war veterans have long accused British authorities of covering up the results of an alleged experiment on the chemical's effects. Thousands of veterans of the conflict have claimed to be suffering from memory loss, tiredness, rashes and constant pain.

A spokesman from the ministry of defence last night said that no British soldiers had been injected with squalene during the Gulf conflict.

fields.headline: Blair's problem with body language
fields.standfirst:
John Sutherland on gesture politics

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: 'We cannot afford the politics of gesture," Tony Blair sternly instructed his (profoundly unimpressed) listeners at the "trash Ken" rally last Wednesday. Meanwhile, his arms were flailing wildly. Even on the TV clips the body language drowned out the PM's soundbites. His shoulders jerked, his eyes rolled, he tripped over his tongue.
fields.body:
'We cannot afford the politics of gesture," Tony Blair sternly instructed his (profoundly unimpressed) listeners at the "trash Ken" rally last Wednesday. Meanwhile, his arms were flailing wildly. Even on the TV clips the body language drowned out the PM's soundbites. His shoulders jerked, his eyes rolled, he tripped over his tongue.

His elbows worked in and out like Lord Groan doing his "owl of death" thing in Gormenghast (the other great disaster of the week). At one point, Tony's hands clapped together to form the "here's the people, here's the steeple" we were taught to do in kindergarten. It was oddly touching. But it was damned bad oratory.

Ian Richardson is in control of his semaphore. Is Blair? It's hard to believe that someone who takes care to cover his bald spot and doubtless consults with Campbell on the weighty question of "jacket or shirt-sleeves" would not rehearse his podium gestures. It seems, incredibly, that Blair has not learned Harold Macmillan's first rule of political speaking: mouth follows hand. As SuperMac would demonstrate: Point. Pause. "You are the Guilty Man!" Never: "You are the Guilty Man!" Pause. Point.

One should not underestimate Blair. Like the estuary accent which denies all connection with public school, Oxford and the bar, the artlessness of his body-language may be as deceiving as the after-dinner speaker's "unaccustomed as I am".

The PM is surrounded by flashy orators trained in the gladiatorial arena of the Oxford and Edinburgh Union debating hall. These champions do not flap or gabble. They know that when you are under pressure you go stock-still, lower the pitch of your voice, raise the volume, and pierce your interlocutor with unblinking eye contact.

Robin Cook, questioned by the press last Thursday about the "ethical" sale of Hawks to Zimbabwe, was a model of platform deportment. His voice sank so low that dogs all over Whitehall began to howl. His face was marble. Almost out of sight, one finger, in his firmly clasped hands, drummed the desk. Cook, one deduced, was at bay.

Not all Blair's body-language is graceless. I recall seeing him walking by himself (long before he had minders) in Pall Mall. He had just made it as leader of the party and was evidently off to some cabal at the Reform. He stopped half way across the road to let the traffic by, flashed a cool glance at the Athenaeum (no friends there!), pursed his lips and jutted his jaw - as he does when resolving something in his mind - drew himself up with a small hunch of the shoulders, and walked briskly off to his appointment. He walks extremely well - unlike Cook, who swings his bottom while pressing his arms against his sides (I'm told he has a better carriage on a horse).

One-on-one, with Frost earlier in that awful week for Labour, Blair demonstrated that his gestural strengths are those of the close-up performer. Over the length of the interview, one saw a whole repertoire: the grimace that breaks charmingly into a grin; the habit of nodding his head vigorously to drive home his points: the thoughtful interval when his eyes swivel to the left indicating that he is using the rational side of his brain (think of the Mona Lisa and your eyes go right).

Most effective was Blair's bobbing movement of the head from side to side. It denotes that he sees both sides of the question. If Clinton feels your pain, Blair sees your point.

Only the smile is out of control. Frost, who is no Torquemada, observed that 25,000 English patients die annually who would survive in German hospitals. Blair countered that two-thirds of British beds are occupied by over-65s. And, he stressed, in five years we shall catch up with Germany - assuming they stand still.

Every watching pensioner could do the maths; 90,000 old Britons will die in the interest of a healthy economy. And then, disastrously, Blair smirked. It was done, of course, to deflect Frost to more congenial topics (which it did). But to the viewer of a certain age it looked horribly callous. It was, truly, a political gesture the Labour Party could not afford.

fields.standfirst: Last night's TV
fields.trailText: Anthony Howard's two-part series Sleaze (C4, Saturday) is a sly reminder that the more the massed ranks of baby Goebbelses in Whitehall try to force us to believe that politics is getting better, in fact it's steadily getting worse. fields.body:
Anthony Howard's two-part series Sleaze (C4, Saturday) is a sly reminder that the more the massed ranks of baby Goebbelses in Whitehall try to force us to believe that politics is getting better, in fact it's steadily getting worse. If Howard had had an unlimited budget and several years of airtime to fill, he could have mined the entire history of Westminster for material and still have had plenty left over. Wisely, however, he stuck to the post-war period, the era in which he grew up and was able to observe the caperings of the ruling elite at close quarters.

The pioneer of political sleaze (although the term would only later be applied to the bribes, bungs and backhanders which MPs would come to cherish as an indispensable boost to their salaries) was a mild-mannered functionary at the Board of Trade called John Belcher. Although his colleague Barbara Castle feared she was being compromised when she was given a mere hairbrush, Belcher's antennae were less acute. He proved easy meat for the unscrupulous Sidney Stanley, a forerunner of the political lobbyists who would seethe like lice through Westminster during the 80s and 90s. Before long, the reckless Belcher was accepting such outrageous bribes as free holidays to Margate and nights out at the Haringay dog track. Puritanical Prime Minister Clement Attlee, determined that his government shouldn't be seen gobbling up perks denied to austerity-struck Britain, carpeted Belcher, who subsequently died a broken man.

In hindsight, Belcher's crime appeared to be mostly naivety, and in comparison to the high-profile sleaze specialists of recent years the man was a non-starter. There was the saga of freeloading Reggie Maudling. There was archive film of Neil Hamilton boorishly demanding more free champagne while Howard unpicked his long, murky involvement with lobbyist Ian Greer and his paid crony Michael Grills. We were reminded how the charmless Lord King bulldozed the privatisation of British Airways through parliament with the aid of friendly MPs.

Mohamed Fayed inevitably loomed large, with Evening Standard editor Max Hastings making the point that Fayed had brought the "ethics of the Cairo bazaar" to British public life, only to find that while in Cairo he could expect something in return for his money, in Britain they just trousered his cash and gave him nothing.

But New Labour's progress hasn't been entirely scandal free. Remember Geoffrey Robinson's offshore trusts and Peter Mandelson's home loan? The Tories were in power for 18 years, so there's plenty of catching up to do. Perhaps a second series in three years' time, Mr Howard?

In Clocking Off (BBC1, Sunday), amnesiac truck driver Stuart Leach suddenly reappeared at his Lancashire home, 13 months after he'd abandoned his vehicle at Hull docks and vanished. His wife Sue was traumatised, his brothers were bewildered, and the boss of the textile firm who employed him was still livid about the loss of the consignment which went missing along with Leach.

As Stuart began to experience violent flashbacks, it looked as if an elaborate saga of crime and thuggery was unravelling. But writer Paul Abbott has conceived Clocking Off as six individual stories about the workforce at Mackintosh Textiles, so he only had 55 minutes to reach the chequered flag.

In a sudden burst of narrative acceleration, we were fast-forwarded through the tale of how Stuart had crossed the Pennines, abandoned his old life, and started another family with his new wife, Marie. A solid cast put some flesh on the tale's protruding ribs, and John Simm played Stuart with a compelling edge of furtiveness and panic, but an excellent story had been brutally truncated to fit its slot. In particular, there wasn't enough time for Abbott to exploit the turnaround from Stuart being perceived as a good guy in crisis to the revelation that he was, after all, a feckless scumbag. Still, at least the punchline was a strong one, as Stuart explained how his memory came back, but failed him as badly as he'd failed both his families. "So I went home," he said. "Wrong house."

fields.headline: Life after Jill
fields.trailText: With series which have been on the screen for more than a decade, viewers usually know what to expect. But this month's edition of the long-running Crimewatch UK (Tuesday, 10.20pm, BBC1) will be unusually tense. For the first time since Jill Dando's murder, Nick Ross will have a new co-host, Fiona Bruce.
fields.body:
With series which have been on the screen for more than a decade, viewers usually know what to expect. But this month's edition of the long-running Crimewatch UK (Tuesday, 10.20pm, BBC1) will be unusually tense. For the first time since Jill Dando's murder, Nick Ross will have a new co-host, Fiona Bruce.

Logically this should be no different from the Today programme on Radio 4 continuing with new presenters after the death of Brian Redhead. But Redhead died of natural causes. Dando was removed in a manner so cruelly appropriate to the series she fronted that there is no precedent in broadcasting for what Crimewatch UK is attempting. There is a tradition in American basketball that - when famous players leave the game - their shirt number is never again used by that team. There would have been a strong case for the BBC retiring Dando's microphone.

The difficulty is not just that the viewers will make comparisons - Bruce has the television equivalent of the stepmother problem - but that the Dando story undermines the programme's premise. A series based on the idea that serious crimes can be solved through publicity knows at first hand an example of tons of newspaper coverage producing no useful leads at all. It is a bitter additional irony that one of the officers in the Dando investigation has just been disciplined for passing information to the media.

And the Dando investigation is merely one of several high-profile cases which have raised criticism of British police forces to levels unprecedented since the 1970s. From the botched Stephen Lawrence murder investigation to the head injuries inflicted on the presenter Sheena McDonald by a speeding police van, cops are having their shoulders felt by the press. Will the major factual television series about policing now reflect these concerns?

fields.headline: Top shelf television
fields.standfirst: This week, Channel 4 will push back the boundaries of TV taste with the start of an 'educational' three-part series on our sexual organs. But  Mark Lawson  wonders if it is anything more than a freak show
fields.trailText: There are two fashionable phrases which television executives use when planning the publicity for a new series: "We've got to help viewers find it" and "We've got to get those fingers on the button."
fields.body:
There are two fashionable phrases which television executives use when planning the publicity for a new series: "We've got to help viewers find it" and "We've got to get those fingers on the button."

These sentiments apply in an unusually literal way to The Clitoris Uncovered, the opening episode of Private Parts (Thursday, 10pm, Channel 4) billed as a three-part series on human sexual organs. Part two tackles the penis, which, in what is presumably a hint to male viewers, comes second. Rumours that the third episode would touch on the bottom - guaranteeing outrage from tabloids and politicians - have proved false. The trilogy finishes with breasts.

Just as teenagers have traditionally ranked sexual activity on numerical scales (from one for kissing to 10 for sex), so it is that the terrestrial television channels become filthier as the digits go up. BBC1 is the most prudish, while Channel 5 has introduced soft porn to mainstream broadcasting. The network with the number 4 has been increasingly explicit but still a little short of 5. But on Thursday, Channel 4 goes all the way to 5.

The first two parts of Private Parts are the most sexually explicit films shown on a major channel. The speakers in the penis film are interviewed sitting naked astride a chair. This is very much on the basis that Arthur Negus, when talking about a vase, liked to be able to lift it up and show it to the viewers. In the clitoris documentary, the concealed location of the subject necessitates the kind of pictures - peeled-back lips and close-in cameras - generally restricted to the badlands of the Internet.

The series presents itself as education and will certainly find its most devoted viewers among those in full-time schooling. These will be the most freeze-framed scenes on television since the disputed goal in the 1966 World Cup Final. The first film ends with a statement about the importance of encouraging people to discuss sex, but the season is mainly concerned with encouraging potential Channel 4 advertisers to discuss money: another illustration of the assumption among the minority channels that sexual content is the most reliable Viagra for ratings.

Framed by the now familiar device of facetious vox pop - market traders and old dears in a rest home being asked if they know their way around a vagina - The Clitoris Uncovered first offers biology: all embryos have a clitoris, which, in those which will develop as males, is swollen by hormones until it becomes the subject of the second episode of this series. Next comes history: the discovery of the female form's delicious little secret by dissection in the 16th century and its subsequent naming by scholars, initially as the amor veneris.

As is traditional in such documentaries, the sexual experts consulted generally look like the kind of people more likely to retire alone to bed with a warm drink. But perhaps this is equivalent to the phenomenon by which most of the people who own football clubs wouldn't know what to do if you threw them a ball.

But this seriousness is merely foreplay for the freak-show which the documentary really is. We meet Steve McIntyre, an artist who specialises in female genitals. Steve has made a chest of drawers on which the handles are moulded from labias. This is followed by film of a session which in other artistic circumstances would be called sittings. Steve is slapping liquid latex between his model's legs. It strikes you that they should start an artistic award for him. It might be called The Turn-Off Prize.

The attempt to ensure that viewers don't turn off continues with further ghoulish prurience. At a sort of gynaecological coffee morning in America, women expose their genitals for photography and commentary by an expert called Betty. Like a Brian Sewell of the vagina, she reviews the lower contours of her guests: "This to me is like art deco. It's simple but it's graceful." Sadly, there is no equivalent critic in the penis film, where interesting remarks could be made about the hang.

Like many contemporary documentaries, this feels as if it was researched by giving a trigger word to an internet search engine. Certainly no human mind seems likely to have made the connection between the clitoris and the subjects of the film's last two sections: body-piercing and androgyny.

Seeking something more unusual than an ear-stud or nose-ring, a young London woman endures jewellery through her clitoral hood. "I'm celebrating my genitals", she declares. The main guests at this celebration may have ended up feeling rather sore and hungover.

The programme then visits a group of androgynous Americans who, as Churchill is supposed to have said about the MP called Bossom (or, in some versions of the anecdote, Cunis), were neither one thing nor the other. When one of the semi-men began to demonstrate the use of a vacuum pump to make his half-way house into a tower, British documentary reached a new level of sleazy cynicism.

The point of The Clitoris Uncovered is supposed to be to help women and men discover a small fleshy button they rarely touch. But the feeling never leaves you that its true motivation is to guide the fingers of leery, beery men towards a small plastic button which their fingers usually miss: the one on their channel-changers marked 4.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Master Of The Abyss
fields.body:
Master Of The Abyss

10pm, National Geographic

At the start of the last century, the deep sea was a dark world of uncharted waters. This documentary looks at the pioneering work of William Beebe to explore the oceans. In 1934, with designer Otis Barton, he built the Bathysphere, a huge submersible steel ball, with walls over a foot thick to withstand the enormous underwater pressure. The risky maiden voyage allowed them access to unseen creatures, opening the way for an era of exploration and, later, shows like this.

Dick Tracy

(Warren Beatty, 1990)

10am, 5.45pm, Sky Premier

Beatty's version of square-jawed Dick Tracy is firmly rooted in the detective's comic-strip origins. He creates a 30s mobsterland of gleaming night-time city streets and livid costumery. Beatty, as Tracy, is impeccable in bright yellow overcoat; Al Pacino is Richard III-like as crimelord Big Boy Caprice, Dustin Hoffman is furtive supergrass "Mumbles", and taking the biscuit is Madonna as nightclub floozy Breathless Mahoney. An extraordinary visual experience; it hardly matters that there's no emotional involvement.

She-Devil

(Susan Seidelman, 1989)

9pm, 3am, Carlton Cinema

A smooth American adaptation that lacks the satanic majesty of Fay Weldon's caustic novel. Still, Roseanne Barr's TV incarnation as the housewife from hell stands her in good stead: plump, dull, and abandoned by husband Ed Begley Jr for slim and elegant romantic novelist Meryl Streep.

Under The Skin

(Carine Adler, 1997)

10pm, FilmFour

A raw and uncompromising study of grief and its emotional twists and turns. Samantha Morton plays Iris, who on the death of her mother (Rita Tushingham), dumps her boyfriend (Matthew Delamere), picks an argument over mum's ashes with her pregnant sister Rose (Claire Rushbrook) and launches into a series of one-night stands.
