webTitle: Work experience: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: Chris Rock in New Jack City (Mario Van Peebles, 1991)
fields.body:
Chris Rock in New Jack City (Mario Van Peebles, 1991)

Who? Bedford-Stuyvesant-born over-achiever - a leading stand-up comic (he starred on Saturday Night Live with Adam Sandler, David Spade and the late Chris Farley), he's also the host of his own Emmy-award-winning show and recently played Rufus, the 13th Apostle, in Kevin Smith's Dogma. And, unlike most comedians who also attempt to act, he is both funny and a damn fine actor - a reputation as such which will only be helped by his role in Nurse Betty, the new film from Neil LaBute.

The role: Pookie, petty drug-dealer turned crackhead turned police informant for tough-but-fair "New Jack cop" Scotty Appleton (Ice-T). Pookie helps Appleton with his mission to take down drug kingpin Nino Brown (Wesley Snipes) by taking a job in his "organisation". Rock, aged 25 at the time, is remarkably fresh-faced, even when suffering the ravages of withdrawal.

Best Line: When Brown first sees him after his swift descent into basehead-dom, Pookie admits "I know I look like stir-fried shit, man".

Cringe factor: Quite the opposite - watching this makes you realise just how capable an actor Rock is.

Other wannabes: As well as Ice-T, there's a gaggle of rap artists making cameo appearances, including Flavor Flav, Keith Sweat and Fab Five Freddy.

Critical judgement: "Chris Rock, whose talents have so far been wasted on Saturday Night Live, gives a nervy, almost childlike performance as a former crackhead", said Hal Hinson in The Washington Post.

Also not starring in: Beverly Hills Cop 2 (1987) as "Parking Valet", and as "Rib Joint Customer" in blaxploitation spoof I'm Gonna Git You Sucka the following year.

New Jack City, Sky Cinema, Sunday January 30, 10.10pm

fields.headline: DTI to investigate Robinson 'grant fraud'
fields.trailText: The department of trade and industry said last night that it would extend its investigation into the business affairs of Geoffrey Robinson to include claims that the former paymaster general fraudulently misled the department about £400,000 worth of government grants for a company he chaired.
fields.body:
The department of trade and industry said last night that it would extend its investigation into the business affairs of Geoffrey Robinson to include claims that the former paymaster general fraudulently misled the department about £400,000 worth of government grants for a company he chaired.

Allegations by Max Ayriss, former chief accountant at Mr Robinson's failed engineering firm TransTec, and by the company's former sales manager, Peter Dickinson, are to be examined by the inquiry into the collapsed firm, announced by the trade secretary, Stephen Byers, last week. Both former employees will be questioned by the DTI.

Mr Ayriss told the Guardian last night that quarterly returns to the DTI contained false and misleading information in the years 1986 to 1988, when Mr Robinson was trying to build TransTec - which he founded - into a sizeable concern. He alleged that Mr Robinson gave instructions that grant applications to the DTI were to be falsified to claim the maximum amount available each quarter.

During the late 80s TransTec was eligible for grants for research and development. The DTI would reimburse research spending up to a certain amount every three months. Mr Ayriss said that TransTec always claimed "the maximum amount", and when its own spending did not justify this "the cost coding would be transferred". Routine labour and material expenditure on manufacturing would be reclassified as research and development on the returns submitted to the DTI.

The department said in a statement: "Max Ayriss and Peter Dickinson have made serious allegations concerning grants to TransTec. Officials from the DTI will be inviting both men in for interview this week and will also ask them to provide any evidence they might have. The department will then take whatever action is appropriate and make this decision public."

Last week Mr Byers appointed two inspectors to investigate the recent history of TransTec, which collapsed just before Christmas after its bank, HSBC, learned that a £12m claim against the company had been concealed in the accounts. But last night the Tory industry spokeswoman, Angela Browning MP, said the inspectors' remit may be too narrow and it is possible "we should be looking at some form of judicial inquiry" into the whole of Mr Robinson's career, in both public and private industry.

One of her parliamentary questions to Mr Byers relates to an allegation made by Mr Ayriss. He said that in March 1988 Mr Robinson obtained a £30,000 grant to buy a building at Coleshill, Birmingham, near TransTec's office's, which Mr Robinson intended to let.

Mr Ayriss said this was "not in the spirit" in which grants were made and that it led to his departure from TransTec.

Mr Ayriss said that for years afterwards he expected a visit from the police about his two years as TransTec's accountant. As a defence he had copied all the relevant documents before leaving the company, which he kept wrapped in a blanket in a wardrobe.

Mr Ayriss - who first met Mr Robinson during the latter's period as chief executive of the ill-fated Meriden Motorcycle Co-operative in the late 70s - now works as financial controller for a company in Birmingham.

Mr Robinson could not be contacted last night.

Mr Ayriss said this was "not in the spirit" in which grants were made and that it led to his departure from TransTec. Mr Ayriss said that for years afterwards he expected a visit from the police about his two years as TransTec's accountant. As a defence he had copied all the relevant documents before leaving the company, which he kept wrapped in a blanket in a wardrobe. fields.headline: Livingstone offers Jackson deputy's role
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has moved to cement his developing alliance with former transport minister Glenda Jackson by promising to appoint her his deputy, and as chairwoman of the Metropolitan Police authority and roving ambassador for the capital, if he is elected mayor of London.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has moved to cement his developing alliance with former transport minister Glenda Jackson by promising to appoint her his deputy, and as chairwoman of the Metropolitan Police authority and roving ambassador for the capital, if he is elected mayor of London.

The unconditional triple offer is made in a letter today to all London constituency Labour parties, backed by a demand that Labour add Ms Jackson to the party's "top-up" list of candidates for the London assembly elections so she can be given the deputy's job.

The Brent East MP's pledge - aimed, he says, at mobilising Labour and Londoners "behind a united team" - was described by Ms Jackson's spokesman yesterday as welcome and flattering.

But the spokesman added that, while she would not rule out taking a mayoral job if she were defeated, she was "not accepting any offers from either of the other candidates at this stage".

Mr Livingstone's promise, which follows a failed attempt by former health secretary Frank Dobson to woo Ms Jackson with a less exalted job offer earlier this month, comes at the start of what could prove to be the most important week of the mayoral contest.

Ballot papers will be posted to all paid-up Labour party members in London mid-week, and all the available polling and balloting evidence suggests that the Labour hierarchy's recent onslaught on Mr Livingstone has done little to dent his commanding lead over Mr Dobson.

However, individual members account for only one third of Labour's mayoral electoral college. In the affiliated organisations' section, three unions and one co-op organisation are not balloting and the MPs' and MEPs' section is expected to deliver an overwhelming majority for Mr Dobson.

The overall result is therefore expected by all camps to be close and the second preferences cast by Ms Jackson's supporters could prove decisive.

Ms Jackson is holding a separate ballot of Labour party members in her Hampstead and Highgate constituency to decide which way to cast her own second preference. The expectation is that the majority will opt for Mr Livingstone.

How far that will influence other Jackson supporters remains to be seen. A member of her campaign team declared yesterday that Ms Jackson was "now effectively the kingmaker".

In his letter to London Labour constituencies, Mr Livingstone said Ms Jackson had "won both widespread affection and respect from Londoners who have been impressed by her honesty and forthrightness".

He also said that, if elected, he would ask Mr Dobson to join his cabinet to "coordinate the fight against poverty in London," and offer Trevor Phillips, Mr Dobson's running-mate, the job of vice-chairman of the police authority.

If Mr Livingstone were selected as Labour's candidate, he would ask Labour's vetting panel to "respect my choice for deputy" and put Ms Jackson first on Labour's top-up list of assembly candidates, moving Mr Phillips into second place.

A spokesman for Mr Dobson said the former health secretary was not in the business of offering jobs to other candidates. But he added: "Let's see what the situation is in May and whether other people show themselves to be team players."

 Mr Livingstone yesterday accused the Dobson camp of a crude smear attempt over his earnings outside parliament, writes Kevin Maguire.

Details of Mr Livingstone's financial affairs have been circulated by a prominent Dobson supporter.

The former GLC leader was branded a "hypocrite" for channelling earnings on top of his £47,000 MP's salary, mainly from journalism, into his Brighton-based company Localaction Ltd.

The pro-Dobson figure claimed the manoeuvre meant 30% corporation tax was due instead of income tax at 40%, while the Brent East MP advocates a new 50% top rate for high earners. And the Livingstone critic said the company would escape higher businesses taxes in the capital proposed by the leftwinger.

Mr Livingstone denied using the company to avoid personal tax and said his income from the firm was taxed at the normal rate.

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Professor Terence Morris writes: Professor Roger Hood's rejoinder (January 11) to my obituary of Professor Sir Leon Radzinowicz (January 1) requires a response on three points.
fields.body:
Professor Terence Morris writes: Professor Roger Hood's rejoinder (January 11) to my obituary of Professor Sir Leon Radzinowicz (January 1) requires a response on three points.

First, the choice of Cambridge, rather than London, for the first institute of criminology. My account relies heavily upon Radzinowicz's own, commendably frank, account of the history of the Cambridge institute, published by the Stationery Office in 1988 (characteristically) subtitled "a report". If there are now "published Home Office papers" - to which Professor Hood refers and which contradict that account - I must admit ignorance of them.

Second, Radzinowicz as an "absentee editor". That would have been unthinkable, given his personality. I attributed that claim to his enemies. While he did actually have some, I was never one of them, nor, to the best of my knowledge, was he ever among mine. Indeed, I noted the "five massive volumes" of the History Of The English Criminal Law as standing "testimony to his prodigious industry".

Third, Radzinowicz and the Mountbatten report. I debated this issue with Radzinowicz when I gave oral evidence to his sub-committee. Mountbatten's proposals were selectively applied after the dispersal policy had been adopted, with the result that he was most unfairly blamed for results he had never intended.

Through a Fleet Street intermediary, I was asked to put Mountbatten's side of the story vicariously. The resulting articles in the Times and the Observer were based upon many hours in conversation with him, which revealed the complexities of the issue. Nevertheless, I remain firm in my judgment that subsequent events were to prove that the dispersal policy favoured by Radzinowicz was no more flawless in execution than the unimplemented proposals of Mountbatten might have been.

Comments by several correspondents suggest that I may not have been entirely unsuccessful in my attempt at an honest portrait of an extraordinary man, certainly a genius, who, notwithstanding his shortcomings, I came to like and admire. I am saddened that Professor Hood appears to dismiss my efforts as lès majesté.

fields.headline: Edward Hollamby
fields.standfirst: Public sector architect who supported high-rise housing, but became an early advocate of conservation
fields.trailText: Edward 'Ted' Hollamby , who has died aged 78, was very much an architect of the 20th century, a public servant who believed not just in high quality architecture but in the existence and nurturing of the public realm, of public architecture and civic design.
fields.body:
Edward 'Ted' Hollamby , who has died aged 78, was very much an architect of the 20th century, a public servant who believed not just in high quality architecture but in the existence and nurturing of the public realm, of public architecture and civic design.

If these words sound old fashioned, that is because Hollamby, educated first at the Hammersmith School of Arts & Crafts, was also a lifelong devotee of the great socialist arts & crafts thinker and doer, William Morris. In 1952, Hollamby, a founder member of the William Morris Society, bought the Red House, Bexleyheath. This important brick building was designed by Philip Webb for Morris in 1859. Its influence was out of all proportion to its size. Here was a modern yeoman's home, asymmetrically arranged, its style drawn from the vernacular. It became a kind of touchstone and even a shrine for arts & crafts practioners.

Hollamby and his wife Doris, whom he married in 1941, and with whom he had three children, were devoted to the Red House, and to them we owe its meticulous restoration. At the time they moved in the property was in a shabby state after years of war service with the national assistance board. During the war, Hollamby served with the Royal Marine engineers.

Like so many architects of his generation, Hollamby pursued a career in local authority offices. He was architect to the Miners' Welfare Commission from 1947 to 1949, senior architect with the London County Council (LCC) 1949-62, and, having moved to the London borough of Lambeth, rose to become director of architecture, planning and development, a position he held from 1969 to 1981.

The LCC architect's department had long been infused with the ideas of Morris and John Ruskin. The handsome and humane arts & crafts style estates it built, beginning with the Boundary estate, Shoreditch, at the very end of the 1890s, were admired worldwide. Architects like Hollamby continued and developed this tradition, although after the second world war the spirit of the modern movement pervaded what were dynamic local authority offices.

These were exciting and challenging places to work in the 1950s and 1960s, attracting the very best young architects and with the focus very much on housing. Of course there were mistakes, yet the energy and concern that were channelled into the civic realm seem flabbergasting at the beginning of the 21st century, at the close of an era which has witnessed both the triumph of the private sector and the effective collapse of the great public sector architects' offices of the postwar era.

The LCC office which Hollamby joined in 1949 was very much under the intellectual thumb of Leslie Martin, principal architect of the Royal Festival Hall. Here, the influence of the latest Scandinavian design met with the powerful formal ideas of Le Corbusier, both laced through with the arts & crafts principles of Ruskin and Morris. Hollamby, with the LCC and Lambeth, worked on a prodigious number of housing schemes, including the controversial study for Thamesmead, the futuristic new town that Stanley Kubrick used to sinsister effect in the filming of A Clockwork Orange.

New estates were matched by considerable conservation work, including the restoration of public parks and a major investment in doctors' surgeries, sheltered housing, old peoples' homes, community and health centres. Although initially caught up with schemes to build 30-storey housing blocks in south London - his unrealised proposals for the high-rise redevelopment of Brixton were perhaps the most controversial - Hollamby was to become a champion of modern low- rise estates responsive to topraphy and local conditions.

The architectural tide, however, was changing with the mood of the political economy, which lost its civic- minded bonhomie as England lurched into the neo- liberal era of Thatcher, Major and, latterly, Blair. In 1981, Hollamby was appointed chief architect and planner to the recently defunct London Docklands Development Commission. Now, the private sector began to take the lead. Vast private sector offices, and homes for the young and wealthy, were the new motive force, as east London, along the banks of the river Thames, began to change from an industrial to a financial quarter.

Hollamby worked assiduously to ensure, as far as this was possible, the highest standards of new architecture. He drew up a design guide for the Isle of Dogs in 1982, campaigned for the Docklands Light Railway, developed a planning strategy for the abandoned Royal Docks and oversaw, on a more delicate note, the refurbishment of the exterior of the bombed-out church of St George's-in-the-East, a gloriously eccentric work by England's greatest architect, Nicholas Hawksmoor.

Hollamby retired in 1985. As well as lecturing, gardening and advising English Heritage, he then wrote Red House, Bexleyheath: The Home Of William Morris (Phaidon, 1991), completing a circle of a life and professional career that had revolved around Morris and the arts & crafts.

Jonathan Glancey

fields.headline: E W Swanton
fields.standfirst: Doyen of cricket commentators influential on the air and within the game's inner sanctums
fields.trailText: E W "Jim" Swanton, who has died aged 92, was one of the most capable and respected cricket writers of his time. He wielded most influence as cricket correspondent of the Daily Telegraph from 1946-75. He also edited and wrote books on the game and, for many years, broadcast about it.
fields.body:
E W "Jim" Swanton, who has died aged 92, was one of the most capable and respected cricket writers of his time. He wielded most influence as cricket correspondent of the Daily Telegraph from 1946-75. He also edited and wrote books on the game and, for many years, broadcast about it. His was a traditionalist approach to cricket; his standards were high and he never hesitated to speak out against any abuse of its values.

Educated at Cranleigh, he reported sport, including cricket, for the prewar Evening Standard and, from 1948-64, doubled rugby football with cricket for the Daily Telegraph. Increasingly, however, he became involved with cricket at many levels. Indeed, the small daughter of a friend once referred to him as "sort of a cricket person". It was a description he relished, and employed as the title of his first volume of autobiography.

He joined the army in 1939, and was an acting major in the Bedfordshire Yeomanry when he was captured at Singapore, and became, for three years, a Japanese prisoner-of-war.

Swanton had broadcast running commentary on cricket for the BBC as early as 1934, and, when he returned from war service, he took it up again. He was an outstanding summariser, coming on at lunchtime and close of play with a shrewd and well-balanced ad lib account and evaluation of the game. His deep, rather fruity voice and style conveyed authority.

In all, he made 20 Test tours - to Australia, the West Indies, South Africa and New Zealand - and wrote books about several of them. He was also joint author (after its first edition) of the authoritative A History Of Cricket, and general editor of The World Of Cricket (later Barlays World Of Cricket).

A founder member of the Cricket Writers' Club, he was its chairman for the first two years. As a speaker he was sometimes weighty, but invariably sound and considerate of his audience.

Tall and powerfully built, he was also a useful batsman at club level, and in three prewar matches, for Middlesex against Oxford and Cambridge universities, he scored 67 runs at an average of 13.40. In 1935 he founded the wandering club known as the Arabs, and made several tours with them, to the West Indies, Malaya and the Far East.

Fastidious about his clothing and his car, Swanton was essentially a serious man with little sense of humour. In his early professional days he was often autocratic, fussy and even pompous. Indeed, the name "Jim" was bestowed on him as a humorous reference to "Gentleman Jim, the Journalist." To this, his own players proved an admirable corrective, pulling his leg until he came to accept it with a slightly wry smile. He was, at bottom, shy and most anxious to be liked.

In May 1973, Swanton became editorial director of the Cricketer, the magazine which had been founded by Sir Pelham Warner in 1921. He modernised it without disturbing its traditions and, when he retired from the Daily Telegraph, the magazine provided him with a platform for his views and recollections. In retirement he also became a committee member of the MCC and of Kent county cricket club (of which he was president, 1980-81). In 1976, he was made president of the Cricket Society. He was awarded the CBE in 1994.

Swanton ensured accuracy in his reports by engaging a series of assistants, and often, too, a scorer, so that when, like every cricket reporter, he was forced to turn his head away from the play, someone else took care that no event was missed. Indeed, it is probable that he was the most thorough, reliable, and accurate cricket correspondent of his period.

He was not an imaginative recorder of play in the manner of Neville Cardus, and he had no striking turn of phrase. But he was a sound, professional journalist who wrote lucidly and without affectation. His judgment and values were sound and he always maintained a historical and moral perspective. In the D'Oliveira affair, to the horror of some of his Daily Telegraph faithfuls, he eventually came down on the side of the angels, and firmly against the South African government.

A bachelor until the age of 50, he married Ann Carbutt, the widow of an old friend, and they settled in Sandwich. There he could follow his other hobby, golf, which he played, significantly, hard, and to the letter of the law. He was as proud of his membership of the Royal and Ancient as of the MCC (of which he became a life vice-president).

Swanton was loyal; he could be generous; and, beyond his autobiographical title, he was very much indeed a cricket person.

John Arlott

Stanley Reynolds writes: Jim Swanton continued his long and active life after the late, great John Arlott wrote the above obituary "for the files" in 1983. Swanton wrote all the book reviews each month in the Cricketer, and in 1990 returned to the Daily Telegraph with a fortnightly cricket column called Personally Speaking, in which he was able to react as a man of the old school to the changes forced on his beloved game - such as pyjama-clad Sunday cricketers using a white ball and a black sight-screen.

He said he "abominated [such changes], the only people who like them are the whizz-kid marketing people". He often used the slightly out-of-date term "whizz kid" as if it had only just been coined. He didn't like whizz kids. They had changed cricket, and they were also responsible for the changes in his other great love, the church of England.

Although, in his memoirs, he rather skipped over his time as a prisoner-of-war, Swanton became converted to the catholic revival within the church of England in those years of captivity. He did not like to speak of it, but he had contracted polio in the slave camps of the Thai-Burma railway. He suffered terrible pain, which withered his shoulder - and his much observed smart tailoring was an attempt to disguise this injury. He said once: "If you don't start thinking of the hereafter then, I don't know when you will." When he returned from the war, his father walked passed him at the station, failing to recognise his own son.

After the war Swanton continued to play cricket and golf as though completely able-bodied. He also did what seemed an amazing thing for a cricket and rugby writer to do: he went to live at Pusey House, the Anglo-Catholic centre at Oxford for six years.

He was very much against the ordination of women, seeing it as a block to reconciliation with Rome. He said if he were a younger man he might consider joining the Catholic church - then, in the next breath, he would speak about the drive to restore the church tower in Sandwich.

Swanton lived in the centre of the old cinque port, with the river Delf, no more than a stream, running alongside his house. He liked telling people that witches used to be drowned there, and enjoyed telling overseas visitors that the eight o'clock curfew bell, which is still rung in Sandwich, was the signal to let the pigs out to dispose of the day's garbage.

He continued to play golf, but latterly had to go about the links in a buggy. He had a lovely garden, and would refer to it in an off-hand way, saying it was the size of "two cricket pitches and a bit". His wife, who actually did the gardening, was a former champion golfer, and, when he first met her, he said he had been in love with her since the 1930s, when he saw a photo of her playing in the women's championships "wearing dashing waterproof trousers".

He always liked going up to Lord's "because they make much of me". He was also proud of the fact that, when the secretaries of state wanted to give the cricket-loving John Major the complete works of EW Swanton as a birthday gift, they were shocked to learn that it ran to 22 volumes, including a history of the church of England.

Matthew Engel adds: EW Swanton's autobiography, Sort Of A Cricket Person, was once misprinted with the second "S" missing. This caused widespread amusement in cricket press boxes; we could all picture Jim as a Latin American dictator. Even as a journalist, he has a remarkable place in the history of both his profession and his game.

It is hard now to convey the influence he wielded in his prime. Perhaps only a thundering Times leader in the mid-19th century carried as much weight at Westminster as Swanton's pronouncements did at Lord's. But he was doubly influential; he was so deeply involved in the inner counsels of the MCC that what he said in private mattered as much as what he said in print.

Just as extraordinary was his professional longevity. I edited a piece of his less than a fortnight ago, and it was as forceful as ever. Though self-deprecation was not his strongest suit, Swanton would call himself a dinosaur. In fact, he was the reverse. His genius was that, whether he liked change or not (and usually he didn't), he adapted to it, understood it, and was able to comment pertinently on it. He kept this up for 70 years. It was a breathtaking performance, and he will be remembered with awe.

Ernest William 'Jim' Swanton, cricket commentator and writer, born February 11 1907; died January 22 2000

He was also joint author (after its first edition) of the authoritative A History Of Cricket, and general editor of The World Of Cricket (later Barlays World Of Cricket). A founder member of the Cricket Writers' Club, he was its chairman for the first two years. As a speaker he was sometimes weighty, but invariably sound and considerate of his audience. Tall and powerfully built, he was also a useful batsman at club level, and in three prewar matches, for Middlesex against Oxford and Cambridge universities, he scored 67 runs at an average of 13.40. In 1935 he founded the wandering club known as the Arabs, and made several tours with them, to the West Indies, Malaya and the Far East. Fastidious about his clothing and his car, Swanton was essentially a serious man with little sense of humour. In his early professional days he was often autocratic, fussy and even pompous. Indeed, the name "Jim" was bestowed on him as a humorous reference to "Gentleman Jim, the Journalist." To this, his own players proved an admirable corrective, pulling his leg until he came to accept it with a slightly wry smile. He was, at bottom, shy and most anxious to be liked. In May 1973, Swanton became editorial director of the Cricketer, the magazine which had been founded by Sir Pelham Warner in 1921. He modernised it without disturbing its traditions and, when he retired from the Daily Telegraph, the magazine provided him with a platform for his views and recollections. In retirement he also became a committee member of the MCC and of Kent county cricket club (of which he was president, 1980-81). In 1976, he was made president of the Cricket Society. He was awarded the CBE in 1994. Swanton ensured accuracy in his reports by engaging a series of assistants, and often, too, a scorer, so that when, like every cricket reporter, he was forced to turn his head away from the play, someone else took care that no event was missed. Indeed, it is probable that he was the most thorough, reliable, and accurate cricket correspondent of his period. He was not an imaginative recorder of play in the manner of Neville Cardus, and he had no striking turn of phrase. But he was a sound, professional journalist who wrote lucidly and without affectation. His judgment and values were sound and he always maintained a historical and moral perspective. In the D'Oliveira affair, to the horror of some of his Daily Telegraph faithfuls, he eventually came down on the side of the angels, and firmly against the South African government. A bachelor until the age of 50, he married Ann Carbutt, the widow of an old friend, and they settled in Sandwich. There he could follow his other hobby, golf, which he played, significantly, hard, and to the letter of the law. He was as proud of his membership of the Royal and Ancient as of the MCC (of which he became a life vice-president). Swanton was loyal; he could be generous; and, beyond his autobiographical title, he was very much indeed a cricket person. John Arlott Stanley Reynolds writes: Jim Swanton continued his long and active life after the late, great John Arlott wrote the above obituary "for the files" in 1983. Swanton wrote all the book reviews each month in the Cricketer, and in 1990 returned to the Daily Telegraph with a fortnightly cricket column called Personally Speaking, in which he was able to react as a man of the old school to the changes forced on his beloved game - such as pyjama-clad Sunday cricketers using a white ball and a black sight-screen. He said he "abominated [such changes], the only people who like them are the whizz-kid marketing people". He often used the slightly out-of-date term "whizz kid" as if it had only just been coined. He didn't like whizz kids. They had changed cricket, and they were also responsible for the changes in his other great love, the church of England. Although, in his memoirs, he rather skipped over his time as a prisoner-of-war, Swanton became converted to the catholic revival within the church of England in those years of captivity. He did not like to speak of it, but he had contracted polio in the slave camps of the Thai-Burma railway. He suffered terrible pain, which withered his shoulder - and his much observed smart tailoring was an attempt to disguise this injury. He said once: "If you don't start thinking of the hereafter then, I don't know when you will." When he returned from the war, his father walked passed him at the station, failing to recognise his own son. After the war Swanton continued to play cricket and golf as though completely able-bodied. He also did what seemed an amazing thing for a cricket and rugby writer to do: he went to live at Pusey House, the Anglo-Catholic centre at Oxford for six years. He was very much against the ordination of women, seeing it as a block to reconciliation with Rome. He said if he were a younger man he might consider joining the Catholic church - then, in the next breath, he would speak about the drive to restore the church tower in Sandwich. Swanton lived in the centre of the old cinque port, with the river Delf, no more than a stream, running alongside his house. He liked telling people that witches used to be drowned there, and enjoyed telling overseas visitors that the eight o'clock curfew bell, which is still rung in Sandwich, was the signal to let the pigs out to dispose of the day's garbage. He continued to play golf, but latterly had to go about the links in a buggy. He had a lovely garden, and would refer to it in an off-hand way, saying it was the size of "two cricket pitches and a bit". His wife, who actually did the gardening, was a former champion golfer, and, when he first met her, he said he had been in love with her since the 1930s, when he saw a photo of her playing in the women's championships "wearing dashing waterproof trousers". He always liked going up to Lord's "because they make much of me". He was also proud of the fact that, when the secretaries of state wanted to give the cricket-loving John Major the complete works of EW Swanton as a birthday gift, they were shocked to learn that it ran to 22 volumes, including a history of the church of England. Matthew Engel adds: EW Swanton's autobiography, Sort Of A Cricket Person, was once misprinted with the second "S" missing. This caused widespread amusement in cricket press boxes; we could all picture Jim as a Latin American dictator. Even as a journalist, he has a remarkable place in the history of both his profession and his game. It is hard now to convey the influence he wielded in his prime. Perhaps only a thundering Times leader in the mid-19th century carried as much weight at Westminster as Swanton's pronouncements did at Lord's. But he was doubly influential; he was so deeply involved in the inner counsels of the MCC that what he said in private mattered as much as what he said in print. Just as extraordinary was his professional longevity. I edited a piece of his less than a fortnight ago, and it was as forceful as ever. Though self-deprecation was not his strongest suit, Swanton would call himself a dinosaur. In fact, he was the reverse. His genius was that, whether he liked change or not (and usually he didn't), he adapted to it, understood it, and was able to comment pertinently on it. He kept this up for 70 years. It was a breathtaking performance, and he will be remembered with awe. Ernest William 'Jim' Swanton, cricket commentator and writer, born February 11 1907; died January 22 2000

fields.headline: Nanjing massacre denial sparks fury
fields.trailText: Japanese former soldiers and a historian roused fury across Asia yesterday by denying that the country's military had killed hundreds of thousands of Chinese civilians in a wartime massacre.
fields.body:
Japanese former soldiers and a historian roused fury across Asia yesterday by denying that the country's military had killed hundreds of thousands of Chinese civilians in a wartime massacre.

About 300 people packed an auditorium in Osaka for the controversial conference, The Verification of the Rape of Nanking: The Biggest Lie of the 20th Century, while another 200 supporters stood outside.

Some 100 protesters, mostly Chinese and Japanese, assembled nearby and were heckled as they waved banners, including one that read: "Nanking is an undeniable fact". There was no violence.

Chinese and western historians say Japanese imperial soldiers killed as many as 300,000 people during Tokyo's 1937-38 occupation of Nanking in China - now called Nanjing.

A post-war tribunal in Tokyo said more than 140,000 were killed. But like many right-wing groups and revisionist academics in Japan, the event's keynote speaker, Shudo Higashinakano, said there was no evidence that Japanese soldiers had widely killed civilians.

"There was no massacre of civilians at Nanjing," said Professor Higashinakano, a historian at Tokyo's Asia university. He said Japan's foreign ministry "has said the atrocity is an indisputable fact. I say, that's not the case at all."

The conference took place despite strong protests from Beijing. A nationally broadcast statement from the foreign ministry spokesman, Zhu Bangzao, said the event had "harmed the feelings of the Chinese people and interfered with the normal development of China-Japan relations".

Survivors of the massacre, some of them in tears, gathered in Nanjing to denounce the meeting.

"They say I'm lying," said Liu Xiuling. "I say I best represent the massacre victims because I still have wounds on my body, wounds on my face, wounds on my legs. Can you deny that?"
AP

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Bodies found in terror inquiry
fields.body:
Bodies found in terror inquiry

Police unearthed six bodies in fields near Turkey's Mediterranean coast yesterday, bringing the death toll to 31 in a series of grisly killings blamed on Hizbullah, the radical Islamic guerrilla movement.

Police were continuing excavations in south-east and central Turkey. The victims were thought to be Kurdish businessmen sympathetic to rival Islamic groups. Reuters, Istanbul

Ex-cult leader's son rescued

Japanese police yesterday rescued the kidnapped seven-year-old son of Shoko Asahara, the former head of the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday cult.

The boy, who was kidnapped on Friday, was found with a cult member at a hotel in Hakone, 50 miles west of Tokyo, police said. Reuters, Tokyo

Man eaten by his pet lion

A man who kept wild animals at his home in southern Italy has been found dead, eaten by a lion.

Police said the 50-year-old had kept a lion, tigers and a panther in the basement of his house near the city of Lecce.

Neighbours called police after the man had not been seen for a week. Officers found his remains, mauled and with his clothes torn, in the lion's cage. AP, Rome

Couple plan gender switch

A Hungarian couple are receiving hormone treatments ahead of sex change surgery that will allow them to switch places, the country's Blikk newspaper reported yesterday.

It quoted a doctor from Saint George's hospital in Szekesfehervar, 40 miles south-west of Budapest, who said the operation was scheduled to be performed in August. AP, Budapest

webTitle: Japan mourns one half of world's oldest twins

fields.headline: Japan mourns one half of world's oldest twins
fields.trailText: Japan lost one of its most beloved celebrities yesterday with the death from heart failure at the age of 107 of Kin Narita, who rose to fame with her sister, Gin Kanie, as the world's oldest twins.
fields.body:
Japan lost one of its most beloved celebrities yesterday with the death from heart failure at the age of 107 of Kin Narita, who rose to fame with her sister, Gin Kanie, as the world's oldest twins.

Their wrinkled faces and beaming smiles have been a familiar sight in recent years as they appeared in everything from commercials to quiz shows.

For many in Japan, which has a "respect for the elderly" national holiday, they were the focus of Confucian reverence for the aged.

In 1991 Kin, whose name means gold, and Gin, which means silver, were designated national treasures by the government.

They were born to a farming family in Nagoya, central Japan, on August 1 1892, a few years after the country's first democratic elections.

Proving that life begins at 100, Gin once joked, she and her sister soared into the national consciousness only at the start of the last decade. To celebrate reaching triple figures they released a rap song, which instantly became a chart hit.

Thanks to numerous product endorsements and contracts to write magazine advice columns, the two giggling twins finally earned enough at the age of 101 to file their first tax returns. Kin joked that they would put the money aside for their old age.

With an average life span of 83 for women, and one of the globe's lowest birthrates, Japan has the fastest ageing population in the world. This has led many commentators to express concern about the implications for pension schemes and medical costs. But Kin-san and Gin-san, as they are affectionately known, have been the smiling faces of this rapidly greying society.

Until recently they appeared remarkably healthy. For their 107th birthday they wielded pink shovels to take part in a tree-planting ceremony.

Although Kin lived to see three different centuries, she reportedly had more ambitions. "After living all those years, she just wanted to live a little bit longer and become the oldest person in Japan," her grandson Yukio Narita said. He said she died in her sleep.

Kin is survived by 11 children, 11 grandchildren, seven great grandchildren and one great-great grandchild. The greatest sympathy, however, will go to her sister, who lived 20 minutes away.

"We never thought we would live this long," Kin said on her 100th birthday. "We could survive because we were twins. We need each other more than anyone else in the world."

fields.headline: Forbidden love outlives apartheid
fields.standfirst: A black woman is reunited with her white mother in South Africa after racist society kept them apart for 30 years
fields.trailText: It took 30 years, the death of her father and the end of apartheid for Sandra Laing - a black child born to white parents - to be reunited with her mother. The two were torn apart by a genetic quirk, in an enduring tragedy of South Africa's racist system.
fields.body:
It took 30 years, the death of her father and the end of apartheid for Sandra Laing - a black child born to white parents - to be reunited with her mother. The two were torn apart by a genetic quirk, in an enduring tragedy of South Africa's racist system.

Last week Sandra's mother, Sannie, wept as she finally kissed the daughter she had turned her back on.

"At last. My daughter, Sandra," she said as they were reunited at a Pretoria retirement home. "Can it be true. Is it really my daughter?" All Sandra Laing could muster through her tears was: "Mammie, mammie."

The two women did not even know if the other was alive until a few days ago, when years of heartache came to an end.

Sandra Laing was born in 1955 in Piet Retief, a small town as conservative as any in apartheid South Africa. Her Afrikaans-speaking parents were white, as were her two brothers. But Sandra's skin was notably darker, and became more so as the years passed. Her tightly curled black hair helped seal her fate.

"In 1966, when I was 10, the police came to take me away from my school. Mr Van Tonder, the principal, said I was not white and could not stay. Two policemen drove me to my father's shop in Panbult," she said.

"They said I was being expelled because I looked different. My father cried," she told the Johannesburg Sunday Times recently.

Why Sandra was born black has never been explained, but probably has roots in the considerable inter-breeding that took place after the Dutch settled in South Africa at the beginning of the 18th century.

Nine other white schools refused to accept Sandra. The state tried to reclassify her as "coloured", or mixed-race. Sandra's father fought the decision until the laws were changed to say that the child of two white parents must be classified as white.

Sandra's parents had blood tests to prove she was their daughter. The education department then ruled that she could be readmitted to her old school but recommended that she did not become a border.

Yet being classified as white did not prevent restaurants and bus drivers from turning Sandra away. Neighbours shunned her. She was not even welcome at the local church.

"I felt a lot of pain and thought it would be best if I left and stayed with people I felt happier with," she said.

At 16 Sandra left home to live with Petrus Zwane, a black Zulu-speaker. In 1973 she went home with her newborn son, but Mrs Laing gave her daughter a box of baby clothes and told her not to return.

"My father was furious because I married a black man. He threatened to shoot first me then himself if I ever put my foot over his threshold again," she said.

Apartheid officials told Sandra she was entitled to a white identity card but that they would take away her two children by Mr Zwane because different races could not live in the same house.

Sandra spent the next nine years getting herself reclassified as "coloured" so she could legally live with her son and daughter.

After Sandra's father died in 1988, she wrote to her mother. Mrs Laing wrote back to say she was moving house and would not reveal her new address. Even her brothers, Adriaan and Leon, refused to speak to her.

Sandra had given up hope of finding her mother until their story was featured in the Johannesburg Sunday Times as a personal tragedy of apartheid. The newspaper helped Sandra, who now runs a creche in Tasaki township on the East Rand, to search for her mother.

Eventually, police records led to the Pretoria retirement home where Mrs Laing has lived for some time.

At the reunion her mother was not concerned about her daughter's appearance. "Now tell me again, about the children," she said.

webTitle: Police seize One Nation party files

fields.headline: Police seize One Nation party files
fields.trailText: Police in Queensland and New South Wales have raided the premises of Australia's One Nation party in a move that could hasten the final destruction of Pauline Hanson's rightwing movement.
fields.body:
Police in Queensland and New South Wales have raided the premises of Australia's One Nation party in a move that could hasten the final destruction of Pauline Hanson's rightwing movement.

Hundreds of documents relating to the party's membership and financial structure were seized.

The raids come amid allegations of impropriety surrounding One Nation, and represent a serious blow to Ms Hanson's hopes of making a political comeback.

Ms Hanson, the party's founder, lost her seat as a Queensland MP in the last federal election but had planned to stand for the senate.

The party is riven with highly publicised splits, mass defections to rival parties and damaging court cases.

But the raids late last week by the Queensland police fraud squad mark the most serious blow yet to the ailing party and an increasingly isolated Ms Hanson.

Ms Hanson claimed the police raids were politically motivated and were the result of attempts by the media and the Queensland and federal governments to destabilise her party.

"It has been a witch hunt on One Nation, and they are determined to get rid of me and get rid of One Nation," she said. "They need to denigrate us. They need to have a go at us. And they want to get rid of me, because they don't want a third political force in this country."

The raids were carried out after a state supreme court found last August that One Nation's registration as a political party was "induced by fraud and misrepresentation", as it did not have the 500 members it claimed in its registration papers. The party is expected to appeal against the ruling.

In another serious threat to One Nation's survival, the state electoral office of New South Wales is investigating whether the party is legally registered.

There are also claims of a missing £1m in membership fees and donations to the party, which is tightly controlled by Ms Hanson and her deputies, David Oldfield and David Ettridge.

"The members have wanted answers to this for a long time and somebody has to look at it," said Heather Hill, secretary of the breakaway City Country Alliance (CCA), which was formed by One Nation's five Queensland MPs, who quit the party last month.

In June 1998 One Nation won a large number of seats in the Queensland state elections and looked set to hold the balance of power in Canberra.

But its isolationist and anti-Aboriginal stance, combined with Ms Hanson's erratic behaviour, failed to deliver the expected votes in the October 1998 federal elections, and she lost her seat. Since then the party has staggered from one crisis to another, culminating in the genesis of the CCA. Several One Nation branches have defected to the breakaway party, while hundreds of disillusioned members have simply given up.

Now there is the looming prospect of criminal charges.

But Mr Oldfield said it was outrageous that the police raids were carried out before One Nation's appeal against the Queensland court's ruling was heard.

fields.headline: Indians reject Ecuador's post-coup leader
fields.trailText: The new president of Ecuador, Gustavo Noboa, faces a tense few days of maintaining civil order after he was handed power at the weekend by the leaders of a "five-hour coup" that ousted the former president.
fields.body:
The new president of Ecuador, Gustavo Noboa, faces a tense few days of maintaining civil order after he was handed power at the weekend by the leaders of a "five-hour coup" that ousted the former president.

Mr Noboa, who was vice-president until the coup, accepted the job from a three-man junta representing the 2,000 Indians and junior military officers who had stormed the empty congress building on Friday and forced President Jamil Mahuad into hiding.

The junta, comprising an army general, an Indian leader and a former president of the supreme court, was persuaded to hand back power to a democratically elected politician by US officials, who threatened to cut foreign aid and discourage foreign investment in the country.

However, the compromise could be shortlived because Antonio Vargas, head of the radical Indian movement which triggered the coup, said Ecuador's 4m Indians would not recognise Mr Noboa's authority.

The military chief, General Carlos Mendoza, announced his support for Mr Noboa five hours after the junta took power. He then resigned from his army post, saying the three-person council had claimed power only to "prevent a bloodbath".

With no military backing, the junta effectively fell apart.

Mr Noboa, the sixth president in four years, faces daunting problems in addition to the Indian opposition. He must confront a severe economic crisis: 7m of the country's 12m population are trapped in poverty.

Inflation topped 60% last year, the highest in Latin America, and the economy shrank by 7.5%. Only one person in three in the labour force has a full-time job.

However, polls show that more than 60% of Ecuadoreans reject the plan. Indian leaders said the proposal was an affront to national sovereignty and would benefit only the rich. The row over the currency triggered the protests which resulted in the coup.

Mr Mahuad, a Harvard-educated centrist who took office in August 1998, made a surprise appearance on television after he was deposed. He condemned the coup, but wished his former vice-president "the best of luck".

Political analysts say the root of Ecuador's problems is a discredited political class, many of whose members seek public office only to exploit their positions and do little to improve the lives of the country's poor. Polls show that virtually no political leaders are trusted by the public.

"The Ecuadorean political system has lost the capacity to represent the people," said the political scientist Simon Pachano. "That is why the Indians and social movements are proposing an overall restructuring of the political system and new forms of representation."

As well as US demands for a return to civilian rule, pressure also came from the United Nations, the Organisation of American States and Ecuador's neighbours.

South America's Mercosur trade bloc, made up of Brazil, Argentina, Paraguay and Uruguay as well as associate members Chile and Bolivia, issued a joint statement urging Ecuadoreans to respect their democratic institutions.

webTitle: Fiesta 'spoiled' as villagers barred from tossing goat

fields.headline: Fiesta 'spoiled' as villagers barred from tossing goat
fields.trailText: In the annual tug of war between animal rights activists and the people of a small Spanish village, the goat won yesterday.
fields.byline: Kernan Turner  in Manganeses de la Polvorosa
fields.body:
In the annual tug of war between animal rights activists and the people of a small Spanish village, the goat won yesterday.

For the first time in years, Manganeses de la Polvorosa, a village 155 miles north-west of Madrid, held its patron saint's celebration without throwing a live goat 50ft from the church bell tower.

"That's Spain today," a tipsy villager muttered disgustedly to his wife after men leading a goat on a rope said they would toss it from the tower only if the crowd accompanied them. No one volunteered.

The city council warned that anyone who helped to toss a live goat would be subject to fines ranging from 250,000 pesetas to 2.5m pesetas (about £900-£9,000).

"We're angry," said a mechanic from a nearby village who has attended the celebration for years. "It's a tradition and the people are disgusted that the ecologists have put a stop to it."

The town council's announcement that the goat would not be tossed this year did not stop several hundred people from gathering below the bell tower in the tiny square in front of the stone church. A band played and several dozen people danced, dressed in carnival masks and colourful costumes.

As the afternoon wore on and it grew dark, people began chanting, "Toss the goat! Toss the goat!"

Cheers broke out when several young men arrived with the goat, but one of them told the crowd the "ecologists" wanted them to kill the goat first.

"Do you want us to kill the goat?" he shouted through a magaphone.

"No!" the crowd roared.

The town was fined about £100 by the regional government after the National Association of Animal Welfare and Protection filed a complaint.

Protests in 1992 persuaded the local governor to ban the toss. Villagers used ropes to lower the goat that year, but a year later the ropes were abandoned and the tradition was resumed.

The origins of the ritual are unclear but, according to one legend, a priest's goat - whose milk fed the poor - accidentally fell from the bell tower and was saved by villagers holding a blanket.

The toss also serves as an initiation ceremony for young men and women who have just reached military enlistment age. Traditionally, they carry the goat to the tower and catch it in a tarpaulin below when it is thrown. Last year the goat survived unhurt. AP

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Harold Jackson: Why We Buy and Costing The Earth
fields.body:
Paco Underhill thinks the world is "dangerously over-retailed", a revelation which has helped him develop a nicely profitable line of business. Throughout the week Barbara Flynn reads from his observations on Why We Buy (9.45am, Radio 4). His researches required dozens of trackers assiduously noting with special shorthand and video cameras 900 different types of shopping behaviour. Among their discoveries: women shoppers hate being brushed against from behind and fewer than half the customers in large department stores ever buy anything.

In the early 1990s the reality of global warming came home starkly to the inhabitants of the Indian Ocean island of Kutubdia. A cyclone created a massive tidal wave which swept over their low-lying homes to drown 30,000 people. In Costing The Earth (9.0pm, Radio 4), Alex Kirby examines the accumulating evidence that these recurrent tragedies stem from the industrial nations' profligate use of energy. Everyone knows it but they take little remedial action.

fields.headline: Japan urged to offer relief
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Pressure is growing on Japan to relieve third world debt in the wake of France's weekend announcement that it will join Britain and the US in writing off 100% of the money it is owed by the world's poorest countries.
fields.body:
Pressure is growing on Japan to relieve third world debt in the wake of France's weekend announcement that it will join Britain and the US in writing off 100% of the money it is owed by the world's poorest countries.

The move, which will be worth about 7bn French francs (£650m), was announced by finance minister Christian Sautter after the Group of Seven meeting in Tokyo on Saturday.

Gordon Brown, the chancellor, who took a similar step in December, congratulated his French counterpart and expressed his hope that it would set a precedent for other nations.

"I believe that this is the start of other countries moving up to do the same," he told a press conference.

Aid agencies and debt campaigners also welcomed France's move. "Now we need Germany and Japan to follow suit," said Justin Forsyth, head of policy at Oxfam.

Although Mr Brown did not name other countries, his remarks appear to be a reference to Japan, which has been dragging its heels on full debt relief.

Germany hinted this month that it may follow the British example.

As the world's biggest provider of overseas development loans, Japan has far more to lose than any other country from writing off its debts.

fields.headline: A tainted vote
fields.standfirst:
The London mayor: special report

Dobbo's my man. It is a cruel injustice that he is being sabotaged by Downing Street's dishonesty
fields.trailText: Dobbo's my man. It is a cruel injustice that he is being sabotaged by Downing Street's dishonesty
fields.body:
In a few days' time, ballot papers will be landing on the doormats of 60,000 or so Labour party members in London, inviting them to choose between Frank Dobson, Ken Livingstone and Glenda Jackson as their party's candidate for the first-ever elected mayor of London. It might have been a momentous, even a magnificent, occasion, if New Labour's control freaks hadn't set out to rig it in favour of their favoured candidate.

Notoriously, however, the party panjandrums ratted on their original promise to conduct a simple, one-member-one-vote ballot of the London Labour party, and announced instead that the choice would be made by an "electoral college".

This is to include not only a section for London trades union members, but also a third section for London MPs and MEPs, plus candidates for the proposed Greater London assembly. Each of the three sections will wield 33.3% of the college's final vote, meaning that the vote of each MP will carry 1,000 times more weight than those of an ordinary card carrying member. More ominously, MPs' votes will be recorded, so the whips will know what they did.

As a result, a substantial, perhaps even a decisive number of party members will use their vote not to choose the right candidate but to poke a burnt stick in Tony Blair's eye for his blatant gerrymandering. Present signs are that Ken Livingstone will get a majority in the rank-and-file section, and that Dobbo, if he is to have any chance whatever, will have to rely on the deeply tainted votes of the MPs - a group who have, in any case, no business voting in the ballot at all, whether whipped or unwhipped.

But if this is the outcome, it will be a cruel injustice to poor old Dobbo. True, he might have made a fuss rather earlier about the blatant dishonesty of his Downing Street backers. But he can't be blamed for what they did, and he has made it pretty clear that he didn't like it. The question should be which candidate would make the best mayor, not whose election would annoy the prime minister most. It is infantile to kick Dobbo just to hurt Blair.

There is a further complication, however. Even if members set aside their annoyance with New Labour's dirty tricks, it has been plain from the start that the choice was going to be made on the basis of which of the three had the more appealing personality, rather than on any discernible matter of policy.

On the whole, Londoners love cheeky-chappies, and Livingstone's reputation as a tweaker of the Thatcherite nose back in the 80s transformed him almost overnight from a loony-lefty into the ultimate cheeky-chappy. On that basis, Red Ken started as favourite and has remained so.

But one significant policy difference has emerged between the candidates during the campaign - the complex, almost esoteric, question of how to finance the massive investment programme needed to keep London's Underground system running.

So far, this too has tended to favour Red Ken, at least among Labour party members, since he has been able to portray the ballot as a sort of referendum between his method of funding the Tube by the sale of bonds, and Dobson's plan for a public-private partnership (PPP) in which the public sector runs the railway and the private sector does the construction and maintenance.

For many "old" Labourites, Red Ken's version looks appealingly like a kind of socialism, while Dobbo's looks suspiciously like the thin end of a quasi-Thatcherite wedge.

But the reality is that Red Ken's plan isn't socialism, and Dobbo's isn't Thatcherism, either.

In essence, both are convoluted ways of getting round that fortress of financial orthodoxy, the treasury, whose idiotically rigid rules of accountancy continue to stand in the way of direct state funding for the Tube -or for any other state enterprise, come to that.

These treasury rules insist that, in the best Thatcherite style, public borrowing is inflationary and therefore bad, while private borrowing for the same purpose is non-inflationary and therefore good.

Though these rules have been slightly relaxed as a result of the EU's formula for calculating the deficits of member governments, they are still applied with baleful rigour by that paragon of presbyterian prudence, chancellor Gordon Brown.

As an unrepentant old Labourite, I am in no doubt that state funding would be preferable to either Livingstone's or Dobson's schemes. But short of some inconceivable cabinet revolution, that option isn't on offer.

So the question is, what is on offer? The answer is Dobbo's PPP - which isn't just his plan, but is also the government's. The stark reality is that Ken Livingstone, even as mayor, simply would not have the power to go for a bond issue. In other words, he is engaging in gesture politics, just as he always has. I'll settle for Dobbo.

webTitle: Lucky Labour hopes to ride out the storms to another victory

fields.headline: Lucky Labour hopes to ride out the storms to another victory
fields.trailText: British prime ministers tend to go in pairs - one fortunate and the other unlucky. Harold Wilson and Ted Heath were both devotees of big government policies, but Wilson won four times and Heath only once. It was Jim Callaghan who laid the foundations for monetarism in the 1980s by abandoning Keynesianism and cutting spending during the sterling crisis of 1976, but it was Margaret Thatcher who reaped all the benefits.
fields.body:
British prime ministers tend to go in pairs - one fortunate and the other unlucky. Harold Wilson and Ted Heath were both devotees of big government policies, but Wilson won four times and Heath only once. It was Jim Callaghan who laid the foundations for monetarism in the 1980s by abandoning Keynesianism and cutting spending during the sterling crisis of 1976, but it was Margaret Thatcher who reaped all the benefits.

Similarly, Tony Blair has so far been a lucky John Major. Both prime ministers have been managers of a post-Thatcherite economy, with Major doing most of the spadework and Blair getting the credit. Having lost the confidence of voters at the time of Black Wednesday, the Conservatives did very little wrong in the subsequent five years and left the economy in relatively fine fettle. Growth was strong, unemployment was coming down and the public finances were gradually coming back towards balance as a result of the big tax increases announced in 1993.

It has been Labour's good fortune to inherit this benign state of affairs. There have been changes in the running of the economy - the independence of the Bank of England, the stringent rules for fiscal policy, the New Deal - but the overall thrust of government policy - pro-market, pro-business, pro-flexibility, anti-interventionist - remains what it was under the Conservatives. The prime minister stuck up for the City in the withholding tax row with Europe just as strongly as John Major would have done; Labour's prepare and decide policy over monetary union is little different from Major's wait and see. There has been no sea change in attitudes to taxation or the need to control inflation.

Steady as she goes

There was a good reason for this approach. Polls showed that the British public had no great desire to turn its back on the policies of the 1980s and 1990s; it was the Conservatives they didn't like. As such, Labour's strategy has been to accept large chunks of the status quo and hope to use the credibility gained with the financial markets to push policy in a more progressive direction. Whereas it would be hard to say that Jack Straw has pushed the home office to the left, there have been signs of this paying off at the treasury, with the working families tax credit, the minimum wage and the decision to use the growth dividend on public spending rather than tax cuts all examples of the government's instinct for modest redistribution.

All this needs to be kept in mind when assessing the impact of the government's wobbly time since the turn of the year. January has been a tough month for Labour, easily its worst since the election in 1997. It has not just been that the litany of problems has mounted - crime, the NHS, Europe, the dome, Ken Livingstone, Mike Tyson, the abolition of trial by jury, Pinochet and the tangled business affairs of Geoffrey Robinson - but that ministers have given the impression that they are not quite in control of events.

At Westminster, news of each unfolding problem has been greeted with ill-disguised glee, mainly because commentators are fed up with writing about Mr Blair as lord of all he surveys and are desperate for a new angle. The millennium celebrations may indeed prove to be the turning point for Labour, with the wheels coming off the Blair juggernaut, but it is far too early to make that sort of prediction.

The government is suffering from a dose of mid-term blues, but the economic news is still good. Labour is not perceived to have screwed up the economy, there has been no financial crisis, and there is scant evidence that voters are in favour of economic policy being driven in a more neo-liberal direction. It is one of few areas where the recent news for the government has not been dire, and so long as that state of affairs continues Mr Blair's luck will hold.

Of course, should the economy take a turn for the worse over the next six to nine months Labour would be in much more of a tight spot than it is, particularly now the public is convinced that the government will do whatever it takes to bring health spending into line with the rest of Europe. A robust economy is required both to generate a feel-good factor and to provide the extra money for the NHS. Ministers will not wish to test the view - held strongly by voters in opinion polls but with rather less conviction in the privacy of polling stations - that the public would be willing to pay higher tax to increase funding for public services.

Treasury forecasts suggest that this can be avoided, with growth of perhaps 3% this year followed by two years of expansion after that of up to 2.75% a year. Any forecasts that the economy will behave in such a smooth fashion need to be taken with a large pinch of salt, especially given the impossibility of fine-tuning the economy with any degree of certainty. Three more years of growth would take the present expansion to 12 years, something that has not happened since the 1960s and early 1970s.

Rosy outlook

So is Labour vulnerable on the economy? There is some concern that the party's own focus groups show discontent with the government's handling of the economy has risen in recent months - mainly as a result of the increase in interest rates since the autumn.

This is somewhat surprising but hardly a major cause of concern, given that consumer confidence is high, real incomes are rising and unemployment is now standing at its lowest for 20 years. Should the jobless total continue to come down at its present rate, it should drop below 1m around the time Mr Blair makes his speech at the Labour party conference in the autumn.

That is the sort of figure - rather than the time spent queueing for the body zone - that tends to count with voters come election time.

There are two risks to this rosy outlook, neither of which is likely to deprive Mr Blair of a second term.

The first is that the wildly excessive valuations of shares on Wall Street might lead to a global stock market panic and a generalised economic collapse. Britain is particularly vulnerable to a financial crisis since it is heavily reliant on the profits of speculation. But even if the worst did happen, and Wall Street hit the self-destruct button, it seems improbable that there would be a stampede of voters to parties on the right which are arguing that the problems of the global economy are caused by too little economic liberalism rather than too much.

The second danger is that the deep, underlying problems of the economy become more apparent over the next year. Gordon Brown, the chancellor, rarely opens his mouth in public without boasting about how the government's remarkable stewardship has abolished boom and bust, but the economy is still vulnerable to bouts of instability and turbulence and looks woefully unbalanced. Britain remains a country that spends too much and invests too little; the manufacturing sector is too weak and the financial sector is too strong. One half of the economy is in need of higher interest rates, or higher taxes, the other will soon be on a life-support machine unless monetary policy is eased.

Miraculously, manufacturing is managing to cope with the ridiculous level of sterling, and output from factories has actually been rising in recent months. The strong pound means that profit margins, already under pressure from strong international competition, consumer resistance to higher prices and the surging cost of oil, are being squeezed still further. Yet interest rates are set to go higher over the coming months as a result of strong consumer demand, a tight labour market and the real danger that the property market will overheat in some parts of the country.

Against this background, the Bank of England can be expected to take few risks with monetary policy. It would be no surprise if growth hit 3.5% this year, and if it does interest rates may end 2000 close to 7%. But not the least of Labour's good fortune is that it has arrived in power at a time when the prospects for a prolonged period of low-inflation growth are better than at any time for the past 40 years. The chances are that by this time next year, rates will be coming down again and the problems of this month long forgotten.
fields.bodyText: British prime ministers tend to go in pairs - one fortunate and the other unlucky. Harold Wilson and Ted Heath were both devotees of big government policies, but Wilson won four times and Heath only once. It was Jim Callaghan who laid the foundations for monetarism in the 1980s by abandoning Keynesianism and cutting spending during the sterling crisis of 1976, but it was Margaret Thatcher who reaped all the benefits. Having lost the confidence of voters at the time of Black Wednesday, the Conservatives did very little wrong in the subsequent five years and left the economy in relatively fine fettle. fields.headline: Worm's eye
fields.trailText: One of the much-touted benefits of an independent monetary policy is that interest rates become far less volatile. Rather than swing around wildly in line with the manic frenzies of their political masters, they will bob around gently in a stable, long-term sort of way. In Britain's case, this seems to be working tremendously well. The rate was 6% at the time of Bank independence in 1997 and is 5.75% today, three years on.
fields.body:
One of the much-touted benefits of an independent monetary policy is that interest rates become far less volatile. Rather than swing around wildly in line with the manic frenzies of their political masters, they will bob around gently in a stable, long-term sort of way. In Britain's case, this seems to be working tremendously well. The rate was 6% at the time of Bank independence in 1997 and is 5.75% today, three years on.

In the interim it has peaked at 7.5%, and troughed at 5%. Contrast that with the malarial temperature chart of yesteryear: 17% in 1980, nearly half that by 1984, back to 14% in 1985, well into single figures in 1988 before soaring to 15% in 1989.

True, base rates went wild in the first place only after the first market reforms of the early 1970s, but why ruin a good theory? Indeed, why ruin a good money-making idea? Because if base rates are becoming more stable and are moving within an increasingly narrow range, then the time must come when they stop moving altogether.

Then the rate will be The Rate, stationary for the indefinite future. All a sharp speculator has to do is work out what that final rate will be and bet heavily on it now, thus cleaning up when the roulette wheel slows to a halt with the ball lodged on the number they chose.

Eleven of our neighbours have already done something similar with regard to their own interest rates, albeit by merging into one large rate rather than going for British-style monetary stasis.

This has triggered a number of weird climate change effects, such as a simultaneous slump in Germany and an inflationary spree in Ireland, but these problems are caused not be any design fault in the euro - perish the thought - but by an excess of orthodox thinking at the European Central Bank and a refusal to embrace exciting new ideas.

By behaving like a national monetary authority, such as the Bank of England, the ECB is making a rod for its own back. Far better to celebrate Europe's diversity and rotate interest rate policy on a monthly basis, each month tailored to the needs of one country.

Chaotic? Not necessarily. Markets would know well in advance which country - recessionary Ruritania or booming Bohemia - had been allotted which month, and would act accordingly, and at least no nation need feel neglected.

There's even a handy spare 12th month in the year. For when Greece joins.
