fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Sunday Times
fields.body:
Sunday Times

German telecoms group Mannesmann is planning to buy UK telecoms group Energis for £12bn. The deal is possible if Mannesmann succeeds in fighting the hostile bid from Vodafone AirTouch. Chief executive Klaus Esser is believed to have made his interest known to Energis and its 46.6% shareholder National Grid. Mannesmann is also thought to have contacted AOL about a European link. Energis is third in the UK market after BT and Cable & Wireless.

William Hill , the second biggest bookmaker in Britain, is holding exploratory talks with investment bankers about spinning off its internet betting arm into a quoted company. The net business is generating£1m a week, and if floated would have a high market rating.

British Midland will finally gain rights this week to fly across the Atlantic, breaking the domination of transatlantic routes from Heathrow by four airlines. Founder and main shareholder Sir Michael Bishop is understood to have secured permission for four flights a day from Heathrow.

Sunday Telegraph

Leading retailer bank Lloyds TSB is to spin off insurance subsidiary Abbey Life for more than £1bn. Analysts say the decision to sell the subsidiary, which has £12bn under management and 1m customers, is part of chief executive Peter Ellwood's strategy to focus the group on its core businesses.

Scottish & Southern Energy, created from the consolidation of Southern Electric and Scottish Hydro, is seeking a merger with United Utilities, the multi-utility group. Analysts said the combined group would be valued at about £8bn.

Executives at Arcadia are preparing to sell up to a quarter of the retailer's shops in an attempt to reduce the £235m annual rent bill and avoid breaking banking agreements. Industry sources say as many as 500 of its 2,000 outlets, including Top Shop and Dorothy Perkins, could be closed in the face of falling sales, pressure on gross margins and a debt of £250m after the acquisition of Sears' chains last year.

Mail on Sunday

British Airways will disclose cost-cutting plans today which may force hundreds of travel agents out of business. It is abolishing commission payments for agents who sell its tickets in a move likely to be followed by other airlines. BA announced in December that it wanted to save £500m in the next financial year and generate more ticket sales via the net.

Arriva , the transport group, is completing an agreed bid of more than £60m for MTL , the debt-laden rail and bus group. MTL was put up for sale in December with debts of £50m. Arriva's move could prompt rival offers from Stagecoach and managers in MTL's bus division. MTL is owned by the 2,500 staff involved in the 1992 buyout.

Sunday Express

CD buyers may be caught up in the world's biggest net fraud. Shoppers at a website run by CD Universe are recommended to stop using their credit cards and contact their issuing bank. The fraud, discovered last week, was masterminded by Russian hackers Maxim Ivanov and Evgeny Federov.

Observer

According to insiders entrepreneur Philip Green is struggling to find someone to chair a group for an attempted bid for Marks & Spencer . He is so far believed to have approached Allan Leighton of Asda, Richard North of Bass and Terry Green of Debenhams.

In a setback to the "rip-off" Britain campaign, an international comparison this week will show little difference between grocery prices in Britain and abroad. The comparison was recommended in a consumer white paper.

Sunday Business

Cable & Wireless is in talks to sell its 54% stake in its Hong Kong telecoms arm Cable & Wireless HKT to Singapore Telecom. The sale is expected to raise £10bn and talks were at an early stage, but could lead to a deal within two months.

Lloyd's of London plans to cut 1,100 jobs as part of a cost-cutting move. New chief executive Nick Prettejohn will present the proposal to the board within the next fortnight. Most of the jobs will be lost from the Corporation of Lloyds which oversees the running of the insurance market.

IoS

Sir Richard Branson's Virgin Group is to launch a new venture to sell wine online. The Virgin Wines business will be led by Rowan Gormley - the man who turned Virgin Direct into an operation with 300,000 customers and £2.5bn under management. The business is set to go online in the summer, and Virgin has been test-marketing the concept under the name Orgasmic Wines. The company will offer a money-back guarantee on featured wines.

Reports out this week Today

Interims Monsoon, Range Cooker Company, Slug & Lettuce Group. Finals None scheduled. AGMs ScS Upholstery, Second Scottish National, Ultraframe. EGMs Vodafone AirTouch.

Tuesday

Interims Aston Villa. Finals London Scottish Bank, ML Laboratories. AGMs Jennings Brothers, Raphael Zorn Hemsley. EGMs Esat Telecom.

Wednesday

Interims Aberforth Split Trust, Daejan Holdings, Haynes Publishing, International Greetings, SFI Group. Finals Northern Rock, SKF AB. AGMs Asset Management, Aukett Associates, Blick, RCO Holdings, WH Smith. EGMs Densitron, Le Riche Group.

Thursday

Interims Misys, Richards. Finals Benson's Crisps, Crest Nicholson, Fitness First. AGMs Cardiff Property, Charlton Athletic, Shaftesbury, Victrex. EGMs None scheduled.

Friday

Interims US Smaller Companies. Finals None scheduled. AGMs Allders, Edinburgh Worldwide. EGMs None scheduled.

Indicators this week Today

UK Car production (Dec).

Tuesday

UK CPI (Dec). UK BCC Economic survey (Q4). US Existing home sales (Dec).

Wednesday

UK Minutes of BoE MPC's January meeting. UK Retail sales (Dec). US Mr Greenspan's confirmation hearing before the Senate Banking Committee.

Thursday

UK Global trade (Nov). UK Non-EU trade (Dec). UK CBI Industrial trends survey (Q).

Friday

UK Preliminary GDP (Q4). UK BBA Analysis of mortgage lending (Dec).

fields.headline: Definitely not common or garden
fields.standfirst: Beautiful buildings don't have to cost millions. They don't even have to be big and brash.  Jonathan Glancey has fallen in love - with a shed
fields.trailText: Beautiful buildings don't have to cost millions. They don't even have to be big and brash. Jonathan Glancey has fallen in love - with a shed
fields.body:
After all the triumphalist millennial bombast of the past months, the mind-numbing talk of dumbed-down cultural megastructures under construction in almost every town worthy of the name from Land's End to John O'Groats, it's high time to turn our attention to tiny buildings. Buildings that delight. Buildings that are only just Architecture. Buildings that, for the most part, have never been touched by the hand, T-square or computer of the architect.

I'm thinking of that lovely litany of small-scale structures that includes potting sheds, shacks, cabins and shelters, the sort of buildings that stand, often a little skewwhiff, in fields, on slipways and causeways, by the sides of half-forgotten roads and among tall lupins and rusty lawn-mowers in summer.

Many of the best of these truly vernacular buildings are hideaways. There's the allotment shed (fashionable now that many families are learning to grow their own food as a reaction to the GM stuff beloved of supermarket billionaires) where men used to escape the family row, roll their own and tipple whisky from flasks hidden among the spiders' webs that laced the crude rafters. There's the bird-hide, where twitchers come weighed down with improbable camera equipment to spend days recording Britain's fast disappearing song-birds, come foul or fair weather. And, here's one, designed by an architect, that combines several enthusiasms, pastimes and delights under one animated roof.

This little building (pictured below right) was shaped by Niall McLaughlin, an Irish architect born in Switzerland, raised in Dublin and based in London for the past 15 years. It combines a hide for the photography of insects - dragonflies in particular - a sauna and a pondside bedroom. The building is one of several being built in the rambling gardens of a house in Northamptonshire that stands on the site of what was once the US airforce base at Harrington. B24 bombers flew from here, many on secret missions, dropping spies working for the Resistance into France. After the second world war it became a missile base. The concrete silos are still here, waiting for a new use. McLaughlin's clients have been adding one folly-like building after the other in the shadow of their unpretentious house. The hide-sauna-bedroom is the latest.

"No, it's not a conventional brief," says McLaughlin, "but a delightful one. Originally, the idea was to build an insect-hide for my client, Gina. She takes close-up photographs of natural life, but insects are her speciality. The hide sits by a pond that has become a breeding ground for dragonflies. A camera boom can be swung from the hide to get very close to the insects. Gina's husband, Jeff, agreed it was a great idea, provided he could have the sauna he's always wanted. So we added the sauna to the hide. Then their daughter wanted a little bedroom where she could come and sleep away from the house, by the pond and under the stars. So we added a bedroom."

McLaughlin drew together the structure's three disparate elements under a sloping, winged roof. This gives the building the look of an insect crossed with an old aircraft, which his clients found compelling. "We always like to have small-scale projects like this in our office," he says. "They're our professional folly, if you like. Everyone in the office has one up their sleeves. My latest is a new bandstand for the De La Warr Pavilion [a 30s Modern Movement masterpiece by Erich Mendelsohn and Serge Chermayeff] at Bexhill-on-Sea. They're fun to do and allow us to play with ideas that might seem too flippant for large-scale buildings."

Is there a danger of over-designing such small, low-key structures? Aren't they best kept well away from the hands of self-conscious architects? "I know what you mean," says McLaughlin. "It's the lashed-together, slightly wobbly character of shacks and shelters that give them their appeal. And there is a difference between what I call a shack and a folly."

In McLaughlin's view, a folly, or at least a folly as architects see it, is a highly self-conscious jewel or oddity. Its design is very often an extreme or pure form of much grander buildings released from the restraints of function. Think of the follies in the gardens of Stowe, or Vanbrugh's Tower of the Four Winds in the grounds of Castle Howard. A shack, on the other hand, serves a function, albeit a simple one, and delights us by its essentially ad-hoc character. Think of Captain Scott's cabin in the Antarctic or the shacks you see dotted and potted about the allotments.

In recent years there have been several books, mostly published in the US, studying the shack or cabin and aimed at architects. The purpose of these is not essentially to encourage a rash of shack building (local authorities in Britain tend to despise genuine vernacular buildings - they're not posh enough - preferring hideous "vernacular-style" cottages, their details a pot-pourri of the most embarrassing moments in the catalogue of trashy English housing). No, it is more a way of getting architects, brought up in a highly eclectic, postmodern era to get back to basics - to clear designery clutter from their designing minds. It's the same quest, in fact, that architects have pursued at various times in post-Renaissance history, not least in the second half of the 18th century, when their holy grail was the "primitive hut", or the source of architecture.

The Abbé Laugier described the primitive hut in his hugely influential Essai sur l'Architecture (1753). It was a miniature Greek Doric temple built of logs lashed together with tendrils. This was a deeply Romantic understanding of how architecture came about - Romantic not only in its artistry, but also in the idea that even the greatest temple is, at root, no more and no less than an elaborate form of primitive shelter.

Small wonder, then, that in an overhyped and highly spun era of bombastic new architecture, a growing number of architects, including McLaughlin and his colleagues, are looking longingly at the simplicity and innocence of the shack, cabin, shelter and hide.

Even so, such small and innocent buildings need not be primitive in terms of form or materials. Look at the main image on these pages. This is a shelter for passengers waiting for a ferry in the Kielder forest, Northumberland, designed by the young architects Softroom. Such shelters - along with plate-layers' huts, the tiny clapboard "waiting rooms" that characterised lonely halts on long-forgotten branch lines closed by Dr Beeching - have traditionally been simple builders' jobs, things of concrete and green timber. This one looks like the sort of super-sophisticated speaker used in the shiniest nightclub, or by the wealthiest band. Not only does it look good, but it comes as a real surprise, combining the best qualities of shack and folly in one surprisingly useful building.

Softroom are a band of architect-designers who studied together at the Bartlett school and have since collaborated with Ron Arad, one of Britain's finest designers (an architect too). They spend much time exploring the way the design of buildings might go when pushed along by the contortions of computer programs.

Much of their work is fantasy and it seems right that the factor of improbability should be programmed into the design of small buildings that can look like anything architect or client wants them to, whether loudspeaker or giant insect. In the wake of the dome, enter the cabin, the shelter and the pondside shack.

webTitle: The return of Dicky Boy: Richard Johnson on the RSC

fields.headline: The return of Dicky Boy: Richard Johnson on the RSC
fields.standfirst: Former matinee idol Richard Johnson tells Chris Arnot why he can't resist his old love, the Royal Shakespeare Company
fields.trailText: Former matinee idol Richard Johnson tells Chris Arnot why he can't resist his old love, the Royal Shakespeare Company
fields.body:
Richard Johnson was earning serious money in Hollywood 35 years ago. "It comes as a curious shock to me now to realise that I was making around £1m a year in today's money. And I managed to spend it all having a hell of a good time," he says, a bright grin emerging from his grey beard and illuminating the hitherto rather tired and crumpled features of the ageing matinee idol.

After flying in from a short winter break in Sweden, he has spent a long day grappling with Chekhov in the Royal Shakespeare Company's rehearsal room, next door to a drive-thru Burger King on south London's Clapham High Street. It's now early evening and we are across the road in a bar offering a vast range of Belgian brews. Johnson asks for red wine instead and carries it to a little cubicle where his actor's voice has no trouble competing with the background music.

Yes, he's looking forward to going back to Stratford, where it all began for him. "It's a bit like revisiting an old lover," he says. "Back in 1957, I was in love both with Shakespeare and with the idea of a company of top actors bringing his works to life in a small town. When I arrived there, Charles Laughton was playing Lear and Paul Robeson was doing Othello. Soon I was Orlando to Peggy Ashcroft's Rosalind. It was a wonderful experience."

Exactly 40 years ago, Johnson was one of the happy few selected by Peter Hall to be an associate artist when the Shakespeare Memorial Theatre became the RSC. He's been returning at roughly 10-year intervals ever since. "It would have been nice to be able to afford to go back more often," he says, the grin playing around the beard again. "Unfortunately, what my agent used to call the 'shit factor' comes into play - the better quality the work, the less the money."

The RSC was still in its infancy when Johnson's name used to appear in the programme "by permission of MGM". He had been spotted as one of the "roaring boys" of British theatre, along with Richard Burton, Albert Finney, Peter O'Toole and Robert Stephens. And, like them, he evidently felt impelled to live up to the tag. "I knew it wasn't going to last for ever, but I also knew I had to enjoy it while the time was right." So there were the latest Aston Martins, the rented villa in St Tropez and the marriage to Kim Novak, closely followed by the expensive divorce. And there were the best hotel suites and the late-night parties with Steve McQueen and Charles Bronson. Not to mention Frank Sinatra, who called him Dicky Boy. "The whole world stopped for Sinatra," he recalls. "He had the most astounding personality and energy."

But the West End stage beckoning with John Mortimer's The Wrong Side of the Park. "My Hollywood agent said, 'What do you want to go back to London for? Nobody will hear of you if you stay there.' But I've always liked the idea of mixing it with the screen work. I've always loved the stage."

It's no exaggeration to describe stage-acting as one of the three passions of Johnson's life. The other two are women - decorously referred to as "the ladies" - and food. "I picked up cooking during the intervals between being married," he says. "I was always being told I should open a restaurant. I suppose it went to my head." Enough for Johnson and his current partner, fashion designer Lynne Gurney, to invest a small fortune in a country- house hotel near Marlborough. And then lose it.

The bank's withdrawal of his overdraft during the recession coincided with another expensive divorce settlement, this time from his third wife, Swedish model Marie-Louise Norlund. "So now I'm constantly worried where the next job is coming from. At least at my age the opposition gets less and less because they keep dying," he chuckles. Johnson himself is over 70. "And no," he says, "it doesn't get any easier. When I was a young man, I could learn my lines on the bus taking me to the theatre. Now I have to sweat over them."

So why does he put himself through it? Why not stick to film and television work, which he reckons is easy by comparison? "Because it's a thrilling thing to know that people have paid to see you. The moment you walk on the stage, you can feel their expectations sucking a performance out of you. There's nothing like it."

Right now, he's relishing the prospect of his latest Stratford comeback as Dorn in The Seagull, seeing the old doctor as having the voice of Chekhov himself. "It's the view of the realist," he says, "wry and humorous, slightly cynical without being unkind." Dorn is also, I point out, a man with a past. Johnson happily concurs. "The ladies have been good to him," he says, "but what can he do about it? Seems a realistic attitude to me." And does it strike a few chords, Dicky Boy? "Mmmm," he mutters.

Previews of The Seagull begin at the Swan Theatre, Stratford-upon-Avon (01789 403403), on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Those little white lies
fields.standfirst: Tempted to bend the truth on your CV? Watch out, warns  Kate Hilpern. It is now easy for companies to check up on you
fields.trailText: You know you're the best person for that dream job you've seen advertised, but your CV doesn't quite convey this. Surely it wouldn't hurt to shove in an extra language O-level and exaggerate your knowledge of Excel? Pretending your typing speed is a bit better than it is won't do any harm either, because it will no doubt improve on the job. In any case, how many bosses are really interested in going in to detail about this kind of stuff?
fields.body:
You know you're the best person for that dream job you've seen advertised, but your CV doesn't quite convey this. Surely it wouldn't hurt to shove in an extra language O-level and exaggerate your knowledge of Excel? Pretending your typing speed is a bit better than it is won't do any harm either, because it will no doubt improve on the job. In any case, how many bosses are really interested in going in to detail about this kind of stuff?

Checking job applicants' CVs for little white lies is about to get much easier. Credit reference company Experian announced last week that it had struck a deal with the UK's universities to compile a database of all degree results after 1995, available to sceptical employers for a fee. Interviewers will simply need to call Experian to check candidates' grades (it plans an internet service soon). By collating the information centrally and accessibly, the company has allowed firms to become merciless in their attempts to distinguish the fraudulent from the faithful.

There is certainly a market for the service. The Association of Search and Selection Consultants recently found that a quarter of all CVs contain lies. Former London mayoral candidate Jeffrey Archer was found to have been economical with the actualité on his CV, suggesting he had studied at the famous public school Wellington and taken an MA from Oxford university. In fact he went to the less famous Wellington school in Somerset, and his time in Oxford was part of a postgraduate diploma for which he was unqualified, never having passed his first degree.

But secretaries at least seem to have been getting away with little white lies. New research has found that a staggering two-thirds of firms that employ support staff do not test their skills - even though these often rate far more highly than qualifications in recruiting for secretarial posts. The report, by recruitment consultants Gordon Yates and the Guardian, also found that a quarter of companies believe it is getting harder to recruit skilled support staff. In particular, there is an emerging sense of exasperation over the general standard of literacy.

"I knew one secretary who didn't even use full stops," laughs Richard Chandler, an HR specialist. "Another said she was proficient in shorthand and yet it turned out she wasn't familiar with a single outline. She'd assumed that using shorthand went out with the dark ages, but thought that it made her CV that bit longer."

Debra Allcock, head of campaigning at the Industrial Society, is quick to defend today's secretarial sinners. "Who can blame them in such a competitive market," she says. Even where outright lies are avoided, manipulating language is still popular - people who have completed a skills-based course but failed it, for instance, may nonetheless award themselves the qualification.

"If you make something up altogether just to secure a job, you're bound to be caught out," says Julia Birt, a 29-year-old PA. Birt speaks from experience - she "exaggerated" her proficiency at Powerpoint and various spreadsheet packages, hoping that if she got the job, someone would teach her. In fact, she had only a very basic knowledge of computers, and had lied quite extensively. Her interview was humiliating. "The employer said my body language was a 'dead giveaway', and told me to go home and rewrite my CV and stop wasting his time. Even if that hadn't happened, the humiliation of being totally incompetent on your first day must be unbearable."

Some sectors are more stringent than others in checking applicants' credentials. Philip Ayling, associate director of recruitment consultants Jonathan Wren, says companies in the City are particularly scrupulous, always checking every last detail. You'll be out of the door quicker than a broker can say "buy" or "sell" if you're discovered.

Perhaps the most discouraging trend for CV liars, though, is employers' increasing use of recruitment consultancies, most of which now insist on examining skills the minute you apply - even down to basic numeracy. So if you can't work a mail merge or create a Powerpoint presentation - let alone find the "edit" icon to amend your CV - it's really not a good idea to pretend that you can.

fields.headline: G7 silent on euro's plight
fields.trailText: The battered euro looks set to plunge to new lows this week after finance ministers from the world's seven largest industrial economies ignored its plight at their meeting in Tokyo this weekend.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny and Jonathan Watts in Tokyo
fields.body:
The battered euro looks set to plunge to new lows this week after finance ministers from the world's seven largest industrial economies ignored its plight at their meeting in Tokyo this weekend.

European ministers, desperate that the Group of Seven's final communiqué should make no mention of the euro's politically embarrassing decline, overrode American concerns that the the weakness of the single currency is exacerbating the US trade deficit.

Instead the G7 focused on the yen, repeating warnings from its last meeting in September about the strength of the Japanese currency.

Consensus over who should be the next head of the International Monetary Fund was also in short supply in Tokyo. Germany still hopes to gain backing for its candidate, deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser, despite France and the US expressing doubts over his suitability for the world's top financial job.

In their final statement the finance ministers of the G7 said they shared Japan's concern that the rising yen could choke off the stuttering Japanese recovery.

However, coordinated intervention seems to be off the agenda, and it will be up to the Bank of Japan to cap the yen's rise if the markets decide to test the G7's resolve this week.

The prospect of a tumultuous week for the world's three major currencies will add to the pound's appeal as a safe haven, and could propel the British currency to fresh records this week. On Friday the pound hit a 14-year high against the currencies of its main trading partners.

Sterling's strength is making the decision on when or if Britain should join the European single currency even more of a political hot potato for the government.

The dilemma facing Labour was underlined yesterday when Europe's top central banker said that Britain would pay for its decision to stay out of the euro at its launch by being forced to accept a punishingly high exchange rate for the pound if it ever joins the single currency.

In an interview with the Observer, Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, said a high pound was "the price you pay for staying out".

Mr Duisenberg's words will dash hopes that Britain would be allowed to devalue sterling from its present stratospheric values - equivalent to 3.20 marks - before joining EMU. The last time sterling was at these levels against other European currencies was in the run-up to Britain's ill-fated decision to join the exchange rate mechanism.

The EMU rulebook states that countries must be members of ERM for two years before joining the single currency. The pound is not currently part of the ERM, but Mr Duisenberg said that in Britain's case, the pound would have to keep a stable value against the euro currencies for the qualifying period.

"The pound would demonstrably have had to have been stable vis-à-vis the euro; it would not have depreciated in the two years ahead of entry," said Mr Duisenberg.

This would rule out any attempt by the government to massage down sterling's value to a more competitive level ahead of entry. Although manufacturing exports are recovering on the back of strengthening world demand, British firms are finding they are being priced out of many markets by the level of the pound, which makes British goods too expensive for foreign buyers.

Europe's bankers and politicians hope that improving growth prospects in the single currency zone will bolster the euro. Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke said yesterday that he expects the euro to strengthen this year.

Sterling's strength is making the decision on when or if Britain should join the European single currency even more of a political hot potato for the government. The dilemma facing Labour was underlined yesterday when Europe's top central banker said that Britain would pay for its decision to stay out of the euro at its launch by being forced to accept a punishingly high exchange rate for the pound if it ever joins the single currency. In an interview with the Observer, Wim Duisenberg, head of the European Central Bank, said a high pound was "the price you pay for staying out". Mr Duisenberg's words will dash hopes that Britain would be allowed to devalue sterling from its present stratospheric values - equivalent to 3.20 marks - before joining EMU. The last time sterling was at these levels against other European currencies was in the run-up to Britain's ill-fated decision to join the exchange rate mechanism. The EMU rulebook states that countries must be members of ERM for two years before joining the single currency. The pound is not currently part of the ERM, but Mr Duisenberg said that in Britain's case, the pound would have to keep a stable value against the euro currencies for the qualifying period. "The pound would demonstrably have had to have been stable vis-à-vis the euro; it would not have depreciated in the two years ahead of entry," said Mr Duisenberg. This would rule out any attempt by the government to massage down sterling's value to a more competitive level ahead of entry. Although manufacturing exports are recovering on the back of strengthening world demand, British firms are finding they are being priced out of many markets by the level of the pound, which makes British goods too expensive for foreign buyers. Europe's bankers and politicians hope that improving growth prospects in the single currency zone will bolster the euro. Bundesbank president Ernst Welteke said yesterday that he expects the euro to strengthen this year.

webTitle: NatWest digs in for last ditch defence

fields.headline: NatWest digs in for last ditch defence
fields.trailText: NatWest will today reveal its final argument in its fight to persuade investors to back its case for independence amid mounting speculation that it has already lost the support of Prudential, its largest shareholder.
fields.body:
NatWest will today reveal its final argument in its fight to persuade investors to back its case for independence amid mounting speculation that it has already lost the support of Prudential, its largest shareholder.

City sources believe the highly regarded fund managers at the Pru are in an awkward position after a deal with Bank of Scotland which would allow the Pru to sell insurance through NatWest branches if its £22bn bid succeeds.

In its final defence against the competing bids, NatWest is expected to release early profit figures for last year of about £2.4bn, and to try to persuade shareholders that it can develop the business in the future better than either of the assailants, BoS and Royal Bank of Scotland.

NatWest will argue that its new management team led by Sir David Rowland, who faces court action next month as a result of a case dating back to his former role at Lloyd's of London, can run the bank better and without incurring the risk it believes would be associated with a takeover. The clearing bank recently bolstered its management with the recruitment of Gordon Pell, a former executive of Lloyds TSB, who has begun to lobby shareholders even though he does not officially join until next month.

The Scottish banks have until next Monday to raise their bids and, in a nail-biting fight to the finish, both are expected to find some extra firepower to increase the cash element of their offers.

In what has become a bitter battle, Royal Bank has toned down a pollsters' questioning of private investors while BoS financial advisers have run into hot water with the takeover panel over claims of fund manager support.

fields.headline: The office gossip
fields.trailText: If anyone knows about image, advertising giant Saatchi and Saatchi does. The company - whose blue chip clients include the army, Sony and Proctor & Gamble - appreciates the importance of first impressions, which is why for 20 years it has employed Gill Collett as the first point of contact for visitors at its plush offices in the west end of London.
fields.body:
If anyone knows about image, advertising giant Saatchi and Saatchi does. The company - whose blue chip clients include the army, Sony and Proctor & Gamble - appreciates the importance of first impressions, which is why for 20 years it has employed Gill Collett as the first point of contact for visitors at its plush offices in the west end of London.

Collett, now 45 and senior receptionist, began working for the company on switchboard and later moved to reception without any formal training. "My predecessor taught me the ropes, but mostly I learnt on the job. I never imagined that I'd be here this long but I've found a job that I do well, and I'm happy to stick with it," she says.

Aside from having to be patient and extremely charming, Collett says that it is her good memory that serves her best in her job - something she is famous for throughout the building. "I only need to see a person a couple of times and I'll remember their face and name," she says. "I'm also good with phone extensions and rarely have to look them up - it's just a skill I have."

Every morning Collett familiarises herself with conference room bookings, double-checking the time visitors are arriving so that she is prepared to receive them. Over the years celebrities including the Spice Girls, Margaret Thatcher and Prince Naseem have graced the foyer.

"I try to treat everybody the same," she smiles. "I make everybody welcome. I'm quite down to earth and don't get jittery around famous people."

Occasionally, visitors can be abrupt and impatient - deal with them politely but assertively, says Collett. "There are a lot of couriers who are paid by the number of packages they deliver, so they might thrust a package under your nose while you are dealing with someone else. They can get agitated, but I just say, 'I'm sorry to keep you waiting, but I'll be with you in a minute'."

Vigilance is a constant part of the job - keeping an eye on any unattended bags, for instance - but she also has to have a sharp eye for spillages, or flowers that are looking a bit tired. Although Saatchi and Saatchi does not dictate a strict dress code, it expects receptionists to be well turned out. Collett believes appearance is an incidental part of the job, but concedes, "It is pretty important to be well groomed and smartly dressed."

The company attracts a wide variety of visitors, including students making job enquiries at the famous firm. "They'll come in asking if we've got any summer jobs or if we do graduate training schemes. I never turn them away, but get them to speak to someone in our personnel office."

Unlike most jobs, receptionists cannot necessarily determine the pace of their work and things can suddenly get extremely hectic. "Normally we have three receptionists, but occasionally you find yourself on your own with the phones going and a queue of people standing in front of you," says Collett. "The last thing you should ever do is panic."

fields.headline: A problem shared...
fields.standfirst: Workplace stress is on the increase, but companies are now recognising the benefits of providing counselling for employees.
fields.trailText: We have all heard of the listening bank, but how about the listening boss? If that sounds too good to be true, you may have experienced a manager who dismisses his employees' emotional difficulties as none of his concern.
fields.body:
We have all heard of the listening bank, but how about the listening boss? If that sounds too good to be true, you may have experienced a manager who dismisses his employees' emotional difficulties as none of his concern.

But as workplace stress continues to be a major reason for absenteeism, and the bill to the employer creeps upwards (the CBI put the cost of lost work days at £10bn in 1998), many companies are finally recognising the benefits of providing emotional support to their workers. And whether they opt for an in-house counselling service, or (more commonly) contract external counsellors, the message to anxious, depressed or stressed-out staff is that it's good to talk.

"Employee assistance programmes" - set up to help staff deal with any problem that may affect them at work - are becoming increasingly common. The Employee Assistance Professional Association estimates that more than 1,000 companies now offer workplace counselling services, reaching 700,000 employees.

Initial advice on issues such as legal queries, relationships, family issues and, of course, workplace problems is often available through a helpline service, which the employee can take further to a series of face-to-face counselling sessions.

"This kind of activity has been on the increase for the past ten years and increasingly so in the past five," says Robert Westlake, chartered psychologist and managing director of the Personal Effectiveness Centre. "The idea of people being more capable of talking and counselling is now more acceptable, and in bigger companies in particular people do feel they can own up to emotional problems. After all, if people have a health problem they take an asprin - if they have an emotional problem, they see a counsellor."

Troubles at home, coupled with the drive towards a leaner workforce and longer working hours, exacerbate stress and absenteeism. But while workplace worries affect everyone, it is often the secretary who is the most put upon, according to Dr Angela Hetherington, clinical director of workplace counsellors PPC. "A manager may be particularly stressed and this anger is more likely to be directed down the line rather than up, and that next in line can often be the PA."

Office rage, where managers become verbally abusive, is also on the increase, says Hetherington. "The manager may tell the PA that she is no good at her job, doesn't dress the part, can't answer the phone properly - and the PA accepts that there is little she can do and that is why she comes for counselling."

Other problems frequently raised in the privacy of the counsellors' rooms are work overload, shifting responsibilities and the effects and speed of change. "Research has shown that one of the causes of stress is lack of control of your workload," says Westlake.

Some of us need a little pressure and stress to work effectively, but what are the symptoms of a person suffering from overload? "The time to take note is when your performance starts to drop off," according to Westlake. "You forget things, have small accidents, inaccuracies appear in your work. Your boss may point it out and you feel overly aggrieved. You may not want to get up in the morning and you take more time off. It really is when the pressure overcomes your ability to work."

Ernst & Young, which has 7,000 employees across the UK, introduced an employee assistance programme in October last year. A 24-hour telephone counselling and advice service is available to all staff. "It is usually the first port of call," explains Richard Gartside, Ernst & Young employee manager. "If they need more help, they can have up to six face-to-face counselling sessions." The service has not gone unnoticed - 7% of Ernst & Young staff phoned in after the launch. And while the counselling is confidential, recurrent generic workplace problems can be fed back to management and adjustments and action can be taken.

"Workplace counselling offers benefits to eveyone," says Hetherington. "The employees get heard and help themselves in the short term, and we collate the information in a report back to the company which in turn helps other colleagues and the organisation in the long run."

Much management emphasis in recent years has gone into being "the organisation that learns". Now it could be a case of support staff seeking out the organisation that listens.

webTitle: One third of mothers forced out of full-time working

fields.headline: One third of mothers forced out of full-time working
fields.trailText: A third of working mothers are quitting full-time jobs for part-time positions or giving up work altogether, a survey reveals today, with many women blaming inflexible employers who refuse to allow them time off to look after their children.
fields.body:
A third of working mothers are quitting full-time jobs for part-time positions or giving up work altogether, a survey reveals today, with many women blaming inflexible employers who refuse to allow them time off to look after their children.

The research, carried out for the BBC's Panorama programme, undermines government initiatives which are aimed at encouraging women who have had children to return to the workforce.

Researchers at the University of Bristol, who analysed the working patterns of 560 mothers, found that they all returned to work full-time after the birth of their first child. But within two years more than a third had given up their full-time positions, with 17% switching to part-time employment and 19% giving up work altogether.

The programme makers also commissioned a smaller-scale study of 73 mothers, taken from the ongoing British household panel survey, which examined the reasons why such a high proportion of mothers are leaving full-time work. Susan Harkness of the University of Sussex, who carried out the research, said: "I think we tended to assume that those women who'd come back to work after childbirth stay in the labour market, so the scale of the dropout was really quite surprising.

"We found that women who returned to full-time work tended to do so when their children were very young. We also found they worked very long hours - there was no reduction in hours prior to and after the birth of the child - so there was no accommodation within their jobs to account for the fact they now had responsibilities for a very young child."

One of the women interviewed was Cathy Schofield, who gave up her job as marketing director for a publishing firm in order to be able to spend more time with her son. "I didn't think I would find myself not exactly being hounded out of work but having my working day made so guilt-ridden that I just couldn't bear to carry on."

The publishing company insist they were accommodating, but Ms Schofield says her boss complained when her son was ill, saying he seemed to be ill more often than other children, and when she stayed at home to deal with an emergency her holiday allowance was docked.

Penny Gillison, a new mother, has been trying to negotiate flexible working hours with her boss to cope with looking after her child.

"You always have this feeling that someone's saying in the background 'oh, you're a terrible mother, how dare you work'... I have no choice at this point in time."

While encouraging mothers back into the workplace has become a key plank of government policy, critics say much more needs to be done, including legislation that would impose the legal right for new mothers to demand their old job back on a part-time basis.

However, any such move would be fiercely opposed by employers. Ruth Lea, of the Institute of Directors, said: "We did a survey 18 months ago of our members and 45% of them said that they would think twice about taking on women of prime childbearing age because of the maternity legislation."

The programme, called Back to the Kitchen Sink, which will be broadcast at 10pm tonight on BBC1, also looks at the latest research into child development, which appears to add weight to the controversial theory that young children whose parents work full time may perform less well at school.

Professor Heather Joshi, of the Institute of Education, analysed several aspects of the lives of 9,000 young adults who were born in 1970. The research found there was a link between a mother's employment in the pre-school years and their children's academic success. The differences were small but meant that girls were 10% "less likely to advance one rung of the qualifications ladder, such as the step between GCSE and A-level", while boys were 12% less likely to do so.

The results follow the findings of the first part of the study, released three months ago, which reported that children whose mothers worked before they were one year old had slightly worse reading scores later on.

"There may be something in the child's early development that equips them better to face these undoubted challenges of doing public exams," Professor Joshi said.

However researchers believe of more significance may be the quality of childcare rather than simply the fact of having a working mother.

fields.headline: Style over content
fields.standfirst:
La Clemenza di Tito
Royal Opera House
Rating: * * *
fields.trailText: The Royal Opera's new Clemenza di Tito is a somewhat messy effort, musically inconsistent (though a handful of individual performances mercifully redeem it) and theatrically intransigent almost to the point of woefulness.
fields.body:
The Royal Opera's new Clemenza di Tito is a somewhat messy effort, musically inconsistent (though a handful of individual performances mercifully redeem it) and theatrically intransigent almost to the point of woefulness. The terrible flaw in Karl-Ernst and Ursel Hermann's production - an import from Salzburg where it was unveiled in 1992 - lies neither in its portentous symbolism nor its clumsy stagecraft (both are more than once apparent) but in its wanton, distrustful revamping of the opera's politics.

Mozart, writing as Europe was tottering under the impact of the French Revolution, examines and questions the nature of autocracy. He draws the conclusion that absolute power, embodied in the Emperor Tito, necessitates absolute moral responsibility and is purchased at the price of soul-shattering emotional isolation. The Hermanns, however, are having none of this, and present us with a portrait of Tito as an ineffectual wimp at the centre of an obscene scramble for domination, his every action the product of stage management and spin. His sidekick Publio, whom Mozart equated with justice untempered by mercy, has mutated into a hypocritical Machiavellian figure. He produces fawning crowds on cue, spies, eavesdrops and manipulates even when the libretto doesn't require him, and finally usurps the imperial throne as Tito slumps, a broken figure, into a discarded chair.

Elsewhere, the opera's political games are played out with an edgy, alienating irony which sits uneasily with the emotional directness and inherently tragic stature of the score. The set is a white, neon-lit corridor of power, mercilessly exposing the characters' private universes to an unremitting glare, and occasionally opening on to the colonnaded vistas of the public world beyond.

The costumes may be described as all-purpose power-dressing. The blokes look vaguely Napoleonic, though Tito dons a Samurai headband in moments of crisis. Vitellia, flouncing round like Eva Peron in a series of tulle New Look ballgowns, is a self-dramatising diva, who slaps on punk war paint when roused and manipulates Sesto by performing Rita Hayworth's glove striptease from Gilda. Later her actions acquire the quality of clunky debasement as she removes her imperial finery while singing Non Piu Di Fiori to a wilted hydrangea. Servilia is frumpily got up in a hausfrau's dowdy dress and pinafore, presumably intended to suggest that she has incipient bourgeois values. In the process she looks like a St Trinian's schoolgirl.

Buried beneath this goo, however, are some remarkable flashes of insight. The erotic circling between Sesto and Vitellia, shot through with hints of sado-masochism, is finely done. Sesto's psychological disintegration from nobility via derangement to self-lacerating guilt is astonishingly handled by Vesselina Kasarova. She is in fabulous voice, her every note and gesture etching itself indelibly on the memory. This performance alone makes the evening worthwhile. On the plus side there is also Vinson Cole's mellifluous Tito, musically transcending the goings-on around him, while Lorenzo Regazzo, sexily imposing, makes an extremely impressive debut as Publio.

The rest of the cast struggle a bit: Patricia Schuman's voluptuous Vitellia is hampered by stridency; Ruxandra Donose's Annio is fruitily sung in a generalised sort of way; as Servilia, Christina Oelze reveals a voice which is a shadow of its former beautiful self. Once past an unaccountably lightweight overture, Nicolas McGegan conducts with mannered gravitas, though poor coordination between stage and pit render the whole too uncertain in places for comfort.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

Vitellia, flouncing round like Eva Peron in a series of tulle New Look ballgowns, is a self-dramatising diva, who slaps on punk war paint when roused and manipulates Sesto by performing Rita Hayworth's glove striptease from Gilda. Later her actions acquire the quality of clunky debasement as she removes her imperial finery while singing Non Piu Di Fiori to a wilted hydrangea. Servilia is frumpily got up in a hausfrau's dowdy dress and pinafore, presumably intended to suggest that she has incipient bourgeois values. In the process she looks like a St Trinian's schoolgirl. Buried beneath this goo, however, are some remarkable flashes of insight. The erotic circling between Sesto and Vitellia, shot through with hints of sado-masochism, is finely done. Sesto's psychological disintegration from nobility via derangement to self-lacerating guilt is astonishingly handled by Vesselina Kasarova. She is in fabulous voice, her every note and gesture etching itself indelibly on the memory. This performance alone makes the evening worthwhile. On the plus side there is also Vinson Cole's mellifluous Tito, musically transcending the goings-on around him, while Lorenzo Regazzo, sexily imposing, makes an extremely impressive debut as Publio. The rest of the cast struggle a bit: Patricia Schuman's voluptuous Vitellia is hampered by stridency; Ruxandra Donose's Annio is fruitily sung in a generalised sort of way; as Servilia, Christina Oelze reveals a voice which is a shadow of its former beautiful self. Once past an unaccountably lightweight overture, Nicolas McGegan conducts with mannered gravitas, though poor coordination between stage and pit render the whole too uncertain in places for comfort. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: You don't have to be mad to work here, but...

fields.headline: You don't have to be mad to work here, but...
fields.standfirst: Marking your territory in the office may make you feel more at home but the slogans, cuddly toys and stress-relievers adorning your desk may reveal more to your colleagues than you bargained for.
fields.trailText: Interested in discovering more about the inner workings of your psyche? Keen to know what impression you make on your work mates and boss? Well look no further than the gubbins on your desktop because - according to the latest psychological research - the way you choose to mark your territory reveals more than your taste in pot plants.
fields.body:
Interested in discovering more about the inner workings of your psyche? Keen to know what impression you make on your work mates and boss? Well look no further than the gubbins on your desktop because - according to the latest psychological research - the way you choose to mark your territory reveals more than your taste in pot plants.

Bordering on the seriously sinister is the kitsch-but-innocent-looking cuddly toy gazing winsomely from the top of your PC screen, which is, in fact, a form of office garlic placed there to ward off the workplace nasties, although what one bug-eyed beanie baby can do against all those scroungers, whingers, backstabbers, gossips and pen nickers is anybody's guess.

Sometimes, such miscellaneous objets d'art land on our desks from a mysterious source and we haven't the heart to toss them in the bin where they belong. But the danger with holding on to that ceramic pixie bearing the slogan "Chill out!" across its little crossed knees or the miniature teddy bear with "I love my mum" on his T-shirt is that even though you know you came by them by accident, your colleagues think you chose them yourself. The result: you're forever after dubbed the office sad case on the brink of a nervous breakdown.

A glance at your desk, then, could be timely, to see what messages you are unwittingly giving off:

Slogans

You have small, "witty" slogans stuck to your office equipment, including the gut-busting classics: "Smile, it may never happen", "Don't let the bastards grind you down," and "You don't have to be mad to work herebut it helps!"

Analysis: you want to present yourself to colleagues as a bit of a wag. By failing to realise that these slogans are about as funny as the flu you reveal yourself to be a wit-free zone. Oscar Wilde was good with the one-liners but he didn't feel the need to have them printed on a T-shirt to make sure everyone got the joke. You can't buy a sense of humour at the card shop. The least you can do is replace these stickers with some Gary Larsen cartoons.

Cuddly toys

Your desk and screen sport a cuddly collection of monkeys, frogs and bunnie-wunnies.

Analysis: you are so desperate to depict the warm, loveable and softer side of your nature that it begs the question 'What kind of hard-faced bitch are you underneath and why are you trying so hard to cover it up?' Either that or you want everyone to think you are already loved and that these toys are some form of amorous token from your myriad of admirers.

Stress toys

Strewn across your desk are stress balls, rubber throwing bricks, half-chewed styrofoam cups and ball points, and past-their-sell-by-date post-it notes covered in unintelligible scrawl.

Analysis: you are so keen to advertise the fact that you are stressed that you are either an angst-ridden hypochondriac or the laziest and craftiest person in the company. Relishing and wallowing in your own anxiety is a trait unforgivable in anyone other than Woody Allen. Tidy your desk and be grateful that anyone puts up with your whining.

Trophies

Your desk is covered with small icons of success: postcards and greetings cards, photos of career highlights, certificates, framed letters of thanks, family pictures, etc.

Analysis: you are deeply insecure and riddled with self-doubt. Why else would you need constant reminders of your achievements to get you through the day? And why the need to shout your worth to all around you? Surely the aim is to get the boss and co-workers telling you how wonderful you are, rather than the other way round.

fields.headline: The sec's files
fields.trailText: • Boardrooms still male
fields.body:
 Boardrooms still male

New research reveals what we already guessed: women across Europe are still not joining their male colleagues around the boardroom table. Of 1,500 business leaders polled throughout the EU, just over half said that none of their top ten most senior positions is held by a woman. The United Parcel Service business monitor found that the UK is slightly above average, but nevertheless 44% of business leaders reported that they had no women at the helm. Belgium topped the league as the least male-dominated country, Italy and Germany came bottom.

 It's a lottery

Office workers often form a syndicate to play the National Lottery. But it is important to regulate it. "A gentleman's agreement isn't enough, especially in the event of a big money win," says Dianne Thompson, a director of Camelot. The lottery operator has produced a free information pack to help the estimated 9m adults in the UK who play in a syndicate. Tel: 0845 9 100 000.

 Mouse with nous

They may only be machines, but sometimes computers do seem to have moods - especially when they are having a bad day! Now American manufacturers say they have developed the first computer mouse with "emotion": it can monitor the user's skin temperature, moisture levels and heart rate. The machines could be programmed, say IBM boffins, to slow down when you are tired, or speed up a computer game if you are finding it too easy. What about a keyboard that senses when you are fed up with typing?

 Training traits

According to a new report from the TUC, while large firms spend an average of £294 per person per annum on staff development, small firms may spend as little as £30. The document also reveals absenteeism levels up to four times higher in small firms than in big corporate enterprises. Although most firms in Britain are classed as small, larger firms employ the lion's share of the workers: 30% work in small firms compared to 44% in bigger companies.

 Conference know-how

Want some tips on making your conference a success? A seminar at The Royal Garden Hotel in central London on 15 March aims to help organisers get the most from their chosen venues. Executive chef Steve Munkley - recently named banqueting chef of the year by the Craft Guild of Chefs - will share his experience on the importance of well-defined aims for your event, how to avoid hidden costs, and how to combine a suitable food and wine menu. Call Conference & Banqueting on 0207 361 1831 for more details.

webTitle: Can mothers really have a career?

fields.headline: Can mothers really have a career?
fields.standfirst: If you think things have improved for working mothers, think again. As  Finola Lynch  discovers, many employers still believe women should choose between work or children
fields.trailText: For the first months of your child's life you want to be at home without chucking your career out of the window. You are a parent working full-time but you need to pick up your children from school or nursery each day. You are bringing up children alone, and if one of them is sick and off school, you have no option but to skip work.
fields.body:
For the first months of your child's life you want to be at home without chucking your career out of the window. You are a parent working full-time but you need to pick up your children from school or nursery each day. You are bringing up children alone, and if one of them is sick and off school, you have no option but to skip work.

These are the daily dilemmas facing the average working parent. But let's be honest. When we say parent, we really mean woman. For despite a raft of "family friendly" government policies, new technology and the emergence of a so-called softer management style, women are still bearing the brunt of childcare responsibility and are forced into making unhappy compromises between home, office and children.

Traditionally, family pressures have often dictated the type of work women undertake. The secretarial sector has always attracted huge numbers of women, not least because its hours have been relatively child-friendly. But the dramatic change in the secretarial role, combined with a fitter and faster workplace, has conspired to make any job a juggling act of home and work pressures.

It's not a joyful task. A survey by Lloyds/TSB revealed this month that in the last quarter of the 20th century, working mothers were the most dissatisfied group of people in society, thanks to the pressures of running a modern family.

Wendy Neusone, 28, who has a two-year old son and works as a full-time secretary for the legal department of the Equal Opportunities Commission, knows those pressures too well. "I set my standards quite high and I don't like to mention it if something goes wrong at home," she says. "You do worry in case it's looked on badly. My husband is away on business a lot because he is a sales rep, and although he helps where he can, nine times out of ten the burden falls on me. It can be a struggle to balance it all."

The government has changed the law to make it easier for women and especially lone parents to stay at work. The Working Family Tax Credit allows eligible parents to claim up to 70% of childcare costs. But with the average yearly cost for two children in full-time care around £6,000, returning to work is still not economically feasible for many women earning middle or lower incomes. Campaigners argue that the only effective way to help working parents is to provide adequate childcare facilities, but currently only one in ten employers offer any kind of help, from creches to information service lines.

So what if you could pick and choose your working hours? Neusone, for instance, works flexitime, which allows her to beat the rush-hour traffic and pick up her son before 6pm, when his nursery shuts. Flexibility is the latest buzzword and new patterns are attracting working parents, since flexitime allows employees to choose within set limits the times they start and finish work. Part-time employment, job-sharing and working from home are now protected by law and are attracting both men and women.

But many employers resist the idea of a more fluid and flexible workforce, and workers in support roles are by definition often less free to design their own working schedules. They often need to shadow the hours of their bosses - who may be hostile to flexitime or jobshare initiatives. "For the employer it's the continuity factor," says Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors. "Employees have responsibilities as well as rights. If you're a PA to a go-getting chap or woman, you've got to be there."

She argues that recent legislation has only made it harder for women to break through the glass ceiling. "When we surveyed our members, 45% said they found women of child-bearing age less attractive to employ than other groups. Basically, you've got to make a hard choice. The future is not female - the truth is if you are talking about the workplace there are a lot of constrictions and limitations."

Her assessment is shocking, partly because it contrasts so sharply with the language of empowerment usually employed about working parents. And instead of believing the workplace will become more family-friendly, she thinks the future will be "surprisingly similar to the present". Childcare, believes Lea, is entirely the responsibility of the worker. "When employers take people on, they know about their family commitments. But they expect them to be adult enough to be able to handle these pressures themselves. It's not up to us to do it."

That view was painfully illustrated last week when a City lawyer won her case for unfair dismissal after contending that her boss deliberately increased her workload when she first became pregnant, and sacked her when she had her fourth child. Even though Aisling Sykes was prepared to take work home to carry on her 14-hour day, her employer, JP Morgan, wanted her in the office. Having children, Sykes claimed, was considered a lifestyle choice, like playing squash.

If the Sykes case is an exceptional example (she was, after all, able to afford three full-time nannies), her dilemma does reflect a worrying trend. Merryn Wells, advice services manager for the Equal Opportunities Commission, tells the story of a pregnant PA who was forced to quit her job when she asked for a little compromise.

"She used to work long hours but once she got pregnant she asked her employer if she could work her contractual hours - 9am to 5pm. Basically, the employer said no, so she tried to work full-time after the birth and could not cope. She felt she had no choice but to resign."

Carolyn Jones, director of the Institute of Employment Rights, is depressed by this climate. "I think back to when the former Labour prime minister Harold Wilson talked about the 'white heat' revolution of technology, predicting it would bring more leisure and family time. Something has gone wrong. Today we are working longer hours, for less pay and less leisure time."

She argues that a flexible workforce makes business sense. "If you adapt the workplace to the workers, you get a more committed team because they are not spending most of their energy simply juggling their lives. The culture and expectation is now about seeing the person as a whole and recognising their broader lifestyles."

Some companies do take a progressive approach. Local authorities, the NHS, charities and IT companies, for example, are known for their pragmatic approach to working practices. At British Telecom, job-sharing is particularly common among its administrative staff, the vast majority of whom are women.

"In the next office one of our directors has two secretaries who job-share," says a spokesperson. "They are both married with children and they swap jobs as commitments come up. It provides that necessary continuity - and the manager is happy."

fields.headline: Hi-techs threaten share schemes
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Government plans to create a generation of share-owning employees could be torpedoed by the stock market imbalance created by the huge rise in the value of internet and telecoms stocks, according to City experts.
fields.body:
Government plans to create a generation of share-owning employees could be torpedoed by the stock market imbalance created by the huge rise in the value of internet and telecoms stocks, according to City experts.

Workers are thought to be far less likely to want to invest their own money in the shares of their companies when all but the very newest of technology sectors are regarded as out of fashion.

"I've now got a serious doubt that [the proposed all-employee share scheme] will take off because everyone can see that it is no longer a sure fire bet to put their own money into shares," said David Tankel of remuneration specialists, New Bridge Street Consultants.

Although employees will benefit from tax breaks on share purchases and may see their spending matched by their employer, Mr Tankel sees the aberrant valuation of some firms' equity as likely to undermine their confidence to invest.

His warnings come as a growing number of large companies are complaining that the soaring price of shares in technology and internet firms has put the shares of more traditional firms under increasing pressure even though their financial performance is robust.

One FTSE 100 chief executive complained that thousands of his staff might lose motivation because of the fall in the share price. He said the historic link between profits and improved share price performance has been severed even if only temporarily and this was undermining the benefit of some share schemes.

It is understood that some companies may restructure staff incentive packages to increase the potential cash rewards even though this could become very costly in terms of lost profits. This is because they fear it will become increasingly difficult to persuade employees that their work performance can increase their wealth.

Pete Mitchell of remuneration consultants Meis, said that some companies were having to be discouraged from trying to cancel "under water" share schemes - whereby the value of shares has dropped below the option price - because this is now frowned on by shareholders.

Under the government proposals, further details of which are expected to become clear in the Budget, companies can offer up to £3,000 of free shares to employees in any tax year and these must be held for three years. They will benefit from the full tax relief only if held for five years.

Another consultant said that if employers decided to match each share purchased by the employee - as the scheme allows - that gave room for the market price to drop by a half before the worker was in danger of being out of pocket.

Some listed companies, such as Scottish & Newcastle, Whitbread, Unigate and Lloyds TSB, have seen their share prices value halved while so much money has been switching into telecommunications and internet shares.

webTitle: World Online takes a tilt at Freeserve

fields.headline: World Online takes a tilt at Freeserve
fields.standfirst:
Europe's largest internet service provider sets scene for aggressive expansion campaign in Britain

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: World Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is this week expected to announce an aggressive expansion of its free service in Britain and a distribution deal with a large retail group.
fields.body:
World Online, Europe's largest internet service provider, is this week expected to announce an aggressive expansion of its free service in Britain and a distribution deal with a large retail group.

The move will put World Online in direct competition with Freeserve - at present Britain's largest free ISP with 1.7m users.

World Online chief executive Simon Duffy said the company's UK expansion will be supported by a multimillion-pound offline marketing campaign. "The UK is a very important market for us, and we plan to target it aggressively," he said.

The service provider has secured an agreement with an unnamed retailer - with a "large high street presence" - which will enable it to compete with the 1,000-plus Dixons stores which at present distribute Freeserve CD Roms.

The Dutch-based company's offering, which is rich in entertainment, is likely to be targeted at the 15-34 age group, which accounts for more than 50% of British internet penetration, according to the BMRB Internet Monitor.

World Online is active as an internet provider in 15 countries, and the expansion in Britain is likely to be the last big market it targets before a flotation on the Amsterdam stock exchange - likely to value it at about £4bn.

Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley and ABN Amro are advising World Online on the float, and analysts say its prospectus will be published within a month.

Analysts believe that the demand for World Online shares after dealing begins could push the value of the company above that of Freeserve and Terra Networks of Spain, the most valuable European ISP.

World Online last week prepared the ground for its move by paying an undisclosed sum for UK internet services and telecommunications company Telinco Networks.

Telinco has about 10% of the UK free dial-up market, 900,000 subscribers and an annual turnover of £30m. It also provides facility management for sites including Bun.com and Themutual.net.

World Online already has a small presence in the UK, with around 100,000 users.

But the Telinco acquisition has taken its user base past the 1m mark, and advisers believe that the marketing campaign - which will be fronted by the Superman film actor, Christopher Reeve - and the distribution agreement have the potential significantly to close the gap on Freeserve.

Further acquisitions of smaller British ISPs are a possibility. World Online is likely to form alliances with domestic youth brands to help accelerate its UK roll-out.

It is at present in negotiations with the nightclub and publishing group, Ministry of Sound, aimed at forming a joint marketing alliance.

British music ISP PeopleSound is also regarded as likely to become a partner.

Mr Duffy said the company is talking to Mark McCormack's international sports marketing group, IMG, about ways to build up World Online's sports channels.

Earlier this month World Online agreed to launch a European live entertainment portal with SFX Entertainment of the US.

SFX is a producer and operator of live music and sports events. Its artists' management roster includes the musician Billy Joel and footballers David Beckham and Michael Owen.

Shareholders in World Online include the Sandoz Family Foundation of Switzerland, Reggeborgh Beheer and Intel.

 Arcadia is strengthening its e-commerce offering by agreeing a deal that will allow customers in Top Shop and Top Man stores to download and buy music while they shop for clothes.

Floor space will be given over to internet kiosks, branded "Chemistry", allowing customers to create their own CDs. A spokesman for Arcadia said the move is part of a strategy to create a social shopping environment in Top Shop stores, and follows the launch of the Zoom portal, cafés, and hair and make-up salons.

fields.headline: Journal goes after FT
fields.trailText: The Wall Street Journal Europe is undergoing a multi-million pound expansion and relaunch next month designed to thwart the efforts of the Financial Times to establish itself as the premier global business newspaper.
fields.body:
The Wall Street Journal Europe is undergoing a multi-million pound expansion and relaunch next month designed to thwart the efforts of the Financial Times to establish itself as the premier global business newspaper.

Dow Jones, the US group which owns the Journal, aims to double the paper's circulation in Europe from 80,000 over the next five years. The target echoes a statement recently made by FT editor Richard Lambert to double global sales from 441,000 in the same time frame.

A redesign of the Journal will increase pagination, introduce more colour and drop some of the paper's American design quirks with the intention of giving it a more European feel. The paper will also reposition itself as the champion of the emerging e-business sector, potentially with added supplements.

Dow Jones is also ploughing money into new printing plant and distribution networks with the total investment including marketing expected to be up to £50m.

The Journal's reputation in Europe has been enhanced by a series of scoops including the recent Time Warner-AOL merger and Mannesmann's bid for Orange. Circulation of the paper, which has had a European version since the mid-1980s, last year grew 15%. The relaunched paper, which is produced in Brussels, is expected to hit the streets on February 7.

"They will be building very aggressively over the next five years," said one insider. "There is a unique opportunity to develop a pan-European newspaper because of the growth in e-commerce and the globalisation of business."

The Journal sells 2.3m copies worldwide of which about 1.8m are in the United States. Of the FT's total of 441,000, about 188,000 are in Britain, 133,000 in the rest of Europe and 102,000 in the US - a 41% increase year-on-year.

The FT - owned by media group Pearson - is expected to invest more than £100m this year into the expansion of the franchise. In the past year about 200 additional journalists have been recruited ahead of the upcoming launch of a German version of the paper and the relaunch of FT.com, its online service.
